President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa has argued that the reforms show that his country is changing and he has urged foreign countries to lift economic sanctions. In his speech, Mandela paid tribute to black South Africans who, during years of oppression, ``met torture without flinching'' and ``met the hangman's noose with songs of freedom.'' He was interrupted several times by applause and received a long standing ovation from lawmakers. Mandela is in the midst of a six-week tour of 14 nations in Africa, Europe and North America that began June 6. He was freed from prison in February after serving 27 years of a life sentence for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-minority government. His release was part of a program of social reforms by the de Klerk government, including legalizing the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. De Klerk has also opened talks with black groups on giving a political voice to the country's 28 million blacks. South Africa's 5 million whites control the government and economy. At a dinner speech at a glitzy Toronto hotel, Mandela told a mostly white audience that whites are not the enemy in the fight against apartheid. ``We are facing a common front _ not against whites, but against racial oppression,'' he said, to resounding applause.

DOC.HEAD: East German Church Files Lawsuit in Artwork Case
DOC.TEXT: An East German church has filed a lawsuit demanding the return of medieval artwork believed stolen by an American officer in the final days of World War II. After hearing oral arguments by telephone Monday, U.S. District Judge Sidney A. Fitzwater barred movement of the church treasures without a court order. Fitzwater also ordered that representatives of the Lutheran cathedral in Quedlinburg be allowed to inventory the cache. The artwork is believed to be held in a bank in Whitewright, a town of 1,760 about 60 miles north of Dallas. The church hopes to recover 15 treasures that had been hidden in a mineshaft during the war. The treasures disappeared in 1945, shortly after American forces occupied the medieval castle town. Among the treasures, said Thomas R. Kline, the lawyer who filed the lawsuit, are a rock crystal flask of Byzantine origin; a wooden box decorated with silver, gold, ivory and precious stones, dating from the 9th or 10th century and containing relics of Henry I; and two manuscripts, one from about 1300 and the other from 1515, bound in precious metals and encrusted with gems. Joe T. Meador, a former Army lieutenant who was among the U.S. troops who entered Quedlinburg in April 1945, is believed to have stolen the artifacts. After he died of cancer in 1980, his brother and sister, Jack Meador of Whitewright and Jane Meador Cook of Mesquite, obtained the treasures and stored at least some in a vault at the First National Bank, The Dallas Morning News said today. They apparently sold at least two of the pieces, the bejeweled illuminated manuscripts, the newspaper said. A secretary for Jack Meador told The Associated Press on Monday night that Meador had no comment on the lawsuit. Mrs. Cook also declined to comment. An affidavit filed with the lawsuit said a church representative had met with bank President John Farley to demand the treasures. Farley confirmed that some of the artifacts are at his bank, The New York Times reported today. Farley said he first saw the artworks in 1986 ``when a customer of the bank brought me two manuscripts to have appraised.'' He would not reveal the customer's name or disclose the number of artworks stored in the bank. Ely Maurer, a State Department assistant legal adviser for cultural property, said the lawsuit was filed primarily because negotiations for return of the collection reached an impasse during the weekend. An unidentified FBI agent was quoted by the Morning News as saying it was unclear whether charges could be brought in the case. He said that the statute of limitations for interstate transportation of stolen property is five years and that international treaties governing theft of art and antiquities have a 30-year statute of limitations. Maurer said charges might be pursued under the National Stolen Property Act, a statute prohibiting interstate or international transport of stolen art. ``The law would extend to heirs who knowingly transferred the property across state lines,'' Maurer said. ``The fact that they moved some of the artworks as recently as this year might make the statute apply.'' He said there is evidence the family knew for some time that the art was stolen.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Despite a setback from the U.S. Supreme Court, country music star Hank Williams Jr. plans to continue his fight against a woman who claims to be his father's daughter. The high court Monday let stand a ruling that Cathy Yvonne Stone, 37, a country music performer known as Jett Williams, is entitled to have her fight for some of the late country music legend's royalties put before a jury. At the same time, the court left intact an Alabama Supreme Court ruling that declared Ms. Stone an heir to the elder Williams. ``The U.S. Supreme Court has refused to hear the case _ this is not a judgement _ and we're simply going to seek other remedies,'' said Merle Kilgore, Hank Jr.'s manager. Ms. Stone was born in 1953, five days after Hank Sr. died at age 29. Her mother, Bobbie Jett, and Williams had signed an agreement months earlier in which he acknowledged he might be the father of the then-unborn child. Kilgore said representatives for Hank Jr. and other parties involved in the royalties battle will meet sometime this week to discuss strategy. Ms. Stone said she has won the five-year fight. ``I feel it's as big a victory for my father, Hank Williams, as myself,'' she said. ``This is what should have been done in the beginning.''

Donald Trump, mired in marital and financial problems, faces more trouble in trying to convert his Ambassador Hotel property into a hotel and business complex. The city Board of Education voted 7-0 Monday to use its powers of eminent domain to seize 17.6 acres of the 23.5-acre property for a new high school to relieve overcrowding. Attorneys for Trump Wilshire Associates, the investment group headed by the New York billionaire, said the dispute is probably headed for the courts. The vote is the latest in a series of problems facing the flamboyant Trump, whose marriage fell apart at the same time his real estate and casino empire hit financial troubles. Trump Wilshire bought the property last year for $64 million. The district estimates it is worth $47.9 million; Trump officials value it at at least $150 million. The now-closed Ambassador Hotel is where Robert Kennedy was assassinated moments after declaring victory in the California Democratic presidential primary in 1968.

The 19-year-old son of Mayor Maynard Jackson has been arrested on charges of assaulting a 30-year-old woman on the street. Maynard Holbrook Jackson III was charged with simple battery Monday after a sheriff's deputy saw him pick up a friend, Maria Norma Duarte, and fling her to the ground, police said. Ms. Duarte received minor cuts on her arms and legs, said Officer D.B. Troutman. She also was sprayed in the face with Mace, police said. Police said the younger Jackson was arguing with the woman over the can of Mace. They gave no other details. Jackson was being held on $1,050 bail for a court appearance today.

Akira Kurosawa, Japan's most influential director and a winner of four Oscars, has received the 1990 Japan Society Award. Kurosawa, 80, who has made many historical epics among his 28 movies, was honored Monday by the Japan Society for increasing appreciation and understanding of Japanese society and culture. But Kurosawa was too busy finishing up his latest film, ``Rhapsody in August,'' to attend the ceremony at the New York Hilton, said his production company. His son, Hisao, president of Kurosawa Production, accepted the award for him. Kurosawa won Academy Awards for best foreign film in 1951 for ``Rashomon,'' in 1971 for ``Dodes' Ka'den,'' and in 1975 for the Soviet-financed film, ``Dersu Uzala.'' He received an honorary Oscar this year. The Japan Society is a private, non-profit organization devoted to cultural, educational and public affairs and improving U.S.-Japan relations.

Gambling there will be no Kryptonite in Orange County trash, Superboy _ Gerard Christopher _ is coming out in favor recycling. Christopher, who stars as the boy of steel on the syndicated TV series filmed in Orlando, has volunteered to appear in televised public service announcements, Jim Becker, county recycling manager, said Monday. Beginning in July, trash haulers will deliver 230,000 orange recycling bins to every single-family home in unincorporated Orange County, Becker said. The bins, which are for newspapers, cans and bottles, will be picked up weekly.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,040.38, down 336.42 points, or 1.04 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Plans Live Coverage
With PM-US-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network will cover much of Nelson Mandela's U.S. visit live, while CBS, NBC and ABC said most of their coverage will be on their regular news programs. The South African anti-apartheid activist's three-day visit to New York begins Wednesday morning with his arrival at Kennedy Airport. He leaves for Boston on Saturday. CNN's first-day live coverage will include his arrival, a ticker tape parade up Broadway and a ceremony in which Mayor David Dinkins gives Mandela the key to the city, CNN spokesman John Bianchi said. The network will also broadcast live such activities as a motorcade through Harlem and a rally at Yankee Stadium on Thursday, and Mandela's speech to the United Nations on Friday. Mandela will be a guest at a special ``town meeting'' to be taped Thursday for broadcast that evening on ABC. He also will appear that night on Ted Koppel's ``Nightline.'' ABC spokesman Arnot Walker said Monday the network is undecided on further live coverage. CBS spokesman Tom Goodman said CBS will cover the Mandela visit ``if news warrants.'' NBC will carry Mandela's arrival in New York live on the ``Today'' show but hasn't decided whether to cover live his address to Congress next week, said network spokeswoman Catherine McQuay. Mandela makes two appearances Friday on PBS, a live 15-minute interview on ``The MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour'' and a taped interview with Charlayne Hunter-Gault.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Turns To Old-Style Politics In One Last Bid For Change
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino has turned to a formula once used by her discredited predecessor in order to revive the ``people power'' spirit that propelled her to office. Last week, Mrs. Aquino unveiled plans for a nationwide movement to channel government, private business and volunteer organizations to deliver basic services and improve lives of millions of impoverished Filipinos. The plan is to bypass ``traditional politicians'' in Congress and the bureaucracy. Those institutions have blocked many of the grandiose plans for reform promised but not delivered by the 4-year-old Aquino government. For the movement, Mrs. Aquino chose the name ``Kabisig,'' a Tagalog word for people locked ``arm-in-arm.'' She cited the spirit of the 1986 uprising against Ferdinand Marcos, when hundreds of thousands of Filipinos stood arm-in-arm to block tanks seeking to crush a military mutiny against the late president. ``We're fast-tracking all of Cory's priorities,'' said Transport Secretary Oscar Orbos, a former congressman and leading figure in ``Kabisig.'' The Roman Catholic magazine Veritas said ``Kabisig'' was designed to circumvent ``traditional centers of power'' and the ``sluggish, energy- and time-consuming bureaucracy grown fat and complacent with inaction.'' Mrs. Aquino hopes to bring into the movement the social activist groups, human rights organizations and labor federations that stood at the forefront of the struggle against Marcos. Those groups have been largely disillusioned with Mrs. Aquino's failure to institute reforms after the ``people power'' revolution. At the same time, the ``Kabisig'' movement has drawn fire from pro-Aquino politicians. ``There were statements in Cory's speech which made me feel insecure, forlorn, dejected and rejected,'' said Sen. Rene Saguisag, a former human rights lawyer and one of Mrs. Aquino's most loyal Senate supporters. Saguisag said the president appeared to be seeking a rubber-stamp legislature. Another pro-Aquino senator, Wigberto Tanada, pointed out that Marcos himself used the term ``Kabisig'' to describe an organization he set up in 1985 to muster political support. Use of so-called ``non-political'' mass movements is a time-tested formula for bypassing established parties. After declaring martial law in 1972, Marcos banned political parties, then organized various ``grass-roots'' organizations ostensibly to invigorate and transform Philippine society. His most successful venture was the New Society Movement, which evolved into a mega-party similar to the largely defunct Communist organizations that once held sway in Eastern Europe. For years, Mrs. Aquino has excused the shortcomings of her administration by claiming that inefficiency was the price of democracy after 20 years of Marcos' ``tyranny.'' She pointed proudly to her new constitution and elected, bicameral legislature as examples of her ``restored democracy.'' Ironically, at a time when surveys show her popularity declining, Mrs. Aquino is now bypassing those institutions to deliver reforms. ``She already has the entire government machinery at her beck and call,'' wrote columnist Emil Jurado in The Manila Standard. ``What reason would she have...for depending on Cory loyalists and non-government organizations for the survival of her administration? Isn't she admitting that her administration is a failure?'' Political analysts cite the controversy over land reform as a watershed in Mrs. Aquino's political strategy. As social activists had predicted, Congress watered down legislation establishing the land reform program. In April, congressmen blocked confirmation of her agrarian reform secretary, Florencio Abad, because of his anti-landlord views. ``Kabisig is calculated to save the elite from itself, yank it...out of high living and make it smell the poverty until it hurts,'' wrote former presidential spokesman Teodoro Benigno in The Philippine Star. ``She knows that if she heads in the same old direction with the traditional politicians, her administration is due for a train crash.''

DOC.HEAD: Killer Put to Death in Arkansas' First Execution in 26 Years
DOC.TEXT: A man who shot and killed a policeman trying to arrest him for a double murder said he held ``no grudges'' before being put to death in the electric chair in Arkansas' first execution in 26 years. John Edward Swindler, 46, was pronounced dead at 9:05 p.m. Monday, three minutes after being given 2,300 volts of electricit in the big oak chair. Arkansas became the 14th state to carry out an execution and Swindler the 130th inmate put to death since the U.S. Supreme Court in 1976 let states resume use of capital punishment. Swindler was condemned for the 1976 murder of Fort Smith policeman Randy Basnett, who was shot at a gas station while trying to arrest Swindler for two murders in South Carolina. Swindler was later convicted of those slayings as well. The U.S. Supreme Court denied a stay of execution on Saturday. In final remarks dictated in his cell to Roman Catholic Monsignor John O'Donnell, Swindler said: ``I have no animosity toward anyone. No grudges.'' ``I hope this brings to light the injustice of capital punishment and the need to abolish it,'' he said. Swindler's body was to be turned over to O'Donnell for cremation. Swindler's family didn't want the body. ``He has professed that he believes in Satan, and I hope he gets to see him real soon,'' his brother, Robert E. Swindler of Lexington, S.C., said recently. The last person executed in Arkansas was Charles Franklin Fields, who was electrocuted in 1964 for rape. R. Gene Simmons, convicted of killing 16 people, including 14 family members, is scheduled to be die Monday by injection. Because Swindler was sentenced before Arkansas changed its method of execution from electrocution to injection, he was given a choice of either method. He left the choice up to authorities, who selected the method specified in his sentence. Shanon Howard, the daughter of Basnett's widow, Cindy, said after the execution, ``All I can say is justice has been done.'' ``This is Randy Basnett's day,'' said Randy Manus, who was selected as a witness to the execution. A handful of demonstrators for and against the death penalty gathered outside the prison as the execution approached, including several members of the Fort Smith Police Department, some in T-shirts decorated with a lightning bolt and the slogan ``Turn Out The Lights, The Party's Over _ John Swindler, 1990.'' Some of those opposed to the death penalty sang ``Amazing Grace.'' When told of Swindler's death, several police officers cheered, grinned, shook one another's hands. One broke into song. On Sunday, about 50 members of Amnesty International held a 26-minute vigil commemorating 26 years without an execution in the state. The human rights group implored Gov. Bill Clinton ``not to end the decency of the past 26 years by reinstituting this brutish form of violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says United States Won't Put Central America On Back Burner
LaserPhoto XGUA-4
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III has told Central American leaders that the United States is committed to marshaling international aid for their war-battered region and will not forsake it for Eastern Europe. Baker met Monday with the presidents of El Salvador, Nicaragua, Guatemala, Honduras, Costa Rica and Panama a day after a Central American summit produced a sweeping plan for regional economic integration and development. ``Central America is poised as never before to consolidate democracy and achieve lasting peace and disarmament and create conditions for growth and opportunity in which all of the peoples of this region, particularly the poor, can share,'' he said. One of the presidents' concerns going into the summit was whether the region would lose out to Eastern Europe in its bid for international assistance. Baker said that would not happen. ``That's why we are exploring with Japan, the European Community, Canada and other industrialized democracies ways to give more support to democracy and development in Central America,'' he said. Baker outlined plans for coordinating aid, trade and investment during a two-hour breakfast with the presidents. He also met privately with each one. ``I'm here today at the request of President Bush to make it very clear that the U.S. will continue to be fully engaged, to be fully supportive of this regional peace process,'' Baker told a news conference afterward. The Central American economic accord grew out of the Nobel Prize-winning regional peace plan signed in 1987. The idea Baker broached is based on the program adopted by 24 Western nations to help Poland and Hungary nurture free-market systems and democratic institutions. Baker said it was favorably received. Honduran President Rafael Callejas estimated that Central America will need $2.5 billion in aid over three years to revitalize its economies, but said the presidents did not discuss specifics with Baker. ``We didn't talk about sums or structures,'' he told a joint presidential news conference. Central American officials have expressed two main concerns about the program: who would run it, and whether the net effect will be less U.S. aid. They also made it clear they need and welcome help _ but on their own terms. ``We are going to decide what we want, when we want it, under what conditions and with whom,'' said Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Enrique Dreyfus. Guatemalan President Vinicio Cerezo said Baker assured the presidents he thinks Central Americans should have a strong say in aid matters. On Sunday, the presidents of El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala and Costa Rica _ all elected civilians _ signed accords for joint action on ending the poverty and underdevelopment that fueled war and revolution in the region for more than a decade. The accords call for the creation of a Central American Economic Community. Attending the meetings as an observer was President Guillermo Endara of Panama, which considers itself part of South America due to its former ties to Colombia but is thinking of joining the Central American Economic Community. The three-day Antigua meeting was the eighth Central American summit, but the first to deal almost exclusively with economic issues. Seven earlier summits focused on the search for peace. The 1987 regional peace plan, authored by former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, managed to bring about an end to the civil war in Nicaragua and the February elections in which the leftist Sandinistas were defeated. The Sandinistas were succeeded by the coalition government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. The peace plan was also the catalyst for talks now under way between the governments of El Salvador and Guatemala and leftist rebels in these two countries.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Tumble, Dollar Lower
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply Tuesday, and the dollar closed slightly lower against the Japanese yen. The dollar ended the day at 153.72 yen, down 0.16 from Monday's close of 153.88 yen. It opened at 153.45 yen, and ranged between 153.43 yen and 153.80 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average shed 336.42 points, or 1.04 percent, from Monday's close, ending the day at 32,040.38. Traders attributed the Nikkei index's decline to an increase in U.S. interest rates and a big drop in the Dow Jones industrial average in New York overnight. Higher interest rates tends to discourage stock investment. ``A rise in the U.S. interest rate largely discouraged investors here because they have been expecting the opposite movement out of their expectation for the slowdown in the U.S. economy,'' said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. He said the index started recovering at midmorning as market players were reassured by the relative stability of the Japanese bond market. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 87.58 points from Monday's close of 87.65, boosting the yield to 7.06 percent from 7.045 percent. On the foreign exchange market, dollar-yen trading remained inactive after the U.S. currency opened lower following its overnight slip on overseas markets. ``Compared to dealings between European currencies and the U.S. dollar, in which the dollar tended to be weaker, the yen-dollar trading was small,'' said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Police Arrest Fourth IRA Suspect
DOC.TEXT: Dutch police arrested a fourth suspected Irish Republican Army terrorist early today after a manhunt involving more than 135 officers with dogs and helicopters, police said. The suspect was found hiding in a forest and surrendered without a struggle nine hours after fleeing a police identity check, said Dutch National Police spokesman Henk Ketelaar. Britain's Press Association quoted Belgian police as saying the man was Paul Hughes, 26, of County Down, Northern Ireland. Ketelaar would only give his initials, P.M.H., in line with Dutch police practice, and say he is an IRA member. Police have declined to comment on Dutch press reports that the four belong to the IRA group believed responsible for the May 28 shooting deaths of two Australian tourists in the southern Dutch city of Roermond. The IRA later said it ``tragically mistook'' the two Australians for British soldiers. The string of events leading to today's arrest began Saturday when Belgian police arrested an IRA suspect identified as Donna Maguire. The woman's two companions escaped police custody and fled across the virtually unguarded Dutch-Belgian border. One was arrested hours later in the Netherlands, while the other was spotted roaming around this border village Monday, still wearing Belgian police handcuffs. Approximately 20 minutes after the arrest of the handcuffed man, police saw a British-registered car driving down the same village street and ordered it to stop. The car's driver accelerated at high speed immediately after being asked to show his papers, and the car was later found abandoned in a nearby forest. Police sealed off the entire village and deployed helicopters and tracker dogs to search for the driver of what they believed to be the handcuffed man's getaway car. At about 1:45 a.m. today, the man was spotted hiding behind a tree by a police dog and surrendered. He was not armed, Ketelaar said. Police have identified the other two apprehended IRA suspects as Gerard Majella Harte, 27, of Northern Ireland, and a man known only by his alias, Andrew Edward Thornton. The outlawed IRA, which seeks to end British rule over Northern Ireland and unite the province with the Irish Republic, has waged a decades-long bombing and shooting campaign against British targets in Northern Ireland, Britain and the European continent.

DOC.HEAD: Some of Worst Massacres in U.S.
With PM-Office Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of some of the worst recent massacres in the United States. All occurred within one day or the space of a few days. Serial killings that occurred over a long period of time are not included. _ July 18, 1984: Twenty-one people were fatally shot in a McDonald's restaurant in San Ysidro, Calif., by James Oliver Huberty, an out-of-work security guard. Huberty himself was then killed by a police sharpshooter. _ Aug. 1, 1966: Sixteen people were killed in Austin, Texas, by Charles Whitman; most were hit by sniper fire after he climbed to the top of a campus tower at the University of Texas. Whitman was killed by police. _ December 1987: Sixteen people, including 14 members of one family, are killed. The mass slaying is discovered after R. Gene Simmons Sr. is arrested Dec. 28 in the killings of two people in Russellville, Ark. A search of his home near Dover uncovers the remains of 14 family members, who authorities say were killed by Simmons just before Christmas. Simmons was convicted of capital murder on two charges May 12, 1988, and sentenced to death. _ Aug. 20, 1986: Fourteen people were shot to death at a post office in Edmond, Okla., by Pat Sherrill, 44, a postal worker who authorities said was about to be fired. After police sharpshooters arrived, Sherrill killed himself. _ Feb. 19, 1983: Thirteen people were fatally shot in the head during a robbery at a gambling club in Seattle's Chinatown section. Willie Mak and Benjamin Ng were convicted of murder. _ Sept. 5, 1949: Thirteen people were fatally shot in 12 minutes in Camden, N.J. Howard Unruh, who told police, ``I'd have killed a thousand if I'd had enough bullets,'' was found insane and committed to a mental institution. _ Sept. 25, 1982: Twelve people, including five children, were killed in Wilkes-Barre and Jenkins Township, Pa. George Banks, 43, was convicted on 12 counts of murder and sentenced to death. _ Easter Sunday (March 30), 1975: Eleven people, including eight children, were killed at a family gathering in Hamilton, Ohio. A relative, James Ruppert, was convicted of two killings and found innocent by reason of insanity in nine others. _ Palm Sunday (April 15), 1984: Ten people, including eight children, were killed in a New York City apartment. Christopher Thomas was convicted of first-degree manslaughter, the judge citing ``extreme emotional disturbance.'' _ July 14, 1966: Eight student nurses were stabbed or strangled in a Chicago dormitory. Richard Speck, 24, was convicted of murder. _ Sept. 14, 1989: Joseph T. Wesbecker, a 47-year-old pressman on disability for mental illness, fatally shoots eight people and wounds 12 others at a printing plant in Louisville, Ky., before taking his own life. _ June 18, 1990: James Edward Pough, 42, walks into a General Motors Acceptance Corp. office in Jacksonville, Fla., opens fire, killing eight and commits suicide. _ Aug. 20, 1982: school teacher Carl Brown walked into a Miami machine shop armed with a shotgun and killed eight shop employees and wounded three others over a $20 welding job. Brown was then fatally shot by witnesses while riding away in his bicycle. _ Feb. 15, 1988: Seven people are killed and five others are wounded at ESL Corp., a defense contractor in California's ``Silicon Valley.'' A former employee, Richard Wade Farley, 39, is arrested. He had been fired for harassing a woman who was among the injured. Charges are pending. _ April 14, 1989: A rampage in Sonoma County, Calif., leaves seven people dead. Ramon Salcido, a former winery worker, is accused of killing his wife, his two daughters, his mother-in-law, her two daughters and a co-worker, and attempting to kill three other people. Charges are pending. _ Jan. 17, 1989: Patrick Purdy, a 24-year-old drifter, opens fire on a Stockton, Calif., schoolyard with a semiautomatic assault rifle and other weapons. Five children and killed and 30 other people are wounded. Purdy then committed suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Seeks To Mend Fences With Peru's Creditors
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Even before he takes office, President-elect Alberto Fujimori is staking his power and prestige on a high-stakes quest for international aid. The political neophyte sets off this weekend for the United States, Japan and South Korea on a trip that represents a dramatic turnabout for Peru. Outgoing President Alan Garcia turned his back on the international financial community. Fujimori, who takes office July 28, wants to bring Peru back into the fold. The president-to-be has a powerful motivation for his effort. The Peru he will inherit is bankrupt, battered by 2,000 percent annual inflation. Thousands of Peruvians are on strike and four in five lack steady work. A 10-year guerrilla war has claimed more than 18,500 lives. If Fujimori succeeds, it won't be the first time he's overcome long odds. His landslide win over famed novelist Mario Vargas Llosa in the June 10 runoff election capped a come-from-behind campaign. As Peru's 86th president, he will join the small minority of democratically elected leaders in the country's 169-year history since independence. Analysts say the survival of Peru's latest 10-year-old stint of democracy likely hinges on Fujimori. A restless military is ready to intervene if the government proves unable to keep Peru from falling into chaos, they say. In Washington, where his 12-day tour will start June 25, Fujimori is to meet officials of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. It may be something of a fence-mending mission. Garcia, upon coming to power in 1985, limited payment on the nation's $20 billion foreign debt to 10 percent of export earnings. Shortly afterward, Peru stopped payment altogether. In the first third of this year alone, Peru missed $1.6 billion in payments to international lending institutions. The amount overdue to private banks is believed to be even higher. Fujimori will travel next to Japan, which has said it is willing to resume loans to Peru if the country shows a willingness to deal with its serious social and economic problems. Fujimori's Japanese ancestry has raised hopes of greater access to Japanese aid. Peru was the largest recipient of Japanese aid in Latin America in cumulative terms until 1988, but dropped to fourth-largest after it defaulted on payments and Japan cut off its yen credits. One official in Japan's Foreign Ministry said Peru owes Japan an estimated $1 billion in government and private debts. Garcia contended in a recent interview that Peruvian democracy has survived because he resisted the austerity measures recommended by the Peru's creditors. But many believe Peru's economy cannot survive much longer without the drastic measures advocated by Vargas Llosa. Inflation in the first two weeks of June alone was 25 percent. Central Bank reserves stand at $900 million, mostly in gold and silver. Liquid reserves are $134 million, enough to pay for less than two months of imports. During the campaign, Fujimori played on worries about Vargas Llosa's plans for ``economic shock treatment'' and cultivated poor, indigenous Peruvians who associated the novelist with the European-descended elite. He said the economy could recover with ``gradual'' measures, but never fully explained what those would be. Vargas Llosa planned to privatize most of the chronically inefficient public enterprises and cut the bloated bureaucracy. But in a country where 40 percent of the population lives in extreme poverty, Vargas Llosa's proposals raised the specter of greater suffering. Fujimori was the beneficiary of those fears. In order to get anything accomplished, Fujimori's government will have to court support from other parties. But Garcia's left-leaning Aprista Party opposes austerity measures, and Fredemo, the center-right coalition that supported Vargas Llosa, is still feeling the sting of defeat. An Aprista leader, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he expects serious instability if Fujimori fails to forge a broad consensus in six months or less. Since Fujimori is a newcomer in Peruvian politics, he has no links to traditional parties, and no established base of support. But analysts say he may be able to turn that lack of political connections into an asset when it's time to compromise _ a time that could come soon.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Harold Olmos, bureau chief for The Associated Press in Caracas, Venezuela, has reported on South American politics for AP for more than a decade.

DOC.HEAD: No More Dancing in Purdy
DOC.TEXT: The Purdy School Board has reinstated a ban on school dances after winning a four-year battle that reached the Supreme Court. ``The board wants to go back to the business of running a good school and have some quiet,'' board attorney Ransom Ellis III said Monday. In 1986, 21 students and parents sued to overturn the ban, claiming it was imposed for religious reasons and thus violated separation of church and state. The board in the town of about 1,000 argued dances might lead to drinking and discipline problems. The Supreme Court in April upheld the century-old ban by agreeing with an appeals court that the rule was not motivated by religious beliefs. Ellis said the dance ban was never taken off the books but had been suspended while the case worked its way to the Supreme Court. ``Tonight's vote reinstates the old rule,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors' Tales and Scenes From a Disaster
With PM-Flash Flood
DOC.TEXT: Notes and survivors' stories from the flash flooding in Belmont County that killed at least 21 people and left 13 missing:

Jennifer Gulash watched homes near The Three Ks, a Wegee nightspot, drift off their foundations and float away. ``We were eating dinner ... and the lights flickered,'' she said. ``My husband, who works nights and was getting ready to go to work, said, `You better get some candles _ you're going to be home alone in the dark.''' After the lights went out, she heard people screaming and looked out to see a couple who lived in a trailer behind the club put their children in a truck. ``I saw them get into the street, then I just saw the water rip through,'' she said. The family she saw made it to high ground in time, she said.

Tom Allison watched the storm rage through Wegee Creek on Thursday night and thought nothing of it. He soon changed his mind. ``We were in my back yard ... but when the rain started blowing in, we went inside,'' Allison said Monday. ``We hadn't been inside five minutes when somebody looked out the back door and said, `Oh, my God.' ``Some people didn't have a chance to see it coming. ... We did, or we wouldn't have gotten out. It's simple as that,'' he said. Allison and his sister, Vicki, who lived nearby, lost everything. ``Who would think of flood insurance for a 10-foot wide creek that never gets over a foot deep?'' Allison said. ``What would you need flood insurance for?'' ``But within a half-hour from the time it started raining, vehicles and houses and trailers were moving down the creek,'' Allison said. ``We watched a minute, a minute and a half, and here comes another building, and it ripped through the pavilion where we had been sitting. ``Then we saw (Ms. Allison's) trailer start to move, and we decided it was time to get out of Dodge.'' They fled to higher ground across the road.

Chuck Vogt, the Belmont County coroner's investigator, stood on a railroad trestle and watched National Guardsmen and Coast Guard divers drag a wrecked car from the mouth of Wegee Creek. He watched a moment longer and then scratched his head. ``You know, we had a mock disaster drill planned for some time later this month,'' he said. ``I don't think we'll need it now.''

``The house can be renovated, gradually,'' said 69-year-old Warren Wright of Pipe Creek, as he and his daughter, Inez, of Steubenville, left the disaster information center at the Jefferson School in Shadyside. ``But the vinyl siding is gone, the furniture is gone, my truck is gone, my workshop is gone, my tool shed is gone and the yard looks like a battlefield.'' His voice grew huskier. ``I built the home myself, 33 years ago.'' Wright said he was reading on his bed when the flood struck. ``I wasn't worried ... until I received a telephone call saying a flash flood was coming,'' he said. ``I thought he was pulling my leg. ... I headed up the road to check on some disabled neighbors. ``The creek came up across the road, and I thought, `Well, I better go back and move some vehicles.' But when I started back I couldn't get back.'' Wright said he lost most of his possessions but no family members. ``I still got off lucky,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede STOCKHOLM
Domestic Flight Hijacked To Finland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS developments. CORRECTS type of plane.
DOC.TEXT: Three people hijacked a Soviet airliner on a domestic flight today and the plane landed in Helsinki, where it was surrounded by police and negotiations began, Finnish air authorities said. The twin-jet Tupolev 154, with 54 passengers and five crew aboard, had been flying from the Latvian capital Riga to Murmansk on the northern Kola peninsula when it was hijacked, said Irmeli Paavola of the Finnish Aviation Authority. The three hijackers had demanded to be flown to Stockholm, according to spokeswoman Malin Engstedt of the rescue service at Arlanda airport outside the Swedish capital. Instead, the plane touched down at Vanda airport outside the Finnish capital shortly before 11 a.m. and taxied to the side of a runway. Witnesses said it was surrounded by police. In Stockholm, the Swedish national news agency TT quoted Finnish aviation officials as saying the hijackers had threatened to blow up the plane during negotiations with Finnish authorities. The agency said negotiations were hampered because the hijackers spoke only Russian. Details were not immediately available on the hijackers' demands. It was the second hijacking in 10 days of a Soviet airliner on a domestic flight. On June 9, Dimitry Semionov, a 17-year-old Soviet youth, hijacked a plane with 114 passengers during a flight from Minsk to Murmansk. The plane was forced to fly to Stockholm, where Semionov surrendered. He said later through a lawyer that he had acted on impulse after a family quarrel and wanted to go to a ``free country.'' Semionov was arraigned in a Stockholm court and could face up to four years in prison, depending on results of psychiatric tests.

DOC.HEAD: Invention Tests Auto Pollution
DOC.TEXT: A new infrared device that measures a car's exhaust from the side of the road as the vehicle drives past may someday replace state testing programs in which emissions are collected from the tailpipe of an idling auto. In a test in Illinois, the device showed that 8 percent of Chicago's autos produce about half the city's carbon monoxide pollution and that relatively new vehicles as well as old clunkers are among the worst polluters. In Nevada, the Environmental Protection Agency concluded that the device, called FEAT for Fuel Efficiency Automobile Test, was an accurate tool. Some officials believe the device, invented three years ago by University of Denver chemistry professor Donald H. Stedman, could streamline emissions testing and improve pollution control. ``Further down the road the ultimate goal is to identify precisely that relatively small percentage and require them to come in for inspection and maintenance rather than requiring everyone,'' said Bill Denham of the Illinois Department of Energy and Natural Resources. In the conventional testing station, the emissions are collected from the tailpipe. With FEAT, the infrared beam source and the detector are placed on opposite sides of a road and take their reading as the car passes, Stedman said Monday. A computer calculates the emissions, and a camera snaps a picture of the license plate to determine the vehicle's age. He said the FEAT can measure 1,000 cars an hour. In contrast, Illinois testing stations typically check 17 vehicles per hour, said James Matheny of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency's Vehicle Emission Testing Program. Marc Pitchford, who was in charge of testing the device for the EPA in Nevada, said roadside testing would save Illinois $12 million a year on its emissions program, which state officials put at $21 million to $23 million. Stedman said hydrocarbon pollution would be reduced by catching cars that pollute sooner. He said many drivers tamper with their cars to pass annual emissions tests. But the FEAT has its skeptics. Matheny said little research exists on how many sensors would be needed and on where to locate them for thorough testing. And Steven Cadle, a research scientist for General Motors who developed a test similar to Stedman's, said the roadside tests assume an auto's output remains constant. ``I would not feel comfortable writing that person a ticket,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall, Dollar Dips
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply today, mirroring Monday's lower prices on the New York exchange, while the dollar closed slightly down against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average shed 336.42 points, or 1.04 percent, from Monday's close, ending the day at 32,040.38. Volume on the first section was 330 million shares, compared with 300 million shares Monday. The dollar ended the day at 153.72 yen, down 0.16 from Monday's close of 153.88 yen. It opened at 153.45 yen, and ranged between 153.43 yen and 153.80 yen. Masato Hayashi, chief customer dealer at the Bank of Tokyo, said trading was active on European currencies but dollar trading was slow while traders ``wait and see.'' ``People need news about the dollar,'' he said. Traders attributed the stock market decline to Monday's lower close in New York. ``The New York market was down, so the Tokyo market fell, too,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader at Daiwa Securities, adding that high money supply figures published in May also have affected trading. Prices for blue-chip stocks and over-the-counter stocks were both down, following three days of high prices for OTC securities. ``Prices for blue-chip stocks have been down since the beginning of June,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, a trader at Nomura Securities. Lower prices signal a cooling-off after a period of feverish trading that saw high volume and prices, he said. On the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 87.46 points at closing, down from Monday's close of 87.65. Their yield rose to 7.085 percent from 7.045 percent on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Pollution Lawsuit Seeks to Restore California Coast
DOC.TEXT: The state and U.S. governments have filed a lawsuit that accuses eight companies of toxic dumping in California waters and takes the unusual step of trying to force industry to return the area to the way it was. The lawsuit, filed Monday in federal court, contends the companies dumped hundreds of tons of such chemicals as DDT and PCBs since the mid-1940s, harming fisheries and births of the bald eagle, peregrine falcon and sea lion. Lawyers called the lawsuit unique. ``In the past, the state recovered funds for cleanup of ocean dumping, but there's never been an attempt to collect money to restore the marine habitat,'' said Michael R. Valentine, an attorney for the state Lands Commission. Targets of the lawsuit are Montrose Chemical Corp., Atkemix 37 Inc., Stauffer Management Co., ICI American Holdings Inc., Chris-Craft Industries Inc., Westinghouse Electric Corp., Potlatch Corp. and Simpson Paper Co. State Attorney General John Van de Kamp said the damages could run in the millions of dollars. ``We are encouraging these polluters to accept the responsibility to clean up the contamination and to restore the marine environment for future generations,'' said Van de Kamp. The National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration also joined the state in the lawsuit. Simpson spokeswoman Maureen Frisch said she knew nothing about the lawsuit. Officials for the other companies could not be reached in calls made after business hours. The lawsuit seeks restoration of an approximately 20-mile stretch of coast from the northern tip of Santa Monica Bay south to Palos Verdes. It was filed under the 1980 Superfund law and the 1972 Clean Water Act. Under the Reagan administration, the Superfund law was restricted to ``human health concerns.'' It could not be invoked in cases of damage to natural resources. The Bush administration, however, restored $2.5 million to pursue litigation that would force polluters to restore land and wildlife.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Trip Generates Little Excitement in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela is drawing huge crowds and garnering accolades at every stop on his international tour. But at home, the reaction ranges from indifference to criticism. Teacher strikes in black schools, the African National Congress' rivalry with other black groups, and even the troubled marriage of a black pop singer have all been judged more interesting by the editors of the Sowetan, the largest black daily newspaper. The Sowetan _ based in the Soweto township where Mandela lives _ generally gives close coverage to his activities. But it has not published a front-page story or picture of his trip since he left South Africa on June 4. Mandela begins an eight-city U.S. visit on Wednesday, when he will arrive in New York. Mandela's repeated calls for continued economic sanctions against South Africa have drawn criticism from another leading black newspaper, one that traditionally backs the ANC. ``Sanctions cannot be prolonged any longer,'' City Press said in an editorial Sunday. ``We do not want to inherit a wasteland.'' The newspaper, South Africa's largest black weekly, argued that it might be time for a policy reassessment by the ANC: ``In the light of the government's reform policy, has the time not come for the ANC to review the use of sanctions as a strategy to end apartheid?'' Mandela, released Feb. 11 after more than 27 years in prison, has received almost daily coverage in white-oriented newspapers and government-run television. Most of the reports have focused on the sanctions issue and what the publications perceive as uncritical adulation of the ANC leader. ``We do not begrudge the Americans their right to fete him,'' said The Citizen, a pro-government daily. ``But we do feel they should welcome Mr. Mandela, the man, rather than Mr. Mandela, the legend, the god, the new Christ...'' Many South Africans _ both black and white _ believe the country's political and racial conflicts are largely internal matters that will be decided by South Africans rather than outsiders. That may be the reason that reports about foreigners' response to Mandela's message has drawn little interest in the country. During Mandela's absence from South Africa, however, his organization appears to have put some major decisions on hold. Mid-level government officials and ANC members last month produced a joint plan designed to clear the way for black-white negotiations on a new constitution and ending apartheid. De Klerk said the government has accepted the plan and is ready to implement it. The ANC has asked to wait until July 10 before responding. Mandela is due back in late July. De Klerk lifted the state of emergency in most of the country June 8. ``We are on the threshold of the real negotiation process ... the ANC must now stop vacillating,'' he said then.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The guy was pointing his gun under people's desks and killing them one by one. I just saw the bottom of the carpet and just prayed.'' _ Rick Langille, a manager at a Florida auto loan agency where a gunman opened fire, killing eight people.

``The government took their best shots and there weren't any shots. There was no powder in their barrel, no bullets in their gun,'' _ Financier Charles H. Keating Jr., on the prospects of recovering his failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

``If you have a $500 suit and unlimited campaign contributions, like the greedy and corrupt savings and loans, you can get whatever you want from Washington. But if you try to get a few dollars for the poor and needy you are totally ignored.'' _ Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, on the scarcity of federal aid for cities.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Kidnapped American Arrives in Ecuador
DOC.TEXT: The parents of an Illinois man kidnapped while working for a mining company have arrived in Ecuador to try to win his freedom. Roy and Marge Heimdal of Peoria, Ill., were met by U.S. Embassy officials on their arrival Monday at Quito's international airport. The Heimdals refused to talk with reporters about the kidnapping of their 27-year-old son, Scott. But before boarding a plane in Chicago, Mrs. Heimdal said, ``I'm not coming back without my son.'' Meanwhile, court sources in Quito said Heimdal's supervisor had filed legal papers suggesting a disgruntled former employee of the IMINCO mining company may be responsible for the April 28 kidnapping. For weeks, officials have been saying the kidnapping was the work of Communist guerrillas. Heimdal was kidnapped while traveling on the Bermeja River in the jungle near Ecuador's border with Colombia. He was working for IMINCO dredging river bottoms for gold deposits. Officials say a band of armed men attacked his boat, killed the pilot and took Heimdal and an Ecuadoran student hostage. The student was later released with a ransom demand. The Heimdals, a working-class family, gathered $60,000 in community donations that they believed to be the ransom demand. But to their dismay, the kidnappers said last week that they were demanding $612,000. On Thursday, the Heimdals made public a four-page letter from their son. In the letter, he said he was being moved daily in the Colombian jungle and surviving on armadillo and monkey meat. The letter said the kidnappers became angry and believed the family to be rich after seeing a television report last week about the fund-raising in Peoria. U.S. Embassy officials had said earlier they were concerned that the wide publicity the kidnapping has received could complicate negotiations to win Heimdal's freedom and might jeopardize his life. The court sources in Quito told The Associated Press that Jeffrey Fino, IMINCO's general manager, filed a written accusation with police on May 1, suggesting a former employee may have instigated the kidnapping. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the documents accuse the man, who had a contract with IMINCO for transporting mining equipment to the jungle area, had threatened Fino. Fino, who is representing the Heimdal family in the kidnapping negotiations, was not available Monday to comment. Since last week, he has not gone to his office, according to his secretary. In an interview last week, Fino said he was beginning to fear the kidnappers were bandits, not guerrillas. The kidnappers have identified themselves as members of the People's Libertion Army, a Communist guerrilla group from Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Thuderstorms Rumble Over Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms developed over the Midwest early today, while much of the West enjoyed fair weather. With the start of summer just a day away, temperatures were in the 70s throughout much of the South and Midwest early today. Thunderstorms rumbled over Des Moines, while rain fell in Boston. Scattered showers and thunderstorms also developed over Virginia, Maryland and Delaware. Today's forecast called for a band of thunderstorms extending from South Dakota to northern Minneapolis and Iowa. Thunderstorms also were expected in northern Florida, while showers were forecast for the Northeast. On Monday, tornadoes touched down in Nebraska near Hildreth and Holstein, in North Dakota near Keen and in Kansas near Cawker City and Russell. Golf ball-size hail fell at Walhalla, N.D. Winds gusted to near 80 mph at Volens, Va. Showers and thunderstorms developed over much of the Northeast and South, and were scattered over parts of the Southwest. The heat was on for the southern Plains, parts of the lower Mississippi Valley, Mississippi and western Tennessee, where afternoon highs were expected to reach 115 degrees through Tuesday afternoon. The high temperature for the Lower 48 states Monday was 110 degrees at Tucson, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Fighting Now A Full-Fledged War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with government troops re-taking town. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `The fighting...''; CHANGES byline
DOC.TEXT: Government troops today shot their way into an east coast town that had been in Tamil rebel hands and were sweeping it for mines and booby traps, military officials said. Batticaloa, 140 miles northeast of Colombo in this Indian Ocean island nation, has been a flashpoint in recent fighting in the war that has grown out of bitter ethnic rivalries. Troops moved in from a nearby airstrip and military camp, the officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Tamil rebels withdrew from the town on Monday into the surrounding jungles to continue fighting. Military officials said law and order in the town had broken down and that looting of stores was widespread. Also today, government forces overran Tamil rebel positions in the east and repulsed an attack on an army garrison in the north, officials said. The army used helicopter gunships and repeated machine-gun fire to stave off an early morning attack by rebels on the Jaffna military garrison, said military officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Jaffna, 190 miles north of Colombo, is headquarters to the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the main rebel milita. The officials said the rebels used bulldozers and heavy earth-moving equipment in their bid to seize the 200-year-old Dutch fort, where the garrison is located. About 150 soldiers were in the garrison at the time, they said. In the east, government police commandos overran two rebel camps and freed 75 people who had been held captive, the officials said. Eight-day-old rebel sieges of two military camps near the town of Batticaloa were broken when army reinforcements crossed swamps and jungles to reach the area, they said. There were no details of casualties in the latest fighting, but Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said Monday that 600 rebels had been killed since June 11. He did not speak of government casualties. In addition, at least 378 people are reported to have been killed. The figure includes at least 137 unarmed policemen said to have been massacred by the rebels. The death toll was compiled from reports by witnesses, military officials and rebel sources. The fighting began June 10 after Tiger rebels overran police stations in the Tamil-dominated northern and eastern provinces, ending a year-long cease-fire with security forces. Two further attempts during the week to stop the fighting broke down. Tamil rebels have been fighting for an independent nation since 1983, claiming their minority community is being discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who control the army and the government. In May 1989, the rebels agreed to a cease-fire with the government. Ten months later, Indian peacekeeping soldiers who had tried in vain to disarm the rebels over 32 months, withdrew from Sri Lanka. That left the rebels in control of most major towns in the north and east. At least 11,000 people, including 1,100 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the war. The government and the rebels began talks on the political future of the regions but the talks had not made much headway before the fighting resumed. Tamils make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people and Sinhalese comprise 75 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Reject Government Amnesty Offer
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the rebel delegation to Liberian peace talks has rejected the government's offer of a general amnesty that would let the insurgents set up their own political party. Thomas Woewiyu, interviewed Monday night, also reiterated the rebel demand that President Samuel Doe leave the West African country. The Liberian leader announced two weeks ago he would not stand for re-election. But he has refused to resign immediately, saying it would leave a dangerous power vacuum during the conflict. On Monday, Doe lifted a ban on several opposition political parties and said the National Patriotic Front rebels could set up a party with no fear of reprisals. ``Doe has no authority to grant anybody amnesty. He is not in a position to grant amnesty. He can only grant himself amnesty,'' Woewiyu said. The two sides adjourned talks Saturday for a week. The rebel delegation signed an agreement urging both sides to exercise restraint during the recess and calling for mutual inspections of troop and supply movements. Fighting had virtually ceased before the talks began. The church-mediated negotiations got under way in neighboring Sierra Leone after Liberian government forces inflicted their first major defeat on the rebels since they invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. In that fighting, rebels were driven from the Firestone rubber plantation and neighboring international airport 35 miles from Monrovia after their chief military commander was killed in a skirmish. Woewiyu said the restraint agreement ``applies more to Doe's extramilitary activities, his death squads chopping off people's heads and throwing away their bodies _ that has nothing to do with a cease-fire.'' Survivors who have fled rebel-controlled territory say the insurgents also committed atrocities. Reporters who have visited them saw the skulls of dead Liberian soldiers stuck on stakes along the roadside. The talks, mediated by the Liberian Council of Churches, were to resume June 25. Woewiyu said the rebels accepted the recess to give Doe time to flee. ``It is Doe who needs an amnesty and he better take it now before it is too late,'' he said. Doe took power in a violent 1980 coup that ousted descendants of the freed American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847. They historically monopolized power and discriminated against indigenous Liberians in their country of 2.5 million residents.

DOC.HEAD: `Mr. Potato' Wins this Year's World Food Prize
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS and FIXES grammar in lead; SUBS 6th graf, `Neiderhauser founded...', with 2 grafs to ADD background. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: A researcher was awarded this year's World Food Prize for developing a strain of potato resistant to the blight that caused Europe's Great Potato Famine in the mid-19th century. John S. Neiderhauser, 74, dubbed ``Mr. Potato,'' was named the fourth winner Monday of the $200,000 prize designed to reward research in production or distribution of food. He developed a strain of potato resistant to late blight disease. The strain is credited with at least doubling yields. ``His achievements toward developing a blight-resistant potato variety have affected countries from Mexico to Bangladesh,'' said Norman Borlaug, founder of the prize. ``Without a doubt, Dr. Niederhauser's discoveries have had a dramatic impact on the food-deficient regions of the world.'' ``Today, the annual increase in world potato production is greater than that of any other crop,'' said Borlaug, winner of the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize for his research fostering the ``green revolution'' in developing nations. Neiderhauser, an American with a doctorate from Cornell University in New York, has done much of his work overseas. He founded the International Potato Center in Lima, Peru, in 1971 and worked for agricultural research foundations in Mexico and Poland. Currently, he is based in Phoenix, where he works as a consultant for Biosphere II, a research program attempting to develop a system in which food could be produced in a closed environment. Such technology could be useful on long space flights, he said. General Foods Inc. established the prize in 1986. But Kraft General Foods, established last year after Philip Morris Companies bought Kraft Inc. and merged it with General Foods, announced in December it was withdrawing funding. The company did not explain why. Prize officials announced Monday that beginning next year, the state of Iowa and private foundations headed by Des Moines businessman John Ruan will sponsor the prize, which costs $600,000 annually to research and administer.

DOC.HEAD: Daily Pronunciation Guide
DOC.TEXT: Here is a guide to the pronunciation of people, places and things in the news:

Frunze FROON-zeh Vaclav Havel VAHTS-LAHV HAH-vel Ion Iliescu YOHN EEL-yes-koo Milos Jakes MEE-LOHSH YAH-kesh Vytautas Landsbergis vy-TAH-TAHS LAHNDS-ber-gihs Lothar de Maiziere LOH-tar duh may-zee-EHR Tadeusz Mazowiecki tah-DAY-oosh mah-zoh-vee-ET-skee Nagorno Karabakh nu-GAHR-nuh ka-ruh-BAHK Kazimiera Prunskiene kuh-zih-MAY-ruh proons-KEH-nuh Nikolai Ryzhkov RIZH-kawf

DOC.HEAD: Raymond Huntley, Actor Who Debunked Pompous Officialdom, Dead at 86
DOC.TEXT: Actor Raymond Huntley, who specialized in comedy roles debunking pompous officialdom in a career on the stage, in movies and on television, has died. He was 86. One of his best-known roles was that of Sir Geoffrey Dillon, the crusty family lawyer in the British TV series ``Upstairs, Downstairs,'' made from 1970 to 1975. Huntley died Friday in London's Westminster hospital. No cause of death was stated in the family's announcement Monday. Huntley was seldom the star of any show but his performances as a supporting actor were noted for their polish and professionalism. He made his first stage appearance in 1922 in Birmingham, the industrial city in central England where he was born. A tall man with a mustache, Huntley during his long career played judges, bank managers, churchmen, bureaucrats and other figures of authority. He could play them straight if necessary but in comedy his natural dryness of delivery was exaggerated to the point where the character he was playing invited mockery as a pompous humbug. His role as the bank manager in the 1949 movie ``Passport to Pimlico'' launched him as a noted film comedy actor. His other movies included the sharply satirical farce ``I'm Alright Jack'' by the film-making brothers John and Roy Boulting in 1959 about Britain's disastrous industrial relations at that time; ``Room at the Top'' in 1958; and ``Hostile Witness'' in 1968. Apart from ``Upstairs, Downstairs,'' his television work included his own series, ``Uncle Charles,'' in which he played a bachelor uncle, and ``That's Your Funeral,'' a comedy about a firm of morticians. His marriage to June Bell was dissolved. Funeral arrangements were not announced.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco OKs $500,000-Plus Settlement with Black Firefighters
DOC.TEXT: City leaders have agreed to pay more than $500,000 to 13 black firefighters to settle claims that they suffered from racist attitudes and abuse during the 1980s. The 13 charged they were the target of physical and verbal harassment by some white firefighters who hassled their black peers with gorilla noises and by posting abusive materials in lockers. ``What's truly frightening is the failure of the fire administration at the time to intervene in these embarrassing incidents of racial harassment,'' Board of Supervisors Harry Britt said Monday. ``They knew that it was going on, but did nothing to stop it.'' The settlements, involving actions that occurred between 1981 and 1988, ranged from $10,000 to $85,000.

DOC.HEAD: Government Arrests Over 40 Critics, Frees 21
DOC.TEXT: Somali authorities have arrested more than 40 people for distributing what the government says are seditious pamphlets criticizing President Mohamed Siad Barre's rule. The arrests were announced Monday by Ahmad Sulayman Abdallah, deputy secretary general of the ruling Somali Revolutionary Socialist Party party. Twenty-one other people were released after proving they had nothing to do with the leaflets. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, last week claimed that up to 50 prominent people, including the country's former president, had been arrested for signing a statement titled ``Mogadishu Manifesto No. 1.'' The statement, signed by more than 100 people and issued May 15, expressed concern at the destruction, killings and flow of refugees from Somalia's civil war, Amnesty International said. It said the statement also criticized the government for violations of human rights, corruption and economic mismanagement. Abdallah's announcement, broadcast on state-run Somali radio and monitored in Nairobi, said authorities were holding more than 40 people for distributing inside and outside the East African nation leaflets ``claiming to advise the president.'' He described them as ``power seekers'' whose aim was to create discord between the people and the government. He did not say when the leaflets first were distributed.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and headline to CORRECT first name to Barbra sted Barbara.
DOC.TEXT: Barbra Walz, a fashion photographer whose pictures appeared on the cover of such magazines as GQ, Metropolitan Home, Parade, Town & Country and Rolling Stone, died Monday of breast cancer at her home. She was 39. Walz's first book, ``The Fashion Makers,'' was published in 1978, when designers were first achieving celebrity status normally reserved for actors or athletes. She photographed her subjects in bathtubs, gymnasiums, dental offices and beauty parlors to capture insight into their personalities. In 1987, Walz published the book ``Starring Mothers,'' about famous mothers and their children. Its subjects included Dianne Feinstein, Patti LaBelle and Carly Simon.

DOC.HEAD: Fugitive Right-Wing Leader Declares War on Government
DOC.TEXT: A fugitive right-wing leader has declared war on the government, releasing a videotape from hiding in which he promises to ``use every means at our disposal'' to overthrow President F.W. de Klerk. Police offered a $19,000 reward today for the arrest of Piet Rudolph, the deputy leader of the extreme right-wing Boer State Party. A spokeswoman, Lt. Nina Barkhuizen, said police had studied Rudolph's videotape, which was received in the mail Monday by a radio station and the Afrikaans-language newspaper Beeld. Government officials said the threat could incite violence as the government negotiates to end apartheid. There was no indication of the degree of support for Rudolph's call, but several right-wing white groups have warned the government that they would use force to preserve their privileges under the system of racial segregation. ``There is no time to plan a counterrevolution. It is now open war,'' Rudolph said in the 20-minute videotape, flanked by four masked men armed with machine guns. ``We will use every means at our disposal to fight the de Klerk government, the overthrow of which is the highest priority to us.'' Rudolph made his statement in Afrikaans, the language of the Dutch-descended whites who run the government. It was translated by the independent South African Press Association. Rudolph is wanted by the police in the theft of arms and ammunition from air force headquarters in Pretoria on April 13. In a statement announcing the reward, Minister of Law and Order Adriaan Vlok said: ``South Africa can't allow people like Mr. Rudolph to rouse emotions with instigating threats.'' ``He is flagrantly and absolutely irresponsibly rousing emotions that can lead to serious incidents of violence,'' Vlok said. He said people who threaten violence, whether from the left or the right, are ``steering people closer to a bloody confrontation.'' In the tape, Rudolph identified ``the enemy'' as de Klerk, the African National Congress and the Communist Party. De Klerk legalized the two left-wing groups in February. They had been banned in South Africa for 30 years. De Klerk has pledged to negotiate a new constitution that would give the black majority a vote in national affairs. Also today, the Communist Party announced plans to formally re-launch the organization and maintain its close alliance with the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico's President Says His Economic Policies Win Japanese Help
DOC.TEXT: Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gotari said today that Japanese interest in helping Mexico solve environmental problems and build its economy were due to his nation's strict economic policies. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said Monday that Japan would provide more than $800 million in credits to help Mexico fight pollution and improve its railways. They include $453 million for a heavy oil desulfurization project, $315 million for a refinery for lead-free gasoline and $40 million for the Mexican national railways locomotive rehabilitation project. Mexico City's pollution, among the worst in the world, is particularly bad because of the nation's almost exclusive use of leaded gasoline. In a speech today before the Japan National Press Club, Salinas said the Japanese were receptive to investing in Mexico and that there were specific plans for 30 projects. He said Japan's largest investment banker, Nomura Securities, was negotiating with a Spanish bank and Mexico to offer a portfolio of Mexican issues known as the ``Mexican Fund'' on the New York Stock Exchange. Salinas attributed Japanese interest in the Mexican market to what he called his country's successful and consistent economic policies. Mexico has brought its deficit to about 6 percent of the gross domestic product and reduced inflation from more than 200 percent to less than 20 percent, Salinas said. As a result, he said, ``Confidence has been strengthened, capital has been repatriated, foreign investment has increased substantially and domestic interest rates have dropped.'' Salinas planned to leave Japan Wednesday for Singapore and Australia. His wife and three children, who attend a private school in Mexico that emphasizes Japanese studies, were to remain in Japan through Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW DELHI
Moslem Militants Fire Rockets At Indian Troops; Killing Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with attacks on three hotels, claim of responsibility, CORRECTS length of gunbattle. Pickup 5th pvs, `At least...'; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants today fired rockets at three lakeside hotels used to house security forces, killing at least two paramilitary soldiers and wounding nine, officials said. It was the militants' first use of rockets since their campaign for independence turned violent in January. Militants launched the rockets in a pre-dawn attack from a boat on Dal Lake, officials said on condition of anonymity. The officials said two hotels were extensively damaged and a third was slightly damaged in the attacks, which led to a gunbattle between militants and security forces. A man claiming to represent a new militant organization, the Moslem Martyr Force, telephoned local journalists to claim responsibility for the attacks. The hotels were being used to bille Minutes after the pre-dawn attack, security forces opened fire toward the lake, a popular tourist spot. The firing continued for about 15 minutes but the militants escaped, the officials said. Earlier news reports said the fighting lasted 90 minutes. At least 575 people have since been killed in the fighting in Srinagar and surrounding areas of the Kashmir valley. The valley forms part of Jammu-Kashmir state, the only one of India's 25 states with a Moslem majority. The valley has been disputed between India and neighboring Pakistan since both were born out of the 1947 division along religious lines of the British-ruled subcontinent. Moslem militants at first demanded union with Islamic Pakistan. But, of late, they have been agitating for independence and the status of a neutral nation. India accuses Pakistan of fomenting the rebellion, a charge Pakistan has denied. On Monday, India agreed to high-level talks with Pakistan in an attempt to defuse the crisis and fears of war between the two countries. In Pakistan on Monday, however, militant Kashmiris declared a government-in-exile to advance their Moslem secessionist movement in the disputed region. The move complicated already tense relations between the two countries. Their governments agreed Monday to talks aimed at easing the threat of war over Kashmir. Amanullah Khan, chairman of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, announced the government-in-exile at a news conference in Muzzaffarabad, capital of Pakistan-held Kashmir. His front is one of the key groups behind the uprising in Jammu-Kashmir state.

DOC.HEAD: Another `Zodiac?': Police Probe Letters For Link to Three Shootings
DOC.TEXT: Letters sent to two news organizations by someone claiming to be the ``Zodiac'' have police investigating whether three non-fatal shootings may be connected, according to a published report today. A letter to the New York Post, with a drawing of a circle carved out with three astrological signs, describes three shootings in New York City since March 8. However, the letter doesn't appear to be similar to those sent by San Francisco's infamous ``Zodiac'' killer, the newspaper said. From 1968 to 1987, someone calling himself ``The Zodiac'' claimed responsibility for as many as 40 killings in notes sent to San Francisco-area newspapers. The case is unsolved. ``This is the Zodiac,'' begins the letter to the Post postmarked June 4. ``The twelve sign will die when the belts in the heaven are seen.'' A similar letter was sent to the CBS news program ``60 Minutes,'' whose staffers turned it over to police, police said. Police said a note found near one victim said: ``This is the Zodiac.'' ``I don't know what I have yet,'' Chief of Detectives Joseph Borelli said. ``If we have a person going around shooting people, I'm worried. We're obviously dealing with someone seeking publicity,'' Borelli said. The shootings occurred March 8, March 29 and May 31 _ two in the same Brooklyn neighborhood and one an adjoining neighborhood in Queens, police said. All three victims survived; one, a 78-year-old man, is still hospitalized, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Ninth Suspected West German Terrorist Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `Maier-Witt and...' to UPDATE with comments about death threats; Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Beer is...'
DOC.TEXT: East German police have arrested yet another alleged Red Army Faction terrorist, a suspect in the 1981 bombing of a U.S. air base and the ninth reputed member of the group captured in less than two weeks. East Germany's interior minister said a tip from a former member of the country's now-disbanded Stasi secret police had led police to Henning Beer, 31. It has been widely believed that the secret police helped fugitive members of the left-wing West German terror group resettle in the East, where they were harbored by the hard-line Communist government. The same tip that snared Beer led authorities to Silke Maier-Witt, whose arrest was announced late Monday, Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel told reporters in East Berlin. Maier-Witt and Beer were both captured on Monday in the East German city of Neubrandenberg, he said. Both had been living and working under false names. The wave of arrests has led to fears of reprisal by the leftist terror gang Red Army Faction. Diestel said that since the arrests started on June 6, his office has received up to five anonymous death threat letters per day aimed at him, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and others. He said there were no indications that East Germany was used as a base of operations for attacks in the West, but that harboring West German terrorists was the ``personal hobby'' of former Communist leader Erich Honecker and his ousted security chief, Erich Mielke. Beer is suspected in the 1981 bombing of the Ramstein Air Base, which seriously injured 17 people, said Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman for the West Germany federal prosecutor's office. Red Army Faction member Helmut Pohl has already been convicted in the Ramstein bombing. In addition, Beer has been charged in a bungled bombing attempt in the Spanish city of Cadiz in June 1988, Foerster said. The Red Army Faction has been waging attacks against NATO, U.S. and West German industrial targets since the early 1970s. Among those killed were a U.S. Army officer and leading West German bankers and industrialists. About two dozen members of the Red Army Faction's old guard are at large. Ms. Maier-Witt, 40, is wanted in the 1977 kidnap-slaying of West German industry chief Hans-Martin Schleyer, and an attempted rocket attack that same year against West Germany's federal prosecutor's office. The first of the recent arrests occurred June 6, when East German officials announced the apprehension in East Berlin of Susanne Albrecht. The 39-year-old suspect is also wanted in the Schleyer case and for the 1977 killing of prominent Dresdner bank chief Juergen Ponto. A week later, officials arrested Inge Viett, 46, in the East German city of Magdeburg. Ms. Viett has been linked to the murder of prominent West Berlin Judge Guenter von Drenkmann in 1974, and the shooting death of a French policeman in 1981. On June 15, authorities announced the arrest of four more suspected terrorists in the East German cities of Frankfurt an der Oder and Cottbus. They have been identified as Monika Helbing, 36, Ekkehard von Seckendorff-Gudent, 39, Werner Lotze, 38, and Christine Duemlein, 41. Ms. Helbing and Lotze have also been linked to the Schleyer case. Ms. Duemlein was released shortly after her arrest because the warrant against her expired in 1985. West German officials said it would not be renewed. On June 16, officials arrested Red Army Faction suspect Sigrid Sternebeck, 40, who is wanted in the 1985 shooting death of U.S. Army Spec. 4 Edward Pimental. Sternebeck allegedly lured the soldier out of a discotheque near Wiesbaden to steal his identification card. The identification card was used the next day to plant a car bomb at the headquarters building of the U.S. Air Force's Rhine-Main Air Base. Two more Americans were killed in the Aug. 8, 1985, blast and 20 people were injured. Both Sternebeck and Albrecht have told investigators they were provided help and new identification by East German secret police, the East German news agency ADN reported.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister's Aide Reprimanded for Stock Trading
