DOC.TEXT: An aide to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu offered to resign after Kaifu reprimanded him for engaging in stock deals last year, an official said today. Aide Mitsuo Ando offered his resignation on Monday, said Shozen Kaneishi, Kaifu's private secretary. Kaneishi said he would decide whether Ando should leave after further investigation. Ando said Kaifu harshly reprimanded him for the stock deal. Ando said he did not believe the deal was corrupt but that it was poorly timed in light of the Recruit stock scandal. Kaifu, who has carefully sought to maintain his own clean reputation, was named prime minister Aug. 9 after the Recruit and sex scandals forced his two immediate predecessors to resign. The stock scandal involved the Recruit Co. information-services conglomerate, which made large donations and questionable stock sales to leading politicians and businessmen. Investigators said the practice amounted to influence-peddling, and 12 politicians, public officials and corporate executives were indicted on bribery charges. Members of Kaifu's Cabinet and other high-ranking parliamentary officials agreed to refrain from dealing in stocks, real estate and golf course memberships. That restriction apparently also applies to top politicians' aides, who played a key role in questionable stock deals in the Recruit affair. Ando confirmed a report in the mass-circulation Asahi Shimbun that he had bought 8,000 shares in Meitech, a firm specializing in hiring out computer engineers. He said the transaction was worth nearly $194,000. When Ando bought Meitech shares, the stocks were traded at $24 per share. Now they cost $40. ``I bought the shares on the recommendation of a securities firm, because I thought (Meitech) was a good company,'' Ando said. ``I have about 20 years of experience in stock trading and used my own funds, from sales of other shares, and plan to keep the shares five or six years,'' he said. ``There's absolutely nothing to be ashamed of, like insider trading or anything. But while at the time I didn't see anything wrong with the deal, now I realize it was careless of me, given the timing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: School Kids Pay with Plastic
DOC.TEXT: If students at Simon Lake Elementary School leave home without it, they won't be able to say ``charge it'' when it comes time for a power lunch of soup, sandwich and milk. The school is taking part in a pilot program being tested in Milford and West Hartford to allow the use of ``debit cards'' instead of cash to pay for lunch in the cafeteria. Milford Food Service Director Edward Huff and computer companies introduced the cards two months ago. The debit cards resemble automatic bank tellers cars and have proved popular. ``This is a tremendous time saver. Collecting money from pupils each day is a very cumbersome task that takes valuable time away from the teaching,'' Huff said. Under the old system, teachers had to record which pupils paid for lunch and how many were absent. With the cards, teachers collect money in advance and that information is sent into a computer system. The students insert the card into a little machine that lights up red, green or yellow to tell students how much money they have left to spend. One student, first-grader Guy Duarte, said there is a potential for embarrassment. ``I think it's dumb because what if your ticket shows up red?'' Guy said. ``You don't get lunch. That would be awful.'' But Huff said if the system showed any pupils had run out of money, they would still get lunch. Janet Bantley, school lunch coordinator for the state Board of Education, praised the new system, saying it not only offers greater accountability, but guarantees the privacy of children on assistance programs. Huff said he expects the debit cards will be in all 12 of the city's elementary schools within the next two years.

DOC.HEAD: House Arrest For Israeli Arab Poet In Unusual Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: A judge said poems by an Israeli Arab incited violence and today placed him under house arrest. It was one of the strongest steps against an Arab citizen during the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising. Israel radio said the judge also ordered that any poetry by Shafik Habib be submitted to the military censor before publication. Habib, a 49-year-old accountant, said in a telephone interview that ``police were trying to set a precedent. We are in a democratic country. There should be freedom of expression.'' He called the action ``a very serious move against an Arab intellectual.'' An Arab legislator demanded a parliamentary debate on the action against the poet. ``This regime is very weak if they are afraid of words,'' legislator Abdul Wahab Darousha said in a telephone interview. Jamal Kawwar, chairman of the Palestinian Israeli Writers' Union, said Habib was the first Israeli Arab citizen to be arrested for his writings. Most punitive measures by Israel during the uprising have involved the 1.7 million Palestinians who live under military rule in the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip. The 810,000 Arabs who live within Israel's boundaries have the full rights of citizens. A military court has sentenced a Palestinian journalist and writer, Samaan Khoury, to 45 months in jail after he was convicted of being an uprising leader active in a Syrian-backed Palestine Liberation Organization faction, military officials said today. Khoury, who is from east Jerusalem and a supporter of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, is not an Israeli citizen. He was accused of writing some of the leaflets espousing violence in the uprising against occupation. He also received a suspended term of 39 months after a yearlong trial that ended Thursday, the officials said. The action against Habib came in the Acco Magistrate's Court, where Judge Eitan Magen put him under house arrest after he was charged with identifying with an unspecified terrorist group because of his poetry. The domestic news agency Itim quoted the charges as saying Habib's poems encouraged readers to violence ``liable to bring about death or injury.'' It said Habib's passport was seized and he was ordered to pay a $5,000 bond. Magen said Habib must remain in his home in Deir Hanna near Acco until further hearings could be held on a police request to jail him until his trial. No trial date was set. Habib was jailed on June 13 and then released today by the judge before being placed under house arrest. The arrest came at a time when more of Israel's Arab citizens have taken part in uprising-related demonstrations, mostly in the aftermath of a May 20 massacre of Arab workers by an Israeli gunman near Tel Aviv. The Maariv daily said the action against Habib came after a collection of his poems were confiscated from a Palestinian in the West Bank city of Ramallah. Police claimed the poems called for attacks on Israel using firebombs, stones and even live ammunition, the newspaper said. Habib disputed the claim of incitement. In the occupied Gaza Strip today, a Palestinian accused of collaborating with Israel was gunned down by masked assailants as he rode in a taxi, Arab reports said. The victim, Mahmud Abu Harb, 35, was shot in the head in Rafah, and masked youths later spray-painted the town's walls with slogans denouncing Abu Harb as a ``traitor.'' Harb's death raised to 224 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs for similar allegations in the 30-month uprising. At least 717 other Palestinians have been killed by Israelis, and 45 Israelis have been slain by Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Opposition Leaders Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to change student groups to opposition, to reflect that students are merely among those being detained.
DOC.TEXT: The government of President-elect Ion Iliescu today announced the arrest of two more opposition leaders in its continuing crackdown on dissent. The wife of another detained opposition figure sought refuge at the Dutch ambassador's home, and a Dutch official said ``we will not ask her to leave.'' Authorities appeared to be adopting a a two-pronged tactic of talking to opposition groups while detaining their leaders. Foreign governments, including the United States, have criticized the way Romania has handled protests. The Interior Ministry today said it had arrested opposition figures Dumitru Dinca and Nica Leon, leader of the small National Democratic Party. The two were being held as part of an investigation into the 53-day anti-government protest on University Square that club-wielding riot police broke up on Wednesday. On Monday, authorities detained Marian Munteanu, a student leader severely beaten by pro-government miners last week. Munteanu was removed from his hospital bed to an Interior Ministry hospital on charges of instigating violence. Wednesday's crackdown by police triggered rioting that ended the next day when coal miners called in by Iliescu cleared the city center, beating with clubs and iron bars anyone they suspected of being a government opponent. The vigilantes also sacked the offices of opposition parties and shut down opposition newspapers. Munteanu's wife, Claudia, sought refuge at the home of Dutch Ambassador Coen Stork, The Netherlands Embassy said. ``She has been at the residence of the ambassador since yesterday evening because she fears for her safety,'' said Charge d'Affaires Kaas Vran Spronsam by telephone. Asked how long she would be able to stay, the diplomat replied: ``We will not ask her to leave.'' Government opponents seek the ouster of Iliescu and the other former Communists who hold top posts in the National Salvation Front, which took power in the December revolution and won election by a landslide last month. On Monday, the opposition newspapers said they would resume publishing. The opposition Romania Libera daily, last published Thursday and often hard to buy, was not on the streets today. But its editors said it appeared. Student activists were targeted last week by the miners in what was the worst street unrest since the December revolt that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Six people were killed and more than 500 injured in the violence, and the government said more than 1,000 were arrested. The Interior Ministry said its chief, Doru Viorel Ursu, was holding talks with student groups. But at the same time, Prime Minister Petre Roman said government forces ``had the responsibility and obligation'' to crack down on dissent. Parliament's lower house on Monday gave police and soldiers the authority to clear from University Square anti-government protesters who had reassembled there beginning Sunday. Most dispersed Monday night, and the square was quiet today. In the 377-member House of Deputies, only 72 voted against Monday's motion to have ``the forces of law and order'' end the demonstration in the square. The vote split along party lines, with the National Salvation Front in favor backed by splinter parties, and the three main opposition parties abstaining or voting ``no.'' Passage was virtually certain in the Senate, where the Front also holds a majority. In a separate measure, the 114 senators present Monday voted for government and police to ``take immediate measures ... to sanction firmly all those who trespassed and will trespass'' on public property. However, the Senate also passed a motion critical of the ``excesses that consisted of roughing up people and damaging political party headquarters and public institutions.'' Iliescu's inauguration, scheduled for last week, was postponed amid the turmoil.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Companies Sued for Allegedly Polluting California Coast
DOC.TEXT: Federal and state officials have sued eight California companies on grounds that they have been polluting waters and damaging marine life off Los Angeles and Long Beach since the 1940's, the government announced today. The Justice Department filed the suit on behalf of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the Interior Department and the State of California, NOAA said. NOAA said four of the companies named in the suit were Montrose Chemical Corp., Westinghouse Electric Corp., Stauffer Chemical Corp. and Potlatch Corp. The others were not immediately identified. The suit alleges that the companies dumped the pesticide DDT and polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, into Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors, onto the Palos Verdes Shelf off Whites Point and at two dump sites in the San Pedro Channel near Santa Catalina Island. Fish, marine mammals and sea birds were injured, NOAA said. The businesses could be required under federal Superfund legislation to pay tens of millions of dollars to restore damage to natural resources and habitat. They could also be required to remove or treat contaminated underwater sediments, restock fish or install artificial reefs. The firms were informed in January of the government's intention to sue. A 90-day extension of the time in which they could be sued was negotiated in March. It expired today. NOAA said the Los Angeles County Sanitation Districts, another potential defendant, signed a time extension giving the government until next April to decide whether to sue. NOAA said its biologists have found that both commercial and sports fish off Los Angeles have high levels of DDT and PCB's. Particularly, the agency said, bottlenose dolphins and California sea lions have the highest body fat concentrations of those two chemicals of any marine mammal it has ever studied.

DOC.HEAD: Silent Gunman Kills 10 People and Himself in 2 Days
With PM-Massacre-List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with breakdown of victims, ages; police saying Pough successfully completed probation and apparently would not be considered felon; adds details. No pickup. Pough prounounced `pew'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JV1, LaserColor JV2
DOC.TEXT: The silent gunman who killed eight people and seriously wounded five at an auto loan agency that had repossessed his car also killed two people on a street the day before, police said. James Edward Pough, 42, shot himself to death after his rampage Monday at a General Motors Acceptance Corp. office. The day laborer from Jacksonville began firing a semiautomatic rifle almost immediately after entering the large one-room office. He shot two customers, then went desk to desk, shooting at employees cowering underneath. Seven employees and one customer, ages 30 to 45, were killed. Six victims were women. ``The shots kept coming closer and I kept hearing the moans of people I know,'' said Rick Langille, a loan manager. ``The guy was pointing his gun under people's desks and killing them one by one. I just saw the bottom of the carpet and just prayed.'' Sheriff James McMillan said Pough has also been identified by witnesses as the killer of a man and woman in separate shootings on Sunday. The victims, ages 39 and 30, were killed with the same .30-caliber rifle used Monday, he said. The shootings Sunday occurred near Pough's home, and at least one stemmed from arguments over ``services of a prostitute,'' McMillan said. He did not elaborate. Before Monday's rampage, Pough was not a suspect in the Sunday shootings. The sheriff also said investigators were trying to determine where and how Pough got his guns. Pough had been charged with manslaughter in 1971 and pleaded guilty to a lesser felony. Generally, felons may not own firearms. But under an agreement, Pough's record was to be wiped clean at the end of the five years if he obeyed the terms of probation. A records check showed Pough successfully completed probation, Asa Higgs, a police spokesman, said today. Authorities were checking to confirm that the conviction had been removed as provided for in the agreement. But apparently, ``he does not qualify as a convicted felon,'' Higgs said. GMAC said it had repossessed Pough's 1988 Pontiac Grand Am in January. Whether the repossession was Pough's only motive for the massacre ``we just don't know,'' the sheriff said. The gunman never said a word, GMAC employees told police and counselors called in after the two-minute shooting rampage. About 80 people worked in the one-story building. ``He just shot until he saw no one else to shoot,'' McMillan said. Pough used a clip-fed semiautomatic rifle for the shootings, then turned a .38-caliber revolver on himself, authorities said. ``There's numerous magazines, plus numerous rounds in his pockets,'' said Deputy Ken Bozeman. ``He was loaded for war.'' The death toll equaled the worst shooting rampage in Florida history, a 1982 massacre at a Miami machine shop where nine died and three were wounded. Of those injured Monday, four were in critical condition and one was in serious condition this morning. Some were shot seven or eight times, officials said. ``I had to keep stepping over bodies to give victims CPR,'' said sheriff's patrolman Steve Dubberly. ``It's the worst slaughter I've ever seen in my life.'' Pough's revolver was registered in 1979, McMillan said. Federal agents were checking whether the rifle was registered. A 9mm semiautomatic pistol registered to Pough was found in his car outside of the building, McMillan said. He also had a registered .357-caliber, but no information was given on that weapon's location. In addition to his 1971 arrest, the sheriff said, Pough was arrested in 1968 ``for dangerously displaying a weapon.''

DOC.HEAD: Roy McDonald, Publisher Of Chattanooga News-Free Press, Dies At 88
DOC.TEXT: Roy McDonald, publisher of the Chattanooga News-Free Press, died in his sleep early today, family members said. He was 88. McDonald, who started the paper in 1933 as a weekly shopper called the Chattanooga Free Press, commonly put in eight- to 10-hour days at the News-Free Press, even into his 80s, checking ads, news copy and story layout. He had worked Monday, the day before he died. He was known as ``Mr. Roy'' to his staff, his colleagues, his family and to the city. The Free Press went daily in 1936, and three years later McDonald bought the financially troubled Chattanooga News to create the current newspaper. The paper now has a joint operating agreement with The Chattanooga Times. McDonald was also a major force in Chattanooga business and civic affairs, serving on the board at Erlanger Medical Center and helping create Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Tennessee. He was born Nov. 25, 1901, in Graysville, Tenn. As a young man, he managed grocery stores for his father before founding a grocery chain called the Homes Stores in 1924. The chain grew to more than 70 stores in the Chattanooga area before he sold it in 1967. The afternoon News-Free Press and the morning Times published jointly until 1966, when McDonald began a Sunday edition to compete with the Times. The Times responded with an afternoon paper called The Chattanooga Post. The newspapers sued each other, and the Post was discontinued in 1970 after Times officials signed a consent decree in an antitrust suit filed by the Justice Department. The Times also paid a settlement to the News-Free Press that was reported to be $2 million to $3 million. McDonald used that money to buy a new press. In 1980, the papers entered a new operating agreement in which the Times, which had lost $2 million over five years, agreed to give up its Sunday edition. Survivors include his wife, Elizabeth; a son, Frank S. McDonald; daughters Helen McDonald Exum, Dr. Martha W. McDonald, Betsy McDonald Anderson and Nancy McDonald Reinke; and numerous grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Runs Aground Near Where Bermuda Star Hit
DOC.TEXT: Oil was taken today from the damaged tanks of a barge that ran aground in Buzzards Bay near where the cruise ship Bermuda Star scraped bottom last week, officials said. Transfer of some 1.2 million gallons began late Monday night and continued today at the rate of 50,000 gallons an hour, U.S. Coast Guard Lt. James Donovan said. The process should be completed today, allowing the barge owner to move the vessel. Four of the barge's 16 tanks were damaged in the accident, but the spill was estimated to be no more than 10 gallons of the No. 2 fuel, used for home heating and diesel engines, said Donovan. ``The slick that went out was almost too small to see,'' Coast Guard Lt. Peter Keane said earlier. The barge, bound from New Jersey to Maine, has a capacity of 5.23 million gallons, was being towed by a tugboat when it hit Monday, the U.S. Coast Guard said. The barge stopped leaking shortly after it hit the rocks, and Coast Guard crews refloated the barge Monday evening. Coast Guard Chief Diego Mello said the barge ran aground on rocks about a mile from where Bermuda Star, with more than 1,000 passengers and crew aboard, ran aground near the entrance to the Cape Cod Canal. The Bermuda Star accident ripped a 90-foot gash in its hull, spilling thousands of gallons of diesel fuel. Those on board were ferried to safety. Buzzards Bay fronts the western shore of Cape Cod, about 50 miles southeast of Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Expresses Discontent Over Movie Portrayal of Khomeini
DOC.TEXT: Iran has asked Turkey to halt screenings of an American movie that mocks the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, a government official said today. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press that Iran made the request through diplomatic channels on Saturday, a day after five movie theaters in Istanbul and one in Ankara began showing ``The Naked Gun.'' The official said the government was considering the matter and would see whether it was possible to edit out the brief segment lampooning Khomeini. The Iranian News Agency IRNA reported that the Turkish charge d'affaires in Tehran was summoned to the Foreign Ministry today and informed of Iran's unhappiness with the film. Turkish Foreign Minister Ali Bozer is scheduled to pay an official visit to Iran on June 25. The Turkish official said his country did not want the film to harm relations with Iran. Turkey is a predominantly Moslem country but has secular laws. Different interpretations of Islam's role in public life has caused strains between Turkey and neighboring Iran in the past. ``The Naked Gun,'' directed by David Zucker, is a spoof and stars Leslie Nielsen as an incompetent detective, Lt. Frank Drebin. In one scene, Drebin punches a character that looks like Khomeini and reveals a spiked punk hairdo under his turban. Others portrayed in the 1988 film include Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat and former Ugandan president Idi Amin. Spokesmen for the five theaters showing ``The Naked Gun'' in Istanbul said they had received anonymous phone calls threatening attacks against the cinemas. Operators of three theaters said they edited out the parts about Khomeini after receiving bomb threats. The two others were still running the film intact. Salih Karakus, director of the Atlantik theater, said he planned to show the movie at least another three weeks. ``It is doing such a good business,'' he said. A spokesman for Metropol Theater in Ankara said no threats had been made and that the movie would continue to be be shown in its original form. ``We are against any kind of censorship,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Seek Origins of Gunman's Arsenal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to RECAST and UPDATE with police saying Pough completed probation and would apparently not be considered convicted felon. Picks up 12th graf, `Pough entered...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Office Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Investigators are trying to trace the weapons used by a man to kill at least 10 people in two days before taking his own life. Authorities reviewed registration forms and other leads on how James Edward Pough, 42, obtained the weapons for the rampage that began Sunday in a Jacksonville neighborhood and ended Monday inside an auto loan company. ``We're trying to find the answer to that right now,'' Sheriff James McMillan said. Pough had been convicted of a felony in the 1970s, and it is illegal in Florida for convicted felons to own handguns. But a police spokesman today said Pough would apparently not have been considered a convicted felon. In 1971, Pough was charged with manslaughter in a shooting death. He pleaded guilty to aggravated assault and was sentenced to five years' probation, court records show. The records show that if Pough obeyed the terms of his probation, the case was to be removed from his record. An overnight records check showed that Pough successfully completed his probation, said Asa Higgs, a police spokesman. Officials were still checking to confirm that the case was removed. Under Florida law, background checks before a weapons purchase depend heavily on what the buyer discloses. Until strengthened gun laws take effect Oct. 1, gun purchasers are required only to have some identification, such as a driver's license, and fill out a questionnaire on arrests, mental illness and drug use. Merchants are not required to check the information, and there is no way for them to confirm it other than by calling police agencies themselves. The new statute requires that all applications be checked by a central computer in Tallahassee. Pough entered a General Motors Acceptance Corp. office Monday and shot customers and employees, some cowering under their desks. Pough killed eight people and seriously injured five before taking his own life. GMAC had repossessed Pough's car in January. The sheriff said that may not have been Pough's sole motive, but he offered no further suggestions. Police said witnesses also identified Pough as the person who killed a man and a woman in separate shootings Sunday near Pough's home. Police said those killings were done with the same .30-caliber semiautomatic rifle used on Monday. Pough shot himself with a .38-caliber revolver that he had registered in 1979, McMillan said. Federal agents were checking whether the rifle was registered. A 9mm semiautomatic pistol registered to Pough was found in his car outside the building, McMillan said. He also had a registered .357-caliber, but no information was given on that weapon's location.

DOC.HEAD: Report Questions GOP Candidate's Experience Claims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Rinfret's son promising detailed resume; `no-comment' from state GOP. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `Nixon did ...
DOC.TEXT: A Republican challenging Gov. Mario Cuomo's re-election bid may have exaggerated some claims about his political and education experience, a newspaper reported today. Some former Nixon administration officials disputed Pierre Rinfret's suggestion that he was a major adviser to the president, The New York Times said. The Times also said Rinfret never earned a doctorate, but has used the title ``Dr. Rinfret'' on resumes, on legal documents and in his political biography. The state GOP nominated Rinfret, 66, last month. The millionaire economist, a political unknown, was chosen after the party made a months-long effort to persuade better-known Republicans to run against the popular two-term Democrat. In his acceptance speech at the State Republican convention, Rinfret said he was ``offered the equivalent of three Cabinet posts'' by Nixon. In an interview, he told the Times that Nixon personally offered to make him a member of his Council of Economic Advisers in 1968 and secretary of commerce in 1972. Rinfret also said two Nixon aides asked him if he would be interested in becoming secretary of the treasury in 1971. Calls to Rinfret at his home and office this morning were not immediately returned. But his son and adviser, Peter Rinfret, promised to release an information packet ``with primary sources'' that would provide much detail, including his father's World War II heroics. ``I'm not going to respond to that,'' said Peter Rinfret when asked if his father might have exaggerated his credentials. Elizabeth DelTorto, a top aide to state GOP Chairman J. Patrick Barrett, said the party would have no comment, adding: ``If Mr. Rinfret wants to say anything, that's up to him.'' Nixon did not respond to several telephone messages left at his office, the newspaper said. But top aides in his administration, including chief domestic policy adviser John Erlichman, Treasury Secretary John Connally and two chairmen of the Council of Economic Advisers, Paul McCracken and Herbert Stein, said they did not know that Rinfret had been considered seriously for any of the posts. Several Nixon aides said Rinfret did occasionally have the ear of the president, but the Times quoted one top Nixon adviser as saying that Nixon consulted Rinfret ``to placate him,'' because he was prone to criticizing administration policy. New York Times columnist and former Nixon aide William Safire, however, said he recalled that Rinfret was offered a job on the Council of Economic Advisers after Nixon's election in 1968. Safire also said Nixon valued Rinfret's advice. Rinfret earned a diploma at the University of Dijon in France in 1946 that university officials said was the equivalent of an American master's degree. After returning to the United States, Rinfret was told by a French diplomatic official that he could call the degree a doctorate, the Times said. But university officials told the Times he would have had to study at least four more years and finish a dissertation to earn the French equivalent of a doctorate. Rinfret said that even if the Dijon doctorate does not count, he can claim a doctorate because of an honorary degree he received from Pepperdine University in Malibu, Calif., in 1973. Rinfret is president of Rinfret Inc., a group of consulting and financial-futures trading firms.

DOC.HEAD: Recovery of Baby Sitter's Body Drives Flood's Horror Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to delete extraneous word `dumped.' SUBS 9th graf, `The federal...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with emergency center opened. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `A National...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XBL1
DOC.TEXT: Friends of Kerri Polivka say they are not surprised she put a 9-year-old girl into a bathtub that was whisked safely away from a trailer home as it was torn apart in a flash flood. The body of 13-year-old Kerri was found Monday in the Ohio River, bringing to 21 the number known to have died in the flooding. Thirteen people were listed as missing. Kerri, of Wegee, was baby-sitting at the home of Amber Colvin when a storm Thursday dumped 5{ inches of rain in about three hours, sending a wall of water rushing down two small creeks that empty into the river. Kerri put Amber in the tub and got in with her. The two became separated after Kerri was hit on the head as the trailer collapsed, Amber said Friday. Amber said she survived by holding onto logs and was rescued 7{ hours later when she reached the bank of the Ohio River. She suffered cuts and scratches. ``She would have thought of Amber first because she was watching her that night,'' said Angel Halpin, a sixth-grade classmate and one of Kerri's closest friends. Angel said she believed searchers sifting through debris along the Wegee and Pipe creeks would find Kerri alive. ``I kept saying to myself that she had a broken leg or something and was just sitting somewhere waiting for help,'' she said. Rescuers held out little hope that any of the missing would turn up alive. Fifty-five people stood in line this morning outside a disaster relief application center in Shadyside before it opened. It is one of three application centers the Federal Emergency Management Agency planned to open this week. The others are in Adena in Jefferson County and Dillonvale in Harrison County. The FEMA said its preliminary assessment showed that at least 700 homes were destroyed or damaged by the flooding in Belmont, Jefferson and Harrison counties. A National Weather Service official said the storm developed so quickly there was no time to issue a flash flood warning. ``We're dealing with God almighty here, nature itself. Sometimes nature just isn't predictable,'' said Ed Heath, director of the weather service office in Akron. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which oversees the weather service, said it would investigate its performance. Such investigations are routine in disasters involving more than five deaths, the agency said. The first funerals were held Monday for victims of the flood. About 100 people gathered at morning services for Roger DeNoon. Funerals were held later in the day for John and Edna Andrecht in Shadyside and 6-year-old Timmy Gatten in Jacobsburg. Several services were scheduled today. ``I'm not sure any of us can prepare for this type of a tragedy,'' said Capt. Tim Muir, a Salvation Army chaplain who delivered the eulogy at DeNoon's funeral. ``The thing we have to look at is found in Isaiah 38:1 _ `Thus saith the Lord: ``Set thy house in order, for thou shalt die and not live.''' News that Kerri's body had been found will be especially difficult to accept at Leona Avenue Middle School, where she was an A and B student who made friends easily, said Principal John Krupa. ``She was just the type of girl everyone would like to have as a daughter. Maybe mine will follow in her footsteps,'' Krupa said. He pulled her student file and looked at it. ``There's nothing anywhere in here that shows she was ever in any kind of trouble and nothing that shows that she was the smartest girl in the world,'' Krupa said. ``Kerri just did her job.''

DOC.HEAD: Well-Traveled Feline Gets New Owner
DOC.TEXT: A stowaway cat that shared a shipping container with a Mercedes Benz for 48 days without food and water has found a new home _ with the car's owner. The black feline, which appropriately has been named Mercedes, will have to wait 226 days to move into her new home with Marla Skartvedt because of Australia's strict quarantine regulations. Qurantine officials had received dozens of calls about the animal since her arrival a week ago on board a ship from London. A spokeswoman for the South Australian Department of Agriculture said the quarantine costs of $1,623 would be paid by Mrs. Skartvedt, the South Australia Animal Welfare League, a cat-food manufacturer and the company that owns the shipping container. She said a special ``Mercedes Fund'' would be set up to take public donations, with anything left over going to cat charities. Mercedes was reported Tuesday to be healthy and happy at the suburban Torrens Island quarantine center.

DOC.HEAD: Pavarotti's World Cup Song Hits Top 10
DOC.TEXT: Forget rap. Luciano Pavarotti is the new kid on the block of the British pop charts. His rendition of ``Nessun Dorma'' from Puccini's opera ``Turandot'' has jumped to No. 3 on the singles chart, due in large part to the daily play it receives as the theme for the BBC's World Cup soccer coverage. The single's popularity propelled Pavarotti's album,``The Essential Pavarotti,'' to the top of the pop album list. Jessica Atkinson, a spokeswoman for Decca Records, this is the first time a classical album has hit No. 1 on the pop album chart. The British Broadcasting Corp. chose ``Nessun Dorma'' as its World Cup theme after Pavarotti sang it during the opening ceremony for the team draw in December, said BBC spokesman Mike Gardner. ``Nessun Dorma'' (``none shall sleep'') is a romantic song expressing the optimism of Calaf that he will marry the hard-hearted princess, Turandot.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Report 14 Clashes With Turkish Troops In 2 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Kurdish guerrillas operating in eastern Turkey said Tuesday they killed 25 government troops and wounded 13 in clashes during the first two weeks of June. A communique by the Marxist Kurdish Workers Party reported 14 separate incidents during the two-week period in the Kurdish-inhabited region of eastern Turkey. The communique, mailed to The Associated Press in Nicosia, said five guerrillas died and one was wounded in the fighting. The estimated 10 million Kurds of Turkey have been waging an intermittent campaign for independence or a measure of autonomy from the Turkish government for decades.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Arrested at U.S. Consul's Office in AIDS Protest
With AM-AIDS Protest, Bjt
LaserPhoto SYD1
DOC.TEXT: Activists protesting U.S. immigration restrictions on people with the AIDS virus surged into the U.S. Consulate on Tuesday after destroying an American flag and scrawling graffiti on the building. Scuffles broke out between police and the protesters who flooded the foyer, and seven people were arrested. The AIDS Coalition To Unleash Power, or ACT UP, timed the protest to coincide with worldwide actions marking the Sixth International AIDS conference, which opens in San Francisco on Wednesday. International AIDS groups, major health organizations and several governments have boycotted the conference to protest a U.S. law under which people testing positive for the AIDS virus can be barred from entering the country. ACT UP spokesman Bruce Brown told the protesters, who numbered more than 100,,that President Bush is ``history's greatest serial killer'' because of his ``wimpish'' stand against acquired immune defiency syndrome. He said many infected people are homeless and begging on the streets because of government inaction. The travel restrictions are fueling discrimination against homosexuals and people with AIDS, and they are a political rather than health measure, Brown said. A police spokesman said the arrested demonstrators were charged with a series of offenses, including malicious damage, assaulting police, hindering police, offensive language and resisting arrest. All were given unconditional bail and ordered to appear in court July 10. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring. The scientific name for the virus is human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Starts Hit Lowest Level Since Last Recession
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts fell in May for the fourth consecutive month to their lowest level since the last recession, the government said Tuesday. Analysts, who said the decline was further evidence that the housing market continues to weaken, attributed the 1.4 percent fall to high mortgage rates, tight credit, a large inventory of new and existing homes, wet weather and a sluggish economy resulting in slackening consumer confidence. The Commerce Department said starts of new homes and apartments totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.21 million units, the smallest number since 1.17 million units got under way in October 1982 at the end of the last recession. David Seiders, the National Association of Home Builders' chief economist, said a survey of its members in early June pointed to continuing weakness. Applications for building permits _ often a barometer of future housing activity _ also have fallen for four straight months, noted Martin Regalia, chief economist with the National Council of Savings Institutions. Such applications declined 4.6 percent to 1.06 million after falling 10.1 percent in April. The May level was the lowest since 1.04 million were recorded in September 1982. ``It's not a rosy picture at all for the remainder of the year,'' Regalia said. Mortgage rates, which dropped into the single digits toward the end of last year, rose above the 10 percent level in January and ranged from 10.33 percent to 10.67 percent in May, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Rates fell to 10.12 percent by last Friday. David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said declining rates may help the single-family sector. But he said builder uncertainty over proposed federal regulations governing handicapped access to apartment buildings will continue to slow the multifamily sector. John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, said many builders have had trouble getting construction loans because of the constraints of the savings and loan bailout law and tighter lending restrictions by banks. Economist Richard Peach of the Mortgage Bankers Association noted that May was a very wet month over parts of the nation, but also cited interest rates and large inventories of new and existing homes. ``It's not an environment in which builders wanted to go out on a limb and start a whole slew of new units,'' he said. Part of the inventory problems, Regalia said, is the effect of the slowing economy on consumer confidence. ``Consumers, rather than spending to the limit, are starting to increase savings dramatically,'' he said. ``One of the first things that goes when you have this kind of ... retrenchment is big-ticket items _ cars and houses, things that people can discretionarily push off into the future.'' Construction of single-family homes in May fell 1 percent to an annual rate of 896,000 units on top of a 9.1 percent drop in April. It was the lowest number of single-family starts since 862,000 got under way in December 1982. Apartment construction slipped 2.5 percent to an annual rate of 311,000 units after rising 2.6 percent the previous month. The building activity means the pace during the first five months of 1990 was 5.3 percent below that of the same period of 1989. Starts slumped 8 percent to 266,000 units in the Midwest and fell 3.3 percent to 337,000 units in the West. Increases were posted in the South, up 3.2 percent to 486,000 units, and the Northeast, up 1.6 percent to 129,000 units.

DOC.HEAD: ICRC Resumes Operations in Ethiopia After Two Year Absence
DOC.TEXT: The International Committee of the Red Cross will resume operations in war-torn Ethiopia after an absence of two years, a spokeswoman said Tuesday. Emergency medical teams from the Swiss humanitarian agency are expected to arrive in Ethiopia by the end of this week to treat victims of the fighting between government forces and rebels, she said. The spokeswoman, who asked not to be identified, said the agreement followed long negotiations with the Ethiopian government. She added that the ICRC will decide later whether to expand its assistance to non-medical operations such as famine relief. The Geneva-based agency withdrew from Ethiopia in June 1988 after the Marxist-led government ordered all foreign relief agencies to leave the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, home of the two insurgency movements fighting the government.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Endorses Separate Russian Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-6 pvs, `The champion...' with 5 grafs to move up differing views of what new party would accomplish. Pickup 7th pvs, `Russia, with...' DELETES grafs 19-20 pvs, `The decision...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today endorsed the formation of a separate Communist Party in the Soviet Union's biggest republic, but warned of friction between national leaders and those in the Russian republic. ``I view ... the Russian Communist Party as part of the Soviet Communist Party. And I sharply disagree with those who seek the salvation of Russia in withdrawing from the Soviet Union,'' he said at the opening of a party conference expected to formally re-establish the separate party. The champion of that movement for greater Russian independence is the newly elected president of the Russian Federation, Boris N. Yeltsin, who sat near Gorbachev on the dais. Radicals, including Yeltsin, view formation of the party a means of weakening central authority and hastening economic and political reforms. Conservatives, especially nationalists, see a Russian party as a vehicle of preserving political and cultural traditions. Gorbachev was expected to receive criticism from both groups. The speaker after Gorbachev, Ivan Osadchi, said the party leadership ``has reduced (the party) to crouching instead in the trenches under massive shelling by anti-socialist forces, which have rapidly organized themselves.'' The Russian party session is viewed as a bellwether of the 28th Congress of the national Communist Party, due to start July 2. Russia, with more than half of the Soviet population and three-quarters of its territory, is home to 58 percent of the country's more than 18 million Communist Party members. The delegates to the Russian conference will also represent the republic at the national congress. The delegates voted 2,607 to 61, with 16 abstentions, to adopt the agenda proposed by Gorbachev to consider the formation of the Russian party and to debate the proposed platform of the national congress, and not to discuss their own platform. The separate Russian Communist Party was absorbed into the national party 65 years ago. Of the 15 Soviet republics, only Russia has not had its own party, in large part because Russians have controlled the national and regional parties. Gorbachev is seeking to steer the conference on a centrist course between radicals who want to hasten steps toward a market economy and conservatives who want to slow the reforms. He defended his cautious economic and political reforms and resisted efforts by radicals to open a debate on Russian sovereignty. ``Already we hear the opinion that perestroika has worsened the situation in the country.'' he said, citing accusations that the reforms had lowered living standards and raised tensions among ethnic groups. He claimed his reforms had accomplished more at home and abroad in three years than similar efforts over the previous 30 years. He cited the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan as a signficant step toward reducing global tension. But he said domestic restructuring ``is hampered by ... an ossified and conservative public consciousness that was formed during decades of totalitarian ideology.'' This conference comes a week after the Russian republic's parliament approved a resolution calling for further legislation to declare that Russian laws supersede Soviet laws on Russian territory. The resolution, which did not carry the force of law, opened the door for the Russian parliament to pass legislation transferring most political and economic decision-making power from central to republic authorities. Although Gorbachev acted as chairman of the session he was not among the candidates considered likely to be elected as first secretary, or leader, of the new party. Those in the running were the Soviet premier, Nikolai Ryzhkov; Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin; Yuri Mananenkov, a secretary of the national party; said Andrei Girenko, another national party secretary. Delegates to the Russian party conference voted 2,607 to 61, with 16 abstentions, to adopt the agenda proposed by Gorbachev. Under it, they will consider the formation of the Russian party and debate the proposed platform of the national congress.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Blast Congress After Rosty Says No Money Coming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT spelling of Rostenkowsky. SUBS 12th graf, `But while...', to CORRECT spelling of Kerrey. Corrects `government' in 6th graf; `there' in 10th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Big-city mayors are angrily attacking Congress after being told by a leading Democrat that they stand little chance of getting any new federal help _ even if there's a peace dividend from defense cuts. ``If you have a $500 suit and unlimited campaign contributions, like the greedy and corrupt savings and loans, you can get whatever you want from Washington,'' Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn said Monday. ``But if you try to get a few dollars for the poor and needy you are totally ignored.'' Flynn and other mayors attending the summer meeting of the U.S. Conference of Mayors went on the offensive after House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski told them cities stood little or no chance of getting any more federal help in the near future. Today, New York Mayor David Dinkins made his first appearance at the conference and, despite Rostenkowski's message, led the mayors in a populist appeal for a city share of the peace dividend. ``Peace has brought with it a spendable dividend,'' Dinkins said. ``And if that money was available to build bombers, it certainly is available to rebuild our cities. ... It is a challenge that we _ the mayors of America _ must mobilize to meet.'' Rostenkowski's assessment came as a blow to the mayors, who spent the weekend crafting a new urban agenda that depends heavily on cities getting billions from the government after a decade of cuts in aid. ``There's no money for such programs until the budget blockade is broken,'' Rostenkowski said in a blunt speech to the more than 200 mayors. ``We need movers and shakers in Congress who will stand for the cities like they stood for the corrupt S&Ls,'' Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, N.J., said in an interview. ``Being in Congress now is like getting tenure _ you're not accountable to the people any more.'' Not all of the attacks came from big-city, Northeast mayors. ``We're trying to control the intense level of frustration that we have right now,'' said Mayor Lee Robinson of Macon, Ga. ``Congress keeps telling us to man the front line on the war on drugs and other issues, but while we're out there getting beat up they're not offering any help and are hiding.'' Not long after Rostenkowski spoke, the mayors heard a somewhat more encouraging speech from Democratic Sen. Robert Kerrey of Nebraska. But while supportive of the mayors' causes, Kerrey too said no funding for them would come from any peace dividend. Instead, he said mayors would have to take their case to the people much like Ronald Reagan did in the early 1980s when his proposed military buildup faced congressional opposition. ``If they believe it is worthwhile, they will do it,'' Kerrey said of the American public. Kerrey said Congress has been hiding behind the federal deficit and brushes off the requests of cities and other constituencies by pointing to the defict targets contained in the Gramm-Rudman law. But Kerrey said Congress could solve the deficit problem if it had the political courage to defend higher taxes and other necessary steps.

DOC.HEAD: Cop Gets Ultimate Coffee Break
DOC.TEXT: After six weeks of searching for 13{ tons of stolen coffee, this was the break authorities were looking for. A police officer became suspicious of a trailer that had been parked along a freeway for nearly two weeks in this San Bernardino County city and ran the license plate through a computer. The computer found nothing wrong, but the notion that something wasn't quite right kept percolating in Officer Tim Lane's police mind. Finally, on Saturday, he ran the trailer's vehicle identification number, and the case of the missing Folgers was cracked. The computer showed the refrigerated trailer was stolen last April in North Hollywood. Inside, officers found about 9,000 three-pound packages of Folgers, which was unloaded Monday. Capt. George Westcott said police traced the lot numbers of the coffee and determined it had been stolen May 2 in San Francisco. It was not immediately known why the coffee was abandoned.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Mexican Scientists Study Southwestern Monsoon
DOC.TEXT: Scientists from Mexico and the United States are launching an intense study of the monsoon-like weather that brings summer rainfall to the Southwest, the government announced Tuesday. The month-long analysis begins July 8, seeking to learn more about the wet and dry seasons in portions of the United States and Mexico. The Southwestern climate can contribute to severe weather as far away as the Great Lakes, said Robert Maddox, director of the National Severe Storms Laboratory in Norman, Okla. Scientists said it may take about a year to analyze the information they collect, and they hope to use it to more accurately predict severe storms. Although monsoons are usually associated with the climate of southeast Asia, they can also occur in climates with sea-to-land breezes in summer and land-to-sea winds in winter. That type of circulation occurs over the southwestern United States and northeastern Mexico. Summer heat in the region causes the air to rise, drawing moist air from the Pacific Ocean and Gulf of California and contributing to thunderstorms. Mexican and American scientists will launch balloons to check upper-air conditions at several sites in the region, and studies will be conducted from aircraft based in Phoenix, Ariz. In addition, scientists will also seek to determine if added heat generated by the city of Phoenix affects weather nearby, particularly the summer storms in nearby mountains. Taking part in the study are scientists from the NOAA's National Weather Service and National Environmental Satellite, Data and Information Service; Arizona State University, the University of Arizona, the Salt River Project, the Mexican Weather Service, the NOAA-University of Colorado Cooperative Institute for Research in the Environmental Sciences and the Mexican Centro de Investigacion Cientifica y de Education Superior de Ensenada.

DOC.HEAD: Ten Albanians Flee to Greece
DOC.TEXT: Ten Albanians arrived in Greece this week after fleeing their homeland, leading to speculation the hard-line country has relaxed border controls, a Foreign Ministry official said Tuesday. The refugees included two brothers whose alleged torture in their homeland last year sparked diplomatic tension between Greece and Albania, the official said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity in line with standard procedures, said the 10 Albanians crossed into northern Greece on Sunday and Monday. Eight of the 10 are ethnic Greeks, he said. ``The fact that more than 50 Albanians have crossed the border since January has led to speculation that Albanian authorities are slackening border controls,'' the official said. Albania, the last bastion of Stalinism in Europe, has indicated it wants to end its international isolation by resuming ties with the two superpowers and joining the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Brothers George and Dimitris Prassos, who were among those arriving in Greece this week, said in an interview published Tuesday that Albania's secret police repeatedly beat them after an abortive attempt to escape last October. They were tied to a tractor and dragged around border villages to set an example for possible defectors, the two told the Athens daily newspaper Eleftheros Typos. They claimed they were jailed until Dec. 22 and lived on a diet of macaroni and rotting onions in custody. The Orthodox Church of Greece reported in December that the brothers had been killed after trying to flee Albania.

DOC.HEAD: Slick Still Offshore; Slight Change in Direction Called `Good News'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with oil slick changing direction slightly; further tests delaying oil transfer, other detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An oil slick lingering in the Gulf of Mexico remained stalled some 7 to 10 miles offshore today as cleanup crews readied for the arrival of tar balls for the second day. Coast Guard officials said an early morning flyover showed no signs that tar balls from the supertanker Mega Borg spill had washed ashore overnight. Earlier, officials in Louisiana had said that tar balls were found on some beaches but that it was possible they were not from the Mega Borg. The slick changed direction slightly, with predictions that it would reach land closer to High Island northeast of Galveston than Sea Rim State Park farther east, the Coast Guard said. ``That's good news,'' said Petty Officer Mark Sedwick. ``That means it will be away from the marsh areas where we were concerned about the wildlife.'' Officials had predicted the 30-mile oil slick would hit the shore along a 45-mile stretch northeast of Galveston, between High Island and Sabine Pass near the Texas-Louisiana border. There are three national wildlife refuges in the area. Meanwhile, about 1,200 volunteers in five counties remained on alert to help clean the beaches if the messy tar balls hit. The General Land Office expected at least 100 volunteers to arrive at Sea Rim State Park today for the second day to prepare for the tar balls. On Monday, about 60 volunteers mobilized for the supertanker tar cleanup instead picked up hundreds of pounds of debris, seaweed and old oil on a six-mile stretch of the state park beach. Clearing the beach of debris will make it easier to clean up the oil later. ``They said they needed volunteers and I said, `Does that mean me?' And I said, `Why not me?''' said Jo Krose, who drove two hours from Kirbyville. Offshore cleanup operations from the supertanker Mega Borg continued today as well, with the oil sheen so faint that it could only be seen by helicopter crews. ``We're getting close to the point where you have to really look for the oil,'' said Coast Guard Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt. ``The cleanup crews have to have a helicopter up there because they can't see it in the water.'' The cleanup effort today included the state-of-the-art Mexican skimmer, ECOPEMEX, and 10 other skimmers, some working within four miles of the shoreline. Booms and other deflector devices also have been deployed along a 45-mile area. The Coast Guard had five beach patrols in areas stretching up to Sabine Pass today. Coast Guard officials said 3.9 million gallons of oil has leaked from the Mega Borg since it was rocked by explosions June 8 some 57 miles off Galveston. Most of that oil has either burned off, evaporated or been collected. The Coast Guard said it had no good estimate of how much oil remains in the Gulf. The vessel's owner arranged for a tanker to begin transferring the Angolan crude off the damaged ship today, said company attorney Robert Klawetter. But Sedwick said crews are continuing tests of the vessel today before any cargo is transferred.

DOC.HEAD: China Buys More US Wheat
DOC.TEXT: China has bought an additional 359,775 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said six private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for October, he said. The sales were part of 2 million tons authorized for China under EEP on May 2. Previous allocations had been exhausted except for 5,050 tons. Dickerson said China has 1,145,425 tons remaining in its current allocation. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about 13.2 million bushels. At current prices estimated by USDA at around $3.33 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $44 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $16.62 per ton, or about 45 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Alfred C. Toepfer International Inc., 100,000 tons; Cargill Inc., 80,000; Bunge Corp., 50,000; Ferruzzi U.S.A. Inc., 45,000; Tradigrain Inc., 44,775; and Central States Enterprises Inc., 40,000. With the latest sales, China has bought about 2 million tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1990-91 wheat marketing year that will begin June 1, compared with 5.6 million tons in 1989-90.

DOC.HEAD: Barry ``Was Snorting Dope Up His Nose' While Warning City About Drug Plague
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with prosecution saying drugs supplied to mayor at his own office, details of alleged crack smoking incidents; editing throughout to tighten, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry ``was snorting dope up his nose'' while warning his constituents about the dangers of drugs, a federal prosecutor said today in opening arguments at the mayor's trial. Barry's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, quickly countered by telling the jury the mayor was the victim of entrapment and that prosecution witnesses include ``notorious drug dealers'' who are not believable. Barry was accompanied by his wife, Effi, in court. He said on his way in that he felt ``fine.'' But he wiped his forehead when assistant U.S. attorney Richard Roberts said the jury would be shown an FBI videotape showing Barry ``smoking crack'' on the night of his arrest. The case against the mayor is ``about deceit and deception designed to keep the police, the public and the government from discovering'' the truth, said Roberts. ``The defendant ... had been smoking crack ... all over town for years,'' said the prosecutor, sometimes even accepting a supply of drugs in his office. Mundy disparaged the prosecution's witnesses as a ``cast of characters'' who have struck deals with the government so that they won't be prosecuted or who have been allowed to plead guilty to reduced charges. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to criminal charges alleging that he possessed cocaine repeatedly over a five-year span and that he lied to a federal grand jury in 1989 about his alleged involvement with drugs. He could face up to 26 years in prison and $1.85 million in fines if convicted on all counts. The opening arguments were a prelude to what is expected to be a month-long trial featuring the FBI videotape made in a hotel room the night of Jan. 18. The jurors will see ``black and white video'' of Barry ``smoking crack ... lighting with a cigarette light ... just like this,'' said the prosecutor, demonstrating for the jury. Roberts twice extended his arms, inhaled deeply, held his breath for several seconds and exhaled. ``The evidence will show entrapment'' of Barry by the FBI at the Vista Hotel, said Mundy. The government ``went all the way to California to bring'' ex-model Rasheeda Moore to Washington as part of the sting operation, Mundy said. But Roberts told a different story. ``You will learn that while preaching about'' not using ``dope, he was snorting dope up his nose,'' Roberts said of Barry, the District of Columbia's mayor since 1979. The prosecution will bring a series of friends and acquaintances to the witness stand to testify about Barry's drug use, said Roberts. But Mundy quickly attacked the credibility of defense witnesses. He said Charles Lewis, a key government witness against Barry, has pleaded guilty to drug charges and agreed to play ``any tune the government wanted him to.'' Barry's lawyer characterized Lewis as one of the ``notorious drug dealers'' who will testify in the case. Roberts said that Barry's friends and acquaintances ``kept him supplied with drugs'' over a five-year span and that ``they conspired with him to keep ... his secret.'' In his first visit to Lewis's hotel room in December 1988, Barry took out a matchbox containing ``rocks of crack cocaine,'' said Roberts. ``You took care of me in the Virgin Islands, I will take care of you up here,'' Roberts quoted Barry as telling Lewis. On another visit, Lewis and Barry ``smoked their way all the way through ``Monday Night Football'' and well into'' Ted Koppel's ``Nightline,'' said Roberts. A jury of five whites and 13 blacks was chosen Monday to hear the evidence in Barry's trial, which is moving into the full trial stage after plea bargaining discussions failed to produce any agreement. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ordered the 18 sequestered for the duration of the trial.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Town Can't Ban Political Signs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to restore dropped first reference to Ms. Colt.
DOC.TEXT: A town's ordinance strictly regulating signs discriminates against political speech and therefore is unconstitutional, a Superior Court judge ruled this morning. Judge Melanie Famiglietti threw out the case against a Barrington man who had been convicted of erecting signs in his yard in 1984 and 1985 without a permit, as required by town ordinances. The judge said the signs that James Lemoi, 70, installed in his yard were appeals for help after the death of his wife and a fire at his house, and a political statement about town officials, both of which were prohibited without a permit from the town. Barrington allows a variety of signs to be installed without a permit to advertise a house for sale or a professional business such as a law firm in a home, or signs in connection with a holiday decoration. Other signs are permitted only if a permit is obtained before they are erected. Famiglietti said that the town cannot regulate signs by their content, which was what it did in the case of Lemoi. ``If these very same signs indicated a doctor's office in (Lemoi's) home or were a theater marquee or were holiday decorations, Mr. Lemoi would not be in court today and would not be fined $13,000,'' the judge said. In December 1984, Lemoi's wife died and just a few days later his house caught fire, causing extensive damage. He was not home at the time and was not hurt. About 10 days after the fire, Lemoi put a sign up in his yard seeking public help. Seven months later, after he was unable to obtain police or fire department reports about the fire, he erected another sign, stating simply: ``Come Clean.'' It was after that sign that Barrington charged Lemoi in District Court with violating the town sign ordinance. He was found guilty and fined $13,000. He challenged his conviction and the American Civil Liberties Union's Rhode Island affiliate took up the case when it reached Superior Court. An attorney for the town, Michael Mosco, said he did not know whether he would appeal the ruling to the state Supreme Court. He said that decision would be made by the town council. Mosco defended the ordinance, saying that requiring a permit for certain types of signs was logical. ``We consider any sign in the town of Barrington as permissible,'' he said. ``We think it's a reasonable sign ordinance.'' But ACLU attorney Elizabeth Colt said Judge Famiglietti's decision clearly stated that the ordinance is unconstitutional. ``You can't distinguish among signs,'' Ms. Colt said, adding that sign regulations have to be ``content-neutral.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Presents Study of 25 Percent Force Cut
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 6 grafs new with figures, comments from Aspin; picks up 3rd graf pvs bgng, `In the'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told budget negotiators today that a 25 percent cut in the nation's military force over the next five years would reduce Pentagon spending by only about 10 percent. Cheney's figures dissatisfied many congressional Democrats who attended the talks. House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin argued that the defense chief could have made different decisions in the structure of the military that could have yielded savings of 18 percent to 27 percent. ``They have made a set of policy choices to get there that I think are awfully cautious,'' Aspin, D-Wis., told reporters. According to Cheney's numbers, a 25 percent reduction in Army divisions, Navy fleets and Air Force wings would reduce the fiscal 1991 defense budget President Bush submitted in January from $303.3 billion to $302 billion. Over five years, it would cut $8.6 billion from Bush's proposal. The 25 percent cut in military strength did not yield a corresponding dollar savings because it would be phased in gradually, and because some of the more expensive elements of the Pentagon budget _ such as weapons development and acquisition _ would not be cut deeply. Cheney said his numbers were meant as an illustration, not an offer to budget negotiators. In the budget talks, Bush administration officials and Congress are searching for somewhere between $45 billion and $60 billion in new taxes or spending cuts before fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. A major source of funds could be the military budget, but Cheney says he's concerned that spending could be cut too sharply or too quickly, harming the nation's defense. He agreed to present budget negotiators with his study, which would look at the effect of reducing the military force structure by 25 percent over a five-year period. ``The good news was that Cheney would entertain such a cut,'' Aspin said in his memo. ``The bad news was that he believes it can be done while cutting the defense budget by only 10 percent over the same period.'' Aspin contended that when high-cost items are pared from the Pentagon's spending list, he could find a cost savings of between 18 and 27 percent. Aspin sent the memo to Majority Leader Dick Gephardt, D-Mo., and House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., two of the most important Democrats in the budget negotiations. But Cheney's aides have insisted that his report to the budget negotiators is not to be taken as a plan for reducing the forces, or the Pentagon budget, even though those cuts might be in store for the nation's military. Besides the 25 percent pare-down, Cheney also planned to lay out the effects of far deeper cuts in defense spending called for in the House and Senate. Pentagon officials have said the study would keep spending levels along the lines that Cheney has projected for the coming years, which is a proposal for a 2 percent cut in real growth after inflation is taken into account. Along the lines of such a cut, the administration proposed in January to spend $303.3 billion for the 1991 fiscal year. The House has passed a more drastic cut to $295.4 billion, while the Senate Budget Committee has approved an even leaner $293.9 billion plan. In testimony on Capitol Hill last week, Cheney said if he were forced to accept the House proposal, he would be forced to lay off 140,000 military men and women. A 25 percent cut in forces, he added, would result in cutting five or six Army divisions and the same number of Air Force tactical fighter wings. Last week, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams decried the House and Senate numbers as taking ``a mindless meat ax'' to the defense budget. Cheney's report to the budget negotiators amounts to ``trying to educate the people who are going to make those budget decisions on why they should not make big reductions in our budget,'' Williams said. The spokesman accused the House and Senate with coming up with defense budget figures ``out of thin air,'' dedicated only to slashing the budget and not taking into account what it would do to the nation's military force. ``Part of the exercise we're going through is to say, guys, if you swing that ax, this is what you're cutting,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sets Himself Afire In Police Station Lobby
DOC.TEXT: An escaped mental hospital patient claiming to be Gen. William Westmoreland's son doused himself with gasoline then set himself afire in a police station lobby this morning. Two police officers rushed the burning man out of the smoke-filled lobby and rolled him on the lawn to put out the fire. The man, Alvin Bray, 45, suffered second- and third-degree burns over 42 percent of his body, said Colonial Hospital spokesman Mike Portacci. Bray was expected to be transferred to Parkland Hospital in nearby Dallas later today. ``He said his name was Gen. Westmoreland Jr. and it was a matter of national security or something like that,'' said Police Chief David Walker. Westmoreland commanded U.S. forces in Vietnam. Bray was sent to the state hospital after claiming to be Westmoreland's son and attempting to deposit what he said was $1 million into the a bank in Keene on March 30, said Johnson County Attorney Dale Hanna. Walker said Bray tried to deposit $9 million in a local bank before going to the police station today. Walker said Bray already was splattered with gasoline when he walked into the lobby carrying a bag holding beer bottles and cans full of gas. He told a woman and a child sitting in the lobby that they'd better leave, police Sgt. Don Echols said. Echols said he went over and tried to calm Bray, then tried to knock the bag out of Bray's hand as Bray moved to light it. The bag ignited and flames spread to Bray's body. Echols and Sgt. Joe Blair dragged Bray out of the lobby and smothered the flames. Echols' uniform also caught fire, but he was not injured. Walker said there was some damage to the lobby. Bray scaled the hospital fence at about 6:20 a.m. and escaped officials who chased him, said Don Gilbert, Terrell State Hospital superintendent. Terrell is located 25 miles east of Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Candles, Summit Will Shed Light on Cruel Plight of Children
DOC.TEXT: Volunteer organizations said Tuesday they will hold simultaneous candlelight vigils in 15 countries this fall to call attention to the plight of children around the world. They are trying to fight preventable diseases that experts say may kill 100 million children in the next decade. ``Over 40,000 children are dying daily of malnutrition and preventable disease,'' said Sen. Bill Bradley at a news conference to launch the effort. ``The nations of the world must act together to declare that children are a priority, that they have a right to learn and grow in peace and freedom,'' the New Jersey Democrat said. The candlelight ceremonies are a prelude to the World Summit on Children to be held at the United Nations on September 29-30. They are to begin at sunset Sept. 23 in Australia and other countries will join in as twilight reaches their part of the world, ending in the United States in Hawaii. ``All the successful communities of the world have become successful because they have become concerned about the health and education of their children,'' said James P. Grant, executive director of the U.N. Children's Fund (UNICEF), which is helping organize the summit. Nearly 15 million children under five die each year, according to UNICEF. ``One day of the world's expenditures on arms is all it would take to save the lives of 20,000 children,'' said Grant. The summit will bring together heads of governments to develop solutions to rising child and maternal mortality, malnutrition, unsafe drinking water and waste disposal, low-birthweight, poverty, homelessness, inadequate access to basic education and children's protection. The U.S. organizations sponsoring the vigils include Africare, CARE USA, the Children's Defense Fund, the Child Welfare League of America, End Hunger Network, Foster Parents Plan, the Hunger Project, the National Council for International Health, RESULTS, Save the Children and the U.S. Committee for UNICEF. The coalition is urging world leaders to ratify the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child approved last year by the General Assembly. The convention sets minimum standards for the well being of children and calls for protection from abuse and exploitation and for certain rights and basic education. It would have the force of international law if ratified by 20 nations. Six countries _ Belize, Ecuador, Guatemala, Ghana, the Vatican and Vietnam _ have ratified the treaty. The executive branches of 60 others have signed it and are awaiting action by their legislatures. Bradley and other participants urged Americans to launch a phone-in and letter-writing campaign to urge President Bush to sign the document and send it to the Senate for ratification. Actress Valerie Harper, representing more than 150 entertainers who plan to participate in the vigils, urged Americans to ``get off our duff and get this done.'' ``We are in the course of reviewing the convention to see if it is in accordance with U.S. law and for other policy aspects,'' said a State Department spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiations on East German Reparations for Nazi Crimes Set
DOC.TEXT: German and Jewish experts will meet in East Berlin next week to start negotiating how much East Germany will pay for the war crimes of Nazi Germany, the World Jewish Congress announced Tuesday. The June 25 meeting follows exploratory talks on the compensation issue between WJC leaders and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere during his visit to New York earlier this month. The negotiations will focus on reparations to Israel and to Jewish organizations for housing and rehabilitating survivors of the Nazi Holocaust, said WJC Executive Director Elan Steinberg. The scope of the East German payments is uncertain, in large part because the country is being merged with West Germany which is assuming responsibility for all East Germany's financial obligations. The talks will not deal with compensation of individual victims or survivors, just as the 1952 reparations agreement with West Germany, known as the Luxembourg Agreement, did not address that issue, Steinberg said. The Luxembourg Agreement, which will serve as the model for the talks with East Germany, only covered West German payments to Israel and Jewish institutions. The West German parliament later passed a law providing for compensation of individual claims. In all, West Germany has paid more than $40 billion in reparations over the years. The Luxembourg Agreement stipulated that West Germany pay two-thirds of the total compensation owed by the German people. For more than 40 years, East Germany's communist leaders refused to recognize any responsibility for the war crimes and refused to pay the remaining third of the claims, citing the systematic persecution of communists by the Nazis. One of the first acts of the new democratic East German parliament elected last March after the communists fell was to concede a share of the blame for the deeds of the Nazis and their systematic annihilation of 6 million Jews. ``We recognize the very complex nature of these negotiations,'' said Steinberg. ``But we hope they won't be too lengthy.''

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Presses Probe of Silverado Closing
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 13-15, Meanwhile, with White House comment.
DOC.TEXT: A House Banking Committee member called on federal regulators today to ``lift the veil of secrecy'' surrounding their investigation of President Bush's son, Neil, in connection with a Colorado thrift collapse. ``If it has brought charges against Neil Bush, it should make those charges public,'' Rep. Frank Annunzio said, referring to the federal Office of Thrift Supervision. ``No law or regulation prevents the agency from revealing the charges.'' Neil Bush denied any wrongdoing in the collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. He appeared May 23 before the committee, which was probing whether his business interests in Colorado conflicted with his role as a director of Silverado. He called allegations of conflict of interest ``frivolous.'' ``I'm calling on the Office of Thrift Supervision to lift the veil of secrecy which shrouds this matter,'' Annunzio, D-Ill., said at the outset of the latest hearing on the Silverado failure. Annunzio cited an undated and unsigned internal Office of Thrift Supervision document which he said contained proposed charges against Neil Bush. But he said no charges were ever brought, nor has there been any indication of whether any charges will be forthcoming from the government. ``The last time I checked, Neil Bush's father was the head of that organization,'' Annunzio said. ``Can any agency of the United States fairly and impartially investigate the son of the president of the United States?'' he asked. Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., defended Neil Bush, noting that he has declared his innocence and citing a May 22 statement by federal regulators that they could find no basis for issuing a prohibition on his further involvement in the banking industry. Parris said the document cited by Annunzio ``is undated, it's unsigned. It was never circulated. It is in fact, a draft. ...
