Mr. Bush appeared here voluntarily. ... for eight hours. ... he believes he is innocent of any wrongdoing.'' ``I think ... it raises the question, is Neil Bush paying a penalty because of who he is, not being given some kind of unique benefits because of who he may be,'' Parris said. One focus of the hearings is the length of time it took regulators to close the thrift after problems developed. The thrift was closed in late 1988, two years after trouble surfaced. ``Nothing has been more costly than regulatory hesitation through the entire savings and loan crisis,'' committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said in an opening statement. Meanwhile, the White House blasted Democrats for the S&L crisis. ``A big part of the problem here is that in the dead of night a few years ago, the Democrats pushed through a bill raising the limits (of coverage for insured deposits) to $100,000 a person,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The increase was part of a broader, bipartisan bill to overhaul the entire S&L industry. ``I'm saying the Democrats have a big role in it,'' he said. Among those subpoenaed to testify were Michael Wise, the former chairman of Silverado, and Kenneth Good and Bill Walters, Neil Bush's former business partners. Wise was likely to be questioned about his role on the Federal Reserve Board's Thrift Institutions Advisory Council. Wise was on the prestigious panel for three years, serving as its president in 1987. The advisory group meets with the Fed's board of governors four times a year to advise it on developments relating to the thrift industry and other regulatory matters. Meantime, Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., acknowledged he wrote letters in 1984 to Paul Volcker, then the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, promoting Wise's appointment to a related panel, the Fed's Consumer Advisory Council. In a handwritten letter to Volcker, Wirth said of Wise: ``He is extremely able and would be an excellent appointment.'' Copies of two letters Wirth sent to Volcker were obtained by The Associated Press from House sources. Wirth, who was a House member when he wrote the letters, received a campaign contribution of $750 from Wise for a Senate bid in 1985, according to the Federal Election Commission. Wise also gave to Republicans, including $1,000 to Wirth's 1986 opponent in the Senate race, Ken Kramer. Wirth, who is a member of the Senate Banking Committee, played down the significance of the letter and blamed its release on political backbiting. He said in a statement that the letter was ``one of hundreds of letters that I write each year on behalf of my constituents.'' Wirth recently cosponsored legislation to create a separate Justice Department division charged with investigating and prosecuting illegal activity in the savings and loan industry. ``We must send a strong message to those in the financial services industry who violate the law that their actions will be punished,'' he said last week. Meanwhile Monday, Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., called on President Bush to create an independent commission to investigate the savings and loan crisis. He said he was disappointed by the increasingly partisan nature of the debate over how the crisis occurred. Pending in the House is a resolution calling for appointment of an independent counsel, or special prosecutor, to handle S&L investigations. At an earlier House Banking Committee hearing, Neil Bush, 34, testified there was no conflict of interest between his business relationships with Good and Walters and the loans they received from Silverado. But regulators have alleged there was a conflict because Neil Bush, who had an oil and gas exploration company, didn't tell Silverado about his separate ties to Good and Walters.

DOC.HEAD: Trooper Crusading Against Drunken Driving Hit by Driver Charged With DWI
DOC.TEXT: A New York state trooper bicycling cross-country to crusade against drunken driving was himself struck and critically injured by a drunken driver, authorities said. Joseph Cyran was less than 40 miles away from his 3,000-mile goal, Atlantic City, when he was struck by a motorist Saturday afternoon in this Gloucester County community. He left from Los Angeles on May 27. The motorist apparently fell asleep and crossed the center line before striking Cyran and carrying him more than 100 feet on the hood, police said. Cyran, 32, of West Seneca, N.Y., near Buffalo, was in fair condition Tuesday at Cooper Medical Center in Camden, said spokeswoman Peggy Leone. Cyran said Tuesday he hopes to attempt the cross-country journey again. ``You can understand how disappointing it can be pushing every day, very hard from sunrise to sunset,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``I'm extremely disappointed that I didn't get to finish.'' He suffered a fractured leg, ankle, wrist, thumb, neck and arms. ``It could be worse _ I could be paralyzed,'' said Cyran. ``I'll recover from this.'' Police said the driver, Ricky Ragunan, 28, of Moorestown, was charged with driving while intoxicated, careless driving, driving an unregistered vehicle, using fictitious tags, seatbelt violations. Ragunan also was issued a summons for failing to have car insurance, police said. ``I hope to goodness that people will read this story and see what a drunken driver can do to your child or even a loved one'' said Cyran's father, Joseph, in a telephone interview Monday from his New York home. Relatives and friends said Cyran had wanted to raise money for the victims of drunken drivers. He was unable to obtain sponsors but decided to make the solo trip anyway, said Trooper Bruce Bell, Cyran's partner.

DOC.HEAD: Former Iran Hostage to Run for State Office
DOC.TEXT: Former Iran hostage Kevin Hermening is a Republican candidate for the state legislature. Hermening, who ran unsuccessfully for Congress in 1986 and 1988, said Monday he will seek the GOP nomination to challenge Democratic state Rep. Brad Zweck in the November election. Neither candidate has any opposition. Hermening, 30, of Mosinee in central Wisconsin, works as a representative for Wisconsin Independent Businesses Inc., a promotional and lobbying organization for smaller businesses. Hermening was a Marine guard assigned to the U.S. Embassy in Tehran when Iranian militants overran the embassy Nov. 4, 1979. He was among 52 Americans held hostage until Jan. 20, 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Arab Poet Put Under House Arrest For Writings
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli Arab poet was placed under house arrest Tuesday and faces trial on charges that his poems about the Palestinian uprising incite violence by Arabs against Jews. Shafik Habib is the first Israeli Arab author to be prosecuted for his writing. ``This is a very serious move against an Arab intellectual. This lit up a red light for all of us,'' said Habib, a father of six who lives in the northern Israeli village of Deir Hanna. Police claimed after Habib's arrest last week that in a collection of poems titled ``Return to the Future,'' he calls for the continuation of the uprising and appeals to Arabs to use firearms and ``kill the Jews.'' Judge Eitan Magen on Tuesday ordered Habib placed under house arrest after he was charged with identifying with a terror group through his writing. Israelis usually mean the PLO when they refer an unspecified terror organization. Magen said Habib must stay at home until further hearings could be held on a police request that he be jailed until trial. No trial date was scheduled. The Israeli news agency Itim said Habib's passport was seized and he was ordered to pay a bond of $5,000. The charges against Habib come at a time of growing identification among Israel's 810,000 Arab citizens with the anti-Israeli revolt of their 1.7 million brethren living in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Last month, after an Israeli gunman killed seven Palestinian laborers, rioting erupted in many Arab towns and villages within Israel. Police responded with tear gas and rubber bullets, tactics they frequently use in the occupied lands but rarely in Israel. There are many close ties between Israeli Arabs and those in the territories. Many in the territories fled from homes that fell under Israeli control at the founding of the Jewish state in 1948. Habib, who defines himself as a ``Palestinian Arab living in Israel,'' said he used to write love poems until the uprising began in December 1987. Anger over the methods used to crush the revolt prompted him to change subjects. In one of his poems, ``News Bulletin,'' he writes about alleged army brutality: ``The commander has issued an urgent order ... break arms and legs, smash necks, crush skulls and chase them, leave them as corpses rotting in the soil.'' But he denies his work incites violence. ``I see something on television, and I write a poem about it. But it's impossible to encourage stone-throwing. And I know not to cross the red line. I'm a responsible person,'' he said in a telephone interview from his home. Habib also argued that all the poems in the ``Return to the Future'' collection had previously been published by Israeli Arab newspapers, which are subject to censorship. The army routinely reviews material submitted to Arabic-language newspapers in Israel and the occupied lands, and it frequently bans publication of items. Israeli Arab leaders said the charges against Habib violated free speech and contradicted Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's pledge that his new right-wing government would seek peace. ``This regime is very weak if they are afraid of words. We are not talking about stones or bombs,'' said legislator Abdul Wahab Darousha.

DOC.HEAD: Guard Foils Robbery With Loot Gunmen Wanted
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen demanded money from an armored truck guard _ and he gave it to them: He swung a bag full of cash at a shotgun-wielding assailant to foil the robbery, police said. The unidentified guard for the Illinois Armored Car Corp. was making a delivery Monday morning to a West Side currency exchange when a masked man pointed a 12-gauge shotgun at his chest, said Police Sgt. Barbara Matula. As two more masked gunmen appeared, the guard swung a canvas bag filled with $18,000 in cash and coins at the would-be robber, knocking away his shotgun, Matula said. The guard jumped back in the truck with his partner and the two put their heads down as the gunmen fired three shots before fleeing, she said. No cash was lost and no one was hurt. Company officials praised the guard. ``He's to be commended for doing a job well done,'' said Ted Bone, spokesman for the company.

DOC.HEAD: Dinosaur Floats Away; Captured After Swim
DOC.TEXT: A dinosaur roamed the Earth briefly _ or at least that stretch of Earth that lies between the Sinclair and Amoco gas stations on U.S. Highway 6. The dinosaur _ the familiar brontosaur that is Sinclair's corporate symbol _ floated loose from its mooring outside the Sinclair station during Monday's floods and cruised along the highway in this southeastern Iowa town. ``We decided to go lasso it before it got down to Amoco or something and deserted us for good,'' Sinclair Marketing manager Dave Arenstdorf said. ``It was something to see, all those cars honking at the dinosaur.'' Arenstdorf said the dinosaur was roped and tied to a telephone pole, where it will remain until it can be moved later this week.

DOC.HEAD: Landsbergis: Lithuania Will Move Slowly on Idea to Suspend Independence
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president made clear Tuesday that his republic's legislature will not rush to consider Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to suspend its declaration of independence. The Lithuanian pro-independence group Sajudis staged a rally outside the parliament building in the republic's capital of Vilnius to oppose suspension of the March 11 act of independence, the news agency Interfax reported. In an effort to break the Kremlin's impasse with the Baltics, Gorbachev last week offered to end his economic embargo against Lithuania and conduct negotiations. In return, he asked Lithuania to freeze implementation of its declaration of independence. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told lawmakers the proposal would not be considered by the full parliament until the republic's prime minister returns from a foreign trip. ``I think that today there isn't such a compelling reason to begin debates without clarifying (our position) beforehand in commissions and groups,'' Landsbergis told parliament. His comment was reported by Haroldus Subacius, a parliamentary spokesman. Lithuania's Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, accepted the moratorium proposal Saturday and asked the Supreme Council, or parliament, to endorse it as well. The Lithuanian government, under Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, is considered far more disposed to compromise with the Kremlin than the parliament, which is headed by Landsbergis and dominated by members of Sajudis. Subacius' account of Landsbergis' comments differed markedly from a report given by the Soviet Union's official Tass news agency. Tass quoted Landsbergis as saying in a radio broadcast: ``The Supreme Council of Lithuania will not discuss the proposal of the government in the form in which it was received, won't vote for or against it today, this week and perhaps, ever.'' Subacius denied the Lithuanian president made the remark. He said Landsbergis made it clear the proposal on the moratorium would eventually be discussed. There was no explanation for the conflicting reports. Mrs. Prunskiene was visiting Greece and not expected to return until Friday, Subacius said in a telephone interview. Lithuania was forcibly absorbed into the Soviet Union in 1940, along with the republics of Latvia and Estonia. Those republics have declared they want to regain their independence, but they have taken a slower approach than Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says It's Willing To Compromise on Civil Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Tuesday it was willing to compromise on the Civil Rights Act of 1990 to avoid a presidential veto, but a key GOP senator voiced skepticism that such a deal could be struck before Nelson Mandela's visit to Washington. ``I don't think anybody wants to see the president veto any civil rights bill. But on the other hand, he's made it quite clear that he wants it changed and he wants the changes to work,'' Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, told reporters after a meeting with Bush. The civil rights dispute dominated the agenda of Bush's Tuesday meeting with GOP congressional leaders. But participants emerged from the session suggesting a compromise on the issue did not appear to be at hand. The administration has been discussing possible compromises in hopes of avoiding a battle over the bill during Mandela's visit. The African National Congress leader meets with Bush on Monday. Hatch, a senior Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said that because the issue is so contentious, he did not believe a deal could be struck before Mandela arrives. In addition, he cautioned against Democrats bringing the matter to the Senate floor during Mandela's visit to try to embarrass the administration. ``This deserves more consideration than that,'' Hatch said. The legislation, cosponsored by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif, would overcome a series of Supreme Court decisions last year that made it harder for workers to bring discrimination suits against employers. The administration claims that the bill, as drafted, would in effect force businesses to resort to hiring quotas to reduce their exposure to lawsuits; sponsors deny that the bill requires quotas, directly or indirectly. President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said after Tuesday's White House meeting: ``He does not want to veto the bill; he wants a civil rights bill he can sign.'' But, Fitzwater added, ``We're willing to veto this bill if it is a quota bill. This is the bottom line.'' Fitzwater said the possibility that the bill might come up in the Senate during Mandela's visit came up at the White House meeting ``but there was no concern about it.'' Fitzwater said that while ``we're not there yet'' in terms of a compromise, ``the consensus of everybody'' at the GOP meeting, including some Republican cosponsors of the bill, was that ``they want something to be for.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh briefed GOP senators at the White House session on possible administration-backed compromises in wording that would avoid the quota problem. ``We'll be doing some heavy negotiating,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Species Invading U.S. Waters, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: The zebra mussel is one of many exotic species invading U.S. waters, and a broad strategy is needed to keep them from wreaking economic and environmental havoc, experts said Tuesday. The river ruffe, spiny water flea and tube-nosed goby soon may become as familiar to the Great Lakes as the zebra mussel, witnesses said at a hearing of the Senate Subcommittee on Environmental Protection. Meanwhile, the asiatic clam, Japanese seaweed and the red tide are damaging shellfish and marine industries along the ocean coasts. The newcomers threaten many native species, interrupt the food chain and pose a danger to the U.S. fishing industry and other segments of the economy, said Gillman D. Veith, director of the Environmental Protection Agency's Office of Research and Development. ``Given the rate of technological change and movement of people, it is likely that the problems resulting from invasions of non-native species will increase,'' said Veith. The city of Monroe, Mich., was forced to ration water for several days and spend $500,000 removing zebra mussels from its water intake pipe last year, said Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis. Shipping, tourism, paper production and other industries could be affected if such problems become widespread, he said. ``There is growing concern that the introduction of non-indigenous species by ships, particularly through their ballast water, has affected the ecosystems and economies of countries around the world,'' said Capt. Thomas E. Thompson of the U.S. Coast Guard. Bills pending in the House and Senate would order the Coast Guard to develop and enforce regulations on dumping of ships' ballast water _ the suspected source of zebra mussels, which are native to fresh-water bodies of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The tiny bivalves with zebra-like stripes have spread with lightning speed through the Great Lakes since their arrival in 1986. They fasten themselves to hard surfaces, such as pipes and boat hulls, and ingest plankton essential to the aquatic food chain. Senators from the region urged quick action and braodening the scopes of the bills to deal with other natural invaders.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Revises Report on Panama Deaths
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Cheney, Pentagon's revised figures on wounded
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon revised its figures today on the number of soldiers accidentally wounded by their comrades in the Panama invasion, saying 16 of the 310 servicemen wounded in action were hit by ``friendly fire.'' On Monday, the Defense Department released figures showing that two soldiers _ and possibly three _ of the 23 killed during the Dec. 20 military operation had been killed in such a manner. As well, the department had originally said 19 of the 324 soldiers wounded in action had been hit accidentally by their comrades. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters that the department had refined the figures in an overnight study of the death reports. The review was prompted by a Newsweek magazine report that nine U.S. soldiers had been killed by their comrades and that more than 60 percent of the casualties had been caused by friendly fire. In his first comment on the issue, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney lamented the deaths, saying such things will occur in complex, night military operations where high-tech weaponry is used. ``I wished it had not happened, on the other hand I don't think it detracts from the overall quality of the operation,'' he told reporters after a Pentagon briefing on the budget. Williams, in his briefing, said that of the 23 killed in action, two Rangers were killed by friendly fire at Rio Hato ``during an intense fire fight with the PDF (Panamanian Defense Force) near dawn.'' He added that there was one other possible death due to friendly fire, and that it was under investigation. ``Of the 310 wounded in action, it now appears that 16 were wounded by friendly fire in several isolated incidents throughout Panama,'' Williams said. ``Yesterday's report of 19 wounded in action included some accidental injuries that we have now determined were not caused by hostile fire,'' the spokesman said, adding that since the cases were being looked at very closely, the numbers could change again. Williams added that another 21 wounded during an intense night fire fight near the Commandancia, the headquarters of Gen. Manuel Noriega, ``may be the result either of friendly fire from an AC-130 gun ship or PDF mortar fire. It is impossible to distinguish whether they were wounded by friendly fire or by enemy fire.'' If those Americans were wounded by the gunship, the incident might have been caught on the videotape that every AC-130 gunship shots of its mission. But Williams said he did not know that for certain and was looking into it. Williams said the Pentagon has looked into every case and deeply regrets any loss of life, for whatever reason. ``Nothing can diminish the sacrifices that all these men made to their country. Casualties caused by friendly fire are an unfortunate circumstance of war,'' he said. The report in the June 25 Newsweek issue quoted unidentified military officials as the source of its information. Williams said confusion over the deaths could have arisen because Noriega's troops used U.S.-supplied bullets and weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Value of Ag Exports Fall Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The value of U.S. agricultural exports dropped slightly in April from year-earlier levels, an Agriculture Department report said Tuesday. A listing of products shipped to foreign buyers showed their value at $3.35 billion, down from $3.42 billion in April 1989. However, the cumulative value since the fiscal year began Oct. 1 was up, totaling $25.3 billion for the seven months against $24.6 billion a year earlier. The value of corn exports in April rose slightly, to $577.2 million from $546 million a year ago, with the Soviet Union the biggest buyer, replacing Japan, the traditional leader. Other big corn buyers during the month were Taiwan, Spain, South Korea and Mexico. But wheat exports dropped sharply in April, to $354.9 million from $514.5 million a year earlier. The Soviet Union remained the largest market, followed by Japan, China, Algeria, Egypt, Taiwan and Venezuela. The monthly report showed soybean exports dropped to $276.5 million from $314.5 million in April 1989. ``Shipments to the (European Economic Community) fell significantly, accounting for most of the decline,'' the report said. ``Other major markets included Japan, Taiwan and Korea.'' Cotton shipments in April were shown at a value of $251.7 million, up from $185.7 million a year earlier. Exports of livestock and livestock products in April totaled more than $538.7 million, compared with $531.4 million in April 1989. Total U.S. agricultural exports in the current fiscal year are forecast at $40 billion, up from $39.6 billion in 1988-89 and the most since they hit a record of $43.8 billion in 1980-81.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Blames Soviets for Chemical Arms Buildup
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze blamed Soviet officials for fueling a chemical arms buildup ``to win an honor banner of socialist competition.'' The outspoken Soviet diplomat said in an interview with New Times, a Soviet weekly, that people were correct to point out imbalances in the weapons stocks of East and West and that those responsible for Soviet advantages acted irresponsibly. ``Those who, apparently not in a struggle with imperialism but in a drive to win an honor banner of socialist competition poured barrels' full of chemical poisons at a time when the world had stopped producing them already, should be called to account,'' Shevardnadze said. The edition of New Times containing the interview was scheduled for release Friday. The Associated Press obtained an advance copy Tuesday from Soviet sources. Shevardnadze's admission that the Soviet side was to blame for imbalances in chemical weapons stocks came a few weeks after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush signed an agreement on the issue in Washington. The pact, concluded when the U.S. and Soviet foreign ministers met in Moscow in May, requires the superpowers to destroy 80 percent of their chemical weapons immediately. They would reduce their stocks to 2 percent of existing levels in the next eight years, and destroy the rest two years later if all other countries capable of producing chemical weapons join them in a global ban, officials said. The United States has an estimated 30,000 tons and the Soviets 50,000 tons of the weapons, according to government sources and independent experts. In the interview, Shevardnadze did not identify which Soviet officials were responsible for the chemical weapons buildup, which he cited as an example of overall bad policy in the arms race. ``Our partners act like a rational hostess who buys only as much food as she needs to fix a lunch. When the guests leave, she's not left with a lot to throw away. We had a different psychology: buy everything and as much as possible, only to discover later a mound of excess,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Erik Wold, Associated Press Bureau Chief in Norway, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Erik Wold, chief of Associated Press operations in Norway for nearly 19 years, died Tuesday. He was 63 and had served the AP in Norway since 1953. Wold's daughter, Jorunn Lie, said he suffered an apparent stroke at home. He was taken to a hospital and died within 20 minutes. Wold, a Norwegian, was born Aug. 4, 1926, in Asker, outside Oslo. He graduated from Oslo Commercial College and joined the AP in Oslo in 1953 after working as a free-lance correspondent for Norwegian newspapers. He became news editor of the Oslo bureau in 1964 and was named chief of bureau in July 1971. AP President and General Manager Louis D. Boccardi said, ``Erik Wold represented a generation of AP bureau chiefs who wrote the book on how to do the job.'' ``He knew his territory, his subscribers and his mission. And he gave every ounce of his energy for all three. We will miss him greatly.'' An amateur ski jumper in his youth, Wold retained a lifelong interest in sports. He was a veteran correspondent for AP at Olympic Games and world and Nordic skiing championships. Wold is survived by his wife, Randi, a brother, four children and seven grandchildren. Funeral plans were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Ex-Landlady To Stand Trial In Boardinghouse Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A former landlady was ordered today to stand trial on charges of murdering nine elderly tenants of her boardinghouse in order to get their pension and disability benefits. Sacramento County Municipal Court Judge Gail Ohanesian, culminating a five-week preliminary hearing, ruled that the 61-year-old Dorothea Puente should be arraigned in Superior Court on July 10. ``I do find that there is ample evidence that death was by criminal means,'' she said, in ordering Puente to stand trial on all the counts with which she had been charged. Puente was arrested after a social worker complained that one of her clients _ a roomer in Puente's home _ had disappeared. In November 1988, authorities dug up seven bodies from the grounds of the home, a Victorian-style welling in downtown Sacramento. Puente was later linked to two other deaths. Prosecutors said Puente had a record of administering stupefying drugs to intended robbery victims, and contended the matronly ex-convict killed her victims for their Social Security and government benefit checks. Defense attorneys said the tenants who died, ranging in age from 52 to 80 and mostly poor and alcoholic, did so either by natural causes or suicide. Among the victim's ailments were a brain tumor, lung disease, heart disease and diabetes. Puente has pleaded innocent. She could face the death penalty if convicted. The judge's ruling came more than seven weeks after the start of Puente's preliminary hearing on April 27, but two of those weeks were spent in recess as defense lawyers prepared their case. The hearing featured testimony by 70 prosecution witnesses and at least eight defense witnesses, and more than 100 exhibits. Puente displayed little emotion throughout her hearing. She sat quietly at the defense table, occasionally writing notes to or leaning over to whisper to her attorneys.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0610 to fix cycle designator.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: When it's misty, the chances are not certain that plans for a celebrity dedication will work out. That's what the director of the new Anderson Civic Center found out Monday at a ceremony to name a street after singer Johnny Mathis. Civic center Director Martin Durham said Mathis was to have entered the parking lot in a convertible Rolls-Royce to cut the ribbon for the dedication of Johnny Mathis Boulevard. But he said Mathis didn't want to come out in the rain, and the owner of the Rolls-Royce did not want his car driven with the top down. ``What are you going to do?'' Durham said. ``The rain ruined it.'' The street was named after Mathis because he was the first person to perform at the center. The singer remained in his dressing room during the ceremony to prepare for Monday night's concert, the first at the 4,500-seat civic center. He performed with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra before a crowd of about 2,500. A message left with Johnny Mathis' publicist, Skip Heinecke, was not immediately returned Tuesday.

Dame Joan Sutherland says she wants to be remembered for her voice in its prime, so she has withdrawn from what were to be her last appearances in Covent Garden later this year. The 63-year-old diva had been cast in the lead role of ``Die Fledermaus'' in December; instead, her final opera appearance will be in Sydney on Oct. 2 in ``Les Huguenots,'' Royal Opera House spokeswoman Katherine Wilkinson said Tuesday. The Covent Garden performance was to be the last of her career. ``Dame Joan _ out of respect for Covent Garden and its public _ does not feel able to sing the part of Rosalinde as she feels that she wishes to be remembered by her past performances and would hate to disappoint the public by proceeding with `Die Fledermaus','' said her London manager, Howard Hartog, in a message to the Royal Opera management. ``Dame Joan is one of the great singers of all time, and Covent Garden was privileged to be her `home' opera house for the early years of her career, beginning in 1952,'' said Paul Finlay, the Royal Opera's director.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bridgforth is cq
DOC.TEXT: Singer Anita Baker and her husband are asking $950,000 for a historic house that they bought for $575,000 and had once planned to demolish, the Detroit Free Press reported Tuesday. Baker, whose hits include ``Giving Him the Best that I've Got,'' and her husband, Walter Bridgforth, had said they wanted to put up an unspecified project at the site of the Chene House. The house was built in 1855 and most recently home for the now-closed Little Harry's restaurant. The building's historic designation stands in the way of its demolition, but failure to find a buyer for the house could lead to a hardship exemption from Detroit's landmark protection laws. The couple's attorney, Renee McDuffee, did not immediately return a telephone call Tuesday to The Associated Press for comment. The house was built by the Chene family on land it received from the king of France in the early 1700s.

New York first lady Matilda Cuomo signed two agreements Tuesday to expand scientific and medical exchanges between her state and Italy. ``It is always a great pleasure for me to return to the country of my parents, relatives and friends _ especially to take part in efforts to deepen the friendship between Italy and New York state,'' Mrs. Cuomo said shortly before signing the documents. The wife of Gov. Mario Cuomo is on a weeklong visit to promote children's rights, economic and cultural exchanges, and the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus' discovery of America. She signed the accords as the co-chairwoman of the New York state program that promotes cooperation with Italy. Under one of the agreements, Italy's National Research Council will exchange information and scientists with the New York State Science and Technology Foundation. Through another accord, the Italian council will set up research fellowships with the Graduate School of Public Health at the State University of New York and share information on health issues. Mrs. Cuomo told reporters she also was working with Italy's hot line to aid abused children. New York state will participate in Italy's first national conference on child abuse in May 1991, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Controllers' Union Say Problems Plague Control Chicago-area Center
DOC.TEXT: An air traffic control center handling 2 million flights a year has had more than 500 radio communication glitches this year, creating a hazard in the skies, union officials said. Six of about 40 sectors of airspace controlled by the center have suffered total radio failure during the last year, leaving controllers and pilots with no way to communicate, said James Poole, president of the National Air Traffic Controller Association chapter at the center. Union officials contended Monday that the center is fraught with aging radio equipment, lack of funding and bureaucratic delays in making repairs. The regional center in suburban Chicago controls planes over the central Midwest, including those bound for O'Hare International Airport. Mort Edelstein, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, acknowledged some problems at the center, but said the FAA is taking steps to correct them. He said agency experts say the center is safe. He contended there has been no case of loss of proper distance between planes due to radio problems in the last three years. Poole said the duration of the communication blackouts in the six airspace sectors ranged from about two minutes to about two hours. They came after failure of three separate communications systems, he said. ``The air traffic system is extremely safe when everything is working,'' said Mark Scholl, chairman of the union chapter's safety committee. ``When you can't talk to the airplanes, the system is not safe.'' Edelstein said communications improvements at the center have been extensive since April 1987. The FAA has earmarked $740,000 to upgrade radio channels and the work is to be completed by November, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Panther Population Suffers Another Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to DELETE extraneous `a'
DOC.TEXT: One of about 30 to 50 Florida panthers believed to be surviving in the wild was struck and killed by a car, game officials said Tuesday. It was the fourth of the endangered animals known to have died this year. The 50-pound, 10-month-old male was run over Monday while crossing a remote road about six miles north of the Big Cypress Seminole Indian Reservation in the Everglades. It was the 13th road kill of a panther since July 1984, commission records show. ``It's the leading contributor to their demise right now,'' said a commission spokesman, Lt. Jim Huffstodt. The previous panther deaths this year were from other causes. Walter McGowan, a biologist with the Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission, said that although the deaths are disturbing, the panther population seems to have held its own or grown slightly during the past decade. ``The animals we are following are reproducing and having young consistently, and they seem to be replacing themselves,'' he said. ``But on the larger question of panther survival, we just have no really hard answers.''

DOC.HEAD: AP Survey: Flag Amendment Vote Too Close to Call
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB grafs 6 and 18 to CORRECT survey numbers to 254-114; Dannemeyer, R-Calif. supports amendment, not opposes
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press survey of Congress shows that the vote on President Bush's anti-flag-burning amendment is too close to call _ with undecided moderate Democrats in control of its fate. Neither side in the politically charged battle could yet claim victory, according to the survey. The amendment was short of the required two-thirds majority in both chambers but still could go over the top in the showdown just before Congress' Fourth of July recess. The House may vote as early as Thursday and the Senate by the end of next week. ``I don't know what the vote outcome will be. I expect it will be close,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Monday. In the Senate, where 67 votes are needed to pass the amendment, 58 lawmakers surveyed favored it or were leaning in that direction, while 24 were against or leaning against. Of the 18 who did not take a position, 15 were Democrats. Supporters and those leaning in favor outnumbered opponents 254 to 114 in the House, where 289 votes are required for passage. Of the 65 who were undecided or had no known position, 54 were Democrats. The telephone survey was conducted late last week and Monday. Some lawmakers responded in person and some through aides. House Democratic and Republican leaders were working furiously behind closed doors to sway the undecideds in the final days before the vote. Both camps said they had won over some of the swing votes even though they stayed publicly uncommitted, and both sides predicted the outcome could hinge on the decisions of a half-dozen lawmakers. The fact that the survey found so many Democrats still on the fence illustrates the political difficulty of the issue for the party. Republican campaign operatives have promised to use the flag vote to portray Democrats opposing the amendment as less patriotic than their GOP challengers, and it's already an issue in many races. In the face of the GOP threat, the Democratic leadership in both chambers has remained strongly against the amendment as a weakening of the First Amendment. But in deference to the divisions in the party and to those members with tough challenges, they have been careful not to make it a ``party'' position. Mitchell kept up his rhetorical pressure Monday, saying that approval of the amendment would provide a victory for flag-burners who seek to goad the nation's leaders. ``It will be a sad irony if a few obnoxious publicity seekers ... are able to stampede those who love America'' into changing the Bill of Rights, he said. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., has spoken out repeatedly against the amendment and has said he would vote against it, making a rare exception to the tradition of the speaker not voting. Even that one vote could make the difference. The survey showed that while the amendment is favored by the vast majority of Republicans in each chamber and has divided the Democrats, there are many curious exceptions to the ideological pattern. Some of the most conservative Republicans, such as Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., came out against the amendment while many liberal Democrats supported it. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., has spoken out against the amendment while his nephew, Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy, D-Mass., said he was undecided. Some Senate Democrats with tough races _ those who might seek political safety by voting for the flag amendment _ weren't necessarily doing so. Sens. Daniel Akaka, D-Hawaii; Paul Simon, D-Ill.; Claiborne Pell, D-R.I.; and Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, all came out against the amendment. Akaka, Simon and Harkin face challengers who plan to vote for the amendment in the House. Pell's challenger, Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I., said she also would vote against the amendment. Flag symbolism was used adroitly by Bush in his 1988 presidential campaign against Democrat Michael Dukakis, and Democrats still fear it. Among congressional Democrats who have been mentioned for the 1992 presidential race, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, put himself in the ``leaning yes'' category while Sens. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., and Bill Bradley, D-N.J., listed themselves as uncommitted. Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va., said yes. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., has bucked the tide by coming out strongly against the amendment and accusing Bush of trying to use the issue to reopen the generational animosities of the Vietnam war. Kerry won a Medal of Honor in Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Tax Change Would Lessen Mortgage Interest Deduction
DOC.TEXT: Experts who advise Congress on taxes recommended a simplification package Tuesday that could dilute the deduction for home mortgage interest. Two of three proposals for simplifying the tax treatment of non-business interest would mean less than a full deduction of mortgage interest for many homeowners. The third option would retain the existing deduction for mortgage interest. Either of the three recommendations would allow a deduction for at least some consumer interest, including credit cards. Under present law, only 10 percent of consumer interest is deductible for 1990; starting next year, no such deduction will be allowed. Overhaul of the deduction for non-business interest was the most dramatic of a series of changes proposed in the name of simplification by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation. The recommendations were made to Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who earlier this year announced a renewed effort to simplify the tax laws. Rostenkowski released the proposals from the staff of the Joint Committee, along with some from the Treasury Department and others from the Democratic staff of his own committee. The committee also received hundreds of pages of simplification suggestions from tax professionals and the public in general. ``At the least, we will have hearings on the proposals in the fall,'' said a spokesman for Ways and Means. Those hearings will help determine whether an effort will be made to write a simplification bill, he said. Treasury and the Ways and Means staff offered their own proposals for simplifying the interest deduction, but neither went so far as the Joint Committee proposal. That proposal included these options: _ Combine all non-business interest, including for mortgages, consumer debt and investment borrowing, and deduct a set percentage, perhaps 75 percent. _ Deduct interest equal to net income on investments, plus some additionl dollar amount. _ Retain a deduction, as under present law, for mortgage interest and allow a separate writeoff for other interest, limited to net investment income. The portion of other interest that could not be deducted in the first year because of the limitation could be carried over into future years. The Joint Committee staff said either of the recommendations would minimize complexity of present law. In addition, the first option would remove the ``incentive for individuals to structure loans as home-equity debt in order to avoid the present-law limit on the deductibilty of personal interest,'' the report stated. Present law has one set of rules for mortgage interest, another for investment interest and a third for credit cards and other consumer debt. The Treasury Department said there is a need to simplify the paperwork burden on families who employ domestics and other household workers. The department said it is not ready to make a specific recommendation but is exploring the feasibility of requiring annual, rather than quarterly, tax filings by household employers.

DOC.HEAD: Somber Barry Arrives at Last Moment for Beginning of Trial
With AM-Barry Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The defendant in criminal case No. 90-0068 wore a red carnation in his left lapel as he arrived at U.S. District Court at the last minute. He seemed in low spirits. Not a word passed between Marion Barry, mayor of the District of Columbia, and his wife, Effi, as they walked slowly down the hallway. They seemed in no hurry to get to the courtroom on the second floor. Few events _ save, of course, the verdict _ are as tough on the defendant in a criminal trial as the opening statements by lawyers. That's when the gloves come off and the defendant hears the allegations put in the harshest possible light. Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts called Barry a dope user, a liar and a hypocrite. As the mayor looked down at the defense table and fidgeted with paper and pen, Roberts said Barry was preaching against using drugs while ``snorting dope up his nose.'' Using hand gestures Roberts said a videotape would show Barry smoking crack ``just like this.'' Barry averted his eyes. Defense lawyer Kenneth Mundy painted a different picture of the former Eagle Scout charged with possessing cocaine and lying to a grand jury. He said the mayor was trapped by prosecutors who ``provided the drugs and the pipe.'' Mundy was particularly scornful of Charles Lewis, a convicted drug dealer and the major government witness. Lewis, Mundy said, ``was willing to put to music any tune the government wanted him to play.'' In the front row, scarcely five feet behind her husband, sat Effi Barry, the 54-year-old mayor's third wife. Barry is a 1960s civil rights activist who organized lunch counter sit-ins, demonstrations and boycotts in the South. He first was elected mayor in 1978. The mayor's limousine arrived at a side door of the courthouse only three minutes before the start of the 10 a.m. trial. Barry was in the back seat with his coat off. News photographers were on all four sides of the building, but the heaviest concentration had their lenses aimed at the circular driveway where the limousine pulled up. Barry obliged them with a wan smile and a wave as he put on his coat. The smile vanished in the near-empty courthouse corridor. A reporter asked the mayor how he felt and Barry managed a ``fine.'' Courthouse guards, whose habit it is to be deferential to celebrity defendants, cleared a path through a non-existent crowd. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's courtroom is the same one used by U.S. District Judge John J. Sirica for the Watergate cover-up trial 15 years ago. About 80 people waited to get into the courtroom; only a dozen made it. In the past, as the mayor's case moved toward trial, there had been demonstrations outside the courthouse, tinged with accusations that the case against Barry would never have been brought were he not black. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens is white. But there were no demonstrators on this first day. The city's business went on as usual. In Washington's city hall, 10 blocks away from the courthouse, Councilwoman Betty Ann Kane introduced a resolution calling on Barry to work for a voluntary early retirement program for city employees. Barry has already announced he won't seek a fourth term, but pointedly said he would not retire early.

DOC.HEAD: Parade Has Only a Hint of the Paper Ribbon It Is Named For
With AM-Mandela-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As it has for the past decade, New York is importing a dash of genuine ticker tape to give an old-time flavor to Nelson Mandela's parade on Wednesday. About 150 miles of the inch-wide paper ribbon was shipped here Friday in 85 plastic bags from Trans-Lux Corp. in Norwalk, Conn., which believes it is the last supplier in what once was a nation of stock tickers and tape. Computers have almost completely replaced tickers. The city still calls a ride through its ``Canyon of Heroes'' on lower Broadway a ``ticker-tape parade,'' although what snows down on the lionized these days is mainly computer cards and fanfold printout paper. Oldtimers say the cards simply cannot duplicate the look of streaming ticker tape, the ``blizzard effect'' one sees in film of the great parade for Charles A. Lindbergh in 1927. ``But with a token amount of tape, mixed with all the other confetti, Mandela will know he's having a ticker-tape parade,'' said Trans-Lux spokesman Matt Brandt. City Sanitation Department spokesman Vito Turso suggested that the best stuff to shower on Mandela, from environmental and economic points of view, would be shredded old telephone directories. ``Also, fax paper, which is not recyclable,'' he said. ``But manila stock IBM cards are worth $320 a ton from a recycler, computer paper $220 a ton and white bond $180 a ton.'' Among recent ticker-tape parades the Lower Broadway: 1986 _ New York Mets, after beating the Boston Red Sox in the World Series. 1985 _ 25,000 Vietnam veterans, led by Gen. William Westmoreland and 26 Medal of Honor winners, in a 10-years-overdue welcome-home tribute. 1984 _ 221 athletes of the U.S. Olympic team are cheered, but 101 spectators are injured when a construction scaffold on the parade route gives way. 1981 _ Welcome home for the Americans hostages freed from Iran. 1979 _ Pope John Paul II.

DOC.HEAD: Few Teachers Use Alternative Programs
DOC.TEXT: The number of states with alternative routes for certifying teachers is growing but few focus on recruiting older, educated adults with real-life experiences, a study said Tuesday. Emily Feistritzer, director of the National Center for Education Information, said a study found that most alternative teacher certification programs _ for people who have not completed a traditional college teacher education program _ are tied to teacher shortages. Since the shortages have not materialized as educators originally had predicted, very few teachers are entering the profession through the alternate routes, she said. ``Very few states in this nation have actually designed a certification path specifically to meet the demand created by the new and growing market of adults who already have at least a bachelor's degree and want to teach,'' said Feistritzer. Connecticut, New Jersey, Texas, Arizona and Arkansas are the best at opening their schools to such would-be teachers, because job offers are available to people who have a bachelor's degree in any subject, according to the study. However, Arizona accepts such teachers only at the secondary school level, and Arkansas uses them only when there are teacher shortages. The United States has hired about 1 million new teachers in the last five years, but only about 12,000 have been certified through alternative teacher certification routes since 1985. The center, a private education research organization, conducted a state-by-state study from December 1989 to May 1990. Thirty-three states report they are implementing alternative routes to the state-approved college teacher education program for certifying teachers _ up from 23 less than two years ago. Eight states were implementing alternatives in 1983. About a third of the states say they use alternative routes only if a traditionally certified teacher cannot be found, the study said. There is enormous variation in the alternative routes, the study found. However, it said most states require a bachelor's degree, at least a ``C+'' college grade average and passage of a basic skills test and sometimes a specialty area test. The study said Connecticut, New Jersey and Texas have about the best state-designed alternative programs available in all fields at all grade levels. Arizona, Idaho, Louisiana, Ohio and Virginia offer programs only at the secondary level. States that offer alternative programs only in areas of teacher shortages are Alabama, Arkansas, California, Georgia, Maine, New York, Oregon and South Carolina. Hawaii, Missouri and Oklahoma offer alternative programs only in shortage areas at the high school level. Some states, the study said, favor emergency licensing. Emergency certificates usually are issued at a superintendent's request and allow people to begin teaching fulltime while taking courses in traditional teacher education programs. Census Bureau statistics show that in 1970, there were 4 million more children of school age, 5 to 17 years old, than there were adults between the ages of 25 and 44 years. Today, there are 34 million more adults in that age category alone than there are children between 5 and 17 years. In 1970, one in 10 of the 110 million adults 25 years and older had a college degree, the statistics show. Today, one in five of the 150 million do. The Bureau of Labor Statistics says one in four college graduates in the work force holds a job that does not require a college degree. Feistritzer said the United States has an opportunity it has never had before _ ``to bring adults who are educated, who have experience in the real world and who have a passion for improving the nation's educational system into its teaching force.''

DOC.HEAD: US To Boycott Romanian Inaugural
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Romania will boycott the presidential inauguration in Bucharest on Wednesday to show concern over the ``government-inspired mob violence'' last week against peaceful demonstrators, a spokesman said Tuesday. Deputy State Department spokesman Richard Boucher also expressed distress that the Romanian government had taken no action against coal miners and others responsible for the attacks against the demonstrators. The inauguration of President Ion Iliescu, who has headed an interim government in Romania since last December, had been scheduled for last week but was postponed until Wednesday because of the turmoil. Boucher said other envoys in Bucharest were planning to join Ambassador Alan Green in boycotting the inauguration. He was unable to say how many may do so. Green returned to Romania on Monday after consultations in Washington. He met Tuesday with leaders of two opposition parties and with members of a non-partisan organization. One of the party headquarters had been ``ransacked during the government-inspired mob violence last week,'' Boucher said. Boucher renewed the U.S. government's call for the release of the more than 1,000 people who he said were arrested for protesting peacefully. ``We call on the government to ensure that fundamental human rights and the rule of law apply equally to all Romanian decisions,'' he said. Boucher also criticized a Romanian parliamentary chamber for approving on Monday a proposal to give police and soldiers the authority to move against anti-government demonstrators assembled in a Bucharest square, saying that could suppress dissent. Boucher also urged that the secret police be dismantled and that legitimate national security concerns be subordinated to democratic controls. The disturbances last week erupted less than a month after Iliescu won election to the presidency by a wide margin. His critics suspect him of continuing to harbor the communist sympathies he once espoused when he was associated with the regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu, who was ousted in a bloody revolt last December. Ceausescu fired Iliescu in 1984. Boucher announced last Friday that all non-humanitarian aid would be withheld from Romania because of the actions against the protestors. About $80 million in food aid and $1 million in medical aid were not affected by the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leaders Reject Coalition With Communists
DOC.TEXT: President Petar Mladenov appealed to all parties Tuesday to leave their political differences behind, but opposition leaders reaffirmed their refusal to join a government with the former Communists. The former Communists, who now call themselves Socialists, on Monday became the only ones in Eastern Europe to win free elections after four decades of unchallenged rule. ``Those who seek to find winners and losers behind the figures would make a mistake,'' Mladenov said, according to the state BTA news agency. He said he would convene the new parliament within one month but gave no date. Mladenov repeated his desire to see a ``competent'' government supported by the entire country, BTA reported. But Petar Beron, a leading member of the main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces (UDF), said the Socialists should form a government alone. ``It's up to the Communists. They have the majority. So let them form the government,'' Beron said. The Socialists won 211 of the Parliament's 400 seats in two rounds of balloting, Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. The UDF won 144 seats, or 47 percent of the vote, giving it considerable sway in the legislature. Beron and other opposition leaders spoke to reporters during a break in a UDF Coordinating Council session, held to discuss future strategy in Parliament. While most UDF leaders seemed adamant in rejecting any kind of cooperation with the Socialists, informed sources said that behind-the-scenes contacts were imminent. Socialist leaders were said to have already approached the Social Democrats, one of the strongest parties in the 16-member alliance, for possible cooperation. However, this could not be independently confirmed. Another UDF official suggested that after municipal elections, scheduled for the fall, the opposition might consider a coalition if the former Communists were knocked out of power at lower levels. But UDF spokesman Georgi Spasov appeared to rule out any compromise. ``If somebody, as an individual, is invited by the Socialists, no one will serve as a puppet in my opinion,'' he told reporters. A senior member of the independent trade union Podkrepa, Lyubomir Pavlov, also ruled out opposition participation in a government. ``They (the Socialists) would obstruct real economic reform'' in a coalition cabinet, Pavlov said. ``They are not for radical economic reform.'' The Socialists have said they favor gradual transition to a market economy, while opposing privatization of agriculture on a large scale. The UDF, of which Podkrepa is a member, favors more radical economic reforms including privatization. In an interview with The Associated Press on Monday, Premier Andrei Lukanov said ``it is an illusion'' to believe that privatization would essentially improve agricultural output. Pavlov said the possibility of a caretaker government could only be considered in the event of a prolonged government crisis. Meanwhile, in a meeting with the press, Zhivko Stalev, head of the Central Electoral Commission, said the panel had received a series of complaints from the various parties competing in the elections. Stalev noted that the majority of complaints concerned problems with electoral lists, distribution of ballots on election day outside the polling stations, the representation of political parties in electoral commissions and inadmissible counting of invalid votes and empty envelopes. Other complaints related to political agitation on election day, the removal of ballots from voting booths and the sometimes inadequate privacy of voters. Some foreign observers had pointed out that in some cases the canvas of makeshift booths was transparent. Stalev said all complaints would be passed on to a commission to be set up by the new Parliament for further action.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at Eastern Europe's Elections
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at the results of multi-party elections held in Eastern European countries since democratic reforms began sweeping the region last year:

BULGARIA _ The Balkan country held its first free multi-party elections in 58 years on June 10 and 17. The ruling Socialist Party, which until April was the Communist Party, clinched an absolute majority with 211 of parliament's 400 seats. The main opposition Union of Democratic Forces, a 16-party alliance, captured 144 seats. The Agrarian Party, a once docile ally of the Communists, won 16 seats and the rest went to small opposition groups and independents. Bulgaria is the first Eastern European nation to freely elect a parliament dominated by the former Communist Party. Analysts say the Socialists won because of Bulgaria's deep Communist tradition, which goes back nearly 100 years, and fears that a rapid switch to private ownership, as advocated by the opposition, would cost jobs.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA _ Parliament elected former dissident playwright Vaclav Havel president Dec. 29, shortly after the nation's peaceful revolution against communism. The first free elections in 44 years were held June 8-9 for the 300-member parliament. The movements that led the revolution _ Havel's Civic Forum and its sister group, Public Against Violence _ won 170 seats. The Communists finished a surprisingly strong second with 47 seats, and a three-party Christian Democratic alliance won 40 seats.

EAST GERMANY _ The first free elections in East Germany's 41-year history were held March 18, and an alliance of parties favoring quick unification with West Germany won 192 of the 400 seats in parliament. Local balloting on May 6 effectively gave communities control of their hometown governments and bureaucracies after four decades of centralized Communist control. The returns were similar to the March 18 results.

HUNGARY _ The first free elections in 43 years were held March 25 and April 8. Voters ended the Communist era by giving the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum 165 of the 386 seats at stake. The Socialist Party, created by reformist Communists last October, won 8.55 percent of the seats.

POLAND _ The once-banned Solidarity Free Trade Union overwhelmingly defeated the Communist Party in partially democratic elections last June. Solidarity formed the first government in Eastern Europe not dominated by Communists, under Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a Solidarity activist and journalist.

ROMANIA _ Free elections were held May 20, the first since 1937. The National Salvation Front, which includes many ex-Communists, won a landslide victory with 66.31 percent of the votes and controls both chambers of the bicameral 387-seat Parliament. The traditional pre-World War II National Liberal Party and the National Peasant Party received 6.41 percent and 2.56 percent of the votes, respectively.

SOVIET UNION _ In March of last year, Soviet citizens for the first time were able to choose candidates in elections for a new Congress of People's Deputies, electing even some dissidents. The Soviet Parliament legalized multiple political parties for the entire country March 13. In February, in the Baltic republic of Lithuania, the Sajudis People's Front won a two-thirds majority of deputies in the new Parliament, thus becoming the Soviet Union's first freely elected, non-Communist dominated, legislature. In March, the parliament elected the first non-Communist president of a republic, Sajudis leader Vytautus Landsbergis. Free elections were also held in the Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia. Boris Yeltsin, the populist rival of Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on May 29 was elected president of Russia, the Soviet Union's largest and most powerful republic.

YUGOSLAVIA _ The first multi-party elections in Yugoslavia's 45-year Communist history were held in Slovenia on April 8 and in Croatia on April 22 and May 6. In both, the ruling Communists were defeated by center-right parties that emphasized the republics' interests over perservation of Yugoslavia's fragile federation. Multi-party elections are planned in Yugoslavia's other republics of Bosnia-Hercegovina, Macedonia and Montenegro later this year. The ruling Communists in the largest state of Serbia have so far rejected Western-style elections. Federal authorities have said elections for the national parliament would be held in the fall. No date has been set.

ALBANIA _ The last bastion of Stalinist rule has begun to talk about cautious economic reforms, but still rejects the kind of broad democratic changes embraced by other Eastern European countries. The Communist leadership, which broke with Moscow in the 1960s, has made it clear it has no intention of relinquishing its leading role or allowing free elections.

DOC.HEAD: Epidemic of Dangerous Pregnancies Linked to Infection, Douching
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 4 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: An epidemic of dangerous pregnancies in which the fetus develops outside the womb is afflicting expectant mothers, many of whom have had a common and often symptom-free sexual infection, researchers say. The number of such pregnancies _ called ectopic pregnancies _ increased fourfold from 1970 to 1985, hitting 78,400 women that year, researchers reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. A woman's risk of developing an ectopic pregnancy, which causes 11 percent of maternal deaths, more than doubles if she has had the bacterial infection chlamydia trachomatis, the researchers said. They based their conclusion on tests of 306 women with ectopic pregnancies and 266 women with normal pregnancies. Chlamydia is an epidemic in itself, infecting an estimated 4 million people a year, more than any other sexually transmitted disease, according to the national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. An unlooked-for finding of the study was that women who douched had almost as high a risk of developing ectopic pregnancies as women who had a history of chlamydial infection, the researchers said. The reasons are unclear, but the findings support previous studies, said the researchers. They speculated that douching may propel bacteria from the lower genital tract to the normally sterile upper genital tract. When bacteria invade the upper genital tract, the resulting infection can scar the Fallopian tubes, blocking the normal path that eggs travel from the ovaries to the womb. That is what often happens in untreated chlamydial infections, said Julius Schachter, a co-author of the study and a professor of epidemiology and laboratory medicine at the University of California, San Francisco. ``What is dangerous is that it (chlamydia) can cause an upper genital tract infection without causing symptoms,'' Schachter said in a telephone interview. ``The first time a woman finds out she's had it is when she has a bad outcome ... either infertility or ectopic pregnancy.'' In 97 percent of ectopic pregnancies, the fertilized egg lodges in the Fallopian tubes, where as the fetus enlarges, it can rupture the tubes or cause severe bleeding. Such pregnancies, though dangerous, can now be detected early and ended surgically. ``You can't prevent this by treating a symptomatic woman because she's never had symptoms,'' Schachter said. ``What we need is a chlamydia control program to reduce infection and prevent complications.'' Such a program _ involving routine screening of sexually active young people and treating those found to be infected _ already exists for gonorrhea, Schachter said. That disease infects an estimated 1.5 million people a year and is another major cause of ectopic pregnancy, says the CDC. Starting a control program for chlamydia would cost an estimated $50 million, he said, citing a CDC figure. ``That would be highly cost-effective, because chlamydia costs billions of dollars in complications,'' said Schachter, who has previously reported that chlamydia infects up to one in 20 pregnant women, 60 percent of whom pass it to their newborns, who may get pneumonia or eye inflammation as a result. Schachter and his colleagues also recommended further research into the practice of douching. Changes in douching habits, if they reduced ectopic pregnancies, could have a quicker impact than a chlamydia control program, they said. However, Dr. Bruce B. Dan of the American Medical Association disagreed. He called for caution in blaming douching for ectopic pregnancy and said physicians ``would do better by telling women at every opportunity how to protect themselves from acquiring chlamydial infections. ``This strategy would also serve to decrease the incidence of gonorrhea, syphilis, human immunodeficiency virus infection (which causes AIDS), and hepatitis B infection, something a change in douching habits is unlikely to do,'' Dan added in an editorial accompanying the study. A related study in Wednesday's Journal found that most of 323 pregnant women with chlamydial infections responded to antibiotic treatment, and suffered significantly fewer pregnancy problems than those who didn't respond to treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Amidst Surge of Protests, African Leaders Gather for Summit
DOC.TEXT: Leaders from 33 African countries, many facing growing opposition at home, gathered under tight security Tuesday for a summit with French President Francois Mitterrand. Navy patrol boats, 12 companies of riot police and more than 1,500 regular police officers were deployed in and around this posh beach resort as delegations arrived for the three-day summit. French officials said 22 delegations would be led by a head of state, two by prime ministers and nine by lesser-ranking Cabinet ministers. French-African summits have been held every two years since the early 1960s. This year's gathering coincides with unprecedented political turbulence in French-speaking Africa and unusually harsh domestic criticism of France's policies in its former colonies. On Tuesday, prominent newspapers on the political right and left said France had persisted too long in supporting corrupt, repressive African governments. ``The French government speaks of democracy and continues to support dictatorial, bloodstained regimes,'' said L'Humanite, newspaper of France's Communist Party. Mitterrand, in an interview with the prominent daily Le Monde, accused other Western countries of indifference toward Africa and said France would never abandon the continent. French aid money was subject to ``extremely rigorous'' review to ensure it was properly spent, he said. There have been anti-government protests and demands for an end to one-party rule in many African countries in recent months. In several countries, leaders have pledged to allow political pluralism. Two of French-speaking Africa's senior leaders _ Felix Houphouet-Boigny of Ivory Coast and Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire _ are not attending the summit. Both recently made concessions to opposition groups by proposing multi-party systems. Mobutu has been beset by calls for an international inquiry into an alleged massacre of scores of university students by security forces. Mitterrand, during a visit last week to four Indian Ocean nations that belong to the Organization of African Unity, said France was committed to remaining a spokesman for underdeveloped counties. ``There is no democracy without development,'' he said. During the summit, Ivory Coast, Gabon, Cameroon and Congo are expected to receive new concessions from France regarding their foreign debt. Because these countries are classified as middle-income, they have not been helped by previous moves by France and other Western countries to write off large portions of foreign debt for several poor countries. After an opening banquet Tuesday night, the summit was to continue with closed-door discussions Wednesday. The closing ceremony Thursday is to be followed by a news conference featuring Mitterrand, Morocco's King Hassan II, who was host of the previous summit, and the leader of the African country chosen to be host of the 1992 summit. Ten non-Francophone countries are attending the summit, including first-time participants Mozambique and Namibia. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, issued documents this week alleging serious human rights abuses in several participating countries _ Mauritania, Cameroon, Chad, Congo, Ivory Coast, Morocco, Niger, Senegal and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Gut Buster Importer Agrees to Pay $130,000 Fine
DOC.TEXT: The importer of the ``Gut Buster'' exercise device has agreed to pay a $130,000 fine to settle a lawsuit charging it failed to report a product defect, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Tuesday. The commission alleged Consumer Direct, Inc. of Canton, Ohio ignored consumer complaints claiming a defect in the ``Gut Buster'' caused its spring to break and created ``a substantial product hazard'' which it was legally obligated to report. The agency said the company had received many complaints of cuts, bruises and other injury caused by the breaks. Consumer Direct maintains that no substantial hazard existed and that it did not violate statutory reporting requirements. However, the company agreed in November 1988 to a repair program to retrofit 2 million ``Gut Busters'' with devices that would avoid the spring breakages. The CPSC reminded consumers to discontinue use of the exercisers until they have obtained the repair kit. Consumer Direct can be reached at 1-800-325-7292.

DOC.HEAD: President Hospitalized With Ear Ailment
DOC.TEXT: President Borisav Jovic has been hospitalized with an ear ailment, the state Tanjug news agency reported Tuesday. In a brief dispatch, Tanjug said Jovic was hospitalized at Belgrade's Military Medical Academy because of ``acoustic ear injury and the indispensability of intensive therapy.'' It gave no further details. Jovic took office as the head of Yugoslavia's collective eight-man presidency May 16 and is to serve for a year.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern States Told of Quake Threat to Bridges
DOC.TEXT: Bridge builders east of the Rockies must learn the lessons of last year's deadly earthquake in California, researchers said Tuesday. ``A major eastern earthquake will happen, it's just a question of when,'' James Cooper, deputy chief structural engineer with the Federal Highway Administration, told about 250 bridge architects and state highway officials attending the International Bridge Conference in Pittsburgh. Bridges are especially imperiled when built on soft soils and underlying hard rock, a combination found in many Eastern cities. Scientists say the condition amplifies tremors. ``An earthquake is like an explosion, sending energy in all directions,'' U.S. Geological Survey seismologist Bob Hamilton said in a telephone interview from Reston, Va. ``In the East, the energy waves travel much further. The crust is older and cooler, less broken up by mountain building. ``Out West, the mountain building is still going on. The crust is busted up, reducing the amplitude of an earthquake.'' Rocky ground covers most of the West. Exceptions are San Francisco and Oakland, Calif., parts of which are built on soft ground known as Bay Mud. The sections of the double-decker Interstate-880 in Oakland that collapsed during the Oct. 17 earthquake was built on Bay Mud. Klaus Jacob, a Columbia University seismologist, noted that other sections of the highway built on harder ground withstood the quake. Jacob said I-880 was weakened by ``that extra Jell-O pudding layer under the structure.'' In the East, major underground faults lie in the central Mississippi River valley, New England and South Carolina. The last major eastern quake, in 1895, was centered near the junction of the Ohio and Mississippi rivers in Charleston, Mo. An 1886 earthquake near Charleston, S.C., leveled most of the city and killed 20 people. Shock waves from an earthquake east of the Rockies would travel 30 to 40 times farther than waves from the same quake in California, Jacob said. The U.S. Geological Survey estimates more conservatively that such a quake would travel 20 times as far. For example, three thundering quakes in 1811-12 near the frontier settlement of New Madrid, Mo., were felt 850 miles away in Washington, D.C. ``We have the luxury in the East of having time between our earthquakes,'' Jacob said. ``Another New Madrid earthquake may be around the corner tomorrow. We should use the time we have to make repairs.'' After the 1971 San Fernando quake in California, the state spent $54 million to tie together sections of 1,200 bridges with steel cables. If a bridge isn't tied, ``when it starts doing that wave, it will bounce off its supports,'' said James Roberts, chief bridge engineer for the California Department of Transportation California engineers also are experimenting with collaring bridge columns in steel, which could have saved I-880, said Ian Buckle, deputy director of the National Center for Earthquake Engineering Research in Buffalo, N.Y. Buckle said state transportation officials should consider both methods when patching up aging bridges or building new ones. The Federal Highway Adminstration, in its 1989 report to Congress, said 41.3 percent of the nation's 577,710 bridges were either structurally deficient or functionally obsolete.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Committee Moves Bill to Floor
DOC.TEXT: The House Judiciary Committee advanced a proposed constitutional amendment banning flag burning to the floor of the House today without making a recommendation for or against the measure. The committee voted 19-17 to move the amendment forward, with five Democrats joining 14 Republicans on the affirmative side. The full House could vote on the amendment as early as Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Man Demanding To Go To U.S. Commandeers Soviet Airliner
LaserPhoto HEL2
DOC.TEXT: A man hijacked a Soviet airliner with 60 people aboard Tuesday and then surrendered to Finnish authorities and sought political asylum. He asked to be taken to the United States, the interior minister said. It was the third hijacking of a Soviet passenger plane in less than two weeks. The 55 passengers and five crew members safely left the aircraft, which was parked beside a runway at Helsinki airport and surrounded by police. The hijacker gave up an hour later after talks with Finnish officials through a cabin door of the twin-jet Aeroflot Tupolev 134. The passengers, all Soviets, were flown to the Soviet city of Murmansk later Tuesday. The Soviet deputy aviation minister, Mikhail Timofeev, identified the hijacker as Oleg Kozlov. Timofeev said the man threatened to blow up the plane. He said a fake hand grenade was seized. Finnish Interior Minister Jarmo Rantanen said no explosives were found on the plane but that the 20-year-old hijacker ``had a bomb-like object under his jacket.'' ``His real aim was apparently the United States,'' Rantanen told a news conference. ``He wants out. He wants to go to the U.S.A.'' The hijacker requested asylum, but processing the request could take weeks, Rantanen said. A 1974 Soviet-Finnish agreement aimed at preventing hijackings says the suspect must be returned to the Soviet Union at Moscow's request. Some observers said, however, that Kozlov's request for asylum could be granted or he could face trial in Finland. The plane was en route from the Latvian capital of Riga to Murmansk on the northern Kola peninsula when it was hijacked, said Irmeli Paavola of the Finnish Aviation Authority. ``Nothing terrible happened in the aircraft,'' one passenger identified only as Anatoli told Finnish TV. ``The crew announced that the plane had been commanded to divert its route. They said we are flying abroad.'' Finnish Radio said two Finnish fighter jets escorted the Soviet airliner to Helsinki as a precaution. The Soviet news agency Tass said a Civil Aviation Ministry commission would investigate the hijacking, the third since June 9. On Monday, a 29-year-old pilot, Valeri Yuricevic, commandeered a 12-seat Antonov-2 aircraft in Izmail, near the Ukrainian port of Odessa, and flew to Turkey, where he asked for asylum. There was no one else on board. Ihsan Dede, governor of the province of Kocaeli, where Yuricevic landed, said the pilot told authorities he wanted to escape ``the undemocratic regime and harsh life conditions'' in the Soviet Union. On June 9, Dimitry Semionov, a 17-year-old Soviet youth, used a fake hand grenade to hijack a plane carrying 121 passengers during a flight from Minsk to Murmansk.
