The plane was forced to fly to Stockholm, where Semionov surrendered. He said later through a lawyer that he had acted on impulse after a family quarrel and wanted to go to a ``free country.'' Semionov was arraigned in a Stockholm court and could face up to four years in prison, depending on results of psychiatric tests.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Revises Report on `Friendly Fire' Deaths
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon revised its figures Tuesday on the number of soldiers accidentally wounded by their comrades in the Panama invasion, saying 16 of 310 servicemen wounded in action were hit by ``friendly fire.'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams also raised the possibility that another 21 U.S. servicemen might have been wounded by an U.S. Air Force AC-130 gunship, and that if the incident occurred, it may have been captured on the plane's video camera. Williams said it is presently ``impossible to distinguish'' whether the 21 were injured by the gunship or from mortar fire of Panamanian Defense Forces during the Dec. 20 military operation. He said he'd asked for a review of the video to check whether the incident might be on tape. In his statement, Williams said the Pentagon stood by its initial count that two _ and perhaps three _ U.S. servicemen had been killed by friendly fire. The third case was still under study, Williams said. The Pentagon has refused to identify which of the 23 servicemen killed in Panama died under such circumstances. On Monday, the department had said 19 of some 324 soldiers wounded in action had been hit accidentally by their comrades. The figures issued Tuesday changed both the number hit by friendly fire and the total number of wounded. Williams said the department had refined the figures in an overnight study of the death reports. The review was prompted by a Newsweek magazine report that nine U.S. soldiers had been killed by their comrades and that more than 60 percent of the woundings had been caused by friendly fire. Williams also disputed the article's contention that there were more than a dozen ``leaks'' about the military operation. ``I know of no so-called leaks,'' Williams said, adding that there is ``No evidence that information was in the hands of the PDF.'' The spokesman noted that with the massive movement of U.S. troops that got under way prior to the invasion, there was much speculation about the event but that it was not compromised. In his first comment on the issue, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney lamented the deaths by friendly fire, saying such things occur in complex, night-time military operations where high-tech weaponry is used. ``I wish it had not happened. On the other hand I don't think it detracts from the overall quality of the operation,'' he told reporters after a Pentagon briefing on the budget. Williams, in his briefing, said that of the 23 killed in action, two Rangers were killed by friendly fire at Rio Hato ``during an intense fire fight with the PDF (Panamanian Defense Force) near dawn.'' ``Of the 310 wounded in action, it now appears that 16 were wounded by friendly fire in several isolated incidents throughout Panama,'' Williams said. ``Yesterday's report of 19 wounded in action included some accidental injuries that we have now determined were not caused by hostile fire,'' the spokesman said, adding that since the cases were being looked at very closely, the numbers could change again. Williams said the Pentagon has looked into every case and deeply regrets any loss of life, for whatever reason. ``Nothing can diminish the sacrifices that all these men made to their country. Casualties caused by friendly fire are an unfortunate circumstance of war,'' he said. The report in the June 25 Newsweek issue quoted unidentified military officials as the source of its information. Williams said confusion over the deaths could have arisen because Noriega's troops used U.S.-supplied bullets and weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Battles Kill 4 After Cease-Fire Collapses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with four killed, six wounded. Pickup 4th pvs, `The latest...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces fought with howitzers and mortars across the Christian enclave Tuesday in a confrontation that killed four people and was the most serious violation of month-old cease-fire. Police said six people were injured in the battles, which began at 9:45 a.m. and subsided five hours later. A French government envoy, Francois Scheer, met in west Beirut with President Elias Hrawi in an effort to salvage a Vatican plan for ending the Christian warfare. The new casualties raised the overall toll to 1,040 killed and 2,780 wounded since the battle for control of the Christian enclave erupted Jan. 30. The fighting is between troops of Gen. Michel Aoun and militiamen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces. A cease-fire was declared May 17. The latest battles covered most of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The streets of east Beirut and the surrounding hinterland were deserted as people huddled in basements and bomb shelters. A police spokesman said it could not be determined who started the clashes but noted that tension had been mounting since Monday, when Lebanon's president rejected a Vatican proposal for a permanent settlement to the conflict. The Vatican has suggested reconsideration of an accord designed to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. It was that accord, supported by the Arab League, that led to Hrawi's election as president. In return for reconsidering the accord, Aoun would agree to recognize Hrawi's government, the Vatican suggested. Prime Minister Salim Hoss and Parliament speaker Hussein Husseini backed Hrawi in his opposition to the idea. ``The French government is helping Lebanon to overcome the difficulties it is facing,'' Scheer told reporters after the 90-minute meeting with Hrawi. ``The dialogue, led by France, could help support the mechanism of the Taif accord,'' Scheer added, referring to the Saudi Arabian city in which the accord was reached. Scheer said he also planned to meet the Vatican ambassador while in Lebanon. The ambassador, Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente, met Tuesday with Aoun at the general's headquarters outside Beirut. ``We are seeking peace, through peace,'' Puente told reporters after the meeting. France and the Vatican have been the Christians' main backers since Lebanon's independence from France in 1943. Neighboring Syria backs the Moslems. The conservative newspaper Ad-Diyar reported Tuesday that Scheer was promoting a five-point compromise plan that called for recognition of the Hrawi government by all the warring factions, in addition to recognizing the Taif accord as ``a frame for a national settlement.'' The compromise also called for the formation of an expanded ``national government respresenting all the factions.'' This echoed the Vatican's suggestion that Aoun be given a government portfolio. The French proposal, according to the report, said the Taif accord should be debated in Parliament and the decision on passing or rejecting it ``should be left to the house.'' It called for parliamentary elections ``as soon as possible,'' the newspaper added. Aoun has rejected the Taif agreement because it does not include a deadline for the withdrawal of Syrian soldiers from Lebanon. Syria has about 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 mandate to quell civil war fighting, but Aoun maintains they violated that mandate by siding with the Moslems in the war.

DOC.HEAD: Government Calls For Talks But Arrests Two Opposition Leaders
LaserPhotos NY22,23
DOC.TEXT: The government appealed for talks with the opposition Tuesday but also pressed its crackdown on dissent by arresting two prominent critics of President-elect Ion Iliescu. The wife of an Iliescu opponent detained earlier on charges of involvement in last week's anti-government violence took refuge at the Dutch ambassador's residence. There was no sign of organized protest at University Square, where demonstrators gathered Sunday and Monday in defiance of the violent suppression of dissent. Riot police June 13 brutally broke up a 53-day anti-Iliescu demonstration on the square, and rioters later attacked government buildings with firebombs. Thousands of coal miners summoned by Iliescu to help keep order then poured into the capital from around the nation and roamed the streets for two days, clubbing anyone they considered opponents of the president. They left Friday, also at Iliescu's behest. Authorities appeared to be adopting a strategy of talking to opposition groups while detaining their leaders and sanctioning police action against any further illegal demonstrations. A communique carried by the state Rompres news agency said Interior Minister Doru Viorel Ursu and the Romanian Information Service had invited student organizations and intellectuals to discuss ``problems of common interest.'' The Information Service is the intelligence agency that replaced the feared secret police of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was toppled and executed in the December revolution. It was unclear whether demonstrators stayed away from the square because of the talks. At the University of Bucharest, students of several departments began or planned strikes. Government opponents seek the ouster of Iliescu and other former Communists who hold top posts in the governing National Salvation Front. It took power during the revolution and won parliamentary elections by a landslide last month. Iliescu was to be inaugurated Wednesday, and U.S. Embassy spokesman Virgil Bodeen said no American representative would attend because of U.S. displeasure over how his government has dealth with the unrest. Parliament's lower house voted Monday to give police and soldiers the authority to clear protesters from University Square and urged police to take ``immediate action'' against unauthorized protests. The Interior Ministry identified the opposition figures arrested Tuesday as Dumitru Dinca and Nica Leon, leader of the small National Democratic Party. It said Dinca was charged with ``larceny and instigation toward committing major crimes,'' while Leon was accused of ``destruction of public property.'' The two were being held as part of an investigation into the 53-day anti-government protest and subsequent unrest, the government said. On Monday, authorities detained Marian Munteanu, a student leader severely beaten by miners. He was moved from his hospital bed to an unidentified Interior Ministry hospital on charges of instigating violence. Dutch Ambassador Coen F. Stork said he offered haven to Munteanu's wife, Claudia, after ``she said that she was very scared to move about ... after what happened to her husband.'' Stork said Mrs. Munteanu would likely leave his home soon. ``She has not asked for asylum, she is just my guest,'' said the diplomat, a key Western critic of Romania's human rights record under Ceausescu. The government reacted sharply to the development. Munteanu ``is not a political prisoner but a criminal,'' it said in a statement. ``We have nothing against his wife, and we are astounded that she chose the Dutch Embassy asking for refuge.'' The Interior Ministry suggested most of the 1,021 people detained last week had been set free. It said in a statement that 69 had been charged with major crimes and 182 with petty crimes. State television said the violence last week caused $7.5 million in damage. Foreign governments, including the United States, have condemned the way Romania has handled protests, and numerous countries have suspended all but humanitarian aid. Stork warned against drawing parallels between the Iliescu government's behavior and the brutal suppression of dissent under Ceausescu. ``There's a little flurry of human rights cases now,'' he said. ``It's not to be confused with the previous period. In those days people didn't dare to ask for help from Western embassies.'' The opposition Romania Libera daily published Tuesday for the first time since miners shut the paper down Thursday, but copies of the 800,000-circulation daily were difficult to find. Editor Mihai Creanga suggested there were some hitches in publishing but refused to elaborate. In an editorial, the paper indirectly criticized the anti-government rioting and Iliescu's use of miners to crush the opposition. ``In a democratic state there is no room for instigation to violence, because, as we know, violence breeds violence,'' the daily said. In Paris, the International Federation of Newspaper Publishers protested Tuesday to Iliescu over attacks on members of the staff and offices of the newspaper.
