DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Landlady Stand Trial on Nine Murder Counts
DOC.TEXT: A woman who ran a boardinghouse was ordered Tuesday to stand trial on nine murder counts for allegedly poisoning her mostly elderly tenants to get their pension and disability benefits. Dorothea Puente, 61, was ordered to be arraigned July 10 in Sacramento County Superior Court. The order by County Municipal Court Judge Gail Ohanesian culminated a five week preliminary hearing. ``I do find that there is ample circumstantial evidence ... that death was by criminal means,'' the judge said, adding that there was sufficient evidence that Puente ``had the opportunity to kill for financial gain.'' Puente, who has displayed little emotion throughout her hearing, sat quietly at the defense table. Puente was orderd to stand trial on all the counts with which she had been charged. She could face the death penalty if convicted. Prosecutors said her murder trial could last at least six months. She has pleaded innocent, and defense attorneys insisted she would be aquitted. ``There is totally insufficient evidence to convict her or anybody else based on the quality of evidence that has been presented in court in this case,'' Assistant Public Defender Kevin Clymo said. Puente was arrested after a social worker complained that one of her clients _ a roomer in Puente's downtown home _ had disappeared. In November 1988, authorities dug up seven bodies from the grounds of the Victorian-style dwelling. She was later implicated in two other deaths _ that of a woman who died of a drug overdose at Puente's house, and that of a man whose body was found in a wooden box in a neighboring county. Prosecutors said Puente has a record of administering stupefying drugs to intended robbery victims. They contend the matronly ex-convict killed her victims for their Social Security and government benefit checks. Defense attorneys said the alleged victims, ranging from age 52 to 80 and mostly poor and alcoholic, died either by suicide or natural causes. Among their ailments were a brain tumor, lung disease, heart disease and diabetes. The preliminary hearing featured 17 days of testimony by nearly 80 witnesses and more than 100 exhibits. Much of the testimony focused on the causes of death. In only one death, the first one, was a cause ever listed. Ruth Munroe, 61, died April 28, 1982, from an overdose of codeine and Tylenol. That death was considered to be either accidental or a suicide until investigators began digging up bodies from the yard. A prescription tranquilizer flurazepam, or Dalmane, was detected in all seven bodies that had been buried in shallow graves on the boardinghouse grounds. The medication's role, if any, in the deaths is unclear. The bodies, buried anywhere from weeks to years, were too decomposed for autopsies to determine the cause of deaths. A total of nine other drugs were found in the boardinghouse bodies. All seven people had been Puente's tenants, and their doctors and fellow boarders have testified that most of them were heavy drinkers. The ninth murder charge was filed in connection with the death of Everson Theodore Gillmouth, a 77-year-old Oregon man who was Puente's fiance and roommate when he died. His body was found by fishermen on New Year's Day 1986 in a wooden box on a bank of the Sacramento River in Sutter County.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Again Hit Iowa, S.D., Delay Cleanup; 1 Dead in Nebraska
With AM-Flash Floods, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Heavy thunderstorms and tornadoes crimped cleanup efforts on Tuesday by Iowa and South Dakota residents who are still reeling from weekend weather, and Nebraska reported its first fatality from recent floods. After morning rains added 1 to 2 inches to watersheds of flooded rivers, Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad added 11 counties to 22 already declared disaster areas. That brings the total to one-third of the state's 99 counties. The National Weather Service said no appreciable additional flooding was expected. Three deaths in Iowa have been blamed on the most recent storms. Police in Des Moines asked employers to send workers home early because storm sewers had backed up, clogging major streets leading out of downtown. In the central Iowa town of Jewell, about 55 miles north of Des Moines, a tornado struck the center building at South Hamilton High School, where maintenance worker Don Strangeland recounted the damage: ``I heard the roof just peeling off the school.'' Just a little north of there in Webster City, another tornado destroyed outbuildings and killed about 30 hogs on a 700-acre farm. ``Two months ago, we were concerned about the drought and now here we are faced with major flooding,'' the governor said. Branstad said agricultural damage could be severe unless flood waters recede soon. ``There's a considerable amount that's been flooded, and it's getting very late as far as replanting,'' he said. Thunderstorms on Monday night also carried heavy rain across the central and eastern part of South Dakota, where residents were still cleaning up from Saturday night's violent weather. Cleanup efforts continued in the southeastern South Dakota towns of Beresford and Alcester where a tornado swept through the area causing more than $1 million in damage to 24 farms. In Alcester, neighbors spent Sunday and Monday helping each other out, Police Chief Kevin Booker said. Residents with pickups helped haul away trees that blocked up to one-third of the streets in town. In the country, neighbors helped remove debris so farmers could get back to their fields to replant crops torn up from the tornado and high winds. A 77-year-old West Point, Neb., man was found drowned, apparently the first person to die in flood waters that have plagued northeast Nebraska for nearly a week. A relative found the body 1{ blocks from the man's home, two miles south of West Point near the Elkhorn River, said Cuming County Sheriff Larry Thiem. More storms ravaged south-central and northeastern Nebraska on Monday night, causing authorities to ask residents of King Lake in northern Douglas County to evacuate as the Elkhorn River reached flood stage. Floods also struck further east. In Pennsylvania, thunderstorms moved throughout the state saturating farmland, flooding basements and causing scattered power outages, authorities said. No injuries were reported. The heaviest thunderstorms were reported in Rosencrans, Clinton County, and Ohiopyle, Fayette County, the weather service said. About 200 McKean County residents were without power in several small afternoon outages caused by lightning and downed power lines, said Bill Manning, a foreman for Pennsylvania Electric Co. And in eastern Ohio, recovery efforts continued in the Ohio River town of Shadyside, where flash floods last week killed 21 people.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Town Can't Ban Political Signs
DOC.TEXT: A town's ordinance requiring residents to obtain permits before installing political signs in their yards is unconstitutional, a Superior Court judge ruled Tuesday. Judge Melanie Famiglietti threw out the conviction of James Lemoi, who had been found guilty of erecting signs in his yard in 1984 and 1985 without a permit. Lemoi, 70, had been convicted in District Court of violating Barrington's ordinance and was fined $13,000. He challenged his conviction and the American Civil Liberties Union picked up his case. Barrington allows a variety of signs to be installed without a permit to advertise a house for sale, a professional business such as a law firm in a home or signs tied to seasonal decorations. Other signs require a permit before they are erected. Lemoi installed signs in his yard twice. The first was an appeal to the public for help after his wife's death and a fire at his house, the judge said. The second, Famiglietti said, was a political statement about town officials. Under the Barrington ordinance, Lemoi should have obtained a permit both times. But the judge ruled that the town cannot regulate signs by their content. ``If these very same signs indicated a doctor's office in (Lemoi's) home or were a theater marquee or were holiday decorations Mr. Lemoi would not be in court today and would not be fined $13,000,'' the judge said. In December 1984, Lemoi's wife died and just a few days later his house caught fire, causing extensive damage. He wasn't home at the time and was unhurt. About 10 days after the fire, Lemoi put a sign up in his yard asking for help. Seven months later, after he was unable to obtain police or fire department reports about the fire investigation, he erected another sign, stating simply: ``Come Clean.'' It was after that sign that Barrington charged him in District Court. Lemoi described Famiglietti's decision as ``swell.'' He said he pursued the case for so long because he believed Barrington was wrong. ``I don't know why they treated me this way,'' he said. ``I was born and brought up in this town.'' ACLU lawyer Elizabeth Colt, who represented Lemoi, said Famiglietti's decision came down squarely on the side of free speech guaranteed by the Constitution. ``You can't distinguish among signs,'' Ms. Colt said, citing the prohibition on political signs. ``It's (sign regulations) got to be content neutral.'' A lawyer for the town, Michael Mosco, said he would leave a decision whether to appeal the ruling to the town council, but he defended ordinance, saying it was reasonable.

DOC.HEAD: Pet Census: Sit Up and Be Counted
DOC.TEXT: Yapping at the heels of the 1990 national census, here comes ... the 1990 Marquette pet census. For the first time since 1959, this city on Michigan's Upper Peninsula will attempt to count its dogs and cats. All of them. Michigan Youth Corps workers are starting to canvass the city this week, seeking information on pets from the city's 8,600 households, animal control officer Paula Maslanka said. The effort is expected to take seven weeks. ``The main objective is to find out where the animals live and get them on file, so when strays come in we can find out who the owner is,'' Maslanka said. ``A lot of people, especially those who have cats, don't realize their animal has been picked up for several days, and I end up keeping them for only so long and I have to put them down.'' Maslanka said she also hopes the census reminds owners to get their pets licensed. She said she has licensed only nine cats in the past few years, even though city ordinance requires all cats to be registered. The same ordinance limits pet owners to three dogs or cats to a house. Maslanka said city records show there was a pet census by police in 1959, but there are no records of its result.

DOC.HEAD: Mother of Heads of CBS and Loews Dies at 91
DOC.TEXT: Sayde Tisch Busch, matriarch of the Tisch family and mother to the heads of CBS Inc. and Loews Corp., has died. She was 91. Mrs. Tisch Busch died Monday at Victoria Hospital, where she had been a patient for 10 days, said her daughter-in-law, Wilma Tisch. She had resided in Bal Harbour since 1960. She was buried Tuesday. Mrs. Tisch Busch was the mother of Laurence A. Tisch, president and chief executive officer of CBS Inc., and chairman and co-chief executive officer (with his brother), of Loews Corp. Preston Robert Tisch is president and co-chief executive officer of Loews Corp. and a former U.S. postmaster general. Sayde Brenner married Al Tisch, a clothing manufacturer in New York City, in 1920. They later bought two boys' camps in Blairstown, N.J., which she directed for 11 years. The family bought their first hotel, in Lakewood, N.J., in 1946. In 1950, they bought the first of several Atlantic City, N.J., hotels, the Traymore. By the mid-1950s, they operated 12 East Coast hotels. As the family company grew, it acquired stock in Loews Theaters Inc., as well as interests in, for example, tobacco and watches. Al Tisch died in 1960. His widow married S. Harry Busch of Knoxville, Tenn., in 1969. Mrs. Tisch Busch is survived by her second husband, her two sons, seven grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: House Will Vote on Balanced Budget Amendment
DOC.TEXT: Conservative supporters of a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget succeeded Tuesday in their long-running quest to bring the issue to the full House for a vote. Using a rarely-successful procedure, supporters of the proposal overcame opposition by the House's Democratic leadership and are now guaranteed a vote no later than next month. ``They can't prevent this now,'' said Rep. Larry Craig, R-Idaho, one of the measure's sponsors. Supporters have long argued that an amendment requiring a balanced budget is the only way to eliminate the huge deficits of recent years, which have been stuck in the $150 billion range. Opponents argue that such an amendment would not work because the real problem is the political stalemate over tax increases and spending cuts that might eliminate the budget gap. For years, Democratic leaders have blocked balanced budget amendments from moving out of the House Judiciary Committee. But under House procedures, a measure can be taken away from a committee and brought to the full chamber for a vote if a majority of the 435 members sign a so-called discharge petition. Craig and his allies announced Tuesday that they had collected their 218th signature, the number needed. The drive to round up those signatures recently had taken a controversial turn. One supporter had threatened to release the names of co-sponsors of the balanced-budget amendment who had refused to sign the petition. But the supporter, Rep. Chuck Douglas, R-N.H., said the matter was now moot. Constitutional amendments must be approved by two-thirds votes of the House and Senate, and then ratified by at least three-fourths of the states. It is rare for discharge petitions to succeed. Since the House's current procedure was adopted in 1931, 482 such petitions have been filed, according to Richard Beth of the Congressional Research Service, the research arm of Congress. Just 43 of the petitions _ including Tuesday's _ have succeeded in collecting enough signatures to force a House vote. The last time one was successful was in 1986, when a vote was forced on a measure easing gun control laws.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troops Sent to Quell Prison Riots
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops sent into two prisons to quell mass rioting opened fire on escaping inmates, killing one and wounding another, the official news agency Tass reported Tuesday. The inmates were shot in a prison in the Ukrainian city of Dnepropertrovsk where 2,000 inmates went on a rampage Thursday and seized hostages, Tass said. The hostages were released Friday. Tass said several inmates died after taking drugs stolen from the prison pharmacy. The news agency initially reported two prisoners were killed by gunfire from security forces, but later said troops opened fire on two escaping prisoners, killing one and wounding another. The inmates were demanding better conditions and the relaxing of prison regulations, the news agency said. Soviet television on Monday night showed Interior Ministry troops and police, many wearing helmets and bullet-proof vests, sealing off the prison. Troops were also deployed to control rioting at a jail in Chelyabinsk, in the Ural mountains. On Sunday, 1,000 rioting prisoners rushed into the jail yard and tried to escape by ramming the gate with a front loader. Tass reported the troops returned to their barracks Tuesday and that the situation in the prison had returned to normal.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Bemoan Their Loss Of Clout; City Machines Rule No More
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, a veteran of Chicago's tough ward politics, was reminiscing about the old days _ when he checked in with City Hall before voting in Congress. ``All of us in Congress now are independent contractors,'' Rostenkowski told the nation's mayors in explaining why cities have a hard time making their case these days. The mayors know that all too well. During their summer meeting this week, the more than 200 mayors, Democrats and Republicans, from big cities and small, have been virtually unanimous in saying cities have lost much of their clout in Washington. But they are deeply divided over how to get it back. Some advocate a militant approach in which mayors use their local organizations against members of Congress who fail to help their cities. Others say the mayors are to blame for their own decline and must put their own houses in order. Their frustration has spilled over repeatedly these past few days. They talk of losing billions when President Reagan cut domestic programs to fund his military buildup. When they try to get some of that back now, they're told the money is needed to reduce the federal deficit. Yet the government quickly finds $300 billion to bail out the savings and loan industry. The S&L crisis, New York Mayor David Dinkins said Tuesday, ``has shown us that federal money abounds.'' The diversity of the mayors, a strength at times, can also prove to be a weakness. At times the cities are forced to compete with each other for the declining share of federal aid. ``It is hard for us at times to speak with one voice,'' said Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, N.J. ``But the bigger problem is that mayors have allowed the Congress to become fat cats, smug, secure, assured of their positions. They're not fighting the real fights anymore.'' James believes mayors could win back some clout ``by holding some congressmen hostage'' when elections roll around. ``Mayors and congressman have had a honeymoon for far too long.'' Many big city Democratic mayors are apoplectic in trying to explain their setbacks in Washington, where Democrats control the Congress. Two of those mayors, Boston's Raymond Flynn and New York's Dinkins, said the mayors need to rally more grassroots support for their causes. They have adopted the multibillion dollar S&L bailout plan as the centerpiece of their populist pitch. ``We, the mayors of urban America, must send a message to Washington that only after we have housed our people, only after we have educated our young people, only after we have repaired our roads, and only after we heal our sick can we commit to the extravagant bailout of a corrupt system,'' Dinkins said. Some mayors speak fondly of the urban heydays, when a Mayor Daley of Chicago, Curley of Boston or LaGuardia of New York could strike fear in Congress and at times even the White House. Now, Flynn said, cash-rich special interests have taken the clout once wielded by city political machines. ``We've got to go to the people to get it back'' he said. Chicago Mayor Richard M. Daley, the son of the late Mayor Richard J. Daley, voiced the frustration of many of his colleagues in saying too few members of Congress are in touch with residents of their cities. ``It's another world,'' he said of Washington. But Milwaukee Mayor John Norquist said the mayors should accept much of the blame for their declining clout. ``We should have a concise, constant message,'' he said in an interview. ``We need to be more aggressive as an organization.'' When they do speak as one, the mayors too often appear to be whining, Norquist said. ``The message certainly needs to be more positive,'' he said. ``Pity doesn't get you much. Pity usually leads to contempt.''

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins, Despite Rosty's Warning, Leads Mayors in Demand for Peace Dividend
With AM-Mayors-Politics
DOC.TEXT: New York's David Dinkins led fellow mayors Tuesday in a populist appeal for a piece of the peace dividend despite a warning from Congress that cities likely would not share in any defense savings. ``We are obliged by the needs of the people we represent _ the majority of Americans _ to put our claim on the liberated resources of the Cold War,'' Dinkins told the U.S. Conference of Mayors. ``The money that had once financed armament factories can now help rebuild our cities.'' Dinkins spent only the morning at the conference because of his role in planning for South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela's visit to New York on Wednesday. But his speech was full of rhetoric welcomed by the mayors a day after House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski told the mayors they stood little chance of winning more federal aid soon. Dinkins made no mention of Rostenkowski. Instead, he listed a series of urban problems that he said threatened safety and the social fabric of urban America. ``We do not seek every penny of the peace dividend, only a fair share for the people of our cities, a fair share that has often been denied,'' Dinkins told the mayors. ``It is a challenge that we _ the mayors of America _ must mobilize to meet.'' In a brief meeting with reporters after the speech, Dinkins said it was up to mayors to lobby Rostenkowki and others in Congress. Dinkins called on fellow mayors to meet with him at an urban summit in New York in October, and urged them to bring along local business leaders to draft a strategy for winning more federal aid. His address was the highlight of a day that had the mayors attending a variety of workshops and visiting an economic enterprise zone in their host city. The meeting concludes Wednesday after the mayors formally endorse a broad new domestic lobbying agenda that calls for major federal funding increases for housing, education, anti-drug, anti-poverty and other urban programs. The success of the plan hinges heavily on whether the mayors can win their uphill fight for more federal aid.

DOC.HEAD: Case of Missing Peasants Still Unsolved
DOC.TEXT: The case of seven Chinese peasants who disappeared from a New York airport nearly two months ago remains a mystery, authorities said Tuesday. Work continues on the Massachusetts farm that was the peasants' destination as the group's nine remaining members prepare to harvest their first crop, an organizer said. ``We just try to keep things going; nothing too exciting,'' said Michael Ming Cui, who is helping Athol resident Molly Aitken run the training program for Chinese peasants. The group of farmers from China's Fujian Province arrived at New York's John F. Kennedy Airport on April 25. They were on their way to participate in an effort to build a model Third World village during an 11-month stay in Athol, a rural town about 50 miles north of Springfield. At the airport, three other Chinese men hustled the seven into a waiting car, Mrs. Aitken said. New York Port Authority police investigated the reported abduction, tracing leads to the New Jersey apartment of a man who rented the car. But there has been no trace of the farmers. The last report of the missing farmers was a letter Mrs. Aitken received in May that said they had only planned to slip away with friends to see more of New York City and were too embarrassed to reappear following the hue and cry. The letter, postmarked New York City, said the men felt they had lost face, and were afraid to return for fear they'd be deported. The port authority has said they are interested only in seeing that the men are safe. Officials with the Chinese Consulate in New York have also indicated they would urge the missing farmers to go to Athol and take up their studies. Port Authority spokeswoman Lynn Tierney said Tuesday she did not know of any developments in the case. ``We're keeping it open. We're investigating and following any leads that come in, but there hasn't been much activity lately.'' Cui said he has heard that the farmers contacted their families in China by telephone around the time of the letter. ``They told their families `Don't worry,' or something like that,'' he said. Meanwhile, the project continues, although not without a few hitches, Cui said. The village being built by the peasants from scratch is to be a model for other governments of poor countries of what can be done. Mrs. Aitken is president of World Energy Foundation, whose aim is transferring solar-power and similar technology to Third World countries. Work on the village has been held up by a problem getting building permits, Cui said. But the farmers have harvested their first crop of lettuce and strawberries last week, and plan to donate the surplus to a food bank in nearby Fitchburg, Cui said. ``We got some production,'' he said. ``At least they learned something,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Families Mourn Losses; Survivors in Shock
With AM-Office Massacre, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jack Studdard, a veteran adjuster with the insurance subsidiary of General Motors Acceptance Corp., went to work Tuesday, a day after a gunman walked in and massacred eight people. ``He thought he'd be better just to go on,'' said his wife, Carol. He went even though the office is closed for the week and he had been talking with Denise Highfill and Lee Simonton, two of the victims. Simonton, a 33-year-old father of two young children, and Mrs. Highfill, 36, died during the two-minute rampage that ended when the gunman, James Edward Pough, fatally shot himself. Simonton, a deacon in the Baptist church, crawled underneath a desk when the gunfire began. Mrs. Highfill was leaving her desk when she was struck down by bullets from Pough's .30-caliber semiautomatic rifle. ``He (Simonton) was a real good solid person, a man loved by everyone who knew him,'' said Rev. Douglas Pigg, who will officiate at Simonton's funeral Thursday. ``He was the quiet sort, who did his job.'' Pigg said he planned to use Simonton's personal Bible given to him as a gift from his wife in 1980 to prepare for the funeral service. Another victim, Cynthia Perry, 30, had just spent Sunday with her parents to celebrate Fathers' Day. ``I feel depressed. I feel cheated,'' said Gail Perry, her mother. ``She was a joy to everyone.'' Jan David, a 40-year-old mother of two boys, was the last victim killed during the massacre, her husband's law partner said Tuesday. ``She worked hard and took care of her family,'' said Jefferson W. Morrow. ``She liked to be with her kids. Get out and fish.'' GMAC President William Lovejoy led a team of officials from Detroit to Jacksonville to counsel victims and their families and set up an office to handle the company's business, spokesman John Andrews said. The company employs 85 people at its suburban office it moved into in 1977. Another victim, Drew Woods, was remembered by a neighbor as a quiet, private person who enjoyed neighborhood children. ``He played catch with the kids, played ball with them,'' said Kathy Brauner. Woods, 38, is survived by his wife, Davita. Two other GMAC employees _ Barbara Duckwall Holland and Sharon Louise Hall, both 45, also died in the shooting along with Julia White Burgess, 42, of Keystone Heights who had come to the office to make a car payment.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Narrowly Votes to Send Amended to the House Floor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series. Edits throughout to tighten. ADDS 2 grafs to UPDATE with group saying retired Justice Powell opposes the amendment and Powell's comment. Note that 1st ADD of the urgent serious CORRECTED the number of undecided and those with no known position to 63, sted 64
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Flag Burning-Text; AM-Flag Burning-Survey
DOC.TEXT: The House Judiciary Committee voted narrowly Tuesday to send a constitutional amendment protecting the flag to the House floor for a vote, as an Associated Press survey showed the measure short of the support needed to pass Congress. The 19-17 committee vote set the stage for a showdown in the House, possibly as early as this week. ``The close vote ... indicates that it's going to be a fairly close vote on the floor,'' said Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, the committee chairman. The AP survey said as much, and indicated that uncommitted Democrats will play a large role in determining the fate of the amendment. In the House, supporters and those leaning in favor outnumbered opponents 255-115, with 289 votes required for passage, the survey showed. Of the 63 who were undecided or had no known position, 53 were Democrats. The survey found 58 senators were either committed to or leaning toward the amendment pushed by President Bush, leaving it nine short of the 67 needed to pass. Twenty-four Democrats and four Republicans were either committed or leaning against supporting the amendment. The top Democratic leadership in the House and Senate are vehemently opposed to the amendment, but a vote against it is seen by Democrats and Republicans alike as risky business in an election year. Only a week ago, a Judiciary subcommittee cleared the amendment, but by an unfavorable 5-3 vote that carried a recommendation against passage. The full Judiciary Committee voted Tuesday to move the amendment to the House floor but took no stand for or against passage. Earlier Tuesday, Democratic opponents failed to get an adverse recommendation and supporters failed to get a favorable recommendation. At Brooks' urging, the panel voted on sending the amendment forward with no recommendation. That carried by a 19-17 margin. During earlier committee arguments, Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., told his colleagues: ``Those who are shocked and revolted and frustrated by the excesses of the counterculture, the pornography, the obscenities that inundates or entertainment industry, the drugs, the AIDS explosion, the high abortion rate, view flag burning as one more slap in the face at the millions of veterans.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, stood up on the Senate floor Tuesday to declare: ``I oppose and condemn the burning of the flag. I find it offensive and obnoxious. I'm proud to be an American, proud of our flag. ``But I do not support changing the Constitution,'' he said. A vote on the amendment could come as early as Thursday in the House and by the Fourth of July in the Senate. ``I don't know what the vote outcome will be,'' Mitchell had said earlier. ``I expect it will be close.'' The Democratic leadership, which sees the amendment as weakening the First Amendment, is looking for votes to block the measure among 18 undecided senators, 15 of them Democrats. They include Sen. Joseph Biden of Delaware, who last year wrote the law the Supreme Court struck down June 11. The AP survey was done June 15-18. Some members responded through aides, some themselves. Just four Republican senators _ John Chafee of Rhode Island, John Danforth of Missouri, Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire and Bob Packwood of Oregon _ are opposed. Thirty-eight Republicans said they would vote yes and three are undecided. That the survey found so many Democrats on the fence so close to a vote illustrates the political difficulty of the issue, which Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., has quipped would make a good ``30-second campaign spot.'' But Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., who was undecided last week, said he found in a visit to his home district that the issue wasn't pressing with constituents. He said he's now leaning against the amendment. Some of those who said publicly they were undecided said privately they were opposed to the GOP-backed amendment. Biden aides said he planned to offer his own amendment that would bar physically defacing or burning the flag without addressing whether the act desecrates the flag. Meanwhile, the Emergency Committee to Defend the First Amendment, a private group that opposes the amendment, said Tuesday that retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis Powell had joined in the call to reject the measure. But Powell told The Associated Press: ``I'd rather you just state that I am a member of the committee, without any further comment from me.''

DOC.HEAD: US Not Seeking Doe Resignation, But Doubts He Can Survive Rebel Attack
DOC.TEXT: The United States has not asked Liberian President Samuel Doe to resign, but doesn't believe he can survive a military battle with anti-government rebels, a top U.S. official said Tuesday. Herman Cohen, the secretary of State for African affairs, told a House panel the United States has encouraged both Doe and the National Patriotic Front rebels to end bloody fighting in their country and seek a political settlement, including free and fair elections. Cohen said the U.S. military warships stationed off the coast of Liberia are there solely ``for the purpose of protecting the lives of U.S. citizens, should the level of violence place them in jeopardy at a time when they have no other means of evacuating'' the country. ``There is no intention of using the (U.S) forces for any political end; they are there to preserve American lives,'' he said. ``U.S. forces will not intervene to stop the fighting or to influence the outcome of the conflict in any way,'' he said. The United States have not suggested to Doe that he resign, but has talked with both sides in the conflict. Doe has said he will not seek re-election, but he has not quit his post; the rebels say there can be no elections until Doe is out of office. The United States has cut off aid, except for humanitarian aid, to Liberia because of human rights problems. Moreover, Cohen said the United States has called on Doe and rebel leader Charles Taylor to end human rights abuses and atrocities that have left more than 1,000 dead and 200,000 homeless since December. Church groups have sponsored mediation talks between Doe's forces and those rebels headed by Charles Taylor, who is wanted by the state of Massachusetts on a felony warrant for escaping from prison. Right now, fighting is quiescent with rebel troops gathered outside the Liberian capital of Monrovia at the Firestone Plantation, Cohen said. But he said the rebels, who number more than 5,000, would likely overpower the government forces, whose strength has dwindled to about 1,000. The government army, instead of fighting the guerrillas, has ``taken out against the citizens instead,'' he said. Based on the past performance of government troops, Cohen said ``it's not likely'' they could defend Monrovia, should rebels attack. He said the United States wants the Liberians to ``avoid a terrible battle for Monrovia.'' As for Taylor, Cohen said it is unclear whether he is truly committed to achieving a democratic government because he gives ambiguous answers to questions. In sum, Cohen said the United States believes the Liberians _ not outsiders _ should resolve the country's problems.

DOC.BYLINE: Owner, FAA Officials Defend New Certificate For `Celebrity Airline' ^By DAVID BRISCOE
DOC.TEXT: The revival of a small charter airline known for carrying celebrities but shut down nearly two years ago for safety violations was defended Tuesday by federal authorities and the carrier's owner. ``You do not fly the class of people that we flew unless you have a reliable airplane,'' Earl Holtz, president of Northeast Jet, told a congressional panel. The House Public Works oversight and investigations subcommittee is looking into the Federal Aviation Administration's oversight of small charter and air taxi services. Northeast gained the nickname ``Celebrity Airline'' by ferrying clients such as first ladies Nancy Reagan and Barbara Bush; presidential candidates Michael Dukakis and Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan.; and pop singers Billy Idol, Barry Manilow and Bruce Springsteen on domestic and international flights. Holtz said the company still will accept any paying passengers. His lawyer, Mark Kahan, said most of the passengers are corporate travelers. Three of the airline's former employees told the subcommittee that Holtz deserved to have his license pulled in September 1988. And Susan J. Woodward, a former Northeast Jet vice president, said the company should not have been allowed to resume flights last month as Private Jet Services. Ms. Woodward said the company's management ``abused license, privileges and their employees.'' Former Northeast Jet pilot Thomas Beamer testified that he had been punished for refusing to fly excessive hours or overweight planes and said he received inadequate training. Joan Szemplenkski, a former aircraft scheduler, said she witnessed ``screaming matches'' between Holtz and the company's chief maintenance officer over whether aircraft were airworthy. Former chief pilot William Telfer said the company kept records that showed compliance when ``violations were in fact occurring on a daily basis.'' Holtz said the accusation ``that I skimped on safety to enrich myself is not and never was true.'' He said the company had well-maintained aircraft and a good training program. ``It is grossly unfair for employees with no specific knowledge of the facts to suggest that I fixed problems illegally,'' Holtz said. Loretta Alkalay, assistant chief counsel for FAA's Eastern Region, said the FAA punished Northeast Jet by not allowing Holtz to apply for a new certification for one year. She said that was ``a significant sanction, a significant deterrent.'' FAA regional operations branch manager Frederick Leonellis said the airline was given a new certificate only after meeting a long list of requirements. The FAA, which oversees the safety of all aircraft, checks to see if an airline has proper equipment, qualified personnel and proper maintenance and training programs, officials said. An FAA emergency revocation order grounded the airline. The 19-page order accused Northeast Jet of flying unsafe planes, overworking its pilots, skimping on training and keeping two sets of maintenance records: one for its own use and one for FAA inspectors. The FAA cited more than 70 examples of unsafe or unauthorized practices. National Transportation Safety Board records show four crashes involving the airline and three fatalities since 1980.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Chief Will Recommend Veto If Jobs Aid Provision Stands
DOC.TEXT: William K. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said Tuesday that he would recommend President Bush veto landmark clean air legislation if the proposal contains a controversial jobs protection amendment when it reaches the White House. ``I consider it bad environmental policy, bad social policy and bad economic policy,'' Reilly said in discussing a provision that would assist workers who lose their jobs because of the tougher air pollution requirements. Both the Senate and House are preparing for a conference committee to work out differences in largely similar bills to strengthen federal clean air laws for the first time in 13 years. One of the differences involves an amendment in the House bill that would allow for $250 million to be spent in added unemployment compensation and retraining for workers if forced out of their jobs by the new legislation. The administration says this could force industry spending well above the $21 billion or so annually called for by the Senate version, partly because it would be extremely difficult to tell if a job had been lost because of the provisions of the legislation. Reilly said his objections to this jobs proposal, sponsored by Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va., were strong enough that he would recommend that the president veto the entire bill if that section is not removed by the conference committee. Stressing that the administration is ``not insensitive to people losing their jobs,'' Reilly said that of the 17,000 to 20,000 jobs estimated to be lost by the tougher legislation, only 4,000 of those job losses would occur by 1995. He said the major impact would not come until the next century, giving society time to prepare through use of current job retraining programs. The jobs issues is certain to be one of the main battles in the conference committee debate. An aid package in the Senate sponsored by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., lost by only one vote. Byrd's amendment would have helped only coal miners while the less costly Wise amendment expands the assistance to workers in all industries. Reilly, briefing economics writers on the economic impacts of environmental legislation, said the United States spends between $80 billion to $90 billion annually on pollution control, counting in both government enforcement efforts and clean-up costs borne by industry and consumers. He said the administration projected that environmental spending, which already amounts to 1.5 percent to 1.7 percent of the total U.S. economy, would rise to 2.5 percent of the gross national product by the year 2000. He said this figure would be 3 percent if the costs of cleaning nuclear waste sites is included. Reilly said the administration understood the need ``to do all we can to protect the environment, but to do it in a cost-effective way.''

DOC.HEAD: Numerous Tornadoes Reported in Missouri Valley, Sunny Skies in West
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms battered the lower and middle Missouri Valley and numerous tornadoes were reported Tuesday, as much of the Northeast got drenched, too. The National Weather Service received more than 100 reports of large hail and damaging winds. The thunderstorms also spawned five tornadoes in Nebraska and four in North Dakota. There were 17 reports of large hail in Nebraska and 33 reports of damaging winds in New York state. In the East, afternoon showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front from Pennsylvania to Maine, as well as in southern Florida. Thunderstorms developing along a cold front produced severe weather from North Carolina to New York state Tuesday. Afternoon thunderstorms produced severe weather in the central Gulf Coast states, and thunderstorms developing along a cold front in the nation's midsection produced severe weather across the northern and central Plains region during the late afternoon and evening. Strong southerly winds blew through Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas, as well as from Missouri to Minnesota. Strong northwesterly winds buffeted the northern Plains. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation; skies were sunny in the West. Temperatures rose into the 90s Tuesday afternoon from the southern Atlantic Coast to the southern Plains, with readings near 100 degrees in parts of Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas. In the San Antonio area, the succession of hot days has caused water supplies to drop at the rate of about a foot a day, officials said. Rationing was under consideration in both San Antonio and New Braunfels. ``This is murder, murder, murder,'' said New Braunfels assistant city manager Hector Tamayo. It was 93 degrees in Miami, tying the record for the date set in 1953. Afternoon temperatures were mostly in the 70s from the northern Plains to the Northeast, and in the 60s in the Great Lakes region. Temperatures were in the 60s along the northern Pacific Coast, and soared above 100 degrees in the desert Southwest. The low in Lower 48 was 33 degrees at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Asks Soviets to Allow Experts to Take Part in Exhumations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to clarify that Polish government asking to take part in exhumations, background. Pickup 4th graf pvs `But the' with minor editing thereafter
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday asked the Soviet Union to allow experts from Poland to take part in exhuming the bodies of Polish officers massacred by the Soviet secret police in World War II. The Foreign Ministry sent a diplomatic note to the Soviet Embassy requesting Polish Red Cross experts be allowed to join in the ``exhumation and identification work,'' the official PAP news agency reported. The request followed the disclosure of the probable burial site of some of the 6,200 Polish officers who were held in a prison camp at Ostashkov, 120 miles northwest of Moscow. For 47 years the Soviets denied involvement in the murders of nearly 15,000 Polish officers in Ostashkov and two other prison camps. The crime became known as the Katyn massacre when more than 4,200 bodies of Polish officers were discovered in 1943 in the forest at Katyn. But the burial sites of the rest, the elite of Polish society called up from the reserves and captured after the Red Army invaded eastern Poland in September 1939, remained a mystery. Soviet authorities acknowledged only in April that the officers had been murdered in 1940 by Stalin's NKVD secret police and intelligence agency, not by the Nazis as Moscow had claimed since 1943. Last week, the KGB, the NKVD's successor, identified a park outside the Ukrainian city of Kharkov as the likely burial place of 3,900 of the Polish soldiers who had been held at the Starobielsk camp. On Monday, Soviet officials told a Polish parliament delegation they had located the apparent burial place of at least some of 6,200 officers held at Ostashkov prison, PAP said. The site is in a forest near Miednoye on the Moscow-Leningrad highway north of Kalinin, about 90 miles from Moscow, PAP said. Mass graves of Stalinist victims, most of them Soviets, have been discovered at the site. PAP, quoting sources close to the Polish delegation, said that although no Polish remains have been identified, ``much goes to indicate they rest there.'' A parliamentary delegation planned to visit the Katyn and Kharkov graves and discuss the legal and financial consequences, including claims by the victims' families, PAP said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Considers Constitutional Amendment To Reverse Missouri Tax Case
DOC.TEXT: Conservatives objected Tuesday to a Supreme Court ruling that directed a local tax increase to correct school segregation, but some legal scholars told a Senate panel the case didn't warrant a constitutional amendment to reverse it. At issue is a 5-4 ruling in April that a federal judge could set aside state tax limitations and order local officials to raise taxes to correct a constitutional violation such as racial segregation in schools. The case involved public schools in Kansas City, Mo. Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., has proposed a constitutional amendment to make clear that judges have no powers of taxation. Danforth and other amendment supporters argued that the court ruling was a straightforward example of the judiciary exercising a legislative function by directing a property tax increase in Kansas City. ``The decision is the predictable result of decades of relying ever more heavily on judicial power to solve social and political problems,'' Robert F. Nagel of the University of Colorado School of Law told the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on the Constitution. ``It is the predictable result of power going unchecked.'' But Nagel and other critics of the Supreme Court decision said that if an amendment is not approved, legislation proposed by Sens. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., and Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., would suffice. The measure would limit the remedial powers of federal judges by prohibiting orders ``requiring the federal government or any state or local government to impose any new tax or to increase any existing tax or tax rate.'' Conservative legal scholar Bruce Fein strongly criticized the Danforth proposal for a constitutional amendment, saying it would have a ``horrendous effect ... on simple justice'' by not permitting courts to correct constitutional wrongs in some cases. ``I believe these proposals would foster arbitrary government, throw a dagger at private and economic liberties and subvert the rule of law,'' said Fein. Fein said critics misinterpreted the decision, saying it ``did not endow judges with ... imperial power'' to raise taxes to any level. Joining Fein in opposition to a constitutional amendment was Patricia A. Brannan, a Washington attorney for the Kansas City school district. She said the ruling followed a basic legal principle that judges must have the power to correct constitutional violations. ``To do less would permit the political reluctance to raise taxes to deprive minorities of a remedy for demonstrated constitutional violations,'' Brannan said in a statement. She pointed out that the Supreme Court held 9-0 in the Kansas City case that a judge could not directly impose taxes. The justices allowed the federal judge to block state laws that prevented the board from increasing taxes enough to pay the district's share of the desegregation plan. Missouri law requires voter approval before property taxes can be increased above a certain levy and in some instances a two-thirds majority is necessary. The locally elected school board, she said, now sets the actual levy within limits allowed by the courts. The school board supported several tax increases, but the voters rejected the proposals. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., chairman of the Senate panel, said he remained undecided on the proposals but was ``reluctant to take the constitutional amendment approach.''

DOC.SECOND: Groups Claim U.S. Policy Helps Khmer Rouge
DOC.TEXT: A group of humanitarian, religious and anti-war organizations claimed Tuesday that the U.S. is strengthening the Khmer Rouge, a militant communist faction in Cambodia, through its dealings with that nation. ``There's a great discrepancy between preachment and practice'' in the Bush administration's policy of condemning the Khmer Rouge while aiding factions allied with it, Sidney Peck, co-chairman of an effort to change the U.S. policy, said during a news conference. Public opinion is growing in the United States for blocking not only a return to power but also any form of cooperation with the Khmer Rouge, he said. Peck said the group has been blamed for more than 1 million Cambodian deaths during its 1975-78 rule over the Southeast Asian country. That message was stressed by members of the coalition of 45 organizations during a day of lobbying Congress, said Peck, who heads Mobilization for Survival, a humanitarian aid group. He said a delegation also discussed Cambodia with Richard Solomon, the assistant secretary of state for East Asia. Coalition representatives said the agony of the Cambodian people was being prolonged by U.S. insistence on a comprehensive Cambodian peace package while the country endures deepening hardship from the cutoff of aid from former communist countries in Europe. ``If we continue to say nothing is settled until everything is settled, we may find we have lost everything ... the comprehensive approach is at odds with a peace process approach (and) runs the risk that it won't be settled at all,'' said Jeremy Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists, a peace movement group. The campaign was triggered in part by Senate Democratic leader George Mitchell's recent announcement of Intelligence Committee oversight hearings to determine if the Bush administration's Cambodia policy complied with Congress' bar on use of U.S. funds that had the effect of helping or augmenting Khmer Rouge operations. Mitchell charged in a June 11 floor speech that the administration ``has been slow to realize'' that its current policy ``in effect sanctions the return of the murderous Khmer Rouge.'' Some lawmakers have talked of stronger restrictions and a House subcommittee last week considered ending current ``non-lethal'' U.S. aid to the non-communist factions in Cambodia. David Elder of the American Friends Service Committee, a Quaker organization, said U.S. policy, however intentioned, has had the effect of creating ``a much stronger Khmer Rouge than before ... visible to every visitor.'' The coalition said it has documents and press reports showing that the U.S.-aided non-communist factions headed by Prince Norodom Sinhanouk and Son Sann have collaborated at the highest military and intelligence levels with the Khmer Rouge in their joint fight against the Hun Sen government in Phnom Penh. That government was installed by Vietnamese troops who in 1979 ended Khmer Rouge rule and occupied the country for 11 years.

DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XBLR3
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of people waited in line outside a newly opened federal disaster relief center Tuesday to find out if the government would help them rebuild lives washed away by a flash flood. Nearly 60 flood victims gathered at the Shadyside Community Center, where federal and state agencies began taking applications for low-interest loans, grants and deposit money to help them find temporary lodging. Rainstorms dumped 5{ inches of rain in about three hours Thursday night, swamping two small creeks and washing away homes, cars and trees in and around this rural eastern Ohio village. At least 21 people were killed and 13 were listed as missing. Few people were insured for the damage caused by raging Wegee and Pipe creeks. Some who came to fill out disaster relief applications said they would never recover most of what they lost. Ben Otto said he bought $30,000 worth of flood insurance last September, but estimated his house suffered another $70,000 in damage that the insurance won't cover. ``I got mud up to here in my house,'' Otto said, holding his hands just below his hips. ``I know I'll never get back what it's worth from the government. I don't expect to.'' Ken Gibbons, 41, who crawled into the rafters of his attic when a 25-floot wall of water crashed into his home, said he sustained $300,000 in losses. He said he had been told that he could only recover about $10,400 in government grants. Like many of the relief applicants, Gibbons was bitter. ``There's too much red tape with the government,'' he said. ``They send money freely overseas to other countries, but don't want to do anything to help people here. ... I'm going to move to Florida and live with my daughter and become a beach bum. Let welfare feed me. To hell with this.'' In addition to his house, he said, the flood wiped out his tavern, a Jaguar and a red Corvette convertible and two rental mobile homes. He said the loss of the bar was the hardest blow. ``I had surgery ... to remove a brain tumor, and I wasn't able to hold another job other than that bar,'' Gibbons said. ``I've had that 15 years, and everybody in this town came down there for entertainment. We were the only place around here that had live bands.'' Bruce Connor, 33, and two fellow members of the Sentinels Motorcycle Club showed up in biker gear to file applications for money to replace Harley-Davidson motorcycles they lost to the flood. ``I don't know if they'll accept it or not, but we're going to try, just like everybody else,'' Connor said. ``Some of those bikes were collectors' items, probably worth a lot of money. We had Harleys from the 1920s and '30s, bikes my father and his father had, and tools they used to work on them.'' Gene Neiditch of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, who manages the local application center, said the Sentinels might be reimbursed. ``If those bikes were their primary source of transportation and necessary to the fulfillment of their occupations, then yes, they may qualify,'' he said. FEMA on Monday estimated that 700 homes in Belmont, Jefferson and Harrison counties in the area were damaged or destroyed by the flooding. Neiditch said the first relief checks could be in the hands of recipients in one to two weeks, but that it may take longer in many cases.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwanese Businessmen Learn Hot Dog Business
DOC.TEXT: If you want to learn, consult an expert. So three Taiwanese entrepreneurs came to the Windy City to study the art of making the classic, Chicago-style hot dog. ``We think that the era of hot dog is now,'' said Ko Sheng Yaw, the 32-year-old president of Chicago Foods Co. Ltd. in Taipei. After five days behind the counter at Wolfy's, a hot-dog joint on the North Side, Ko and his two associates will take their new skills home Wednesday with the plan to open five or six hot-dog outlets by year's end. Western fast food is well established in Taiwan; McDonald's, Wendy's, Hardees, Burger King and Pizza Hut all have operations there, according to Ko. But to Taiwanese, a hot dog is a pork or chicken sausage, normally without condiments or bun. ``What I've got to do is introduce the way the real hot dog is to my country fellows,'' Ko said. That means a beef hot dog on a bun, topped with onions, tomatoes, mustard, peppers and a bun-length pickle wedge. But Ko said he'll leave behind the bright green relish Chicagoans favor. To Taiwanese, he said, the color is ``too vivid to be true.'' The men planned to shop for souvenirs to decorate their restaurants _ Chicago Bears paraphernalia, pictures of the Sears Tower _ ``to make it Chicago-connected,'' Ko said. To steep themselves in American marketing and fast-food service, the men visited supermarkets and hot-dog stands, then spent five days working for 65-year-old Mickey Becker, who's run Wolfy's for 24 years. In white plastic aprons and white paper chef's hats, Ko, his sales manager and deputy manager took their places behind the stainless-steel counter. ``We learn how to make the best quality for the customer,'' said the sales manager, Yang Yuncheng, 31, who manned the french-fry vats at lunch hour Tuesday. He has nearly mastered the wrist action necessary to flip the fries in the basket to check for doneness. At about noon, a school group of about 150 teen-agers jammed the restaurant. And the orders started coming. ``This is real rush hour,'' said Ko, who has picked up the jargon, if not the precise syntax, of American English. Ko told Chao Ming, his deputy manager, to put more hamburger buns in the toaster, then pulled a stack of cheese slices from the refrigerator. Yang salted french fries and scooped them into cardboard containers. ``Two tomatoes, two tomatoes,'' reminded Rita Rosenthal, a 13-year Wolfy's veteran, when Ko _ by now splattered with ketchup and mustard _ put just one tomato slice on a hot dog. Ko also is vice president of Vienna Enterprise, which last year contracted with the Chicago-based Vienna Sausage Manufacturing Co. to sell Vienna Beef hot dogs in Taiwan. Vienna Sausage arranged the 10-day Chicago visit for Ko and his staff. ``They have to do it themselves and see the importance of having fresh ingredients and cooking the hot dog to the right temperature, the whole nine yards,'' said Vienna Chairman James Eisenberg. Ko plans to sell hot dogs to grocers and through restaurants. A hot dog fan himself, he plans to promote his product with free samples. ``Of course it will cost a lot, but it will be worth it _ otherwise they won't have their first bite,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Slovak Nationalists Hold Rally to Celebrate Showing In Elections
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 supporters of the Slovak National Party rallied Tuesday in downtown Bratislava to celebrate the party's showing in this month's elections. ``Slovakia to the Slovaks, Slovaks arise,'' the crowd chanted during the one-hour rally in the capital of the Slovak republic. The Slovak National Party, which advocates an independent Slovak state, captured about 11 percent of the overall vote in the June 9-10 elections, winning 15 seats in the country's 300-seat bicameral federal parliament. The party ran only in Slovakia. The winner in Slovakia was Public Against Violence, the sister organization of the Civic Forum in the Czech republic, founded by President Vaclav Havel. The two movements, which led last November's peaceful revolution that overthrew the orthodox Communist regime, won a total of 170 seats in the national Parliament. The Communists came in second and the Christian Democrats a disappointing third in the predominantly Catholic and rural republic in the eastern part of the country. Slovaks represent about a third of the country's 15.5 million people. The election's biggest surprise was the showing of the Slovak nationalists. But they will be excluded from the coalition governments being formed in the republic and at the national level, according to Civic Forum and Public Against Violence. The Slovak nationalists are suspected by their opponents of harboring sympathies for the Nazi-allied Slovak state created during World War II. Party leaders deny these allegations. ``Our program is to create spiritual and material well-being in Slovakia, with the perspective of joining confederated Europe as a developed independent Slovak republic,'' party chairman Vitezslav Moric told The Associated Press. The current Slovak Interior Minister, Vladimir Meciar, a member of Public Against Violence, was entrusted last week with the task of forming the new Slovak government. ``We do not want to join their coalition and they do not want to work with us either,'' Moric said. A leading Public Against Violence official, Peter Tatar, accused the Slovak National Party of exploiting ``the natural patriotic emotions ... which can be stimulated in Slovakia through the inferiority complex of a small nation.'' ``Their image is built on the search for an enemy and they found this enemy in the Czechs, the Hungarian minority and in fact any ethnic group,'' Tatar said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says Mayor Supplied Cocaine; Barry Claims Entrapment
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede and INSERTS new grafs 11-20, bgng Lewis, a, to UPDATE with new testimony on alleged D.C. crack smoking; picks up 13th graf pvs, ``The mayor
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry Trial-Scene
DOC.TEXT: Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, testifying on the first day of Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial, said Tuesday that he and the mayor repeatedly used drugs in the Virgin Islands and smoked crack cocaine in Washington. Lewis described using cocaine with Barry and model Rasheeda Moore once in June 1986 in a hotel room. ``We were all standing in line. We were using straws,'' Lewis said. Prosecutors opened the trial charging that the three-term mayor was ``smoking crack and using cocaine all over town for years.'' Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy countered that Barry was a victim of entrapment and said the trial would reveal ``the depths to which the government was willing to go and did go'' to bring down the mayor of the nation's capital. The two lawyers sparred before the jury while Barry watched intently from the defense table. He wiped his forehead when he heard Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts say jurors would see a government videotape made the night of Barry's arrest showing the mayor ``smoking crack ... lighting with a cigarette lighter. ``Just like this,'' he added, extending his arms and inhaling deeply. Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. He could face up to 26 years in prison and fines of $1.85 million if convicted on all counts. The trial is expected to last upwards of a month. ``While the defendant was preaching `down with dope' to the community, he was putting dope up his nose,'' Roberts told jurors in his opening statement. ``This case is about the other side, the secret side, of Marion Barry.'' Mundy told the 12 jurors and six alternates, ``This is a case about deals the government made with the devil. Approximately seven years ago, the government made a determination that it was going to get Mr. Barry ... and that it was prepared to go to any lengths.'' Lewis, a former city employee who pleaded guilty to cocaine conspiracy charges last November, portrayed the mayor as an experienced drug user. In a Dec. 16, 1988 visit to Lewis' Washington hotel room, Barry shook rocks of crack cocaine out of a matchbox and he returned the next night with crack cocaine hidden in his pants leg. The two men fashioned a homemade pipe to smoke the crack, said Lewis. The mayor told him when he ``was in the Virgin Islands, I take care of him, when I was in D.C. he takes care of me,'' Lewis testified. At one point, said Lewis, the mayor sent him out to buy crack cocaine on the streets, which Lewis called a ``very easy'' task.'' Lewis also said the two men used drugs at two Virgin Islands hotels and aboard two boats in trips the mayor made to the islands in 1986 and 1988. ``How many packets (of crack) did you and Mr. Barry smoke during his trip to the Virgin Islands'' in 1988? asked Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin. ``I would say somewhere near two dozen packets,'' replied Lewis. ``Who smoked more, you or Mr. Barry?'' ``The mayor did,'' said Lewis. ``He smoked more than I do.'' Lewis told of using cocaine supplied by Barry in a Virgin Islands hotel room in June 1986 and was asked whether anyone else used the drug. ``The mayor, Miss Moore,'' Lewis said. Lewis testified Barry also smoked marijuana on a boat trip later that day. Lewis said he encouraged Moore, who cooperated in Barry's Jan. 18 arrest at a Washington hotel, and the mayor to use cocaine in the boat's bathroom, out of sight of another couple on the cruise. They made repeated trips to the lavatory, Lewis testified. He said that during a March 1988 trip, the mayor gave him $300 and asked him to buy crack cocaine. Lewis, Barry and several others consumed ``between 15 and 18 bags'' of the cocaine that had been bought with the $300, Lewis testified. ``Then I went and bought some more,'' he said. When Retchin asked Lewis how crack cocaine had made him feel, Lewis said, ``You feel good. You feel great, as a matter of fact.'' Barry smiled broadly as Lewis further described the cocaine high. Lewis' testimony that he obtained drugs for the mayor, got money from the mayor, and used drugs with him all relate to the felony perjury charges against Barry. The mayor told a grand jury in January 1989 that he had never given anything of value to Lewis, used drugs with him or seen Lewis use or sell drugs, according to the indictment. In his opening argument, Roberts portrayed Barry as a regular drug user whose friends and acquaintances brought drugs to him even at his City Hall office.

DOC.HEAD: East German Leaders Get Death Threats After Red Army Captures
DOC.TEXT: East German leaders have been receiving death threats since the start of a sweep against leftist terrorists sheltered by the former hard-line Communist government, an official said Tuesday. East Germany's interior minister said a tip from a former member of the country's now-disbanded Stasi secret police led police Monday to Henning Beer, 31, suspected in the 1981 bombing of a U.S. Air Force Base in West Germany. Beer was the ninth suspected member of the left-wing West German Red Army Faction terrorist group captured since the sweep began on June 6. It has been widely believed the secret police helped fugitive members of the Red Army Faction resettle in the East. East Germany Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel said since the arrests began, his office has been receiving up to five anonymous death threat letters each day. Diestel said the threats are aimed at him, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and other officials. Red Army Faction members often claim responsibility for their actions in the name of killed or imprisoned leftist terrorists. There are believed to be several dozen active members and supporters of the Red Army Faction still at large. In an interview with West German television Diestel said: ``We will continue to do our job.'' Interior Minister Dietmar Schlee of West Germany's Baden-Wuerttemberg state told reporters in East Berlin he fears reprisal attacks in West Germany as a result of the crackdown. The Red Army Faction has been waging attacks against NATO, U.S. and West German industrial targets since the early 1970s. Among those killed were a U.S. soldier and leading West German bankers and industrialists. The most recent victim, Deutsche Bank chief Alfred Herrhausen, was killed in a November bombing attack. Terrorists claimed responsibility for the Herrhausen killing in the name of the ``Commando Wolfgang Beer.'' Wolfgang Beer, brother of the suspected terrorist arrested Monday night was a Red Army Faction member killed in a July 1980 automobile accident. Leftist radicals have claimed that authorities engineered his death. Diestel said that harboring West German terrorists was the ``personal hobby'' of former Communist leader Erich Honecker and his ousted security chief, Erich Mielke. Diestel said there were no indications the terrorists used East Germany as a base of operations for their attacks in West Germany. Beer and fugitive suspected terrorist Silke Maier-Witt, 40, were both arrested Monday in Neubrandeburg, according to Diestel. He said that for the first time a member of the disbanded Stasi secret police give key information aiding in the capture, but provided no further details. Both Beer and Ms. Maier-Witt had been living in East Germany under false names. Diestel said he expects both to be tried in West Germany, along with the others recently captured. In Karlsruhe, West Germany, a spokesman for the chief federal prosecutor's office said Henning Beer is suspected in the Aug. 31, 1981, bombing of Ramstein Air Base. That attack in West Germany seriously injured 17 people. Helmut Pohl, a member of the Red Army Faction has already been tried and convicted of taking part in the Ramstein bombing.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at Reforms in South Africa Since September 1989
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronological look at the progress of reform in South Africa's apartheid system of racial separation:

Sept. 6 _ President F. W. de Klerk launches a series of reforms, allowing peaceful demonstrations and the opening of segregated beaches. Oct. 15 _ Six African National Congress leaders imprisoned for more than 25 years, including Walter Sisulu, are released. Two weeks later, the first legal ANC rally in 30 years is held.

Feb. 2 _ President de Klerk legalizes the ANC and more than 60 other opposition groups, suspends the death penalty, and eases emergency restrictions. Feb. 11 _ Nelson Mandela is released after serving 27 years in prison. May 2-4 _ The ANC and the South African government hold their first talks, and agree to work together to end violence and negotiate a new constitution. June 7 _ President de Klerk ends the national state of emergency, except in violence-torn Natal province. June 19 _ President de Klerk repeals the Separate Amenities Act. The act, passed in 1953, gave governments and privately owned enterprises the right to reserve facilities for whites such as parks, hotels, swimming pools, toilets and recreation centers.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: `Not Happy' Over Informatin Gap
With AM-Transport Plane a0658
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney expressed irritation Tuesday that his months-long review of the Pentagon's costliest aircraft programs failed to turn up problems in the Navy's planned new attack plane, the A-12. ``I was not happy to discover that the contractors were having problems with the A-12. I have had sessions in which I've expressed my views on that subject,'' Cheney told reporters following a budget briefing at the Pentagon. Cheney was queried about the Navy's decision to order a special review of the secret program, which came after the plane's joint developers announced a delay in its progress _ a delay widely interpreted as foreshadowing extra costs. Officials at McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp., had reported that the first flight of the plane would be delayed until late 1991. The problems reportedly involve the plane's composite materials, which save weight and lower radar reflections, but are very difficult to fabricate into aircraft parts. The plane is considered to be the Navy's top aircraft priority, given that it is destined to replace the service's aging fleet of A-6 Intruder all-weather attack planes, a point Cheney stressed. ``We need the A-12 soon as we can get it into the force. So it remains a priority program,'' he said. In a concession to congressional budget cutters, Cheney announced in April that he was sharply cutting the proposed A-12 purchase. Although the Navy had originally planned to buy 858 of the long-range, carrier-based aircraft, the secretary said he envisioned buying only 620. No cost for the super-secret program has been made public, but it has been reported that the plane was being developed under a $4.8 billion fixed price contract. Extended production would cost tens of billions more. The secretary was asked whether he was unhappy that the problems with the aircraft had not surfaced during the review, which supposedly included top-to-bottom looks at the B-2 Stealth bomber, the C-17 transport plane and other advanced tactical fighter programs. ``We're going to continue to work the problem to see if we can, in fact, get better data than we've had to date,'' Cheney replied. ``One of the problems you're faced with from time to time in this business, is ... the problems of cost overruns and slips in schedule,'' Cheney said, adding, ``But, obviously, I was not happy with the way the A-12 thing was handled.'' The secretary, pressed why the problems didn't emerge in the review, said, ``That's the question I've asked and I don't have all the answers yet.'' He said he's made his dissatisfaction known ``in terms of my personal conversations with the people who work for me, but I prefer to keep those matters personal.'' Cheney met last week on the A-12 with the chief executive officers of McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics, as well as Deputy Secretary Donald Atwood, Undersecretary of Defense for Acquisition John Betti and Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III.

DOC.HEAD: After Three Months, Government Rests Case Against Mrs. Marcos
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution rested its case Tuesday in the federal fraud trial of former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos and Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, and defense lawyers said they planned to call no witnesses. The jury is to begin deliberations next week following motions and closing arguments. ``In our view, the government has utterly failed in its case. You only call witnesses if you have a case to rebut,'' said Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerry Spence. The prosecution called 95 witnesses during the three-month trial in U.S. District Court in Manhattan. They included former Marcos associates who described a pattern of corruption they said enriched Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos, during his 20 years in power. Other witnesses traced the flow of more than $220 million in allegedly stolen funds from secret Manila bank accounts through Swiss and U.S. banks to the purchase of four New York commercial buildings, jewelry and art works. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. If convicted, she faces a maximum of 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine. Khashoggi is accused of helpingn, Peterson said Khashoggi told him in January 1986, two months before the court order, that he had acquired ``an interest'' in several New York buildings.

DOC.HEAD: Namibian President Seeks Development Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout; adds byline
DOC.TEXT: The new president of Namibia, a socialist who spent 30 years in exile, asked President Bush Tuesday to increase aid to his newly independent nation. President Sam Nujoma said Bush was ``quite positive'' in his response when Nujoma asked for an increase in the $10 million in assistance already promised by the United States. However, administration officials said no further aid was immediately envisioned for the southwest African nation although Bush told Nujoma that the United States wants to provide moral support for the emerging democracy and its move to a free market economy. The U.S. assistance is less than that promised by Britain, India and the Nordic countries. But neither the Soviet Union nor South Africa has pledged any money yet, Nujoma said. He did not say how much more money he was seeking from the U.S. He will travel to the United Nations later this week to seek support from the international community. In particular, the 1.5 Namibians need help in education, housing, health care and agricultural and rural development. ``We would do whatever we could to be helpful,'' said an administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Another official said the main purpose of Bush's meeting with Nujoma was to encourage the new president's efforts toward a mixed economy and moderation of his socialist views. The White House also announced Tuesday that Bush will name Genta Hawkins Holmes ambassador to Namibia. Holmes is the deputy chief of mission at the U.S. embassy in Pretoria, South Africa, and previously served as deputy chief of mission in Haiti and Malawi. Namibia formally gained its independence from 75 years of South African rule on March 21 when power was turned over to an independent government headed by Nujoma. Namibia was under South Africa's control as a trusteeship until U.N. supervised elections were held last November. The independence process occurred after a guerrilla war lasting nearly 30 years that was waged by black nationalists. Nujoma heads the South West Africa People's Organization, the rebel group that fought the war and won the most votes in the balloting last fall. U.S. officials see Namibia as an example of a general trend toward democratic rule in Africa. Namibia is one of the first African countries to gain independence with an elected government, and independent judiciary and curbs on the power of the executive. Nujoma is focusing his attention on economic reform. ``We have requested the U.S. government to increase financial support the agricultural, rural development, education, health care ... in order to uplift the standard of living for the people of Namibia,'' Nujoma told reporters after his meeting with Bush. He said his country is grateful for the $10 million offered by the United States, but needs more to help cope with debts left by the South African government. Namibia's per capita income of $1,000 a year is among the highest in Africa, but it is partly based on South African aid, which is ending with independence. The country faces a $191 million budget deficit this year on an overall budget of just over $766 million. The Bush administration lifted economic sanctions against Namibia when the country became independent. The sanctions were directed against South Africa and were carried over to Namibia because it was under South African control. The sanctions remain in place against South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Harassment Not Grounds for Retaliation, State Dept. Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS four grafs Xu testimony
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has documented at least 25 cases of harassment and intimidation of Chinese students by their own government in the United States, but the State Department does not believe that is grounds for sanctions against Beijing, a department official said Tuesday. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., reacting to information given in a closed-door FBI briefing, called the administration's position ``shocking'' and bluntly told the official: ``I'm not sure we're living in the same universe.'' Solarz said the briefing clearly showed a consistent pattern of intimidation that requires sanctions under a law he wrote nine years ago. ``It's going on in every region of the country,'' said Solarz, who added that he believed the evidence points to hundreds of cases in which Chinese Embassy officials have threatened students in the United States. The Bush administration has announced its intention to renew most-favored-nation trading status for China, almost exactly a year after Beijing's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in and around Tiananmen Square. Kent Wiedemann, director of the State Department's office of Chinese affairs, said the contacts with students involved relatively few of the Chinese Embassy and consular officials in the United States and represented ``a very sporadic pattern.'' ``They were mostly in 1989, in the summer and fall, and have dwindled to basically nothing by the beginning of this year,'' Wiedemann told a joint hearing of Solarz's Asia subcommittee and the human rights subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The contacts usually involved threats or implied threats of consequences for students when they return to China, or to their families, if they continued pro-democracy activities, he said. But they were ``sufficiently few in number and sufficiently indirect as to not be a consistent pattern'' as the law defines it, he said.
