Solarz bristled at the testimony, saying the administration ``seems to be more interested in kowtowing to China than in calling a spade a spade.'' He pointed to documents produced by Lin Xu, a former Chinese Embassy official in Washington who sought political asylum in the United States on May 2. The papers, which Wiedemann said he believes authentic, describe a plan to pressure the most activist students into inaction by threatening not to renew passports or to deny their families in China permission to come to the United States for visits. Xu, testifying later before the subcommittees, said the harassment has intensified this year. Speaking through a translator, he said the Embassy's activities included keeping dossiers on activist students, videotaping protests, enlisting ``professional students'' to spy on their peers and warning students not to lobby Congress on behalf of legislation protecting them from deportation. He said about 200 students were placed into ``Category Five,'' the group of the most active pro-democracy leaders who were subjected to the greatest intimidation. There are about 40,000 Chinese students in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Ask for Aid for Millions Affected by Chernobyl Disaster
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet official said it could take more than 200 years to clean up damage from the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear accident and asked for international aid to help 2 million people affected by the disaster. The sudden plea _ more than four years after the accident _ comes after Soviet scientists said the situation was much worse than Moscow had portrayed. One-fifth of the republic of Byelorussia's more than 10 million people have to be moved from areas contaminated by radiation, said Victor Borovikov, a Byelorussia diplomat. He said that includes 27 cities and more than 2,600 villages. Byelorussia, which has no nuclear power plants, was hit by 70fallout from the nuclear power plant at Chernobyl, in the Soviet Republic of Ukraine. Borovikov said 25,000 people were ev percent of the acuated after the April 26, 1986, nuclear plant disaster. But, he said, ``then Moscow said there was no panic, no danger. In the past four years we've realized the situation was not so simple.'' He said the republic had planned to spend $14 billion to move 180,000 people from the high-radiation zone by the end of 1995 but would now try to do it by the end of 1991. Borovikov was in Brussels for the departure Wednesday of a truck convoy carrying donated children'He said experts now say it could take up to 200 years ``to totally wipe out'' effects of the accident, so authorities are focusing on reducing the damage. ``We have no experience in this field, which is why we're asking for international help,'' said Borovikov, the republic's U.N. ambassador in Vienna. Borovikov said immediately after the accident people were paid by the Soviet authorities to stay in the contaminated zones but they now are demanding immediate relocation. He said people in uncontaminated areas don't ``want to accept the newcomers. They tell their children not to play with the children of the newcomers.'' At least 31 people were killed after a nuclear reactor exploded at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant. It was the worst nuclear accident in history.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Suggests Western Aid for Soviets
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand said in an interview published Tuesday that the European Community and other wealthy Western countries should consider extending financial aid to the Soviet Union. Mitterrand told the newspaper Le Monde that he hoped the EC and other wealthy nations would consider the possibility of ``financial, commercial and technical aid'' to the Soviets. He said he would make a proposal to this effect at the upcoming EC summit meeting in Dublin, Ireland, and the subsequent summit in Houston of leaders of the seven major Western industrial democracies. ``If (Soviet President) Mikhail Gorbachev succeeds, that would be in the interest of all,'' Mitterrand told the newspaper. ``That would mean that he would have improved the quality of life for the Soviets and had relaxed, decentralized and adapted the Soviet Union's constitutional and political system. I believe he is capable of this, although it is a terribly difficult task.''

DOC.NOTE: EDs: RETRANSMITS a0703 to restore keyword line
DOC.HEAD: Groups Claim U.S. Policy Helps Khmer Rouge
DOC.TEXT: A group of humanitarian, religious and anti-war organizations claimed Tuesday that the U.S. is strengthening the Khmer Rouge, a militant communist faction in Cambodia, through its dealings with that nation. ``There's a great discrepancy between preachment and practice'' in the Bush administration's policy of condemning the Khmer Rouge while aiding factions allied with it, Sidney Peck, co-chairman of an effort to change the U.S. policy, said during a news conference. Public opinion is growing in the United States for blocking not only a return to power but also any form of cooperation with the Khmer Rouge, he said. Peck said the group has been blamed for more than 1 million Cambodian deaths during its 1975-78 rule over the Southeast Asian country. That message was stressed by members of the coalition of 45 organizations during a day of lobbying Congress, said Peck, who heads Mobilization for Survival, a humanitarian aid group. He said a delegation also discussed Cambodia with Richard Solomon, the assistant secretary of state for East Asia. Coalition representatives said the agony of the Cambodian people was being prolonged by U.S. insistence on a comprehensive Cambodian peace package while the country endures deepening hardship from the cutoff of aid from former communist countries in Europe. ``If we continue to say nothing is settled until everything is settled, we may find we have lost everything ... the comprehensive approach is at odds with a peace process approach (and) runs the risk that it won't be settled at all,'' said Jeremy Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists, a peace movement group. The campaign was triggered in part by Senate Democratic leader George Mitchell's recent announcement of Intelligence Committee oversight hearings to determine if the Bush administration's Cambodia policy complied with Congress' bar on use of U.S. funds that had the effect of helping or augmenting Khmer Rouge operations. Mitchell charged in a June 11 floor speech that the administration ``has been slow to realize'' that its current policy ``in effect sanctions the return of the murderous Khmer Rouge.'' Some lawmakers have talked of stronger restrictions and a House subcommittee last week considered ending current ``non-lethal'' U.S. aid to the non-communist factions in Cambodia. David Elder of the American Friends Service Committee, a Quaker organization, said U.S. policy, however intentioned, has had the effect of creating ``a much stronger Khmer Rouge than before ... visible to every visitor.'' The coalition said it has documents and press reports showing that the U.S.-aided non-communist factions headed by Prince Norodom Sinhanouk and Son Sann have collaborated at the highest military and intelligence levels with the Khmer Rouge in their joint fight against the Hun Sen government in Phnom Penh. That government was installed by Vietnamese troops who in 1979 ended Khmer Rouge rule and occupied the country for 11 years.

DOC.HEAD: No Panic in Cockpit or Control Towers as Avianca Crashed, Tapes Show
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that plane was on go-around for another landing when it crashed, not in holding pattern; SUBS 13th graf: ``Had the,'' for the same rason
DOC.TEXT: An eerie calm marked the conversations between the copilot and air traffic controllers before a Colombian jetliner ran out of fuel and crashed last January in New York, according to tapes played Tuesday by federal regulators. Avianca Flight 52 plowed into a hillside in suburban Cove Neck, Long Island, killing 73 of 158 aboard, including the three-man cockpit crew. The disaster occurred Jan. 25 after the plane missed its first approach to Kennedy International Airport and was going around for another attempt. On the tapes played at Federal Aviation Administration headquarters, the copilot sounded almost blase as he told air traffic controllers the plane was running low on fuel. ``Climb and maintain 3,000 and, uh, we're running out of fuel, sir,'' the copilot told a controller after the plane missed its first approach to Kennedy in heavy fog and wind. Asked whether the plane had enough fuel to fly 15 miles to the northeast and turn around for another approach, the copilot said almost timidly, ``I guess so. Thank you very much.'' Nor was there a trace of panic when, minutes later, the Avianca copilot radioed: ``Avianca zero-five-two, we just, ah, lost two engines and we need priority, please.'' The controller then told the plane to turn left, but Avianca 52 never replied. In between giving instructions to another plane, the controller calmly called twice again for Flight 52. No answer. Then the controller said evenly, ``Avianca zero-five-two radar contact lost.'' By then, the plane had crashed in Cove Neck, an affluent New York City suburb. The flight had originated in Bogota and Medellin, Colombia. The National Transportation Safety Board scheduled hearings Wednesday and Thursday in Melville, N.Y., into the cause of the crash. The tapes played Tuesday confirmed earlier reports that the copilot never used the word ``emergency'' in describing the plane's situation. According to transcripts of the cockpit conversations, released in March, the pilot told the copilot twice in Spanish to tell air traffic controllers the plane was in emergency. Had the copilot used the word ``emergency,'' the plane would have gotten immediate clearance to land. Instead, it was kept in a holding pattern for more than an hour before starting its first landing approach. The tapes also underscored how many flights were stacked up outside Kennedy that evening. Another flight, on American Airlines, also reported having ``enough fuel for the approach and landing and that's it.'' Several flights reported encountering wind shear, a dangerous, unpredictable crosswind. At one point, a controller in the Kennedy tower got confused as to whether he was talking to an Avensa flight or the doomed Avianca jet.

DOC.HEAD: East German Prime Minister Says NATO Must be Modified
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said Tuesday that a unified Germany cannot belong to NATO unless the organization's structure and strategies are ``radically modified.'' De Maiziere said the unification of East Germany and West Germany should be seen as part of a pan-European process and stressed that the future security of Europe should be based on ``collective'' structures. One must not ``displace the blocs but go beyond them,'' he said. But he added that ``intermediary structures'' were necessary. ``A united Germany belonging to NATO would not be acceptable to our neighbors to the East unless the structures and strategies of NATO are radically modified,'' de Maiziere said. He was speaking at a news conference at the end of a two-day visit. He expressed hope that at the July meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization progress would be made on this issue. De Maiziere also expressed concern that West German companies were exporting products to East Germany and not moving factories to produce such goods into the East. ``This evolution risks dividing Germany anew,'' he said, ``a rich one and a poor one. ... There, history has already left us a heavy heritage.''

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Panel Says FEC Ruled Improperly In Campaign Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court panel ruled Tuesday that the Federal Election Commission ruled improperly that spending limits had not been exceeded in the 1983 Senate campaign of Dan Evans in Washington State. The court reversed an earlier U.S. District Court decision approving of the FEC's action. The case was sent back to the lower court for reconsideration. The citizens lobby group, Common Cause, had complained to the election commission that two Republican political action committees were affiliated and had ``coordinated'' their spending on Evans behalf. Together the funds exceeded the federal limit. The groups were the Republican National Independent Expenditure Committee (RNIEC) and the National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC). Evans, who had been appointed to fill the seat left vacant by the death of Sen. Henry M. Jackson, won a full term in a special election in November 1983. He has since left the Senate. ``We are unable to uphold the commission's decision ... because it gives no indication that the agency considered whether the NRSC and the RNIEC were affiliated,'' said the appeals court. ``The brief lacks any discussion of the affiliation issue that is independent of the analysis of the separate coordination issue.'' Under the law, affiliated political action committers are those that are established, financed, maintained or controlled by the same person or group. In the course of the 1983 campaign, Democrats had complained that RNIEC, which had been set up by Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., spent $185,000 in ``electiongrams' to Republicans in Washington State urging them to turn out to vote in the special election. The RNSC already had put the maximum $260,000 into Evans' race. Common cause claimed Rodney Smith served as financial director and treasurer of the NRSC until two months before he became a co-founder of the other group and that Heinz continued to be a member of NRSC a short time after he became involved with RNIEC. The appeals court said ``there is simply no indication'' that the FEC ever considered whether Smith or Heinz had authority or influence over the two committees.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Scores Railroad, Pipeline Company In Double Accident
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety investigators blamed both a railroad and a pipeline company Tuesday for inadequate procedures in a May 1989 derailment and resulting pipeline explosion that killed six people in San Bernardino, Calif. The National Transportation Safety Board said the Calnev Pipe Line Co. gasoline pipeline was damaged by earth-moving equipment clearing the 69-car Southern Pacific train that ran off the rails into several houses after speeding out of control down an incline. Four people were killed in the May 12 derailment and two in the petroleum pipeline explosion and fire nearly two weeks later. The board said the probable cause of the train derailment was failure to determine the accurate weight for the train on that run,; failure to communicate to communicate to the engineer that fewer engines than he thought had working dynamic brakes and the inadequacy of Southern Pacific rules on allowable speed and brake operation down the incline. Dynamic braking is the running of the electric motors on the engine as generators and dissipating the electrical energy thus produced in a bank of resistors. The NTSB blamed the pipeline accident on inadequate testing and inspection of the line following the derailment. It said Calnev's failure to inspect and test check valves on the 14-inch pipe also contributed to the accident. The four-member board, which investigates all major transportation and pipeline accidents, issued 23 recommendations for federal and local action. The independent board. which held a hearing on the accident last year in San Bernardino, has no regulatory powers but its recommendations often lead to new procedures to improve safety. The board advised Southern Pacific to require train dispatchers and train operators to improve communication on condition of the train, the number of locomotives with functioning dynamic brakes, the tonnage of the train and other items critical to safety. Investigators determined that only three of the six locomotives on the Southern Pacific train had functioning dynamic brakes while the engineer in the lead engine thought he had four. The train's total weight was incorrectly estimated in Southern Pacific's computerized system at 6,150 tons when it was actually 9,000 tons, board staff investigators said, and the railroad's computers could still list the wrong weights for operating crews even after changes made by Southern Pacific following the accident. ``Based on actual tonnage, available dynamic brakes and Southern Pacific operating rules, (the train) should not have been permitted to operate down the 2.2 percent grade,'' the board said in its conclusions. ``The head-end engineer may have been able to bring the train safely down the hill had he crested the hill at 15 mph, which he would have been required to do if the dispatcher had informed him of the correct trailing tonnage.'' It said the railroad's operating rules provided ``inadequate guidance to the head engineer on the allowable speed'' and air brake settings down the grade. It recommended that Calnev test all mainline check valves annually.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Maintains Cool Stance Toward Jerusalem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds new 7th and 8th grafs with quotes to CLARIFY that U.S. not turning back on Middle East situation; pickup up 7th graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration responded coolly on Tuesday to an Israeli peace overture to Syria and dealt cautiously with the new government in Jerusalem. The administration kept talking to the Palestine Liberation Organization, even as it withheld a judgment on the way Chairman Yasser Arafat has handled an attempt by guerrillas to raid a Tel Aviv beach last month. A State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said he knew of no plans to invite the new Israeli foreign minister, David Levy, to Washington. The usually warm relations with Israel turned chilly last week when Secretary of State James A. Baker III questioned Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's commitment to peace talks. ``The phone number (of the White House switchboard) is 202-456-1414,'' he said in remarks during a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing. ``When you're serious about peace, call us.'' On Monday, in another thrust at Shamir's hard-line Likud government, the White House disclosed President Bush had written the prime minister to find out whether he supports his own plan for Palestinian elections. In the letter, Bush urged Shamir to open a dialogue with Palestinian Arabs. Shamir, who last year proposed negotiations with elected Palestinian representatives on the West Bank and in Gaza, said Monday he would reply to Bush. Despite the tensions in U.S.-Israeli relations, a senior administration official said that Washington ``is not going to turn its back on the Middle East situation, no matter what happens. We have a lot of friends out there, both in Israel and in Arab countries. ``We will work every hard to stay engaged,'' the official said, insisting on anonymity. The official added, ``There is absolutely no daylight between the president and Secretary Baker'' on the Middle East. On Tuesday, the State Department commented tersely on Shamir's invitation to President Hafez Assad of Syria to visit Jerusalem for peace talks. ``The U.S. supports contacts between Israel and its neighbors,'' Boucher said at the daily State Department briefing. He used the same word _ ``contacts'' _ to describe the talks Robert Pelletreau Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia, has held with PLO officials even after the Palestine Liberation Front claimed responsibility for the attempted May 30 raid on Tel Aviv. ``There have been continuing contacts ... but I don't have any details to add,'' Boucher said. Abul Abbas, leader of the PLF, is a member of the PLO Executive Committee. The State Department has been urging Arafat to denounce the raid and discipline Abbas. ``When we have something to say, we'll say it,'' Boucher said to a question about the 16-month U.S. dialogue. Shamir's invitation to Assad appeared to be an attempt to show the Bush administration the new government in Jerusalem seeks peace with its Arab neighbors. Last Tuesday, the Israeli Cabinet secretary, Eliakhim Rubinstein, flew to Washington to inform the Bush administration the Shamir government is determined to come to peace terms with its neighbors. Rubinstein met with Robert Kimmitt, the under secretary of state for political affairs; Dennis Ross, the head of the State Department's policy planning staff; and John Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for the Near East. Meanwhile, U.S. Ambassador William Brown met in Israel with Shamir and with Levy, who is recovering from a mild heart attack. Boucher said he knew of no invitation to Levy, who is largely an unknown figure to U.S. policy-makers, to visit Washington. Nor, Boucher said, did he know of any telephone contacts between Baker and Levy. ``We have an embassy there and we're in very close touch with the Israeli government all the time about a variety of issues,'' the spokesman said. Baker dealt closely with Levy's predecessor, Moshe Arens, the American-educated engineer who has shifted to defense minister. Unlike Arens, who grew up in New York City, and most prominent Israelis, Levy does not speak English.

DOC.HEAD: Chattanooga Publisher Roy McDonald Dead At 88
DOC.TEXT: Publisher Roy McDonald, who turned a free weekly newspaper into one of Tennessee's most successful and distinctive papers, died Tuesday at age 88. McDonald, founder and owner of the Chattanooga News-Free Press and the Chattanooga Publishing Co., died in his sleep at his home on nearby Lookout Mountain, family members said. Known to friends, family and the city as ``Mr. Roy,'' McDonald had a reputation as both a hard-nosed businessman and a generous boss who earned his employees' loyalty. The publisher, who even in his 80s remained a daily fixture in the News-Free Press newsroom, worked in his office as usual Monday, the day before he died. McDonald was remembered for his circulation battles with The Chattanooga Times, which ended in an antitrust settlement and a joint operating agreement with the other paper. ``I knew him both as a formidable competitor and as a fair and collegial partner,'' said Ruth S. Holmberg, publisher of The Chattanooga Times. ``His wit and personal charm, his strongly held views, his faultless memory, his fierce loyalty to family and friends, his devotion to his craft all combined to create one of the most memorable persons in my life.'' McDonald, who proudly called himself ``a merchant, not a journalist,'' started the Free Press in 1933 as an advertising circular delivered door-to-door at no charge. In 1936, it became a daily paper with afternoon and Sunday editions, and three years later McDonald bought the financially troubled Chattanooga News to create the current paper. The News-Free Press has a conservative editorial policy and a style that includes a standard streamer headline on the front page and many photographs. ``I always felt that running a picture was cheaper than setting type,'' said McDonald, who routinely spent part of each afternoon laying out ads for the next day's paper. ``The only thing you were out was newsprint.'' Funeral services were set for Friday. Survivors include his wife, Elizabeth McDonald, and five children: Frank McDonald, the newspaper's president; Helen Exum, Betsy Anderson, Dr. Martha McDonald of Memphis and Nancy Reinke of Arlington, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lankan Military Blasts Rebel Positions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 15th pvs `In the' to UPDATE with assassination of Tamil leaders in India. Pickup 16th graf pvs, `The cease-fire...'
DOC.TEXT: Government troops blasted and burned rebel bunkers Tuesday, pushing Tamil Tiger guerrillas into jungles in the east, the military said. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told Parliament the offensive would crush the rebels. ``There is no escape for the Tigers. ... They will have to die here,'' he said. In other eastern areas and in the north, the rebel force _ known as the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam _ launched its own offensive and relentlessly rained government positions with mortars and rockets, military officials said. The military officials, who cannot be named under briefing rules, said at least three rebels were killed and three policemen injured when commandos clashed with the Tigers near Tirrukkovil in eastern Ampara district. They said a rebel leader, identified only as Dayaparan, was fatally shot by soldiers in northern Vavuniya district, where the guerrillas stepped up rocket and mortar attacks on a military camp. According to reports by witnesses, military sources and Tiger officials, about 1,000 people have died in fighting that began June 11 when a 13-month-old cease-fire collapsed. The guerrillas have been fighting since 1973 for a separate homeland. The Tigers apparently remained in control of the predominantly Tamil north. But the government attack on their bunkers drove them from Batticoloa district in the east. The Tigers alleged Tuesday that the government offensive had forced more than 100,000 Tamils and Moslems to flee their homes in the district. Batticaloa town, 136 miles from Colombo on the eastern coast, had been the flashpoint in the week's fighting. Sri Lankan military officials in Colombo said dozens of armored personnel carriers and soldiers on foot moved out of an air base and a military camp Tuesday and blasted their way into Batticaloa town. Residents contacted by telephone said they heard bombs explode and could see columns of smoke. The residents, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said civilians stayed inside when the soldiers moved in. The military officials said soldiers first cordoned the town, then destroyed rebel bunkers and cleared land mines and booby traps. Hundreds of troop reinforcements Tuesday reached the besieged military camps at Kiran and Kalawanchukudi in Batticaloa district, forcing the Tigers to retreat into the jungles, the officials said. In the northern Jaffna peninsula, soldiers used helicopters and armored cars to repulse a rebel attack, they said. In the Indian city of Madras, six unidentified gunmen burst into a house where moderate Sri Lankan Tamil leaders were staying and opened fire, killing 13 people, including at least seven of the leaders, the Press Trust of India reported. Madras, the capital of India's Tamil Nadu state, has been used as a base by several Sri Lankan separatist groups. Most of India's 60 million Tamils live in Tamil Nadu, which is separated from Sri Lanka by a narrow sea strait. The cease-fire was called in May 1989 after the two sides opened negotiations to end the Tamil revolt against the Sinhalese-dominated government. At least 11,000 people have been killed in fighting since 1983. During negotiations, the government had pledged to delegate provincial autonomy to the Tamils in the north and the east, where the rebels control most of the major towns. At the same time, it allowed the Tigers virtually a free hand in the region. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, and they claim they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese who make up 75 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Excalibur Opens with Medieval Fanfare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0740 to CORRECT writethru designator, restore dropped grafs 3-5, `An estimated ...' SUBS 13th graf, `Glenn Shaeffer ...,' to CORRECT spelling to Schaeffer.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto VG1
DOC.TEXT: The world's largest hotel _ a giant castle with court jesters, friendly dragons, slot machines and poker tables _ opened with medieval fanfare Tuesday on the Las Vegas Strip. The 4,032-room Excalibur is the latest effort to lure middle America to this gaming capital. It was built for a modest $290 million, less than half the pricetag of the recently-opened Mirage hotel. Rooms start at $45 a night. An estimated 30,000 tourists and local residents swarmed into the sprawling resort for the ribbon-cutting, and a flood of the curious swept through the main entrance before the ceremony was done. Hotel executives stood aside as customers lined up by the hundreds at check-in counters and set slot machines whirring. ``This shows that bigger can be better,'' Gov. Bob Miller said. Hotel officials expected a full house Tuesday night. Hundreds of Las Vegas business, political and social figures received a sneak preview Monday night. ``Isn't this the most sensational thing you've ever seen?'' actor Ernest Borgnine enthused as he watched a knight on a white horse prance across a lobby. ``Just look at this. What can you possibly say?'' Minstrels, jugglers and harpists entertained guests, a 10-foot dragon cavorted and a man in a suit of armor walked stiffly amid the guests. The entertainers will be standard fare at the hotel, which mixes some of the aura of a theme park with the glitz of a casino. Tuesday's formal opening marked a milestone for Circus Circus Enterprises Inc., the gaming-hotel operation that has carved a niche for middle America in Nevada. The $1.6 billion Circus Circus company, which started with a single struggling Strip hotel-casino 16 years ago, has become the envy of the gaming industry with a strategy focusing on low-rollers rather than coveted high-rollers. Chairman William Bennett announced to stockholders last week that the company planned to reduce its $500 million debt by about $200 million in the coming year, largely on added revenue from the Excalibur. Glenn Schaeffer, chief financial officer for Circus Circus, said the company could probably pay off all its debt in three or four years from Excalibur revenue, but may opt to look at new projects. Schaeffer said the company, which once eyed Atlantic City, now has no interest in expanding to New Jersey. ``Our desire is to have the strongest balance sheet in the industry,'' he said. The Excalibur is anchored by four 28-story towers and covers 70 acres. It has about 500,000 square feet of public entertainment space, including a Renaissance village, 12 food outlets and a casino the size of four football fields, with 2,630 slot machines. Shows will feature a medieval flair, with live jousting. An arcade will feature a dozen themed game booths such as archery and electronic crossbows. The hotel has 4,300 workers, enough wallcovering to paper an area 10 acres in size, enough carpeting to blanket 11 football fields. It will replace another Las Vegas property that held the title of the world's largest hotel _ the 3,530-room Flamingo Hilton. Tuesday's opening will give Circus Circus a total of 11,320 rooms in Nevada, with hotels in Las Vegas, Reno and Laughlin. By comparison, Atlantic City's 12 major hotels total 8,100 rooms. With the addition of the Excalibur, Las Vegas now has 75,000 hotel rooms.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Slick Stalls in Gulf, Volunteers Maintain Tar Ball Vigil at Beaches
DOC.TEXT: A 30-mile oil slick from the wrecked supertanker Mega Borg lingered 10 miles off the Texas coast Tuesday, and the Coast Guard backed off predictions of where or when it might reach land. ``I think predicting anything at this time is probably very premature,'' said Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Frank Whipple. Coast Guard officials had predicted that it would float ashore near Galveston on Tuesday. ``I think what's very good news is the fact that it's not coming closer to the beach right now; it's staying offshore,'' Whipple said. ``That allows more evaporation, allows the contractors more time to pick the oil out of the water. We've been trying all along to remove as much of it from the water before it got to the beach.'' Whipple said crews have recovered 463,000 gallons of an oil and water mixture skimmed from the Gulf of Mexico. The spill of 3.9 million gallons of the 38 million gallons of oil aboard the Mega Borg followed a June 8 explosion aboard the supertanker about 57 miles from Galveston. Most of the oil spilled has burned off, evaporated or been collected. Coast Guard officials have been hesitant to say just how much oil remains in the slick and sheen. ``We're kind of staying away from those figures,'' Chief Warrant Office Rick Meidt said. ``We've already picked up something like five times more oil than we thought was in the water. But, I should point out, what we're picking up is an oily water mixture that is about 20 percent oil and 80 percent water.'' Coast Guard officials said the slick could come ashore closer to High Island 30 miles northeast of Galveston, rather than Sea Rim Park, which is further to the northeast. ``That's good news,'' said Petty Officer Mark Sedwick. ``That means it will be away from the marsh areas where we were concerned about the wildlife.'' About 1,200 volunteers from five counties were on alert to clean up beaches should the tar balls arrive. State officials also wrapped up tests on oil-eating bacteria that was poured into the oil during the weekend. ``We've got some good samples,'' said Blanton Moore of the Texas General Land Office. ``We know some change occurred, but what that change is we don't really know until we run some lab samples.'' The Mexican skimmer Ecopemex and 10 other skimmers continued to skim oil off the water. Booms and other deflector devices have been deployed to protect the shoreline. Two crew members died in the explosion, and two others are missing and presumed dead.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Says Insurgents Demanding Exile of Liberia President
With AM-Liberia-Victims, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the rebel delegation to Liberian peace talks has denied accepting a cease-fire and said the insurgents continue to demand the exile of President Samuel Doe. Thomas Woewiyu, interviewed Monday night, also spurned Doe's offer of a general amnesty that would permit the insurgents in Liberia to set up their own political party. Doe on Monday legalized several opposition political parties and said the National Patriotic Front could set up a party without fear of reprisals. ``Doe has no authority to grant anybody amnesty. He is not in a position to grant amnesty. He can only grant himself amnesty,'' said Woewiyu. He added, ``Our ultimate leader (Charles Taylor) controls the military machine and whatever Doe says will not stop our military leader's military planning.'' The rebel delegation signed an agreement calling for both sides to exercise restraint during the recess in the talks. Fighting had virtually ceased before the talks began after government forces inflicted their first major defeat on the rebels since Taylor's forces invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. The rebels were driven from the Firestone rubber plantation and neighboring international airport 35 miles from Monrovia after their chief military commander, Elmer Johnson, a former Boston area resident, was killed in a skirmish. Woewiyu said the agreement ``applies more to Doe's extramilitary activities, his death squads chopping off people's heads and throwing away their bodies. That has nothing to do with a cease-fire.'' Survivors who have fled rebel-controlled territory say the insurgents also committed atrocities. Reporters who have visited them saw the skulls of dead Liberian soldiers stuck on stakes along the roadside. ``The reason for the recess is for further consultation. We have an unnegotiable precondition to be met and Doe's people at the peace talks were not in a position to discuss the subject of Doe's departure from government. ``It is Doe who needs an amnesty and he better take it now before it is too late.'' Woewiyu said the rebels accepted the recess to give Doe time to flee. The talks, mediated by the Liberian Council of Churches, are scheduled to resume June 25.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped American's Employer Says Abductors are Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: The employer of a young American kidnapped in the Ecuadoran jungle said Tuesday he believed the abductors were guerrillas from neighboring Colombia. Jeffrey Fino, general manager of IMINCO, the small gold mining enterprise that employed Scott Heimdal, said a Peoria, Ill., television station was mistaken in reporting a former contractor had orchestrated Heimdal's kidnapping. Fino said a legal complaint filed by the company against the contractor has been misinterpreted by the news media. ``This is an old document and an old action that the company filed against a contractor'' Fino said. ``He supplied us with information that there may be a kidnapping. We don't know where that information came from. That's the only thing that ties him to the kidnapping. I can't say he collaborated with the kidnappers,'' he said. Fino described the contractor as an Ecuadoran who had become a naturalized U.S. citizen. The man mentioned in the civil and criminal complaint filed by IMINCO on May 1 had a contract with the company to transport mining equipment to the jungle area where IMINCO was searching for gold, Fino said. The Associated Press obtained a copy of the document Tuesday. The complaint accuses the man of attempting to extort $48,000 from Fino in return for not harassing him with legal actions against the mining enterprise. The document also says he told the company he had information that Fino might be kidnapped or killed. The complaint asks the police to investigate the contractor's ``possible complicity or cover-up of the crimes of kidnapping, assassination and ... attempted extortion.'' But Fino said Tuesday he believed Heimdal's kidnappers were Colombian guerrillas. ``According to communications from Scott and other evidence, we feel the kidnappers are Colombian guerrillas,'' he said. The armed men who seized Heimdal April 28 as he traveled along the Bermeja River near the Colombian border identified themselves as members of the People's Liberation Army, a Communist guerrilla group in Colombia. The kidnappers killed the boat's driver in the attack. In an interview last week with The AP, Fino showed photos taken of Heimdal in the guerrilla camp. The rebels wore camouflage uniforms and had automatic weapons. Fino, who has been closely involved in negotiations to win Heimdal's freedom, said the kidnappers have behaved erratically in their meetings with his go-between. Heimdal's parents, Roy and Marge Heimdal of Peoria, arrived in Quito Monday night to try to win their son's release. They refused to talk to reporters. The Heimdals, a working-class family, gathered $60,000 in community donations to pay ransom for their son's release. But they learned last week they had been mistaken and the kidnappers had all along demanded $612,000 _ that the $60,000 was only to ``guarantee'' they wouldn't kill Heimdal. ``It looks like I'm going to have to go and get him out,'' Mrs. Heimdal told the Peoria Journal Star this weekend. ``I'm tired of just sitting and doing nothing about all this.'' U.S. Embassy officials have said they are concerned that the wide publicity the kidnapping has received may complicate negotiations to win Heimdal's release and could endanger his life.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Pressure on Congress for Tree-Planting Initiative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grafs 3-5 new to UPDATE Bush remarks; adds overline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush urged a group of outdoor enthusiasts Tuesday night to pressure Congress for funds to plant a billion trees a year. ``Take this message with you, please, to the legislative branch,'' Bush said. ``Don't leave our tree-planting initiative out on a limb.'' Bush made the remarks at a black-tie dinner where he was honored as an outdoorsman. He received the Sheldon Coleman Great Outdoors Award, named for the man whose name is emblazoned on camping equipment. He joked that his award should have gone ``to a more accomplished outdoors person. It probably should have gone to the only person I know who can fish and read at the same time _ Barbara Bush.'' Reflecting on time in the outdoors, Bush said, ``these are special moments ... very, very special. So, preserving nature for future generations demands special effort.'' The president has asked Congress for $175 million for the first year of a multi-year initiative to plant a billion trees and launch a community program to plant another 30 million trees. ``I've seen too many budgets frittered away on other priorities,'' the president said. ``We all agree that trees are good for our water, good for our air, good for our communities.''

DOC.HEAD: Libya Denies Gadhafi Urged Work on Atom Bomb
DOC.TEXT: Libya's official news agency said the country's leader, Moammar Gadhafi, did not call on Arab scientists to develop an atomic bomb and accused the West of distorting Gadhafi's weekend speech. ``The leader of the revolution asserted America had prevented Libyan students from studying space and the atom,'' the British Broadcasting Corp. monitors quoted the JANA news agency as saying in an English-language commentary. In Libya, Gadhafi is referred to as ``the leader of the revolution.'' ``America is hostile to Arab and to Libyans. It bars them from studying sciences and from reaching technical standards. ... The Israelis had made more than one nuclear rocket aimed at every Arab city. America is sending above our heads artificial satellites and this is provoking us,'' JANA added. JANA said there was ``no hinting at any atomic bomb or missiles'' in the speech. On Sunday, the BBC monitors quoted Gadhafi as exhorting students to ``intensify efforts to reach space and manufacture the atom in defiance of America.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Awaits `Transcendent Symbol of Freedom'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 16th graf, `This being...,' to UPDATE with protest by Jewish group; picks up 17th graf pvs, `Rock promoter...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mandela-Ticker Tape; AM-Mandela Itinerary
LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: An army of police, 100 tow trucks, 150 miles of ticker tape, hawkers of $15 T-shirts and every last dog in the bomb squad _ all were ready for Nelson Mandela's arrival Wednesday in the United States. No one seemed readier than the man who will put Mandela up for three nights, Mayor David Dinkins. Speaking Tuesday at a national mayors' meeting in Chicago, New York's first black mayor said that Mandela comes to America ``as a transcendent symbol of freedom, and as a solitary person who is altering world history.'' He also promised to alter life in New York, accustomed though the city is to gridlock-wreaking visitors. A security effort, code named ``Operation Topaz,'' enlisted thousands of city police officers and federal and state agents in an attempt to make sure the first visit to an American city by the leader of the African National Congress is a safe one. A key weapon was what police call the ``Mandelamobile,'' a flatbed truck outfitted with a bulletproof glass bubble large enough for Mandela and several others. There are concerns about the health of the 71-year-old Mandela, whose 27 years in a South African prison included stretches of hard labor. Ambulances will be stationed at cross streets along the route, and the city's Emergency Medical Service has been given a detailed medical history. Given the geographic breadth of his schedule and the police's determination to keep his travel route clear, Mandela's visit was expected to cause particular difficulties for motorists during the next three days. ``This is more of a headache than when the president comes,'' said Stephanie Pinto, a spokeswoman for the Traffic Department. City workers had painted New York's official colors _ blue and orange _ in a line down the middle of Broadway, filled potholes along the route of Mandela's motorcade, and _ in a move that one observer described as unprecedented _ washed the windows on City Hall. Mandela, whose stop in New York is the first on a 12-day tour of eight U.S. cities, will sleep at Gracie Mansion, the mayor's residence. The place has only three bedrooms, which meant the mayor's son David was evicted. Or, as his father put it, ``He's been kind enough to relocate.'' But is the maple, imitation-bamboo bed in the state bedroom big enough for the 6-foot-4 Mandela? ``Our measurements say it will work,'' insisted Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch. Mandela arrives Wednesday morning at Kennedy International Airport and stops in Brooklyn to speak to a group of young people before proceeding to Manhattan for a ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway's concrete ``Canyon of Heros.'' For an old-time flavor, the city imported genuine ticker tape. About 150 miles of inch-wide paper ribbon was provided by a Connecticut company that claims to be the nation's last ticker-tape supplier. Computers have almost completely replaced tickers. The rest of Mandela's New York City visit has plenty of contrast, ranging as it does from a street rally in Harlem on Thursday to a $2,500-a-person reception on Friday night catered by actor Robert De Niro's new Tribeca Grill. The latter is part of an effort to raise funds for Mandela's African National Congress and the battle against apartheid in South Africa. The tour's organizers also have licensed the sale of various items, including a Mandela tour poster ($5), a ceramic cup with Mandela's picture ($8) and a T-shirt bearing ``amandla,'' the Zulu word for power, and Mandala's name ($15). This being New York, there were several developing controversies amid the preparations. At Gracie Mansion on Tuesday evening, about 100 Jewish protesters condemned Mandela's support for the Palestine Liberation Organization while supporting his cause in South Africa. ``We ask our black brothers and sisters to understand our pain in being here,'' said Rabbi Avi Weiss. ``Nelson Mandela is a hero in the anti-apartheid struggle. We join as one in this struggle.'' Weiss' group planned another demonstration for Wednesday near City Hall, where Mandela is to receive the key to the city. Rock promoter Bill Graham pulled out as organizer of a concert and rally scheduled for Thursday night at Yankee Stadium, citing disagreements with city officials. They, in turn, blamed Graham's failure to promote the event for poor ticket sales. About 20,000 of 45,000 tickets have been sold, and Graham has been replaced by another well-known producer, Ron Delsener.

DOC.HEAD: Former Director of FDA Generic Drug Division Indicted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 2nd graf, `The indictment ...,' with Seife unreachable, FDA declining to comment; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The indictment ...' SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Seife, 66 ...,' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury on Tuesday indicted the retired head of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's generic drug division on two counts of perjury in a corruption scandal involving the division. The indictment accuses Marvin Seife of lying to government investigators about meetings with generic-drug company executives and about whether he let them buy him meals, said U.S. Attorney Breckinridge Willcox. Seife, who prosecutors said lives in San Antonio, did not have a telephone listing in that area. His lawyer's name was not available. FDA spokeswoman Faye Peterson said the agency had not seen the indictment and declined to comment. The indictment was the latest development in the investigation into corruption in the generic-drug industry and among its regulators, which began in the summer of 1988. So far, four of Seife's former subordinates have been convicted on corruption and racketeering charges. Five generic-drug company executives, three pharmaceutical companies and one industry consultant have been convicted on similar charges. Seife, 66, retired Dec. 31 after 17 years as director of the generic-drug division, where he was responsible for reviewing manufacturers' applications to market generic drugs to the public. According to the indictment, Seife gave a sworn statement Oct. 25 to an FDA investigator in which he falsely denied meeting with two generic-drug company executives on Dec. 11, 1987, to discuss FDA matters. The indictment alleges that Seife made a similar false statement July 11 to the House of Representatives' Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations. The second count of the indictment charges that Siefe also lied in the statement to FDA investigators when he said, ``I have made it a practice never to have meals with the regulated industry.'' The indictment alleges Seife accepted numerous lunches, dinners and drinks paid for by generic-drug companies. If convicted on both counts, Seife faces a maximum of 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. The case has been handled by federal prosecutors in Baltimore because the FDA's headquarters are in Rockville.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Appeals for Help for Black South African Students
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 19th graf `He speaks' to UPDATE with Mandela speech in Montreal. Pickup 20th graf pvs, `Mandela described...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela appealed to Canadian students Tuesday to raise funds to help black youth in his South African homeland who must deal with harsh police repression and an inferior educational system. ``A reign of terror is being launched by the police, specifically against students,'' the black nationalist leader told about 1,000 teen-agers at a Toronto high school before flying to Montreal, the last stop on his three-day Canadian visit. On Wednesday morning, he is to travel to New York to begin an eight-city U.S. tour. ``I ask you, as students, to raise funds for the black students in South Africa who are facing such enormous difficulty,'' said Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress. Concluding his visit to Toronto at Central Technical School, Mandela, 71, was flanked by his wife, Winnie, and External Affairs Minister Joe Clark. His speech began more than an hour late because Mandela, who was released in February after spending 27 years in prison for his anti-apartheid activities, needed ``a little rest,'' a member of his entourage told the crowd. The racially mixed audience at the inner-city school remained upbeat as they waited, chanting ``Freedom power!'' and ``Viva Mandela!'' Mandela beamed and waved as the students gave him a standing ovation. During his 20-minute speech, Mandela asked for the creation of ``a special fund'' to help black students in South Africa. They receive an education ``far inferior to whites,'' he said, and those who have spoken out against the system ``have been crushed with force'' by the white-minority government. ``They have arrested students who have protested. Others have been crippled for life. They have confiscated their books. It's an intolerable, brutal reign of terror.'' Many black students have fled the country to seek an education, depriving the black majority of future leaders, he said. Tony Silipo, chairman of the Toronto board of education, later told the audience a nearby high school had already pledged some money. While the students remained hushed during Mandela's appeal, they cheered wildly when he grinned and joked with them. He mockingly worried that his many years in prison may have left him ``old and ugly. ``Now, I want you to tell me if that is true?'' ``No, no!'' came the response. Students leaving the school's auditorium said they were inspired by Mandela's message. Many referred to racial tension in the city following recent police shootings of blacks. ``He speaks for everyone, not just black people,'' said Katherine Duncan, a black 12th grader. In Montreal, 20,000 people jammed into a square behind city hall to listen to the South African leader, who appealed to Canadians to maintain economic sanctions against South Africa. Prior to the address, Mandela visited Quebec's Premier Robert Bourassa, who called Mandela ``a living symbol of freedom.'' Mandela described as ``absolutely fantastic'' the reception he's been given during his Canadian tour, which began Sunday in the Canadian capital of Ottawa. ``It is for that reason that we admire you, that we respect you and that we love you,'' he said. Mandela is in the midst of a six-week tour of 14 nations in Africa, Europe and North America that began June 6. Mandela's release from prison was part of a program of social reforms by the government of President F.W. de Klerk that included legalizing the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. De Klerk has also opened talks with black groups on giving a political voice to the country's 28 million blacks. South Africa's five million whites control the government and economy.

DOC.HEAD: State Asks Federal Judge for Broader Inspection Authority
DOC.TEXT: Florida needs more regulatory powers to control ``outlaws'' and ``pirates'' who provide abortions, a prosecutor argued Tuesday as the state tested the limits of a federal injunction. The state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services has proposed new rules to regulate abortion clinics. But any change would have to be approved by U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez, who rejected similar efforts with the injunction in 1982. State Assistant Attorney General James Peters argued Tuesday that new rules are warranted, citing a U.S. Supreme Court decision last summer and the potential for AIDS transmission in unsanitary clinics. But Charlene Carres, representing Florida clinics which filed a class-action lawsuit opposing the state's effort to revise the injunction, said existing regulations are sufficient and that attempts to go further would violate a patient's right to privacy and drive up the average $300 cost of an abortion. It is ``the exceptions in the industry _ outlaws, pirates or whatever _ who need this type of protection,'' Peters said. ``What happens here, judge, is that we are frozen. We are standing on our own tail.'' Carres, an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer, countered that no new rules are justified and noted that the state's own statistics show first-trimester abortions to be much safer than childbirth. Gonzalez promised to rule within a month. In 1982, Gonzalez ruled the state could check on licenses, records and disposal of fetal remains and make sure only physicians perform abortions. Placed off limits to government regulators were staffing, equipment, medical-care standards and transportation of patients during emergencies. The state claims it is entitled to re-enter those areas, in part because of the U.S. Supreme Court ruling in July that upheld a Missouri law requiring viability tests for fetuses after 20 weeks. That decision was the first limit backed by the nation's high court since abortion was legalized in 1973. Florida's latest move asks Gonzalez to revise his injunction so clinics can be further regulated. The state cited ``intolerable conditions'' found at south Florida clinics last fall after The Miami Herald detailed bloodstained wrappings and leaking oxygen tanks at one clinic. Gov. Bob Martinez, a vocal opponent of abortion, has repeatedly tried unsuccessfully to control abortions in Florida through legislative, administrative and judicial means. The state Supreme Court threw out a parental consent law in October. Days later, the Legislature adjourned a special session on abortion regulations without passing a single bill. And state regulators say snap inspections of abortion clinics last fall failed to correct problems. The attorney general's office says it is trying to guarantee abortions under safe medical conditions. But abortion rights advocates claim the state is trying to impose harsher rules than are required for comparable procedures like vasectomies.

DOC.HEAD: Five European Countries Sign Accord to End Border Checks
DOC.TEXT: Five EC nations on Tuesday signed an accord under which they will end border checks for their nationals, apply a joint visa and asylum policy and share data on illegal aliens, suspected criminals and missing persons. The long-awaited accord between Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, France and West Germany was hailed as an example for a no-borders pact among all 12 European Community nations. ``Our agreement is a model ... for the free movement of people in the Community,'' Dutch Deputy Foreign Minister Piet Dankert told reporters on behalf of the signatory nations. Yet he doubted all 12 EC nations were ready to remove their borders after Dec. 31, 1992, under the EC's single-market scheme. The 12 EC states have not even found unanimity for an accord on handling of asylum-seekers in the EC. The five-nation pact will be extended to include East Germany after its expected merger this year with the Federal Republic, making it the first international treaty viewing East and West Germany as a single entity. Negotiations are to open this week with Italy, which wants to join the Schengen accord, named for this village on the Luxembourg-German-French border where it was signed. The accord, in the works since 1985, must be ratified by the national parliaments to take effect. Ratification may take two years. Under the accord, the five signatory nations will: _Remove internal border checks for their citizens and legal residents and let legally admitted people from outside the five nations move within their boundaries for three months without a visa. _Apply a joint policy to prevent ``asylum shopping,'' whereby refugees go from one nation to the next to get residency visas. _Intensify cooperation between police and justice officials and allow police to chase suspected criminals across national boundaries. _Simplify extradition procedures and harmonize gun-control legislation. _Share information on people wanted or missing or who are considered dangerous. Such a databank will also keep tabs on such items as stolen cars and passports. The Schenger agreement primarily benefits passenger traffic. On road transport, the five EC nations pledged to keep border checks ``at the lowest possible level'' by removing some of the red tape that hampers road transporters. The agreement allows any state to revert to full-fledged border checks on national security grounds. Reflecting the sensitive nature of dropping border controls, Tuesday's signing ceremony was three years behind schedule. In past negotiations, the issue has encountered several hurdles, ranging from Luxembourg's refusal to water-down its bank secrecy laws to concerns elsewhere that the computer databank may lead to an invasion of privacy.

DOC.HEAD: Police Release Dramatic 911 Tapes from Florida Office Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-6 with 6 grafs to ADD quote, CORRECT other quotes to conform with newly compiled transcript, CLARIFY that police did not delay sending police while getting gunman's description; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Authorities said ...' SUBS penultimate graf, `The wounded...,' to include Ms. Griggs' first name.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JV4
DOC.TEXT: Police released dramatic tapes on Tuesday of terrified office workers pleading for help from police as a gunman roamed through the building and shots rang out in the background. ``We're being killed!'' whispered a General Motors Acceptance Corp. employee as James Edward ``Pop'' Pough methodically made his way through the auto loan office. ``Send the, send the SWAT team now!'' `` ... He's killing everyone,'' another panicked caller whispered as the workers waited for police to arrive. In the tape recordings of calls to the police 911 hot line, the callers' voices reflected the terror of the situation as the gunman fired under desks, killing eight and wounding five others before turning the gun on himself. ``He's still in there shooting ... shooting everybody! Come on!'' implored Barry Kimbal, an employee who ran to a neighboring business to call for help. As police were dispatched, emergency operators asked workers for a description of the gunman, his shirt color and what kind of car he was driving as rapid firing could be heard over the phone. ``All I know is he came in and starting shooting,'' said another panicky voice. Authorities said the 42-year-old Pough _ who had a violent past, a failing marriage and an arsenal of deadly weapons _ entered the office Monday morning, and blazed away with a clip-loaded .30-caliber carbine. In just a few minutes, seven employees and a customer died; five other people were critically wounded. The gunman then killed himself with a .38-caliber revolver. Authorities could suggest no motive other than that Pough had a 1988 Grand Am repossessed by GMAC. The last time GMAC had contact with Pough was in March, when they mailed him a letter telling him he still owed money, GMAC President William Lovejoy said. The families of the eight dead, still in shock, were planning funerals and mourning the loss of their loved ones. ``What a waste. What a damned waste,'' said victim Janice David's husband, Ray David, tears on his cheeks and the couple's son in his lap. ``I feel depressed. I feel cheated,'' said victim Cynthia Perry's mother, Gail Perry. ``She was a joy to everyone.'' Mayor Tommy Hazouri called the shootings ``the darkest moment in Jacksonville history.'' Police said Pough had shot and killed a man and a woman Sunday morning in a prostitution-related dispute. Police confirmed Tuesday that he shot and wounded two teen-agers about 10 minutes later. Ballistics tests completed Tuesday confirmed that the rifle used in the GMAC killings was the same gun used in the Sunday shootings, Sheriff Jim McMillan said. Pough also had a 9mm machine pistol which authorities found in his car. ``We will be following up today and talking to his relatives to see if anything happened that might have caused this or if he gave any kind of indication,'' police spokesman Asa Higgs said Tuesday. Questions surfaced about Pough's background and how he could buy a handgun after pleading guilty to an aggravated assault charge in which he shot and killed another man in 1971. Duval County Circuit Judge Warren Jones withheld a guilty verdict, pending completion of five years' probation with the condition that Pough not own a weapon. When Pough completed his probation, that condition was lifted, Chief Assistant State Attorney John Delaney said Tuesday. ``He was not technically a convicted felon,'' Delaney said. That made it legal to own a gun under Florida law. But McMillan said it was illegal for him to own a gun under federal law. ``It's a loophole we need to plug up,'' the sheriff said. The prosecutor couldn't give the details on the 1971 crime or why the charge was reduced from manslaughter, because the file has been destroyed. In 1968, Pough was fined $75 for displaying a knife in a threatening manner, and an arrest warrant was outstanding in a 1982 unemployment compensation fraud case, according to court records. Pough, who was separated from his wife, lived in a run-down duplex in Jacksonville's predominantly black Northwest Quadrant. Neighbors described him as quiet, pleasant and helpful. But in March, a circuit judge granted Pough's wife, Theresa, an injunction to keep him away. The protective order prohibited Pough from communicating with her, and meant he had to stay away from where she worked and lived. For the last year, Pough had been doing maintenance work for the W. W. Gay Construction Co. at the Anheuser-Busch brewery. A team of GMAC officials led by Lovejoy flew into Jacksonville to counsel victims and their families and to set up a temporary office to handle GMAC business. ``The first step for us is the mental health of our employees,'' said Lovejoy, who announced that GMAC was establishing an assistance fund for the families of those killed or wounded. The company is contributing $100,000, and Lovejoy said it would solicit donations from other General Motors employees. The victims were identified as Drew Woods, 38; Denise Highfill, 36; Sharon Louise Hall, 45; Barbara Duckwall Holland, 45; Lee Simonton, 33; customer Julia White Burgess, 42; Mrs. David, 40; and Ms. Perry, 30. The wounded were Ron Ecchevaria, 49; Jewel Belote, 50; Nancy Dill, 31; Phyllis Griggs, 42, and David Hendrix, 25. Ecchevaria's condition has been upgraded from serious to fair and Ms. Belote is listed in serious but stable condition, both at University Medical Kenter. At Baptist Hospital, Ms. Griggs is in stable but serious condition, Dill is in very serious condition and Hendrix is critical but stable.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Barbara Cason Dead of Heart Failure
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Cason, a veteran actress best known for playing the role of comedian Garry Shandling's mother on ``It's Garry Shandling's Show,'' has died, a spokesman said Tuesday. She was 61. Miss Cason died Monday of apparent heart failure in her home, spokesman Laurence Frank said in a statement released by his public relations firm. Ms. Cason, whose stage credits include New York productions of ``Marat Sade'' and ``Oh, Coward!'' helped found the Front Street Theatre in her hometown of Memphis, Tenn. She appeared in films such as ``Cold Turkey'' and ``Heretic II.'' She is survived by her husband, actor Dennis Patrick. Funeral services were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Politicians Return from Hostage Talks in Tehran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Niall and Eoin cq
DOC.TEXT: Three Irish politicians returned home Tuesday from hostage talks in Iran, and said conciliatory gestures by the United States and Israel could help win the release of Western hostages in Lebanon. The three said they discussed the fate of Irish teacher Brian Keenan and the other 15 Western hostages believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite extremists in Lebanon. ``We discussed all the hostages, both those (Westerners) being held in Lebanon and the Islamic hostages held by the Israelis,'' Niall Andrews, a representative of Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey's Fianna Fail party in the European Parliament, told reporters at Dublin airport. ``The Iranians are not looking for ransom, or for money. They are looking for peace and a proper humanitarian settlement to the hostage problem,'' he said. ``The Iranians seemed to have the impression that if there was reciprocation on the side of the Israelis and the Americans, they could bring about very easily and very quickly a resolution to the hostage situation on all sides.'' Andrews' brother, David Andrews, a Fianna Fail representative in the Irish Parliament, said Iranian officials wanted the United States to reciprocate for Iran's role in helping obtain the release in April of two American hostages, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed. The Andrews brothers said their visit to Tehran with Irish senator Eoin Ryan was privately organized and not sponsored by the government or any other organization. The three said they planned to brief Haughey on their talks and report to Keenan's family on the latest moves to obtain his release. David Andrews said he suggested to Iranian officials that members of the Keenan family might meet in Tehran or Dublin with families of Iranians held in the Middle East. He said the Iranian officials promised to consider the proposal. The three politicians did not name the Iranian officials with whom they met. Keenan, 39, from Belfast in Northern Ireland, holds dual Irish and British citizenship. He was working as an English language teacher at the American University of Beirut when he disappeared while walking to work April 11, 1986. The longest held hostage is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, seized by gunmen near his home in west Beirut on March 16, 1985. The most prominent prisoner Israel holds is Sheikh Abdul-Karim Obeid, a Lebanese Shiite Moslem cleric captured in July 1989. Israel holds more than 5,000 Palestinians detained during the 2{-year-old Arab uprising against Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and West Bank. In addition, more than 300 Arab prisoners, mostly Shiite Moslems, are held by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army at al-Khiam just north of the Israeli-Lebanese border. Israel has said it would free some of its Arab prisoners in exchange for the release of three Israelis held by Shiites in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Train Hits Tanker Truck, Three Die
LaserPhoto JXN2
DOC.TEXT: A freight train rammed a tanker truck loaded with alcohol Tuesday, touching off a fireball that engulfed the front of the train and killing three of the freight's crew members, authorities said. ``I would say they suffocated from the fire, but I can't prove that,'' said fire Capt. Lester Blaylock. The tanker exploded on impact and the CSX Corp. train continued for several hundred yards, trailing flames and leaving burning puddles in this western Tennessee city, Blaylock said. Killed were the train's engineer, reserve engineer and head brakeman, said a CSX spokesman. Their names were withheld until relatives could be notified. The truck driver, John Gilboy, 25, of New Jersey, was treated for minor injuries at a hospital and released, said Police Chief Lucion English. Gilboy was issued a misdemeanor citation for failing to stop at a railroad crossing, said Sgt. Leon King of the state Public Service Commission, which oversees the trucking industry. Eleven firefighters were overcome by heat and fumes. Employees of several small businesses near the tracks left the area until the fire was brought under control about 30 minutes after the 8:05 a.m. crash, said Ed Ellington of the Haywood County Emergency Management Agency. No other injuries were reported. City police dispatcher Patsy Crutchfield said the front of the train was destroyed, but did not know how many of its 50 to 75 cars were affected. The flames did not spread beyond the train and truck. The accident occurred in an industrial area on the east side of town, where a farmer's cooperative, several factories and other businesses are located. English said the crash was being investigated by local, state and federal officials. Warning lights at the crossing apparently were working at the time of the crash, said Ellington. ``From all reports, the truck driver just crossed the track and the train struck the tank of the trailer he was pulling,'' Ellington said. ``Apparently he didn't see the signal or something.'' The tanker was owned by Linden Bulk Transports of New Jersey, and was loaded with ethylhexanol, an industrial alcohol, he said. Cleanup crews mopped up several small spills but most of the tanker's cargo burned away, he said. The train had been headed to Memphis from Nashville. The crossing was cleared by late afternoon. Brownsville is 40 miles northeast of Memphis.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Schedules Trial Involving Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lede to delete word `obscenity' to clarify that trial ordered on charge of illegal use of minor, while judge wants hearing before ruling on `pandering obscenity' charge. Note contents of grafs 5, `The first ...' and 9, `According to ...'
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled Tuesday that an art gallery and its director must stand trial on at least one charge stemming from an exhibit of sexually graphic photos by Robert Mapplethorpe. ``This court will try to make a decision of what, in Ohio, constitutes the definition of obscenity,'' Hamilton County Municipal Judge David Albanese said. ``It has been an awesome judicial effort in the past and will continue to be so. ``Obscene material is not protected by the First Amendment. This case is not about the rights of the curious to view an exhibition.'' Albanese rejected several defense motions to dismiss two misdemeanor charges against the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie. The first charge, set for trial Sept. 24, involves photographs of two children. In one, a boy's genitals are exposed; in the other, a girl's genitals are exposed. The arts center and Barrie were charged with illegal use of a minor in nudity-oriented material or performance. The second charge, pandering obscenity, involves five photos showing homosexual acts. Albanese said he wanted an evidentiary hearing on that charge before ruling whether it should go to trial. He scheduled the hearing for Aug. 20. The exhibit ``Robert Mapplethorpe: A Perfect Moment,'' included 175 photographs. The defense contends all of them should be considered in determining whether the entire exhibit is obscene. Prosecutors want the judge to consider only the five photos. ``This court is not presumptuous enough to believe that it has the background and information necessary to try to rationalize whether these pictures can be taken as a whole or independently,'' Albanese said. According to court records, the photos cited in the indictment included pictures showing a hand and other objects inserted into anuses. If convicted, Barrie could be sentenced to six months in jail and be fined $1,000 on each charge. The arts center could be fined $5,000 on each charge. In his ruling, Albanese said he considered the arts center to be a gallery rather than a museum, and noted that a museum is permitted more latitude in displaying art. A county grand jury indicted the art gallery and Barrie on April 7 after secretly attending the public opening of the exhibit that day. According to art gallery figures, the exhibit drew 80,000 people during its seven-week run. One of the defense motions rejected by Albanese alleged that prosecutors improperly sought a biased judge to issue a search warrant allowing them to enter the art gallery to videotape the exhibit. ``This court believes that any judge on the Hamilton County Municipal Court at any time, under the proper procedures, can and should authorize the issuance of a search warrant; `judge shopping' simply does not exist in this cause,'' Albanese wrote. He noted that the indictments were returned before the search warrant was obtained.

DOC.HEAD: NBC President Calls FCC Rules Reverse Protectionism
DOC.TEXT: NBC's president assailed federal syndication and financial interest rules Tuesday as ``reverse protectionism'' that favors foreign-owned media conglomerates and hurts the three major U.S. networks. The assertion by Robert C. Wright, made at a speech at the Center for National Policy, came less than a week after NBC, CBS and ABC urged the Federal Communications Commission to drop its 20-year-old rules. Their action came after they and Hollywood producers and studios failed to reach a compromise last week on ways to alter the rules, which the FCC originally adopted as a means of curbing network power. Wright said the rules are outdated due to changes in television, including the growth of cable, the establishment of 300 new independent stations, the 4-year-old Fox network and home videocassette recorders. The rules ``have fostered concentration and inhibited competition in the 20 years since they were adopted,'' he said, adding that they ``constitute nothing less than reverse protectionism. ``They are domestic trade barriers aimed only at three U.S. companies, but which leave our foreign competitors alone. Even more absurd, the rules restrict us from competing against the foreign studios in the foreign markets... ``Can anyone imagine Japan giving NBC or Time Warner access to its markets while at the same time restricting Sony?'' The FCC rules bar the networks from a financial interest in shows they don't wholly own, and prohibit them from doing business in the lucrative program syndication market in the U.S. The producers and the studio have asked the FCC to strengthen the rules, and investigate the networks for possible violations of them. The Justice Department has sided with the networks' position. The Center for National Policy is a policy institute involved in trade and related issues, according to a corporate press release from NBC.

DOC.HEAD: Former Dictator Somoza's Family Allowed to Return to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Former dictator Anastasio Somoza's family will be allowed to return to Nicaragua under a recent amnesty declared by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's new government, a presidential spokesman said Tuesday. A niece and nephew of Somoza, exiled since his overthrow by the leftist Sandinistas in July 1979, said they were flying to Managua, the capital, Saturday to become the first members of the old ruling family to return to Nicaragua. Presidential spokesman Antonio Lacayo said the government ``knew absolutely nothing'' about the planned arrival of Luis and Julia Sevilla Somoza. But he said, ``All Nicaraguans can come back and begin a new life if they want to under the new law.'' Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-backed administration, which took power after defeating the Sandinistas in February's elections, decreed an unconditional amnesty on May 10 ``for all the political and related common crimes committed by Nicaraguan citizens up to the date of publication of the current law.'' A previous amnesty for political offenders declared by the Sandinistas only covered crimes committed after the fall of Somoza, leaving his family unprotected. Luis Sevilla Somoza, one of about 100 Somoza family members living in exile in the United States and Europe, said he and his sister Julia planned to spend a week in Managua, meeting with ministers of Chamorro's government and Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo. Sevilla Somoza said he wanted to explore ways to help rebuild the country and investment opportunities during his upcoming trip. ``Basically it's a trip to see what's going on and find out how we can help the government and the church,'' he said. Lacayo was cautious in commenting about the intentions of the Sevilla Somozas. ``Although they are covered by the broad amnesty declared, their coming to work with the government or recover property is another thing,'' Lacayo said. The Sandinistas confiscated Somoza family holdings after the revolution that brought the guerrilla movement to power. About a half-million Nicaraguans, or 17 percent of the country's citizens, are living abroad. Thousands fled immediately following Somoza's ouster, and many more abandoned their homeland during the Sandinista's rule to escape hard times caused by U.S.-backed economic sanctions and the civil war with Contra rebels. Since Mrs. Chamorro's election visit, the United States has restored normal economic relations with Nicaragua and the Contras have mostly demobilized as part of a peace plan. But the economy has continued to worsen, with the new administration devaluing the currency 11 times in less than two months. Despite the amnesty, few Nicaraguans have returned home from abroad. The 1978 assassination of Mrs. Chamorro's husband, La Prensa newspaper publisher Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, was one of the events that sparked the overthrow of Anastasio Somoza by the Sandinistas. Mrs. Chamorro later broke with the Sandinistas over their leftist policies. Anastasio Somoza fled to Paraguay, where he was assassinated on an Asuncion street by bazooka-wielding assailants in 1980. Sevilla Somoza said his family believes that the sore feelings have subsided and it is safe for them to return to Nicaragua. ``We were never in the government, in politics or the army,'' he said. ``We are good people with much to offer.''

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Washington
Amateurs Getting Another Crack at Hubble Telescope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS details.
DOC.TEXT: A second group of amateur astronomers will be given a chance to use the Hubble Space Telescope, the telescope's operators announced Tuesday. They said an earlier offer to amateurs was such a success that they decided to do it again. ``I think it shows we were so pleased with the types of proposals, the imagination, creativity and thought that went into the first ones that it justified doing it again,'' said Ray Villard, a spokesman for the Space Telescope Science Institute at Johns Hopkins University. The Hubble Space Telescope was launched into orbit April 25 aboard the space shuttle Discovery. Free from the distorting effects of Earth's atmosphere, the $1.5 billion telescope is designed to study the furthest reaches of the universe. Five amateur astronomers were chosen from hundreds of applications the first time. They have been allocated 17 hours of telescope time, about 1 percent of the time granted to professionals, Villard said.
