For Release Sunday, June 24, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: A Korean Orphan's Search for a GI Named Billy
With BC-Korea-Forgotten War
DOC.TEXT: Baik Sung-hak was a 12-year-old orphan and felt lucky to be taken on by a U.S. artillery unit as a ``washy-washy boy.'' He was not paid in money, but in food, candy, gum and the friendship of a GI he called Billy, who also had been an orphan. Thousands of children were orphaned or separated from their families in the three years of the Korean war, which began in 1950. American soldiers often gave the children food, candy and coins, but the GIs always moved on. ``Billy stayed in my heart,'' said Baik, now a wealthy, 50-year-old hat manufacturer. An enemy shell landed beside Baik on a riverbank one day. He was enveloped in burning gasoline and jumped into the river, screaming. ``Billy jumped in after me, got me out, rushed me to the hospital,'' he said. ``When I woke up after 18 hours, Billy was there. Billy was kind to all the orphans, but especially to me. We orphans usually ate the leftovers, but Billy would always save a plate of food for me.'' Baik was sent to an orphanage after the war. He ran away, worked at odd jobs and began what would be a 30-year search for Billy through newspapers, veterans organizations and military listings on two continents. Eventually, he became a successful businessman and established Billy House, a home for orphans and the handicapped northeast of Seoul. In 1986, he was invited to a reunion in Kansas City of 14 men from Billy's old unit. ``At the reunion, I went through files and files of pictures,'' he said. ``I remember screaming, `That's Billy!' and the others just stared at me.'' ``That's not Billy, that's David Beattie,'' someone said. No one knew where Beattie lived. ``Billy'' was what ``Beattie'' had sounded like to a 12-year-old Korean orphan. In September 1989, a friend telephoned Baik and told him Beattie had been located in Philadelphia. That was where they met, later that month, for the first time in nearly 40 years. ``The minute I saw him, I knew he was Billy,'' he said. A few weeks ago, Beattie, 59, returned to Korea for the first time since the war as Baik's guest. ``Hak was a strong boy and he was always willing to help me,'' he said, referring to Baik by one of his given names. ``I never thought of looking for him. After the war was over, I went back home and that was it.'' ``I recognized Hak as soon as I saw him. I didn't know what to say. When we first met, we just stared at each other for a few minutes.'' Baik says he wants their children to meet. He has two and Beattie has four.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 24

DOC.TEXT: The stock market suffered its sharpest setback in almost five months, beset by worries about the outlook for corporate profits. Prices came under pressure from light but steady selling throughout the session Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had closed out last week at a record high, fell 53.71 to 2,882.18. It was the largest loss since the index dropped 77.45 points on Jan. 22.

A majority of U.S. workers could face lifetimes of low-paying jobs and America will lose its global economic race unless drastic changes are made in training average workers, a commission warned. ``What we are facing is an economic cliff of sorts. And the front line working people of America are about to fall off it,'' said the bluntly-worded study released Monday by a 34-member Commission on the Skills of the American Work Force.

The nation's chief federal bank regulator, watching credit across the Northeast dry up amid rising loan losses, tried to reassure jittery bankers and their customers that the industry is sound. Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke told a group of Providence executives Monday that the federal government has not toughened its regulations or its audits of banks. What it has done, he said, is reacted to changes in the economy and in the process has uncovered bad loans at many institutions.

The Supreme Court gave broader powers to an agency guarding the pensions of 30 million American workers, making it less likely that taxpayers will have to pay billions in bailouts down the road. By an 8-1 vote Monday, the court said the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation acted within its authority when ordering LTV Corp. and its subsidiary, LTV Steel Co., to restore pension plans with unfunded liabilities of $2.3 billion.' Also Monday, the court allowed the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to regulate a type of stock market investment called an index participation. The court, without comment, left intact an appeals court ruling that gives the CFTC, rather than the Securities and Exchange Commission, such regulatory power.

The American Stock Exchange, Chicago Board Options Exchange and Cincinnati Stock Exchange announced plans to start a computerized, nighttime trading market for stocks and stock options. Like an after-hours trading plan announced last week by the New York Stock Exchange, the proposal issued Monday aims to regain some of the business in U.S.-listed issues captured by foreign competitors _ especially the London and Tokyo exchanges _ while U.S. stock markets are closed.

An agreement among several major banks to loan $60 million to developer Donald Trump was in limbo as the institutions, once close to a deal, continued haggling over its terms. The deal, aimed at helping the developer continue making payments to bankers while his $3 billion in bank and bond debts are restructured, was nearing completion late last week. But over the weekend, the deal fell into disarray as several banks jockeyed for a better position and no agreement could be reached.

The head of First Executive Corp. said that former junk bond financier Michael Milken did not dictate investment strategy to the giant California insurance concern, which invested heavily in the risky securities. Fred Carr also told a House subcommittee Monday that while a Milken-controlled company had a major stake in a First Executive subsidiary, neither Carr nor First Executive invested in any partnerships run by Milken. Milken formerly headed the junk bond department of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

Representatives of UAL Corp.'s non-union employees met with the chief of the union group trying to buy the airline company in hopes of avoiding a setback in the buyout effort. The meeting Monday in Chicago between Gerald Greenwald and leaders of the non-contract group was their second within a week, said Stephen Fraidin, a lawyer for the non-union workers. It followed a stinging statement Sunday by the 26,000 non-contract workers expressing disappointment that the union group had not accepted proposed wage concessions and benefit modifications under which the non-contract workers could support the buyout plan.

Congress and the Internal Revenue Service are zeroing in on a common target: an income-tax gap that is pushing above $100 billion a year. The gap is the difference between taxes owed and taxes paid voluntarily on legal income. The difference between the two is caused mostly by overstating deductions and underreporting income. Billions of dollars owed on illegal income are not included.

The dollar fell against most major currencies Monday, buffeted by technical factors and expectations of lower U.S. interest rates. Bond prices fell, however, amid concern that interest rates might not decline soon. Gold prices rose modestly overseas but slipped lower in U.S trading. Grain and soybean futures rallied, reflecting concerns about flood damage to corn and soybean crops. Oil futures fell steeply; pork bellies extended their recent sharp losses and livestock futures were mixed; orange juice futures plunged again, copper futures rose and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Steady to Slightly Higher at Latest Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on three-month Treasury securities edged up slightly at the latest auction while rates on six-month bills were unchanged. The Treasury Department sold $8.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.74 percent on Monday, up from 7.73 percent last week. Another $8.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.64 percent, identical to last week. The three-month rate was the highest since May 29 when three-month bills sold for 7.80 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.00 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,804.40 and 8.06 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,613.80. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, edged down to 8.05 percent last week, compared to 8.08 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Palo Alto Computer Giant Announces New Workstation Series
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. unveiled a line of products that for the first time blends its workstation technology with that of Apollo Computer, which Hewlett-Packard bought for $500 million last year. The success of the new Series 400 computer workstations will help determine whether Hewlett-Packad's biggest acquisition will give the Palo Alto-based company a competitive edge in the $5.8 billion worldwide workstation market. So far, competitors say the acquisition of Apollo, which is based in Chelmsford, Mass., has caused Hewlett-Packard to lose market share. ``HP has gone AWOL since the Apollo acquisition,'' said Scott McNealey, president and CEO of Sun Microsystems Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., Hewlett-Packard's leading rival in the workstation market. Hewlett-Packard on Monday introduced a set of workstations based on Motorola Inc.'s 68030 microprocessor. The company also planned more advanced workstations, but delays in production of a computer chip will keep it from shipping those systems until later in 1990. The workstations will cost $5,000-$14,000, and they will offer performance levels that match Sun's market-leading SPARCstation, according to Bill Kay, general manager of Hewlett Packard's workstation group. The introduction comes as Hewlett Packard restructures in an effort to reverse a four-quarter trend of falling profits despite rising revenues. The company's earnings fell 8 percent to $186 million, or 78 cents a share, in its second quarter ending April 30, while sales rose 16 percent to $3.3 billion. The industry of the 1990s requires a strong position in workstations _ systems that are more powerful than personal computers but less powerful than minicomputers. Minicomputers, fast becoming an industry dinosaur, are the core of Hewlett-Packard's business and yield the highest profits of its product lines. Although the Apollo acquisition briefly vaulted Hewlett-Packard to No. 1 in workstations, Sun quickly regained the lead with faster, cheaper and more advanced products. Others also are fighting for a piece of the market. Since the Apollo acquisition, Hewlett-Packard's share of the workstation market slipped to 26 percent last year from 30 percent in 1988. Sun controlled 30 percent of the market at the end of last year. ``Everybody says that because of the merger we lost the lead,'' said Lew Platt, executive vice president for Hewlett-Packard's computer products. ``But that lead has been handed off a number of times in the last few years. Nobody's had it consistently.'' Hewlett-Packard's new workstations aren't expected to close the gap, according to analysts and competitors. The company's competitors have been selling workstations based on a more advanced technology called reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, in the same price range for more than a year. RISC speeds up computers by cutting the number of instructions they have to complete to perform a task. Hewlett-Packard is the only major workstation vendor that hasn't come out with a low-cost RISC-based workstation. Kay countered that the company's new workstations will match the performance of RISC-based machines. He also said the company will have its own competitive RISC workstations on the market at the end of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Giant Chairman: No Special Arrangement with Milken
DOC.TEXT: The head of First Executive Corp. told Congress that former junk bond chief Michael Milken did not dictate investment strategy to the California insurance concern, a big junk bond buyer. Fred Carr also told a House subcommittee Monday that while a Milken-controlled company had a major stake in a First Executive subsidiary, neither Carr nor First Executive invested in any partnerships run by the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. banker. ``This is a chance for me to clear the record,'' Carr told the investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee in a statement. The panel has been investigating some 400 limited partnerships _ controlled largely by Drexel employees _ that bought significant stakes in hot junk bond issues underwritten by Drexel before they were made available to the public. Critics have said the activity drove up the price of those issues at the expense of Drexel customers, but the transactions' legality has never been resolved. Under questioning by the subcommittee chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., Carr denied Milken had authority to trade on behalf of any First Executive accounts. Dingell said the subcommittee had information that Milken used to dictate trades on Friday afternoons to an assistant who would pass them on to First Executive. But Carr said, ``I have no knowledege of what he dictated to anybody.'' The subscommittee also plans to call Milken and disgraced stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky as witnesses. The subcommittee authorized a subpoena for Boesky last year. And the panel voted unanimously last month to subpoena Milken, who pleaded guilty in April to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. But the Justice Department is concerned about Milken's testifying, under immunity, before he is sentenced Oct. 1. Dingell, the subcommittee chairman, has said he wants to hear from Milken before Congress adjourns Aug. 3 for a month-long summer break. William McLucas, head of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Alan Cohen, chief of the securities fraud unit of the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan, declined to discuss the issue. But sources close to the case have said the Justice Department is concerned that if Milken testifies under immunity before Congress and then withdraws his guilty plea, it could make it difficult to prosecute him. Carr testified without immunity Monday. Dingell said the purpose of the hearing was ``to determine whether the regulatory system is properly addressing the increasing use of junk bonds as security for insurance policies that people depend upon to be safe and sound.'' Junk bonds are high-yielding corporate bonds with low investment ratings, meaning they carry a high risk of not being paid. Junk bonds were used to finance many mergers, takeovers and leveraged buyouts in the 1980s. Dingell noted that insurance companies account for about 30 percent of the junk bond market and junk bonds constitute between 45 percent and 60 percent of First Executive's holdings. First Executive suffered a $836 million net loss in the fourth quarter of 1989 because of a writedown in the value of its junk bond portfolio. The company rebounded to post a profit of $45.5 million in this year's first quarter. ``A proper regulatory system should assure that insurance companies do not face insolvency because they overdose on junk bonds,'' said Dingell. ``The collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert and defaults by some issuers have forced First Executive to write-down its portfolio by more than $1 billion during the past several months,'' Dingell added. But Carr insisted in his opening statement that ``Executive Life is an example of a life insurance company that has managed to remain sound and solvent despite the recent massive turmoil in the so-called junk market, despite extreme adverse publicity.''

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Options, American and Cincinnati Stock Exchanges Plan Late Trading
DOC.TEXT: The move toward off-hours trading to compete with foreign exchanges got another boost as three exchanges agreed to cooperate on a computerized system to trade stock and stock options through the night. The American Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Cincinnati Stock Exchange on Monday announced plans to implement an automated nighttime system in two to three years. The New York Stock Exchange announced a different after-hours plan last week. London and Tokyo have been getting more of the business in U.S.-listed issues while markets in this country are closed. ``This agreement is a milestone in the internationalization of securities markets, and we welcome other securities exchanges to join us in this endeavor,'' said Duke Chapman, chairman and chief executive of the CBOE. Officials of the exchanges, speaking at simultaneous news conferences in New York and Chicago linked by television, said they had asked the NYSE and Tokyo exchanges to join them. But the Big Board indicated it didn't want to give up its leading role in U.S. stocks. ``The New York Stock Exchange today has the largest, most cost efficient computer system in the world and we would like to invite the CBOE and AMEX into our system ... which was announced last week,'' said NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano. The AMEX, CBOE and Cincinnati exchange plan to operate their electronic trading system between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m. Eastern time. Stocks now trade from 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. and options from 9:30 a.m. until 4:10 p.m. or 4:15 p.m. The CBOE would build and maintain the electronic exchange's main computer while Reuters Holdings PLC would provide the network to link dealers with the computer. Reuters currently provides electronic dealing networks for foreiggn exchange and bond dealers and also is a leading supplier of financial market news. The CBOE and AMEX would provide a market in their stock options, while the Cincinnati exchange would offer stocks listed on that regional exchange. The New York Stock Exchange last week revealed plans to begin limited after-hours trading this year with an eye to 24-hour trading by the end of the decade. The plan calls for thrice-nightly auctions of Big Board-listed stocks at 8 p.m., midnight and 5 a.m., beginning next year. The deal announced Monday represents a major cooperative effort at a time when competition is heating up among exchanges that handle stock options. A new federal rule allows for multiple listings of stock options, which now are assigned to particular exchanges. Under the computerized nighttime system, the marketplace that establishes itself as the primary exchange for a particular issue will handle the stock option in the after-hours session. ``The American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange will still compete,'' Jones said. But, he conceded, ``In the newly carved-out trading hours we will put aside some of today's competitive battles.'' The precise number of issues that will be traded have yet to be determined. The Cincinnati exchange trades about 500 issues, while the American exchange and CBOE account for about 80 percent of the nation's options trading. The exchange executives said it was possible that other products, such as stock index options, could be traded through the system. ``The CBOE and AMEX would have to agree to make their products available,'' said Richard DuFour, the executive vice president for product development at the CBOE. ``We'll choose products that are most attractive to overseas customers.'' Options are financial instruments that give holders that right to buy or sell 100 shares of a stock at a designated price for a certain amount of time. The three exchanges and Reuters announced their intention to work on a common system in March 1989. They said they reached a definitive agreement about a month ago, and the boards of the companies finished approving the plan late last week.

DOC.HEAD: LTV Says It Still Can't Afford Pension Plans, Despite Court Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Chriss in 8th graf is CQ
DOC.TEXT: LTV Corp. says it cannot afford to resume responsibility for $2.3 billion in pension liabilities despite a U.S. Supreme Court decision upholding a government agency's effort to force the company to fund the plans. LTV Senior Vice President Julian Scheer said the decision Monday in favor of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. will delay the company's efforts to emerge from bankruptcy court protection. ``LTV filed for Chapter 11 protection four years ago because, among other things, we could not afford to make payments into these three pension plans,'' the company said in a statement. ``That situation has not changed. We still cannot afford the plans. It will be the company's objective to continue to seek a resolution which recognizes the fact.'' LTV, which has sold off much of its steel operations, plans to reorganize as a streamlined company. Chriss Street, a bankruptcy expert at Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Chicago who has dealt with many of LTV's creditors, said the company probably has enough cash to pay the claims, ``but in paying the pension claim they would have to turn the keys to the company over to the PBGC and all the other creditors would essentially be left holding the bag.'' The Supreme Court ruling ``assures that LTV will be mired in further litigation,'' Street said. Gary Heinz, an analyst at Delaware Bay Co. in New York, said he would expect creditors to push the bankruptcy judge to end the company's exclusive right to come up with a reorganization plan. By an 8-1 vote, the Supreme Court said the PBGC acted within its authority when it ordered LTV and its subsidiary, LTV Steel Co., to restore the pension plans with unfunded liabilities of $2.3 billion. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, who chairs the PBGC's board of directors, said the ruling would help the agency protect the pensions of 40 million American workers and retirees. ``While pensions as a whole are healthier than ever, some companies in certain industries have seriously underfunded pensions,'' Mrs. Dole said. ``PBGC's victory in this case will help discourage unwarranted termination of pension plans and encourage better funding of pensions.'' After filing for bankruptcy reorganization in 1986, Dallas-based LTV and its Cleveland-based LTV Steel subsidiary advised the PBGC that they could not fund their pension plans. The plans were ended in 1987. But in a later deal with the United Steelworkers union, LTV Steel agreed to make up any benefits promised under the old plan but not covered by the federal pension insurance program. The PBGC, a government agency that takes over pension plans that end with insufficient money to fund benefits, objected and ordered LTV to reassume responsibility for the pension plans. Monday's court ruling backed the agency. ``We're not happy with the decision, (but) it's certainly is not considered a back-breaker,'' LTV's Scheer said. ``The question is how do we handle this tremendous obligation. We don't have an answer.'' ``Retermination certainly is something we'll have to look at,'' he said. ``We hope and we believe that there is room for negotiations with the PBGC, taking into consideration the fact that they understand our economic realities.'' Michael S. Gordon, a Washington pensions lawyer, said the ruling's impact may be limited. ``While companies might be tempted to rid themselves of pension liabilities through the bankruptcy code ... I think that's a pretty harried course for most major corporations. I don't know that it's impact is as cosmic as some would have you believe,'' Gordon said. ``Nonetheless, it was a loophole that could be exploited. It's closed now and it's a good thing,'' he said. LTV has returned to profitability after posting billions in losses, much of it tied to its bankruptcy costs and accounting for pension funds. In 1988 alone the company lost $3.15 billion on sales of $7.3 billion. Last year, LTV earned 264.9 million on sales of $6.36 billion. Earnings in the first three months of 1990 slipped to $44.2 million from $76.6 million a year earlier. Sales dropped to $1.49 billion from $1.61 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Ashland Asks Kaufman to Overturn Verdict
DOC.TEXT: Pollution damage claims against Ashland Oil Co. soared to $2.725 billion as hundreds of people joined a lawsuit against the company over alleged refinery discharges. Ashland, however, asked a judge Monday to overturn a $10.3 jury award that forms a basis for the other claims. The company said the trial was riddled with errors and added that the judge and jury foreman did not disclose past relationships with the plaintiffs' attorneys. ``In the collective experience of Ashland's counsel, they have never encountered a trial afflicted by errors as numerous or as grievous as those committed in the trial of this matter,'' the company's motion said. Rod Jackson, the plaintiffs' lead attorney, dismissed Ashland's motion as ``desperation.'' Kanawha County Circuit Court Judge Tod Kaufman, who presided over the trial, is to hear the appeal June 29. He is out of the country on vacation and was unavailable for comment Monday, his office said. Late last month, a jury awarded $10.3 million to four residents living near Ashland's refinery in Catlettsburg, Ky. The residents alleged that a caustic white substance emitted from the refinery had damaged their property and affected their health. The exact nature of the substance was not established at the trial, and Ashland argued that residents presented no evidence of illness or property damage. On Monday, 681 more current and past area residents filed suit in Kanawha Circuit Court against Ashland, bringing the total number of suits pending to more than 1,100, Jackson said. He is representing 912 residents in one suit, he said. The new claims raise the total compensation sought to $2.725 billion from $840 million previously, Jackson said. Most of the plaintiffs live in western West Virginia, across the Ohio River from the refinery. Ashland reported profits of $85 million last year on sales of $8.5 billion. Ashland spokesman Roger Schrum said the allegations in the latest suits are without merit. The company has requested affidavits from each person filing a suit because ``Mr. Jackson has gotten carried away with his numbers in the past,'' Schrum said. In their motion to overturn the May verdict, Ashland's lawyers said Charleston lawyer Rudy DiTrapano, a partner of Jackson's in the law firm that represented the plaintiffs, once represented Kaufman's family. The judge's parents and brother were killed in a 1980 car accident. DiTrapano filed two lawsuits on behalf of their estates, later settling them for $40,000. DiTrapano and Jackson each made contributions to Kaufman's general and primary election campaigns in 1988, according to the company's motion. Jackson, partner in the firm DiTrapano & Jackson, said a law firm is under no obligation to reveal past legal relationships with a judge. ``This is just another red herring across the judicial path. It has nothing to do with the case,'' Jackson said. Ashland Oil also said jury foreman Lou Henri Hunt in 1987 was represented in two different cases by Jackson and by a law firm run by the father of plaintiff's attorney D.L. Hamilton. Hunt should have disclosed her relationship with the lawyers and should have been dismissed from jury duty, the company said. But Jackson said Hunt's relationship with the Hamilton firm came up during jury selection. Hunt declined comment Monday. ``The trial is over. I'm just tired of this,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Excalibur Prepares for Tuesday Grand Opening
DOC.TEXT: The world's largest hotel _ a gargantuan castle designed to entice a growing legion of Middle America gamblers _ opens today, and a full house is expected to enjoy mock medieval pageantry at the 4,032-room property. ``Isn't this the most sensational thing you've ever seen,'' actor Ernest Borgnine enthused as he watched a knight on a white horse prance across a lobby area of the Excalibur Hotel and Casino in a pre-opening VIP party Monday night. ``Just look at this. What can you possibly say.'' Hundreds of the Las Vegas business, political and social elite milled about the $290 million property. Minstrels, jugglers and harpists entertained guests, a 10-foot dragon cavorted and a man in a suit of armor walked stiffly amid the guests. The entertainers will be standard fare in what promises to be one of the country's more unique properties. Tuesday's formal opening will mark a milestone for Circus Circus Enterprises, Inc., the gaming-hotel operation that has carved a niche in Las Vegas and Nevada for Middle America. Chairman William Bennett said he was pleased with Monday night's turnout, and with his latest property. ``Everything seems to be going just fine,'' he said. Glenn Schaeffer, chief financial officer for the company, said the Excalibur was getting 4,000 reservation calls a day. ``People think we have a hit,'' he said. The $1.6 billion Circus Circus company, which started with a struggling Strip hotel-casino 16 years ago, has become the envy of the gaming industry with a unique strategy focusing on small-time players rather than coveted high-rollers. Bennett announced to stockholders last week that the company planned to reduce its $500 million debt by about $200 million in the coming year, largely on added revenue from the Excalibur. Schaeffer said Monday the company could probably pay off all its debt in three or four years from Excalibur revenue, but may opt to look at new projects. Schaeffer said the company, which once eyed Atlantic City, now has no interest in expanding to the New Jersey market where the likes of Donald Trump are struggling. The giant castle at the south end of the glitzy Las Vegas Strip is the brainchild of Bennett, who amassed a personal fortune of $500 million catering to families in a gaming environment. The Excalibur is anchored by four 28-story towers, covers 70 acres and has a staff of 4,300. It will replace two other Las Vegas properties that have held the title of the world's largest hotel. Tuesday's opening will give Circus Circus a total of 11,320 rooms in Nevada, including two hotels in Las Vegas, one in Reno and two in Laughlin. By comparison, Atlantic City's 12 major hotels total 8,100 rooms. The Excalibur will give Las Vegas 75,000 hotel rooms. The success of Circus Circus has nudged Las Vegas toward other family-oriented features, transforming the gaming capital into a total resort destination. Circus Circus rooms average $33 a night, while the Excalibur will average $45. Some 500,000 square feet of public entertainment space includes a Renaissance-era village, 12 food outlets and a casino the size of four football fields, with 2,630 slot machines. Shows will feature a medieval flair, with live jousting. An arcade will feature a dozen themed game booths such as archery and electronic crossbows.

DOC.HEAD: Pension Ruling Will Keep Pension Insurance System Solvent, Officials Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-LTV-Pensions, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For the McMahon family in Aliquippa, Pa., a Supreme Court ruling on retired steelworkers' pensions means an extra $120 a month. For the federal agency that insures the pensions of 30 million American workers, the ruling means a savings of up to $8 billion in potential pension liabilities. The court on Monday broadened the authority of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. to order employers to restore terminated pension plans in a case involving LTV Corp. and its subsidiary, LTV Steel Co. ``We feel like justice was done. We weren't asking for miracles. We only want what we're owed and to keep other retirees from having this happen to them,'' said Carole McMahon, who said her husband's $950 monthly pension was shortchanged $120 a month after LTV filed for bankruptcy protection in 1986 and its pension plans were terminated. Federal officials called the ruling a victory that benefits all Americans because it helps keep solvent the nation's system of insuring pensions. Not only will the ruling keep the PBGC from having to pay LTV's unfunded liabilities of $2.3 billion, it also might save another $8 billion because companies will be discouraged from following LTV's lead, said James B. Lockhart, exeutive director of the agency. ``It removes a major cloud that has been overhanging the agency for 2{ years,'' Lockhart said. He added the agency knew of a handful of companies that were considering terminating their pension plans through bankruptcy proceedings. However, Michael S. Gordon, a Washington pension lawyer, said the LTV case was ``a relatively isolated example.'' ``While companies might be tempted to rid themselves of pension liabilities through the bankruptcy code ... I think that's a pretty harried course for most major corporations. I don't know that its impact is as cosmic as some would have you believe,'' Gordon said. ``Nonetheless, it was a loophole that could be exploited. It's closed now and it's a good thing,'' Gordon said. The PBGC takes over a pension plan's assets and liabilities when a company ends the plan with insufficient money to satisfy promised benefits. The agency then pays the pensions, but sets limits on some types of benefits. Ultimately, taxpayers shoulder the burden of PBGC liabilities. Mrs. McMahon, who is part of a union retirees' activist group, said the ruling would protect other retirees across the country. ``If this had not happened, all of these other companies would have seen LTV escaping and taking these losses from their retirees,'' she said. Though retirees are pleased to have their pensions fully funded, they are worried LTV might make up the difference with decreased health care benefits, Mrs. McMahon said. ``People are scared right now because we don't know what's going to happen,'' she said. Alice Lynd, a Youngstown, Ohio, lawyer representing LTV retirees, said the average LTV pensioner received $40 a month less after LTV terminated its pension plan. The PBGC has money problems of its own _ a $1 billion deficit. It currently lists assets of about $3.2 billion and liabilities of about $4.2 billion. The Dallas-based LTV and its Cleveland-based LTV Steel subsidiary, after filing for reorganization under federal bankruptcy law in 1986, advised the PBGC that they could not fund the pension plans they sponsored. The plans were ended in 1987. In a deal with the United Steelworkers union, however, LTV Steel agreed to what government lawyers called a ``follow-on'' arrangement. Under it, LTV agreed to make up any benefits lost to retirees that are not covered by the federal pension insurance program. The PBGC contended such arrangements are abusive, and the agency ordered LTV to reassume responsibility for the pension plans. When LTV refused, the agency sought to enforce its order in federal court.

DOC.HEAD: Midland Cogeneration Plant Sold for $2.3 Billion
DOC.TEXT: The Midland cogeneration power plant, once an aborted nuclear plant seen as a white elephant, has been sold for $2.3 billion, CMS Energy reported. The deal was believed to be the largest sale-leaseback in U.S. history, the company, based in Dearborn, said Monday. Paul Knopick, a CMS spokesman, said 65 percent of the plant _ built as a nuclear facility but later converted to a gas-fired cogeneration plant _ was bought by a group of major companies that did not want to be identified. The remaining 35 percent was bought by a CMS subsidiary, with the plant leased back to the original partnership that converted it into a gas-fired facility. The deal is for 25 years. The original partnership included CMS and Dow Chemical Co. Michigan's largest utility, Consumers Power Co., a CMS subsidiary. The partnership halted construction of the plant in 1984 after spending $4.2 billion. It was 85 percent complete when the facility became mired in financing and regulatory wrangles. The Midland Cogeneration Venture partnership spent $600 million to convert the plant to a gas-fired cogeneration facility, the nation's largest. The plant now makes steam for industrial use and also produces electricity. It began producing power for Dow in March. About $380 million of the $2.3 billion deal was in cash, Knopick said. The partners also agreed to form a second partnership to investigate expanding the Midland plant, he said. ``We know the Midwest, Canada, and Michigan are going to need more electricity in the 1990s and we see the Midland Cogeneration Venture as being a key provider of that power,'' he said. Knopick said the capacity of the facility, which produces 1,370 megawatts of electricity and 1.35 million pounds per hour of steam, could be doubled.

DOC.HEAD: Arthur Andersen Announces Joint Venture With Soviet Companies
DOC.TEXT: Arthur Andersen & Co. has announced it will set up a joint venture with two Soviet businesses, becoming the first U.S. public accounting firm to do audit work in the Soviet Union. The Soviet Ministry of Finance has approved the joint venture, called Arthur Andersen in the U.S.S.R., according to a statement issued Monday by the Chicago-based accounting firm. Andersen has a 70 percent stake in the venture, with Promstroybank of the U.S.S.R., the largest bank in the country, having 30 percent and NPO Dinamo Moscow, an engineering industrial company, having 5 percent. ``As part of the Arthur Andersen audit, tax, financial and business consulting unit, this joint venture will provide assistance to Soviet state and other enterprises in adapting themselves to free market management techniques,'' according to the company statement. ``It will also consult with Soviet Western joint ventures and is the first western organization to audit such ventures.'' Andrea Von Knoop was named general director of the new venture. Von Knoop is a former employee of the Deutsche Bank. According to the statement, the joint venture, based in Moscow, marks the re-emergence of Andersen operations in the Soviet Union. After eight years of activity there, the firm suspended Soviet operations in 1983, the statement said. But it also said that for more than a year, teams from Andersen have been working in the Soviet Union on various projects.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were lower at midday Tuesday but above lows hit at the start of trading. Dealers said that after an initial slide of more than 20 points following a big decline on Wall Street Monday, bargain hunters scooped up leading stocks. Fund managers, trying to unload large amounts of cash, were buying at the lower levels, a dealer said. Wall Street will be the main focus during the afternoon, following Monday's fall in the Dow Jones industrial average of 53.71 points to 2,882.18. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 3 points, or 0.1 percent, at 2,367.5. Volume was 259.8 million shares at midday, compared with 241.4 million shares at the same time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Heinz Earnings Up in Fourth Quarter, Year
DOC.TEXT: H.J. Heinz Co. said today its earnings increased 15.5 percent in the fourth quarter as price increases and sales gains boosted income. The maker of ketchup and other food products reported fourth-quarter net income totaled $135.3 million, or 51 cents per share, compared with $117.2 million, or 44 cents per share, in the same period of 1989. Fourth-quarter sales increased 3.9 percent to $1.69 billion from $1.63 billion a year earlier. Heinz said strong growth in sales of ketchup and tuna was offset by declining sales of other products. Net income for the year ended May 2 increased 14.6 percent to a record $504.4 million, or $1.90 per share, from $440.2 million, or $1.67 per share, in fiscal 1989, Heinz said. Sales for the year increased 4.9 percent to about $6 billion from $5.8 billion in 1989. Heinz Chairman Anthony J.F. O'Reilly said the year's increase in operating profit reflects the company's continued strength. ``Our big brands _ ketchup, tuna, frozen potatoes, baby food, and Weight Watchers brand food products _ continue to prove their market strength and brand leadership, providing a solid foundation for the future,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Changing Technology A Topic at Vegas Convention
DOC.TEXT: The newspaper industry is witnessing new technologies that will turn problems into opportunities, but those new systems are only as good as the people who run them, according to industry executives. ``Without the right well-trained people, all the technology in the world won't do us much good,'' Lloyd G. Schermer told delegates to the 62nd annual technical exposition of the American Newspaper Publishers Association on Monday. ``That's why, in this decade as never before, we must develop our people.'' Schermer, chief executive officer of Lee Enterprises, Inc., Davenport, Iowa, said newspapers will need technology, training and teamwork to meet the competitive challenges of the 1990s. Schermer also warned that proposed new postal rates pose a threat for publishers. First, second and third class mailers face double digit postal rate increases while the rate would drop 10 percent for third class mailers who can demonstrate 75 percent or more ``saturation'' coverage, he said. Only one or two third class mailers that specialize in direct mail advertising would be able to take advantage of the lower rate, Schermer said. ``The monopoly postal service clearly sees its future as a distributor of advertising hard copy rather than first class letters,'' Schermer said. Madelyn P. Jennings, senior vice president of personnel for Gannett Co. Inc., said people are a critical commodity for newspapers wishing to realize the most from new technologies. ``If we leave out the people quotient, we can't possibly get the return on the investment promised,'' she said. ``We are pioneers in a new territory. Our success depends on a skilled and motivated workforce.'' ``You wouldn't put up with a press operating at 75 percent of capacity,'' she said. ``You shouldn't put up with employees working at 75 percent of capacity. People and presses don't work very well unless they're cared for.'' In the decade ahead, the quality of people will make the difference in America's newspapers. ``Developing our people isn't a cost, it's a blue chip investment,'' she said. Two Las Vegas newspaper executives, Review-Journal general manager David Osborn and Sun president Brian Greenspun, delivered welcoming addresses at Monday's opening general session. Some 14,000 newspaper executives are focusing on changing newspaper technology at the convention, which runs through Wednesday. The event features the largest display of newspaper equipment in the world, with 350 exhibitors displaying their wares over 365,000 square feet of exhibition space. The show provides an opportunity for manufacturers and suppliers to the newspaper and graphics arts business to present their products and services to an international audience of top newspaper executives. Recycling, desktop publishing and telephone technology, along with other advances in the industry, will be the topics at general sessions and workshops throughout the three-day event.

The stock market recovered from its worst drop since January to open slightly higher this morning. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which was off 53.71 Monday, gained 4.45 to 2,886.63 in the first half hour today. Monday's fall was the worst loss since it dropped 77.45 points on Jan. 22. Losers and gainers were about even in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 466 up, 478 down and 516 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 16.41 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. One analyst said the market was showing signs that Monday's drop was not the beginning of a large selloff, but rather the start of a near-term correction. Ralph Acampora, of Kidder, Peabody & Co. said there might be some volatity and trading in a 50 to 60-point band on the Dow, but said the market needs to come down somewhat. Many market watchers have noted that the recent rise may not be supported by corporate earnings. Occidental Petroleum, whose debt and preferred stock were downgraded by Standard & Poors late Monday, was the most active stock on the NYSE, down ~ at 25}. Software Toolworks, which dropped 4~ to 19 in the over-the-counter market Monday, gained \ as the most active stock. A Barron's magazine article raised questions about the hopes behind the stock's steep rise since last year. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks increased .20 to 195.13. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .21 at 360.55. Declining issues outnumbered advances Monday by about 7 to 2 on the NYSE, with 348 up, 1,205 down and 446 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 133.47 million shares, against 205.13 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Reports Judge's Ruling in Chip Dispute as Temporary Setback
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today ordered Motorola Inc. to pull a key computer chip off the market, dealing a setback to the company in a legal battle over trade secrets with former partner Hitachi Ltd. The order also will prevent Hitachi from selling its own microprocessor in the United States. Motorola said it would immediately appeal the decision by U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton of Midland. Bunton's order was released in Austin, where the Motorola's MC68030 microprocessor is made. A microprocessor is a computer chip that handles the processing functions in a computer. In a statement from its Schaumburg, Ill., headquarters, Motorola said it expected a patent appeals court to stay Bunton's order. The company said it is confident it would continue to provide an uninterrupted supply of its market-leading microprocessor to customers. Bunton banned the sale of the chips on March 29 and fined both companies, saying they violated each other's patents. But he stayed the order a day later after Motorola argued that the chip ban could devastate outside computer makers that depend on Motorola microprocessors to run their machines. Today's order lifts the stay. The judge said the companies had been given enough time to settle on their own. ``The parties have chosen not to forge a settlement in the interim, and this court is not inclined to continue its indulgence,'' Bunton said. Motorola contends that Bunton's order gives Hitachi unequal bargaining power in any settlement negotiations because, as Bunton said in his order, Motorola's processor is more ``commercially viable'' than Hitachi's. Hitachi said it needed the injunction because Motorola could continue to design around the MC68030, which would eliminate any incentive for Motorola to settle the patent infringement dispute. Tim Kellogg, spokesman for Motorola, said the company would file its appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The court is a special appeals court for patents and customs in Washington. ``We are confident that the CAFC will promptly stay the lower court's decision, pending appeal,'' Motorola said in a statement. ``We are dismayed that Judge Bunton made this decision knowing full well that the two parties have been engaged in earnest attempts to settle this matter,'' the company said. The companies received word of the order Monday, but it was not released until today.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 460.73 down .06 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's GNP Grows 5 Percent in Fiscal Year
DOC.TEXT: Japan's economy grew 5 percent in the past fiscal year, boosted by brisk fourth quarter activity, the Economic Planning Agency announced Tuesday. It was the third straight year in which Japan's gross national product, the country's total output of goods and services, expanded 5 percent or more. The government had forecast a 4.6 percent rate for the year. In the fourth quarter, which ended March 31, the agency said the GNP grew an inflation-adjusted 2.5 percent. For the first time in five years, exports contributed slightly more to economic growth during the quarter than did domestic demand. But increased domestic demand, rather than exports, accounted for most of the year's economic expansion. Domestic demand contributed 5.7 percent to total growth, compared to a negative 0.7 percent for exports. An agency official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the results showed that Japan's economic expansion, now in its 43rd month, continues to be led by domestic demand as Japan's economy shifts away from its past dependency on exports. The official said the healthy growth rate in the January-March quarter showed that the sharp instability in Japan's stock and currency markets during the period had little impact on the economy. From January through March, Japanese stock and bond prices plunged sharply and the yen weakened to 157.65 yen to a dollar from 143.40 yen. However, personal consumption and private capital expenditures, the main pillars of Japan's current economic expansion, continued to grow, although at a less rapid rate than during the previous two quarters. GNP growth fluctuated sharply in fiscal 1989, and averaged slightly lower than the 5.3 percent registered in fiscal 1988 and the 5.4 percent in fiscal 1987. Analysts disagreed about the significance of the 8.5 percent surge in exports during the fourth quarter, which overwhelmed a 2.1 percent rise in imports. The government official said temporary factors such as a sharp jump in auto exports to the United States in March to fill the unused portion of Japan's quota under its voluntary export restraint agreement were mainly responsible for the increase in the contribution of exports to growth. Toshiaki Kakimoto, chief economist with Sumitomo Bank, said statistics from April should show a return to strong domestic demand. ``The external sector should become negative again,'' he said. But Kenneth Courtis, strategist and chief economist with Deutsche Bank in Tokyo, said temporary factors cannot explain all of the external sector's rebound from a negative 1.0 percent contribution in the October-December quarter to a positive 1.3 percent in the last quarter. Courtis said the yen's weakness together with strong economic growth in Asia and Europe are more fundamental reasons behind the surge in exports. Now that Japan's markets have calmed down, the Japanese consumer is back on the street spending at a strong clip, Courtis said. ``Japan's economic expansion has been running on two motors: capital spending and consumer spending. Now exports are starting to kick into gear,'' he said.

Institutional investors were sitting on the sideline mostly, he said. However the stocks institutions were buying were mostly among the Dow industrials, helping push the average upward. Ralph Acampora, of Kidder, Peabody & Co. said there might be some volatity and trading in a 50 to 60-point band on the Dow, but said the market needs to come down somewhat. Many market watchers have noted that the recent rise may not be supported by corporate earnings. Occidental Petroleum, whose debt and preferred stock were downgraded by Standard & Poors late Monday, was the most active stock on the NYSE, down ~ at 25}. Software Toolworks, which dropped 4~ to 19 in the over-the-counter market Monday, gained ] as the most active stock. A Barron's magazine article raised questions about the hopes behind the stock's steep rise since last year. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks increased .56 to 195.49. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .06 at 360.82.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip Slightly After Monday's Gains
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, defying predictions for an extension of the strong gains posted in the previous session. The early weakness appeared to be centered in the corn market following Monday's weekly Agriculture Department crop-progress report showing 97 percent of the nation's corn crop planted as of Sunday. Soybean planting was 79 percent complete. Forecasts for rain in the Midwest today and Wednesday were considered bearish for the newly planted crops. Wheat futures were narrowly mixed after the USDA announced this morning it had accepted exporters' bids to sell nearly 360,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat to China at subsidized prices. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.30 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1{ cents lower with July at $2.85} a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent lower with July at $1.41\ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents lower to 4 cents higher with July at $5.95 a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures were lower. Live cattle futures were .13 cent lower to .08 cent higher with June at 77.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent to .18 cent higher with August at 85.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .87 cent higher with June at 60.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .55 cent to 1.15 cents lower with July at 63.67 cents a pound. Cattle futures advanced on Monday, hog futures were mixed and bellies were sharply lower.

DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for light sweet crude was $15.80 per barrel at 12 p.m. Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Airline Sabena Posts New Operating Loss
DOC.TEXT: The Belgian national airline Sabena Tuesday confirmed it had suffered an operating loss of more than $36 million in 1989. Announcing the results before the group's annual stockholders meeting, Sabena chairman Carlos Van Rafelghem said: ``We won't be able to go on living through such situations.'' Sabena, British Airways and Dutch KLM last year set up Sabena World Airways. BA and KLM each have 20 percent stakes in the new operating company. The company's senior vice president, Gerard Spinnox, said the outlook for 1990 was not good, saying the airline could be heading for an overall loss of $42.8 million for the year. Rafelghem said Sabena's flight operations had been ``marginal'' for the year. He said the company may have to ``disinvest'' in the coming year. Although Sabena was adversely affected by both strikes and the strength of the Belgian franc during 1989, the chairman said that all European carriers were going through ``a dire patch at the moment.'' Commenting on the European Commission's inquiry into the effect on competition of the Sabena-BA-KLM linkup, Rafelghem said that if the Commission could prove that Sabena World Airways would hurt competition, he would have to make changes. However, he said that it was not Sabena's intention to interfere with Dutch and British airline business.

DOC.HEAD: Bahrain Stock Exchange Gearing to Move Into International Phase
DOC.TEXT: Bahrain's year-old stock exchange has recorded satisfactory progress and is gearing to move into the international phase, its director Fawzi Behzad said Tuesday. Speaking at a news conference marking the first anniversary of the stock exchange, Behzad also announced that the stock exchange will start issuing in July its ``Awal'' index, emulating such well-known barometers as the Dow Jones indusrial average. Arab Banking Corp., the island's largest of more than 60 offshore banking units, has opened the way for international dealings by allowing trading of 25 million shares it recently offered to investors. The Arab Banking offering soon will be traded on the Bahrain and Paris stock exchanges, and later in Kuwait and London. ``We're very happy to have ABC, a Bahrain-based company, acting as a window to foreign investors,'' Behzad said. ``We're opening the way to the international investors to participate in the local market.'' The Bahrain Stock Exchange is expected to seek permission for resident foreigners to own and trade shares indirectly through mutual funds and other trusts, he said. Only Bahrainis and citizens of the other five Gulf Cooperation Council member states are allowed to trade on the Bahrain stock exchange. The GCC is an alliance seeking a common market. It groups Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman and the United Arab Emirates. Aside from Bahrain's stock exchange, Kuwait has one that has been slowly reinvigorated after the 1982 crash of the non-official Manakh stock exchange under the weight of $94 billion in post-dated checks. Oman also has a fledgling stock exchange. Behzad said the GCC stock exchanges were cooperating to create a strong capital market in the wealthy Gulf states which sit on two-thirds of the world's proven oil reserves. Behzad said that the first year saw 77.6 million shares traded and worth the equivalent of about $78.8 million through 3,160 transactions. Transfer of ownership involved 11 million shares worth $8.1 million through 177 transactions. A total of 29 companies are so far listed on the exchange and ABC will be the 30th.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Names Beatrice Executive As New CEO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that Wilson is co-owner, sted chief financial officer; INSERTS 3 grafs after 2nd graf to UPDATE with Rentschler comment; picks up, Checci said, 3rd graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines today named Frederick B. Rentschler president an chief executive officer to take over duties handled by co-owner Frederic Malek. Rentschler, president and chief executive officer at Beatrice Co., will manage operations at the nation's fourth-largest airline. Like Malek, Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi and co-owner Gary Wilson, he has no previous airline management experience. Rentschler also will be a director of Northwest. Rentschler, who starts Monday, said he has no fears about coming from outside the industry. He said the job of chief executive officer is the same, regardless of what kind of company you run. ``It's strategy and direction and deciding how to finance things,'' Rentschler said at a news conference. He said he will be surrounded by 4,000 experienced middle and upper managers who know the airline industry thoroughly. Checchi said Rentschler will bring ``strong consumer marketing experience'' to the carrier. Checchi and Malek have said they intend to change Northwest's reputation as a poor performer with vastly improved service in an attempt to make it America's most preferred airline by 1995. Malek, whose new title is vice chairman, said he is stepping aside to devote more time to outside commitments. He said he would continue to play a role in strategic planning. ``I have always felt it critical to have a top executive full time at the helm,'' Malek said in a statement. ``We have that now in Fred Rentschler, a man who brings added skills and experience to strengthen our collective leadership.'' Rentschler is available because Beatrice has agreed to be acquired by ConAgra Inc. for $1.34 billion. The buyout was announced June 7. Rentschler, 50, is credited with turning around the Swift Hunt-Wesson foods division of Esmark Inc. before Beatrice acquired that company. He was forced out in 1984, but returned in 1986, when Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. acquired Beatrice in a $6.1 billion leveraged buyout. In the past three years, Rentschler has overseen numerous divestitures that included the sale of Avis rent-a-car, a Coca-Cola bottler, Tropicana Products Inc. and other prominent brands. The food business sold to ConAgra is all that remains. Before working at Beatrice, Rentschler was president and chief executive of Armour-Dial Inc. Investors who put $420 million of equity into KKR's Beatrice buyout reaped a total of about $2.2 billion from the selloff of its businesses. Beatrice, ranked 25th in the Forbes magazine list of the 400 biggest privately held U.S. companies, had $4.3 billion in sales in its most recent year. Its brands include Hunt's, Wesson, Orville Redenbacher's, Manwich, Peter Pan, Snack Pak, Swiss Miss, La Choy, Swift Premium, and Butterball. Northwest ranks 11th on the same list, with annual revenues of $5.6 billion. Rentschler would go from overseeing a company of 16,400 workers to a company with a work force of 37,000. Northwest has been without experienced airline industry executives in its highest ranks since former NWA chief executive officer Steven Rothmeier and his four top executives resigned in October. A group led by Checchi and including Malek and Wilson had led a $3.65 billion buyout of Northwest in June 1989. All three men are former executives of Marriott Corp. Checchi and Malek said in October the airline will spend $422 million over the next five years to lure customers with better service. Since Northwest Orient Airlines acquired Republic Airlines in 1986, performance at the new airline suffered and excessive complaints about lost baggage and late arrivals continued for months after Checchi's group bought Northwest. Government-issued performance ratings have improved in the past six months.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Used Lincoln To Finance Real Estate Speculation, Government Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with morning arguments. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Charles H. Keating Jr. used his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association as a tool to funnel federally insured deposits into his speculative real estate ventures, government attorneys argued today. ``It was not a true savings and loan association,'' attorney James Murphy, representing the Office of Thrift Supervision, said in final arguments to U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin. The Office of Thrift Supervision wants the judge to dismiss Keating's suit, which seeks to revoke the April 1989 seizure of his Irvine, Calif.-based S&L. ``In its essence, it was a real estate investment and development company and it was being operated in a very high risk strategy and what was being used were federally insured deposits,'' Murphy said. In advance of the closing arguments, Keating said he was ``extraordinarily optimistic'' based on the evidence regulators presented. ``The government took their best shots and there weren't any shots. There was no powder in their barrel, no bullets in their gun,'' he said. Murphy said the April 1989 seizure of the thrift was neither arbitrary nor capricious, as Lincoln claims. Nor was the government out to get Keating, who has an ``almost palpable'' antipathy to federal regulations and regulators, he said. In fact, the thrift office's predecessor, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, went out of its way to ensure its examiners were unbiased, in 1988 switching jurisdiction over Lincoln from its San Francisco office to Washington. ``In retrospect, I think it's fair to say the bank board got taken in,'' he said. Closing arguments from Keating's lawyers were scheduled for later today, capping 30 days of hearings spread over six months. On the eve of the session, Keating said in a telephone interview he believes he has received a fair hearing. ``We sure feel we've had our day in court,'' he said. ``I can't think of anything that to me would have been more fulfilling.'' Separately, Keating is the target of a federal grand jury probe in Los Angeles and a defendant in a $1.3 billion civil fraud suit filed by federal regulators in Arizona, headquarters of his American Continental Corp. holding company. The proceedings before Sporkin, former enforcement director of the Securities and Exchange Commission, have become Keating's first chance to present the facts of the case as he sees them. Keating himself took the stand for eight days. The House Banking Committee heard lengthy testimony on the case last fall, but Keating denounced the hearings as one-sided and refused to participate. The Sporkin hearings began on Dec. 7, less than a month after the congressional sessions ended, and were originally scheduled for only two days. But each witness offered and each of the nearly 1,000 documents introduced seemed to raise more questions than they answered and the court proceedings dragged on. In ruling on the government's motion for dismissal, the judge could uphold the seizure, find it invalid or order a full trial on the matter, which could take several years. Although they were held to help decide a preliminary motion, the proceedings have, in effect, become a mini-trial for Keating's claims that he was the target of vindictive regulators who ran his business into the ground. The testimony has focused on four transactions that regulators said will prove their April 1989 takeover of Lincoln was justified. In essence, the government contends that Keating arranged for Lincoln subsidiaries to earn phony profits from fake land and stock deals in order to funnel the money to his Arizona holding company via a tax-sharing agreement. The four transactions examined at the hearings include the tax-sharing agreement between Lincoln and American Continental, two land transactions in Arizona and a stock sale. Lincoln's failure will cost taxpayers about $2 billion, regulators estimate, making it the nation's costliest thrift collapse. The Senate Ethics Committee is examining allegations that five legislators _ Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. _ improperly intervened with federal regulators after accepting political contributions from Keating.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Little Changed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished little changed on London's Stock Exchange after a sluggish session Tuesday. There were few developments to inspire investors, dealers said. The lack of British economic indicators and major corporate news, combined with the Royal Ascot horse race meeting, kept investment interest at a minimum, dealers said. The London market opened nearly 25 points lower because of a sharp drop on Wall Street Monday. But dealers said there was no outright selling and the lower levels inspired some genuine institutional interest. ``Institutions are reluctant to sell any stock so close to the end of the quarter,'' one market maker said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed 0.8 point, or 0.03 percent, lower at 2,369.7, near the day's best level of 2,372.9. The low for the day was 2,348.9 and came early in trading. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 4.5 points to close at 1,907.4. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 1.67 points to close at 1,284.16. Volume came to a light 408.3 million shares, little changed from 403.4 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: GM to Manufacture 1,000 Natural Gas-Powered Trucks
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. plans to become the first major automaker to produce a fleet of natural gas-powered vehicles, the Houston Chronicle reported Tuesday. A consortium of pipeline companies and producers will help pay for and purchase the 1,000 light trucks, the Chronicle said. The half-ton trucks will be built at GM's plant in Troy, Mich., and converted to natural gas by PAS Inc., a Detroit-area supplier, the newspaper said. Quoting industry and state sources, the newspaper said the announcement had been planned for Wednesday, but would come instead at July's Economic Summit in Houston. GM officials did not immediately return telephone calls this morning to the Associated Press. The newspaper said GM would not comment. ``This is a way to speed up GM's research,'' said Vicki Cho, a spokeswoman for Southern California Gas Co., the nation's largest gas distribution company. ``We need to be involved in making this happen.'' The Chronicle said the consortium has agreed to provide as much as $1 million in funding for the final researching and testing of the vehicles. The consortium _ also expected to purchase many of the GM trucks _ is composed of about 10 companies in Texas, California and Colorado. Besides Southern California Gas, it includes Entex and Enron Corp. of Houston; Southern Union Gas Co., Lone Star Gas Co., Pacific Gas and Electric and San Diego Gas and Electric. Executives representing the companies say the auto giant has reached a preliminary agreement to produce about 1,000 natural gas-burning trucks in 1991. David Polletta, general manager of PAS Inc., said the vehicles will be sold under the GM name and guaranteed by a GM warranty program. Industry officials say the GM move is the biggest boost yet for a natural gas vehicle movement that has been slow to materialize. ``From the industry's standpoint, this is something we've been trying to do for a long time,'' said Susan Syler, a spokeswoman for Entex, a Houston natural gas distribution company. ``We think that if we can get one of the Big Three out with these vehicles, the others will follow.'' Officials with the Texas General Land Office have been coordinating the project and had scheduled a briefing for Wednesday to discuss the GM project. However, spokesman Mark Glick said Monday that the announcement will be made in July during the Economic Summit in Houston. Officials say an announcement on the project has been delayed because GM is considering expanding the venture beyond light trucks. They say GM is may produce a wide range of natural gas-powered vehicles _ something that gas producers have urged for years. ``That's where the discussions are going,'' said Jack Smith, natural gas vehicle marketing development manager for Southern California Gas. ``This could be part of a much larger effort.'' Because of its environmental advantages over oil-based fuels, natural gas has in the past year won the favor of Congress and several state legislatures, which have passed laws requiring use of the fuel in some of the nation's most polluted cities. In many states, lawmakers have instructed public transit systems and utility companies to begin converting to natural gas. Last fall, GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. announced a plan to work with the nation's major oil companies in investigating the cost of using alternative fuels. The automakers, along with 14 U.S. oil companies, agreed to spend $11.3 million on the research effort.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0628 of June 18, New York-datelined AM-Work Skills, may wish to publish the following, which clarifies one element of the report.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press article June 18 about a report on increasing the skills of U.S. workers omitted details of a recommendation to ensure that all students leave school with a high level of basic skills. The report, ``America's Choice: High Skills or Low Wages!'', recommended that no one under 18 be allowed to work unless they earned a ``Certificate of Initial Mastery'' demonstrating basic skills, or were enrolled in a program aimed at earning such a certificate. The AP article did not take note of this second option.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached on Listing All Import Charges
DOC.TEXT: World trade negotiators on Tuesday tentatively agreed that countries should list all charges in addition to fixed tariffs that importers must pay. A spokesman for the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said the proposed measure would help importers and exporters by increasing the clarity of import duties. Implementation of the accord is dependent on a successful conclusion to the GATT-sponsored Uruguay round of trade negotiations. The talks are scheduled to end in December with a package of new rules to liberalize trade in 15 sectors, including an agreement to cut tariffs. According to the text of Tuesday's agreement, governments would have to list all ``other duties and charges'' in their schedules of bound tariff items. A tariff is ``bound'' under GATT rules once a government gives a commitment not to increase it. GATT members would also have to freeze these ``other duties and charges'' at the rates existing when negotiators reach agreement on a Uruguay round tariff accord. Examples of such charges include fiscal taxes, stamp taxes, port improvement taxes, import surcharges and landing taxes, according to a GATT statement. Currently governments are under no obligation to publish such charges. As a result many traders are unaware of their existence until they import a product. Bound tariffs, by contrast, have to be listed. GATT spokesman David Woods said the proposed measure would yield ``worthwhile, practical results for traders.'' The GATT statement said the text of the decision was based on a proposal submitted last year by New Zealand.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Restructuring Brings Substantial First-Quarter Losses
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc., struggling under the weight of bankruptcy proceedings, reported first-quarter losses of more than $430 million Tuesday, due mainly to its plans to close nearly one-third of its 679 stores. The nation's fourth-largest retailer, based in Rocky Hill, said it lost $430.9 million, or $11.56 per share, in the quarter ending April 28. In the first quarter last year, Ames lost $16.5 million, or 52 cents per share. The loss includes a $225 million charge to cover expected costs of closing the stores, a $104.5 million charge to cover additional anticipated markdowns, and an $18 million writeoff for deferring financing costs. Net sales for the first quarter were $934.8 million, compared to $1 billion for the period last year. The results are not surprising, given the company's struggle to stay afloat through bankruptcy proceedings, a retail analyst said. ``Clearly this is a gigantic number, but it is typical of the process,'' said Howard Davidowitz, chairman of Howard Davidowitz and Associates, a retail consulting firm in New York. ``You try to identify unprofitable operations and wipe them out. ... That doesn't come free.'' Ames filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code on April 25. A hearing is scheduled Thursday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York on Ames' plan to close the stores, which employ about 17,500 full- and part-time employees. Most of the stores being closed are former Zayre stores, which Ames acquired in 1988. The company employed about 55,000 people at the time of the bankruptcy filing. If the court approves, Ames plans to conduct inventory liquidation sales and close the stores in August or September. ``The majority of our loss in the first quarter reflects actions which are absolutely necessary to stabilize our business and reduce losses,'' Stephen L. Pistner, chief executive officer of the department store chain, said in a prepared statement. ``The store closings and write-down of inventory represent an important first step toward our objective of emerging from Chapter 11.'' The stores being closed are in 16 states: Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Virginia and West Virginia. Ames also plans to close distribution centers in Plant City, Fla., and Worcester, Mass. A center under construction in Leesport, Pa., will be completed if the court approves. Davidowitz said it will take another six months to determine whether the steps Ames has taken will save the company. ``The big question is, can Ames really go forward? Is there a viable company left? The book's out. Nobody knows,'' he said. ``It really is a new Ames,'' Davidowitz said. ``They've addressed all their problems. Now we're going to see how they go forward.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Slip; Grains End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell modestly Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government reported generally favorable crop conditions. Corn and wheat futures ended mixed, though, with selling interest offset by news of a wheat sale to China and reports of further rain damage to newly planted corn in soggy central Iowa. Monday's weekly Agriculture Department crop-progress report showed corn planting 97 percent complete as of Sunday and soybean planting 79 percent finished, about the same as a year earlier. Conditions of those crops generally were rated fair to good. Corn futures rallied late in the session amid reports that overnight showers had washed away more young corn in central Iowa, but traders did not consider the reported losses to be critical. ``If there has been some corn acreage in Iowa flooded out, they may come back if they get a week of dry weather and plant soybeans on that acreage,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Wheat futures were supported by the USDA's announcement Tuesday morning that it had accepted exporters' bids to sell nearly 360,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat to China at subsidized prices. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 1{ cent higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.31{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent lower with July at 2.85} a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 3\ cents lower with July at $1.40\ a bushel; soybeans were 5\ cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $5.91{ a bushel.
