DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: The energy futures market ended mostly lower Tuesday in choppy trading, with unleaded gasoline losing more than a penny a gallon as dealers cashed in on a recent price runup. The July contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline tumbled 1.64 cents to settle at 59.92 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after gaining 0.05 cent on Monday. Other contract months also declined. Unleaded gasoline was a hot commodity in recent weeks. The near-month contract has risen about 6 cents a gallon since early June on seasonal demands and amid reports of tightening supplies. But James Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc., said, ``The market has recognized that gas is overbought.'' He said dealers eager to cash in on the sharp price increase decided to dump their gasoline contracts. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, wholesale heating oil settled 0.43 cent lower at 47.43 cents a gallon, after losing 0.51 cent on Monday. Other contract months declined. Meanwhile, the July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 29 cents on the Merc to close at $15.65 a 42-gallon barrel, extending Monday's 68-cent decline. Steel attributed the drop in crude to the fact that the July contract was set to expire on Wednesday. Other contract months posted smaller losses. The August contract, for instance, had been up around $17 a barrel before settling at $16.92 a barrel, down 3 cents. In natural gas trading, the July contract closed at $1.536 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.540 on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Families Sue Kawasaki, Farm Over Accident
DOC.TEXT: Two Maryland families have filed a lawsuit against Kawasaki Motors Corp. and a West Virginia farm after their sons were injured in an all-terrain vehicle accident. The suit filed Monday in Kanawha County Circuit Court, which seeks $11 million in compensatory damages and $55 million in punitive damages, lists the defendants as Kawasaki Motors Corp., Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. and Kawasaki Motors Manufacturing Corp.; and Canfield Farms Inc. of Montrose, W.Va., and owners Loyal and Donald Canfield. According to the suit, Timothy Clark of Baltimore and Brian Cunningham of Pasadena, Md., sustained severe head injuries when they were thrown off a four-wheel all-terrain vehicle at the farm on Sept. 1, 1988. The suit claims the Kawasaki companies negligently designed and manufactured the all-terrain vehicles without adequate printed warnings. It also claims Kawasaki's advertisements for the vehicles promoted unsafe uses. The suit also alleges the farm owners did not heed warnings from Kawasaki not to allow children under 16 to ride without supervision or helmets. Cunningham was 11 at the time and Clark 15. Calls to Kawasaki Motors Corp. headquarters in Santa Ana, Calif. on Tuesday were not immediately returned.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Both Slide
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to fall against major foreign currencies Tuesday in a market once again dominated by technical factors. Meanwhile, gold prices slipped lower. There was no news to affect foreign exchange dealings, and analysts said the dollar's slide was caused by technical factors, which also brought the U.S. currency lower on Monday. ``A lot of people don't understand why we're down here,'' said Robert Ryan, chief foreign exchange dealer for Bank of New York Co. ``But it's hard to fight a trend.'' The British pound rose to a 15-month high against the dollar in London, a move dealers said was helped when sterling broke above a chart level of $1.7150. Traders also reported some concerns that U.S. interest rates _ which support the dollar when they're at higher levels _ might decline because of the slowing economy in this country. The pound rose to $1.7198 from $1.7130 late Monday in London. In later New York trading, the pound rose to $1.7225 from $1.7145 late Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.72 yen, down 0.16 from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 153.65 yen, and in New York, it fell to 153.485 yen from 153.65 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.6725 West German marks, down from 1.6760; 1.4090 Swiss francs, down from 1.4157; 5.6230 French francs, down from 5.6395; 1,227.25 Italian lire, down from 1,230.00; and 1.17385 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17455; Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.6712 West German marks, down from 1.6770; 1.4100 Swiss francs, down from 1.4165; 5.6177 French francs, down from 5.6390; 1.8800 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8865; 1,226.00 Italian lire, down from 1,230.00; and 1.1738 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1727. Gold edged 20 cents lower on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $349.10 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $347.90 a troy ounce, down 35 cents from Monday. DOC.HEAD: Speculators Sell into Collapsing Orange Juice Futures
DOC.TEXT: Speculators continued to sell heavily into the orange juice futures market Tuesday, extending to three days a collapse that analysts attribute almost entirely to bearish chart patterns. On other commodity markets, oil and pork futures extended recent losses; cattle futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and precious metals retreated. For the third straight day, all contracts for September 1990 through May 1991 delivery of frozen concentrated orange juice fell the permitted daily limit of 5 cents on the New York Cotton Exchange. The limitless nearby July contract plunged 9.6 cents to $1.667 a pound, the lowest close since Dec. 29, the last trading day of last year. The plunge of 23.45 cents, or 12 percent, in the July contract since Thursday represents the most dramatic retreat to date from the record high of $2.065 a pound reached on Jan. 22 after a Christmastime freeze destroyed about one-third of the Florida orange crop. Analysts said the collapse was triggered Friday when the July price slipped below $1.885, breaking a major trend line and creating a bear market in the eyes of chart-driven speculators. ``Once we broke that, it was Katie-bar-the-door,'' said Ernie Thomas, commodity specialist with Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets in Winter Haven, Fla. Both Thomas and analyst Esther Eskanasy of Cargill Investor Services Inc., said hedgers representing various sectors of the Florida orange juice industry joined the selling in significant numbers Tuesday, perhaps indicating they either cannot or will not pay the increases in margin required to maintain bullish futures positions. ``There's not a lot of confidence that prices will be able to recover,'' said Ms. Eskanasy. She said the market may find no substantial support above $1.50 but Thomas said the trade selling could give speculators pause. He predicted a leveling-off at around $1.60 a pound followed by a rebound. The energy futures market ended mostly lower Tuesday in choppy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report. The report showed a smaller-than-expected decline of 1.2 million barrels in U.S. supplies of crude oil last week, a smaller-than-expected drop of 464,000 barrels of gasoline and a 2.9-million-barrel increase in distillate stocks, which was within expectations. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 29 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $15.65 a barrel; heating oil was .43 cent lower to .19 cent higher with July at 47.43 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .15 cent to 1.64 cents lower with July at 59.92 cents a gallon. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pork futures extended their recent losses due to continuing slack demand. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cattle-on-feed report for the seven largest cattle-producing states. The report showed 1 percent more cattle on feed June 1 than on the same date a year ago. May feedlot placements were even with the year-ago number while May marketings were 3 percent higher. Live cattle futures settled .17 cent lower to .15 cent higher with June at 77.12 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .18 cent higher with August at 85.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent to .80 cent lower with June at 60.47 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.13 cents to 1.95 cents lower with July at 63.10 cents a pound. Soybean futures prices fell modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government reported generally favorable crop conditions. Corn and wheat futures ended mixed, though, with selling interest offset by news of a wheat sale to China and reports of further rain damage to newly planted corn in soggy central Iowa. Wheat futures settled { cent lower to 2\ cents higher with July at $3.32\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1 cent higher with July at 2.86{ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent lower with July at $1.41{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $5.93\ a bushel. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 20 cents lower across the board with June at $349.10 a troy ounce; silver was 0.9 cent to 1 cent lower with July at $4.827 a troy ounce.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.HEAD: Stocks Move Moderately Higher
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices posted moderate gains Tuesday as late bargain hunting and computer-program buy orders gave some direction to an otherwise lackluster session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.38 to 2,893.56. Advancing issues outnumbered losers by about 10 to 9 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 778 up, 708 down and 519 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 134.93 million shares, up slightly from 133.47 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 163.12 million shares. The market fluctuated in a narrow range for much of the day, breaking free in the afternoon. Many market watchers said investors were waiting for indications of where stocks were headed following Monday's 53.71 point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. ``It's been pretty quiet action. Basically the market is just buying time,'' said Jon Groveman, a stock market analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co. Program trading helped push the market up in the closing hours as arbitragers tried to take advantage of differences between stock index futures and the cash value of the stocks that make up the index, said Thomas Walsh, head of equity trading for Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. Tuesday's close was the ninth highest for the Dow industrials, but all of the top 10 closes have come since June 1. ``I don't think we're going to see a collapse, but an absence of buying interest until we get an indication of where the (federal) budget talks are going,'' said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Gruntal & Co. Citing the light volume this week, Walsh said Tuesday's gain ``was no more of an upbeat than yesterday was a downbeat. ... Nobody's in the game.'' Occidental Petroleum, whose debt and preferred stock were downgraded by Standard & Poors late Monday, was the most active stock on the NYSE, down | at 26. Occidental said from its Los Angeles headquarters late this afternoon it would not lower its $2.50 per share annual dividend. The ratings agency said it lowered Occidental because of high fixed costs. Among other actively traded issues, Chrysler was up 1[ at 16| as speculation continued over talks about a possible link between the third-largest U.S. automaker and Fiat SpA of Italy. Neither company would confirm details of the talks. Boeing was down ] at 58| and Philip Morris was up 1{ at 44\. On the over-the-counter market, Telephonos de Mexico was the most active stock, unchanged at 1 11-16, Software Toolworks was up 1{ at 20{ and Oracle Systems was up | at 23[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $9.938 billion, or 0.29 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed stocks rose 0.68 to 195.61. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.11 to 420.01 and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 1.59 at 358.47. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 0.26 to 460.53. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.83, up 0.07.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Slip
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices slipped Tuesday in light trading as the market shrugged off news that growth in the nation's housing market dropped to its slowest pace since the last recession. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond lost 7-32 point, or $2.19 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, climbed to 8.47 percent from 8.46 percent late Monday. The market did not have the expected reaction to the Commerce Department report that housing starts fell 1.4 percent in May to the lowest level since October 1982. Usually, signs of economic weakness lead to an upturn in bond prices on the belief that the news will prompt the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. Falling rates can boost the value of fixed-return investments such as bonds. But the bond market ``acted perversely,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Co. in New York. ``Bond prices fell on the news.'' Brusca said the market's reaction may be explained by the fact that it already was well known that the housing market is weak. The reaction also shows the market is more concerned with other factors, such as upcoming economic reports that include the revised first-quarter gross national product Thursday and durable goods and personal income Friday _ and upcoming government bond auctions, Brusca said. William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., agreed there was concern among traders about a possible oversupply of Treasury securities. The government on Wednesday was expected to announce details of its upcoming auction of two-year and four-year notes. The market's downward path began Friday, when the government issued a report showing industrial production rose at a greater-than-expected pace in May. The market interpreted the report to mean it was unlikely the Fed would ease interest rates soon, since the report indicated inflation may be rising. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds Tuesday, prices of short-term governments fell from 1-32 point to 1-16 point, intermediate maturities fell from 3-32 point to [ point, and long-term issues fell as much as \ point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.98 to 1,157,29. Yields on three-month Treasury bills auctioned Monday traded at were slipped to 7.98 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 7.73 percent. Yields on six-month bills auctioned Monday remained at 8.06 percent as the discount held at 7.64 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.12 percent as the discount rose 4 basis points to 7.57 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8[ percent, down from 8\ percent late Monday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 3-32 point to 91 16-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.52 percent from 7.51 percent late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Chapter 11 Retailers Lose $99.5 Million Last Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. lost $99.5 million during the quarter ending May 5, but the loss was less than expected, the retailers said Tuesday. ``Federated and Allied's first quarter results were surprising only in that they exceeded our expectations for how the business would perform in the period immediately following the Chapter 11 filings,'' said chairman Allen Questrom. ``The companies' strengthening performance during the quarter indicates that we clearly are moving in the right direction,'' Questrom said. Federated lost $57.6 million on sales of $1.01 billion in the quarter, compared with a loss of $62.2 million on sales of $1.02 billion during the comparable period a year ago, the company said. Allied lost $41.9 million on sales of $581.4 million, compared with a loss of $40.3 million on sales of $572.5 million during the same quarter last year. Federated's chains include Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Burdine's of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati, Rich's of Atlanta and Goldsmith's of Memphis. Allied's chains include The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Jordan Marsh of Tampa, Maas Brothers of Tampa and Stern's of Paramus, N.J. The two divisions, which cited $7.7 billion in debts in filing for U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection in January, operate 260 stores in 28 states. Spokeswoman Carol Sanger said that more important than the $99.5 million loss was the $419 million cash Federated had on hand on June 6, and the $189 million Allied had on hand that date. At the same time last year, Federated had $18.8 million in cash, and Allied had no cash, she said. Although Federated received a bankruptcy judge's permission to obtain up to $400 million, and Allied up to $300 million, in debtor-in-possession financing, neither company has used any of that credit, Sanger said.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Controller Retiring
DOC.TEXT: John L. O'Connor, Ford Motor Co.'s vice president and controller, will step down July 1 and retire effective Oct. 1, company Chairman Harold Poling said Tuesday. O'Connor, 62, will stay with Ford in an advisory capacity from July to October. He has been a vice president and controller since 1987, having joined the nation's No. 2 automaker in 1952 as a cost-accounting trainee and rising through the company's financial ranks. During his career, he was finance manager for Ford of Portugal and Ford of Italy, the automaker said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Getty Expects Indictment
DOC.TEXT: Getty Petroleum Corp. said Tuesday that the U.S. government intends to indict a Getty subsidiary and one of the company's officers for allegedly conspiring with a customer to evade federal gasoline excise taxes in 1985. Getty said in a release that it was advised by the U.S. Attorney's Office in Brooklyn that the government intends to seek the indictment against Getty Terminals Corp. and an unnamed company official. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney was not available for comment late Tuesday at his home or office. Getty said the allegations are without merit and, if indicted, the company would defend itself. Getty Petroleum Corp. markets gasoline, heating oil and petroleum products in 13 states.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco, French Both Unhappy With Ruling in Tanker Spill Case
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for Amoco Corp. and French plaintiffs both are unhappy with a judge's ruling that Amoco should pay nearly $160 million in damages for a 1978 oil spill off northern France, indicating a final settlement is still far away. U.S. District Judge Charles Norgle on Monday issued a seven-page order in the case, spelling out recommended damages for the massive spill from the Amoco Cadiz tanker. He set July 24 as the date he would specify final judgments and instructed parties to the lawsuit to calculate interest owed them. Norgle's order says he is in basic agreement with damage recommendations made last year by former U.S. District Judge Frank McGarr, who was appointed a special master in the case. ``We don't expect to have to pay it,'' Frank Cicero, a lawyer representing Chicago-based Amoco, said of the expected judgment. ``We think Judge McGarr erred on both his legal rulings and his evidentiary rulings. We believe we'll get it reversed.'' Cicero said the company believes the shipbuilder, not Amoco, was at fault in the spill. He said the company will appeal to the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals after the July 24 hearing. The appeals process could take two years, Cicero said. Warren Marwedel, a lawyer for the French plaintiffs, said his clients will appeal because they believe Amoco is liable and that the award was too little. The order specifies amounts in French francs and British pounds, which come to about $123.5 million to be paid to the French national government, local governments and businesses. About $35.9 million would go to the Royal Dutch-Shell Group, the company that paid for the supertanker's cargo.

DOC.HEAD: Shoppers, Start Your Engines: Latest Time-Saver Is Drive-Up Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `At its ...' to CORRECT wine's name to Opus One sted Opus. Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: On Colorado Boulevard, where the little old lady from Pasadena terrorized other drivers, motorists no longer have to leave their cars to grocery shop. They can cruise instead to a drive-up window for the eggs, detergent or some of the other 1,400 grocery items, fast food or household goods at the Drive-Thru Express Store opened by the supermarket chain Vons Cos. The window isn't just another car-crazy California trend. It's more an example of how supermarkets are trying to compete with convenience stores, fast-food restaurants and vast ``hypermarkets.'' ``We think that somebody who's tired today can swing by the store and pick up dinner for tonight, they can pick up their detergent to do the laundry, and even pick up a fresh fruit tray for their breakfast tomorrow,'' said Phil Hawkins, Vons' vice president of sales. ``And it's all at a good price.'' Similar setups have been tested at convenience stores in such cities as Edgeworth, Pa., and Springville, Utah. ``There's even a drive-through newsstand in Lancaster, Pennsylvania,'' said Sheri Aguirre, a spokeswoman for the National Association of Convenience Stores. Markets across the country now include everything from post offices to bank branches to cafes. Vons, Southern California's largest retail supermarket chain with 328 stores, is a regional leader in such experiments. In its Hispanic-angled Tianguis markets, for example, mariachis play on weekends and shoppers can purchase pigs' heads, hand-rolled tortillas, cactus, and Mexican sweetbreads. At its upscale Pavilions stores, you can buy a $50 bottle of Opus One, the Napa Valley red wine produced in collaboration by California's Robert Mondavi and Bordeaux's late Baron Philippe de Rothschild, or some fresh sushi, chocolate amaretto mousse or tiny red teardrop tomatoes. Three Vons stores have convenience stores built into the supermarket, and more of them are planned, according to spokeswoman Mary M. McAboy. It's one of those Express Stores that has been expanded with the drive-up window experiment. Ms. McAboy said windows likely will be tried at other locations, although no final decision has been made. Hawkins, the vice president of sales, said that when the drive-through opened in March, Vons officials estimated conservatively that 100 drivers per day would use it. The number as of May was about 200 per day, mostly at mealtimes. Express Store items range from corn flakes, cat food and condoms to specialty pizzas _ the Santa Fe version is topped with blue corn tortillas and peppers and bean sprouts and ginger top the Chicken Oriental type. On one recent morning, there was no waiting in line at the unostentatious window. It took 55 seconds for a clerk's voice to come over the speaker, then 95 seconds to fill the simple order: some antifreeze, motor oil and mints. The store was out of one item, a Barron's weekly business newspaper. ``It's not that busy during the day,'' said Mieko Becker, an employee. ``There's a lot more at night when the moms line up for milk, things like that.'' No alcoholic beverages are sold through the window, and for now there's no fresh meat or produce available. ``We think people want to touch, smell and look at the fresh products,'' Hawkins says.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Names Beatrice Executive As New CEO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB 5th graf ``Checchi, Malek... '' to specify time element of takeover. SUB 12th graf ``Wilson said ...'' to CORRECT Marshall title to chief executive sted chairman, company name to British Airways PLC sted Ltd.
DOC.TEXT: In yet another move to give Northwest Airlines consumer-oriented leadership from outside the industry, the company Tuesday named Frederick B. Rentschler president and chief executive officer. Rentschler, president and chief executive officer at food giant Beatrice Co., will join Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi and three other airline novices in top management at the nation's fourth-largest carrier. ``Hopefully one of the strengths that we will bring is that we will cross-fertilize the company with the expertise derived from many industries and we feel that that will be our strength, ultimately,'' Checchi said. Rentschler, 50, replaces president Frederic Malek, a co-owner who will play a smaller role as vice chairman. Checchi, Malek and Gary Wilson, all former Marriott Corp. executives, took control of Northwest last August in a $3.65 billion buyout. Since then, eight of the top 11 posts at Northwest have been filled by Checchi, members of the buyout group, or outsiders hired by Checchi. Three of the outsiders had no airline management experience, including chief financial officer John Dasburg, another former Marriott executive. Mark Daugherty, an airline analyst with the securities firm Dean Witter Reynolds, said Northwest could be making a mistake. ``I think it's important to try to get people within the industry,'' Daugherty said. ``It's a very competitive cut-throat, low-margin business. I don't think the companies have the liberty or luxury of breaking new people in.'' Checchi said he doesn't have an ``ounce of reservation'' about Rentschler's lack of airline experience. Checchi said Rentschler will be backed up by 4,000 experienced middle and upper managers, including two top executives from the regime of former chairman Steven Rothmeier. Rentschler said the job of every chief executive officer includes strategic direction, setting objectives, communicating clearly, selecting good employees and motivating them. ``Those are leadership qualities which are essential I would say in any chief executive position _ be they packaged goods, marketing driven organizations or be it an airline,'' he said. Wilson said British Airways PLC Chief Executive Sir Colin Marshall _ a former Avis Rent-a-car executive _ has proven that an outsider can run an airline. Wilson said that not having pre-conceived notions about the industry can give birth to refreshing ideas. Candace Browning, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Co. Inc. in New York, said the hiring of Rentschler fits with Northwest's emphasis on service. ``I think strategically that was the right thing to do,'' she said. Checchi said Rentschler was primarily hired for his ``strong consumer marketing experience'' in an attempt to improve Northwest's poor service image. Rentschler is available because Beatrice has agreed to be acquired by ConAgra Inc. for $1.34 billion. The buyout was announced June 7. Rentschler is credited with turning around the Swift Hunt-Wesson foods division of Esmark Inc. before Beatrice acquired that company. He was forced out in 1984, but returned in 1986, when Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. acquired Beatrice in a $6.1 billion leveraged buyout. In the past three years, Rentschler has overseen numerous divestitures that included the sale of Avis, a Coca-Cola bottler, Tropicana Products Inc. and other brands. Before working at Beatrice, Rentschler was president and chief executive of Armour-Dial Inc. Beatrice, ranked 25th in the Forbes magazine list of the 400 biggest privately held U.S. companies, had $4.3 billion in sales in its most recent year. Northwest ranks 11th on the same list, with annual revenue of $5.6 billion. Beatrice had 16,400 workers while Northwest has 37,000. Malek said he is stepping aside to devote more time to outside commitments. He has been busy assembling a seven-nation economic summit in Texas next month for President George Bush. He also is co-chairman of Coldwell Banker Commercial Group and an investor in Caterair International, an airline catering business.

DOC.HEAD: Governors, Premiers Sign International Trade Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Governors of the six New England states and the premiers of five eastern Canadian provinces have agreed to form a cross-border partnership to promote the region's goods, especially in Europe. The Mystic Covenant, as it is dubbed, pledges the governors and premiers to work together to market the region, its companies and its products overseas through joint trade missions and trade shows. ``It's clear that increasingly our fates and our destinies are going to be intertwined,'' said Vermont Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin. ``We've got a head start at being global players by our association with the Canadian premiers. This lesson can now be applied on a global scale.'' The agreement was signed Tuesday at the end of the 18th annual conference between the governors and premiers. The two-day meeting was dominated by discussions about opportunities in Europe, particularly the plan of the 12-nation European Community to form a single market in 1992 and the budding free markets of Eastern Europe. Also at the meeting, the six governors reached a separate agreement to develop a regional strategy on international trade for New England. Neither trade agreement will diminish competition between the states or between the United States and Canada for foreign capital, the officials said. ``When it comes to attracting foreign investment, we're going to be competitors and we're going to be healthy competitors against each other,'' said William Herman, an economic development official for New Hampshire. ``But for the export promotion it makes sense that we try to do it as a region,'' Herman said. The meeting gathered the executives of Massachusetts, Vermont, Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Maine, Quebec, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, New Brunswick and Newfoundland. The governors also accepted a bleak economic forecast from Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist for Connecticut National Bank. Perna predicted the region will create few new jobs over the next 30 months and forecast that housing starts will not rebound at all during the period. ``There is light at the end of the tunnel, but it's flatness,'' he said. ``It's not a traditional rebound.'' The governors also urged Congress to extend funding of the federal Clean Water Act, which is scheduled to be phased out by 1994. They asked for grants of $2.4 billion a year to build modern wastewater treatment plants.

DOC.HEAD: Company To Eliminate 1,100 Jobs, Take $35 Million Charge
DOC.TEXT: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. said it will eliminate 1,100 jobs and take a charge of $35 million against second quarter pre-tax profits as part of a restructuring of its U.S. tire sales and support staff. The job cuts will come over the next several months mainly through layoffs but also through some early retirements, spokesman Walter C. McClenny said. Gene Culler, executive vice president of North American tire operations, said the reductions would result from the realigning of operations into 28 sales regions that will report directly to the company's Akron headquarters. Currently, the company has 43 sales districts reporting to five regional offices. Culler said high-tech improvements in Goodyear's tire ordering and distribution system ``make many of our traditional operations obsolete in a new era of quality and cost consciousness.'' Goodyear's earnings have been under pressure recently, with the company blaming pricing competition, sluggish North American vehicle production and difficulty containing its own costs. Its earnings plunged 78 percent in the first three months of this year to $20.9 million despite a 2 percent gain in sales to $2.69 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rally, Dollar Firmer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against the yen Wednesday morning and share prices rose on the Tokyo Stock Exchange after an opening slip. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 140.27 points, or 0.44 percent, ending the morning session at 32,180.65. The index lost 336.42 points on Tuesday. The dollar was changing hands at 153.93 yen at late morning, up from 153.85 yen at the opening and 153.72 yen at Tuesday's close. The dollar inched up against the yen and the West German mark following an unsubstantiated market rumor that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was forced to step down, dealers said. Prior to the rumor, the dollar had traded softer against the mark, they said. ``The dollar has been weaker against major European currencies, but it does not lead to the currency's decline against the yen because there is no specific reason to buy the yen against the dollar now,'' said Koichiro Amaya, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. On the stock market, the Nikkei eased slightly at the outset because of uncertainties over the foreign exchange market, but it soon recovered as participants made arbitrage purchases in an attempt to take profits from price gaps between the spot and futures markets, said Minoru Shimizu, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. In bond market, the price of the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.34 points from Tuesday's close of 87.46, boosting the yield to 7.11 percent from 7.085 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Some Progress Reported As Trump Loan Talks Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with report of agreement; picks up 4th graf pvs, `Last week ...' INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf, `The developer ...' to CLARIFY amount of bond and bank debt.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump and his bank lenders reached a tentative agreement Tuesday to restructure the $3 billion debt load the developer ran up in assembling his real estate empire, a newspaper reported. The New York Times reported in an early edition of Wednesday's paper that Trump's four lead banks agreed to lend him $65 million and defer interest and principal payments on about $850 million of the developer's nearly $2 billion in bank debt. The agreement hinges on the four banks getting other lenders, particularly Japanese banks that are involved in loan syndicates for Trump, to agree to the deal, the newspaper said. The new loan package will be secured by nearly every asset in Trump's real estate and gambling empire, it said. The Times cited unidentified people involved in the talks. The banks and Trump's spokesman, Dan Klores, refused to comment on the status of the talks. The four banks are Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp. and Bankers Trust Co. Last week, the parties reportedly were close to agreement on a plan under which Trump would receive a $60 million loan that would enable him to keep making debt payments. But over this past weekend, the deal began falling apart as bankers argued over the contribution each would make and the collateral each would receive. Trump has yet to make a roughly $43 million payment due last Friday on junk bonds used to finance the purchase of Trump Castle, one of the developer's three Atlantic City hotel-casinos. Trump is in technical default on the bonds, but is within a grace period during which he can still make the payment. The developer also has not yet made a $30 million debt payment due Manufacturers Hanover Corp. Trump has about $1 billion in junk bond debt outstanding in addition to roughly $2 billion in bank debt. Trump, who has tried to downplay his problems as they became public in recent weeks, continued that campaign Tuesday. He put out a statement announcing the Trump Shuttle _ the northeastern air service he bought last year from Eastern Airlines _ had made its monthly interest payment on time. Investors, meanwhile, showed some optimism that Trump would be able to iron out his difficulties and meet his debt payment obligations. Traders reported that Trump casino bonds, which have fallen sharply recently, recovered some ground Tuesday. The Trump Castle bonds were trading at about $58 per $100 face amount, up about $2 from Monday, in late afternoon transactions. Bonds used to back the Taj Mahal casino were up more than $1 to $52.50, and Trump Plaza bonds were trading at about $82, unchanged from Monday. The debt restructuring plan is aimed at helping Trump to keep making his debt payments while waiting for his assets to rise in value so some eventually could be sold. The assets, which include hotels and office and apartment buildings in New York, have fallen in value due to the slumping New York real estate and Atlantic City casino markets. Trump Shuttle also has posted disappointing results. The four major banks last week reportedly agreed to provide an additional $60 million in loans and to temporarily suspend interest payments. In exchange, the banks would have gotten equity in some of his properties. Bank creditors also reportedly were seeking to force Trump to give up some of his authority over the day-to-day operations of Trump Organization. If Trump is unable to make the payment on the Trump Castle bonds, bondholders could claim the property or the casino could be forced into bankruptcy. If Trump went into full default, he could lose his licenses to operate the casinos.
